On Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall, the soprano Christine Brewer addressed the awkwardness head-on when she turned to the audience members at Prayer and, in a genial tone, encouraged them to relax.

title: Communities Come Together to Make Homes More Affordable
description: At the Hog Island Oyster Company in Marshall, Calif., diners eat at picnic tables overlooking Tomales Bay, where oysters and clams grow just offshore.

title: Your Morning Briefing: China-Taiwan Meeting, Volkswagen Emissions
description: Good morning, Asia.

title: Wife of Co-Pilot in Plane Crash Speaks
description: Natalya Trukhacheva, whose husband was the co-pilot of the Russian plane that crashed in the Sinai Peninsula on Saturday, told Russian television that he had complained before the flight about the condition of the plane.

title: Failed Co-ops Add Ammunition to G.O.P. War on Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  The financial failure of more than half the nonprofit health insurance companies created under the Affordable Care Act has handed Republicans a new weapon in their campaign against the health law, thrown the Obama administration on the defensive once again and left more than a half-million consumers in the cold.

title: Brazilian Official in FIFA Case Is Handed Over to the U.S.
description: United States prosecutors have extradited a third defendant in the unfolding FIFA corruption case that stretches from Argentina to Switzerland.

title: Review: Persecution and Promise, a Whooping and Wailing Czech Musical Evening
description: Persecution and Promise: A Legacy of Czech Music, a program of music and talk at the Buttenwieser Hall of the 92nd Street Y on Monday evening, featured several piquant musical effects and strange sounds  or, indeed, nonsounds.

title: Curds and Whey, Her Way
description: A Mennonite woman is making some of the best French-style goat cheese in America.

title: Dentons Law Firm Steps Up Global Expansion
description: The global law firm Dentons has announced that it is planning to combine with two firms, one in Australia and the other in Singapore, to create the largest law firm in the world.

title: How an Architect Designs a Blockbuster Art Show
description: Opening this week, Francis Bacon: Late Paintings, a new exhibition at Gagosians Madison Avenue gallery, offers a comprehensive survey of the artists lesser-known later work. To create a setting worthy of the enterprise, Gagosian directors Valentina Castellani and Stefan Ratibor sought the expertise of a longtime collaborator: the architect Annabelle Selldorf.

title: A Mennonites Knack for Fine Goat Cheese
description: BLOOMSDALE, Mo.  A Mennonite woman with a used 2001 Porsche Boxster and a Hello Kitty collection is making some of the most delicious French-style goat cheese in America.

title: China, Taiwan and a Meeting After 66 Years
description: BEIJING  President Xi Jinping of China and Taiwans president, Ma Ying-jeou, will meet on Saturday in Singapore, the first such meeting since before the Chinese Communist revolution of 1949 and the retreat of the Chinese Nationalists across the Taiwan Strait.

title: Smaller Overseas Entrepreneurs Find China Too Frustrating
description: BEIJING  With the blessing of local officials, Amir Porat, an Israeli entrepreneur, set up a surgical supply factory in 2013 in Chinas coastal Jiangsu Province, training workers and taking orders. All he needed to start production was $250,000 of specially designed molding equipment from Israel.

title: Michael D. Hammond, Co-Founder of Gateway Computers, Is Dead at 53
description: Michael D. Hammond, co-founder of Gateway, a computer manufacturer that was started in an Iowa farmhouse and became known for shipping products in boxes with a spotted cow design, died on Thursday at his home in Sioux City, Iowa. He was 53.

title: Chinese Coexist With Coal
description: Despite Chinas pledge to cap and then reduce carbon emissions, coal production continues to grow, creating tough choices for those who work in and live near the mines.

title: China Burns Much More Coal Than Reported, Complicating Climate Talks
description: BEIJING  China, the worlds leading emitter of greenhouse gases from coal, has been burning up to 17 percent more coal a year than the government previously disclosed, according to newly released data. The finding could complicate the already difficult efforts to limit global warming.

title: 2 Illegal Movie-Sharing Websites Are Closed
description: LOS ANGELES  Two websites that film companies said had jointly become a clearinghouse for illegal movie viewing were closed last month by orders from courts in Canada and New Zealand, the Motion Picture Association of America said on Tuesday.

title: Royals World Series Parade
description: The Kansas City Royals led a parade through the packed downtown in Missouris largest city to celebrate their World Series championship.

title: Anna Wintour, Prizes and Potpie at CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund Dinner
description: Fashion events come in as many styles as fashion, but you can always count on Champagne and, at one of New Yorks most touted annual parties, on chicken potpie. At the CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, 12 years strong, potpie  a favorite of Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue and one of the forces behind the young designer prize  remains immobile on the menu.

title: Ahmad Chalabi: 1944-2015
description: James Glanz, a former Baghdad correspondent for The New York Times, recounts past encounters with Ahmad Chalabi, who helped persuade the United States to invade Iraq and then unsuccessfully tried to attain power.

title: Mets Manager Terry Collins Is Said to Receive Extension
description: After guiding the Mets to their first pennant in 15 years, Manager Terry Collins will be rewarded with a two-year contract extension that will be officially announced at a news conference on Wednesday, according to a person in baseball with knowledge of the situation. If Collins finishes out the extension, he will have managed more games than anyone else in Mets history.

title: Major Investors on Start-Up Issues and Womens Speech Patterns
description: Silicon Valley may have become known as a land of exuberance and innovation  or one of irrationality as companies pursue the future. But two prominent investors counseled the tech centers denizens to think of the future in other ways as well.

title: Gore Calls for Exxon Mobil Inquiry on Climate Change
description: Former Vice President Al Gore said on Tuesday that there should be an investigation into Exxon Mobil over what he said was the oil companys misleading the public about the risks of climate change.

title: Review: Resettling the Meaning of Home in Brooklyn, With Saoirse Ronan
description: Many American families cherish faded memories of the Old Neighborhood and the Old Country, places that help supply both a sense of identity and a story of progress  complementary answers to the question Where do we come from?

title: An Artistic Homage to a Classic Work of Philosophy
description: In 1936, the German critic Walter Benjamin published The Work of Art in the Age of Mechanical Reproduction, a seminal essay thats arguably even more influential in 2015 than it was eight decades ago. Now, Benjamins observations on authorship, authenticity and capital have found their way into Vanessa Beecrofts photographic series for yoox.com, the Italian e-commerce retailer.

title: Review: Michel Houellebecqs Submission Imagines France as a Muslim State
description: Published in France on Jan. 7, the day of the terrorist attacks on the satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo, Michel Houellebecqs new book, Submission  a novel set in 2022 in which an Islamic party sweeps into power in France and Islamic law is embraced  became an instant best seller there and the center of a heated debate over the lines between satire and Islamophobia, free-expression and hate-mongering.

title: Review: In Jackson Heights, an Ode to the Immigrant Experience
description: All of creation converges in In Jackson Heights, a thrilling, transporting love letter from Frederick Wiseman to New York and its multi-everything glory. Set in the Queens neighborhood of its title  where people from across the globe are staking a claim on America while speaking Spanish, Tibetan and Punjabi  Mr. Wisemans latest documentary is a movingly principled, political look at a dynamic neighborhood in which older waves of pioneers make room for new, amid creeping gentrification. Its an immigration story, so it goes without saying that it is also about New York and the United States  that teeming nation of nations, to steal a phrase from Walt Whitman.

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: China, Elections, Robin Williams
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: Jacques Rivettes 1971 Film, Out 1: Noli Me Tangere
description: Within what is an intense but relatively narrow circle of cinephiles, Jacques Rivettes 1971 film, Out 1: Noli Me Tangere (the subtitle is Latin for touch me not), is considered, as more than one writer has put it, a kind of filmic holy grail. The nearly 13-hour work, a cinematic soak both sprawling and intimate, has been almost impossible to view in the more than 40 years since its production. The movie was screened in New York in 2006 by the Museum of the Moving Image, but the two-week engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, beginning on Wednesday, is its New York theatrical premiere.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Britain Will Present Legislation to Increase Oversight of Surveillance
description: LONDON  After the revelations by Edward J. Snowden of wholesale surveillance and the rapid development of communications technology, the British government is about to present a draft bill intended to clarify the states powers and increase transparency and oversight for intelligence agencies and the police.

title: Ahmad Chalabi and the Legacy of De-Baathification in Iraq
description: Since the American invasion of Iraq in 2003, few Iraqis have loomed as large on the countrys political stage as the politician and wheeler-dealer Ahmad Chalabi, who died Tuesday.

title: Islamic Faith Healing in Indonesia
description: A healing practice based on passages from the Quran has broad appeal in Indonesia, as practitioners forge a bond with patients.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Ticky Burden, Former All-American and Knick Who Fell Into Crime, Dies at 62
description: Luther Burden, better known as Ticky, a sharpshooting guard who played briefly for the Knicks in the 1970s but whose life took an ignominious turn when he was convicted of robbing a Long Island bank in 1980, died on Thursday in Winston-Salem, N.C. He was 62.

title: Clemson Tops First Set of College Football Playoff Rankings
description: Clemson (8-0, 5-0 Atlantic Coast Conference), which has not been the top-ranked team in an Associated Press poll since just after the 1981 season, was named No. 1 in the first College Football Playoff rankings of this season, which were released Tuesday night.

title: John Kerry Confronts Human Rights as He Zips Through Central Asia
description: ASHGABAT, Turkmenistan  Secretary of State John Kerry seems unlikely to make it to North Korea in his 15 remaining months in office. But on Tuesday he got the next best thing: A two-hour visit to another of the worlds most-sealed-off autocratic states, where the leader recently unveiled a 69-foot-high gold statue of himself on horseback, to go along with the regularly produced videos of his sporting prowess.

title: Buoyed by Poll, Hillary Clinton Has Day Full of Optimism in Iowa
description: CORALVILLE, Iowa  With a new poll showing the fickle Iowa electorate warming to her candidacy, even the weather agreed with Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday.

title: Elon Musk Says Never Mind the Hiccups, Tesla Is on Track
description: Tesla Motors on Tuesday sought to reassure investors and its devoted fans that it was still on track to produce more than 50,000 cars this year, though the electric-car company hinted at some production issues with its new Model X sport utility vehicle.

title: Missing Italian Marathoner Found on New York Subway, Still in His Running Gear
description: For most runners, the finish line of the New York City Marathon is the end of an arduous journey.

title: Matt Bevin, Republican, Wins Governors Race in Kentucky
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  Matt Bevin, a Republican political novice, wealthy Louisville businessman and Tea Party favorite, was elected Kentuckys next governor on Tuesday and swept fellow Republicans into statewide office with him. The stunning victory heralds a new era in a state where Democrats have held the governors mansion for all but four of the last 44 years.

title: Stanley Druckenmiller Offers a Bearish Warning
description: Stanley F. Druckenmiller, the hedge fund titan and founder of Duquesne Capital, is not optimistic about much these days.

title: In Downtown Los Angeles, a Potential Anchor for Offices
description: LOS ANGELES  Wilshire Grand Center, an estimated $1.2 billion mixed-use project in downtown Los Angeles, promises many things upon its 2017 completion date.

title: A Conversation With Michael D. Colacino
description: Mr. Colacino, 58, is the president of Savills Studley, a commercial real estate services company specializing in tenant representation, largely in the office sector. He has been with Studley since 1991 and has been president since 2002; the company, which is based in New York, merged with Savills of London last year.

title: CBS Weighs a Bigger Streaming Push
description: The CBS Corporation shocked the television industry last year when it announced a streaming service for its broadcast network that would not require a traditional cable subscription.

title: Review: Veritas, a Play About Harvards Gay Underground Put on Trial
description: To get to Veritas  a tidy site-specific production at the Cave at St. Georges Church from a troupe called the Representatives  you enter through a door below street level, an apt evocation of the plays depiction of a gay underground at Harvard in 1920. You are offered wine and directed to a corner where a man leads you to the first of two intimate rooms where the show is staged.

title: Regulators Unbundle Some Attractions of Mergers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has quietly taken a stand against corporate inversions.

title: Carl Icahn Talks Investments, Trump and a Minefield
description: There are few on Wall Street who can captivate an audience like the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn. On Tuesday, the activist hedge fund manager, who has drawn ire from corporate America for his abrasive manner with corporate chieftains, entertained once again.

title: Lawyers Offer Contrasting Views ofSheldon Silver as His Corruption Trial Starts
description: For two decades, Sheldon Silver was one of the most powerful men in New York politics, his control and demands as speaker of the State Assembly virtually unchallenged. And throughout that reign, prosecutors said on Tuesday, Mr. Silver capitulated to greed, taking illicit payments and selling his office.

title: Obama Wont Yield to Companys Bid to Delay Keystone Pipeline Decision
description: WASHINGTON  The White House on Tuesday said President Obama had no intention of bowing to a request from the company behind the Keystone XL oil pipeline to delay a decision on the project, saying he wanted to take action before his tenure ends.

title: Backlash Against U.S. in Iran Seems to Gather Force After Nuclear Deal
description: TEHRAN  Anyone who hoped that Irans nuclear agreement with the United States and other powers portended a new era of openness with the West has been jolted with a series of increasingly rude awakenings over the past few weeks.

title: As Transgender Students Make Gains, Schools Hesitate at Bathrooms
description: CHICAGO  Asked to call a transgender boy by a male name he has chosen for himself, teachers and administrators around the country have leaned toward a simple response: Sure. Allow a high school student who was born male but identifies as female to join the volleyball team? Fine.

title: Japan Post in Strong Stock Market Debut in Tokyo
description: TOKYO  For decades, whenever Japans leaders had an important project to pay for, they turned to the post office.

title: Latino Groups Call on S.N.L. to Drop Donald Trump
description: The decision by Saturday Night Live to invite Donald J. Trump as its host this week is no laughing matter  at least for the Hispanic and pro-immigration groups that have intensified their calls for Lorne Michaels, the shows producer, to rescind the invitation.

title: Turing Commits to Modest Price Reduction on a Drug
description: Turing Pharmaceuticals, which ignited a firestorm by acquiring a 62-year-old drug and increasing its price fiftyfold overnight, said on Tuesday that it would lower the price somewhat by the end of the year and take steps to broaden financial support to patients.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Norm Siebern, All-Star Who Left Yankees in Trade for Maris, Dies at 82
description: Norm Siebern, a solid outfielder and first baseman who was an American League All-Star three times and played in three World Series, but who may be best known as part of the trade that brought Roger Maris to the Yankees, died on Friday in Naples, Fla. He was 82.

title: Success Metrics Questioned in School Program Funded by Goldman
description: It was, in the vernacular of corporate America, a win-win: a bond that paid for preschool for underprivileged children in Utah while also making money for investors.

title: Sidelight to a Spy Saga: How a Brooklyn Newsboys Nickel Would Turn Into a Fortune
description: The newsboy Jimmy Bozart knew that the two schoolteachers who lived on the sixth floor of 3403 Foster Avenue in East Flatbush were reliable tippers: Every week, they paid him 50 cents for their Brooklyn Eagle subscription; actual cost, 35 cents.

title: U.N. Leader Pledges to Reveal Donor Data
description: UNITED NATIONS  A month after a former president of the United Nations General Assembly was arrested in connection to a corruption scheme, the current head of the world body said he would make public what funds he receives from government and private donors and explain how they are used.

title: Plan to Build a New High School in Queens Collides With Local Sentiment
description: Amid widespread overcrowding in New York Citys public school system, it might seem counterintuitive that there would be resistance  of the very angry and full-throated sort  to the opening of a new school.

title: Like Forks and Tridents
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Ruth Bloomfield Margolin made her New York Times debut in 2014 and she is back today to play GAMEs with us.

title: HBO Documentary Successfully Examines Enigmatic Life of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar has been part of our sports culture for a half century while seemingly urging himself to stand apart from it. He did his work on the basketball court but did not feel the need to submit to the public confessional. He came to national renown as a 7-foot teenager when he was mocked for his height and felt stung by racism, even from the high school coach he so admired, Jack Donohue.

title: Colin Welland, Oscar-Winning Writer of Chariots of Fire, Dies at 81
description: Colin Welland, a Liverpudlian screenwriter who won an Oscar for Chariots of Fire (1981), the dramatic tale of two Olympian runners who defied both the odds and the British establishment in 1924, died on Monday at his home in London. He was 81.

title: Voters in Ohio Reject Marijuana Legalization Amendment
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Ohio voters on Tuesday blocked a constitutional amendment to legalize marijuana for medical and recreational use, The Associated Press said.

title: New Crop of Immigrants in Parliament Is Seen as Reflection of Canada
description: OTTAWA  He was a teenage refugee, fleeing civil war in Somalia, when he came to Canada 22 years ago. Now, after completing high school and earning degrees in history and law, Ahmed Hussen is about to be sworn in as a member of Parliament  one of 46 nonwhite candidates elected to the House of Commons on Oct. 19, most of them immigrants.

title: The Rangers Get Some Luck Against a Familiar Rival
description: Rangers center Derick Brassard said he was merely trying to shovel a pass to his linemate Rick Nash, parked on the other side of the Washington goal. But the puck bounced off the stick of Washington forward Marcus Johansson and rolled into the goal instead.

title: Houston Voters Reject Broad Anti-Discrimination Ordinance
description: HOUSTON  A yearlong battle over gay and transgender rights that turned into a costly, ugly war of words between this citys lesbian mayor and social conservatives ended Tuesday as voters easily repealed an anti-discrimination ordinance that had attracted attention from the White House, sports figures and Hollywood celebrities.

title: Mayor de BlasioJoins in Criticism of 2nd Avenue Subway Cuts
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio, joining a chorus of criticism, said on Tuesday that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority should revisit its decision to delay construction of the East Harlem leg of the Second Avenue subway.

title: Joseph Ganim, Disgraced Ex-Mayor of Bridgeport, Conn., Wins Back Job
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  For months, Joseph P. Ganim asked residents of Connecticuts largest city to give him a second chance as mayor.

title: Scream Queens Season 1, Episode 7: Feather McCarthy
description: Maybe the Mets lost because they couldnt stand to wait two weeks for the next episode of Scream Queens.

title: Michael McMahon, Ex-Congressman, Is Elected Staten Island District Attorney
description: Michael E. McMahon, a former congressman and New York City councilman, was chosen as the new district attorney of Staten Island on Tuesday, winning a contentious special election in the citys most conservative borough.

title: Dispute Over South China Sea Prompts Asian Officials to Cancel Joint Statement
description: BEIJING  Differences over the South China Sea forced countries from Southeast Asia, along with China and the United States, to cancel a joint statement at a meeting of defense ministers in Malaysia on Wednesday.

title: Verizon and N.B.A. Form Partnership for Go90 Content
description: Verizon Communications has signed a content and marketing partnership with the National Basketball Association that will bring daily league highlights, new original series and access to some live games to its new mobile video streaming service Go90.

title: Boston Globe Owner Set to Start Health News Website
description: John Henry, the billionaire owner of The Boston Globe, formally unveils a new publication on Wednesday dedicated to coverage of health, medicine and life sciences.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Its impossible, absolutely impossible, for a member of the Assembly to do his or her job and to go out, make laws, deal with people, do the job that a person in the Assembly does, and not have some form of conflict of interest.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | venison
description: venison  \ve-n-sn also -zn\  noun

title: Special Races Do Not Alter Party Tallies in New York Legislature
description: On an Election Day in which three of the five State Legislature seats in New York being contested were left vacant by Albany lawmakers who ran afoul of corruption laws, it would seem reasonable to expect their misdeeds  and the ethical state of the capital they worked in  to play a large role in the races to replace them.

title: New Jersey Voters, in Rebuke of Christie, Oust 3 Republicans From Assembly
description: New Jersey Republicans faced a stinging defeat in off-year elections on Tuesday, as three Republican members of the State Assembly were beaten for re-election in a rebuke to the party and Gov. Chris Christie.

title: Georgia Prisoner Accused of Killing Sheriff Is Caught After Escape
description: A prisoner awaiting trial on accusations that he killed a Georgia sheriff spent nearly 12 hours on the run on Tuesday after he escaped custody by slipping out of his leg shackles and using them to break the window of a patrol car that was transferring him to a local jail, the authorities said.

title: What to Watch Tonight
description: Happy Hump Day, viewers, and who better to bounce us across the divide than Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, speaking out for the first time in years? Weve also got over-the-top action from Jackie Chan and Bruce Lee. And for those with a standing date with Empire, the Lyons protect their pride.

title: Corrections: November 4, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: News of Meeting Hits Chinese Airwaves
description: Chinas state broadcaster, CCTV, informed its viewers on Wednesday about the planned meeting between the presidents of China and Taiwan.

title: SABMiller and Anheuser-Busch InBev Deadline for Talks Is Extended
description: LONDON  SABMiller and Anheuser-Busch InBev will get more time to try to seal a takeover deal as British regulators once again extended a deadline for their talks, the companies said Wednesday.

title: Axel Springer Raises Outlook, Citing Strength of Ad Sales
description: PARIS  Axel Springer, the German publishing and digital media group, on Wednesday raised its forecast for 2015 revenue as increasing sales of digital classified advertising offset continued declines in print circulation and other revenue.

title: Pretrial Release in Los Angeles
description: To the Editor:

title: The Next Republican Debate: For Civility and Substance
description: To the Editor:

title: So Bernie Sanders Doesnt Shmooze
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bill That Would Make Roads Less Safe
description: When it comes to Americas transportation system, Congress seems determined, year after year, to do the wrong thing. The House will vote on a bill as early as Wednesday that does not dedicate enough money to improving the quality of deteriorating highways and mass transit systems, but does include policies that will make American roads less safe.

title: A Refugee, Not a Criminal
description: Its not a mystery why Abdul Rahman Haroun wanted to flee Sudan. The mystery is how this 40-year-old man from a rural village managed to reach Europe, get all the way to Calais in the north of France, then over the security fences and past police officers guarding the mouth of the Channel Tunnel and steer clear of 100-mile-an-hour trains to finally reach Britain.

title: Forcing Consumers Into Arbitration
description: To the Editor:

title: Why Are Asian-Americans Such Loyal Democrats?
description: In just two decades, Asian-American support for the Democratic presidential candidate more than doubled, from the 31 percent Bill Clinton got in 1992 to the 73 percent cast for President Obama in 2012, according to exit polls.

title: The Catholic Churchs Sins Are Ours
description: Its fashionable among some conservatives to rail that theres insufficient respect for religion in America and that religious people are marginalized, even vilified.

title: Schoolkids in Handcuffs
description: The video that went viral last month showing a white sheriffs deputy in a Columbia, S.C., classroom throwing and dragging an African-American student across the floor may well be indicative of a deeper problem with the security program in that school district.

title: Let Refugees Settle Italys Empty Spaces
description: Milan  AS Europe frets over what to do about the hundreds of thousands of refugees pouring onto the Continent, it occurs to me that the ancient Romans, as they so often do, might offer a solution.

title: The Tough Realities of the Paris Climate Talks
description: IN less than a month, delegates from more than 190 countries will convene in Paris to finalize a sweeping agreement intended to constrain human influence on the climate. But any post-meeting celebration will be tempered by two sobering scientific realities that will weaken the effectiveness of even the most ambitious emissions reduction plans that are being discussed.

title: How A.L.S. Rescued My Father
description: I laid my hand on his cold collarbone and  as the sun set behind my old school, which could be glimpsed from the bedroom window  he started to die. The vibrating pulses below his necks paper-thin skin ebbed. His breathing grew shallow until it disappeared entirely, like ripples on water that slowly level out.

title: Furor Prompts Another Auction of Margaret Thatcher's Clothes
description: Clothes, jewelry and political mementos owned by Margaret Thatcher, Britains longest-serving prime minister of the 20th century and the countrys only female prime minister to date, are to be auctioned after the Victoria and Albert Museum in London turned down the chance to preserve her wardrobe for the nation.

title: Bangladesh on the Brink
description: Over the last few weeks, the body count of intolerance has been unbearably high in Bangladesh.

title: News Qs | Lionsgate Seeks to Build on Its Library of Film Properties With Theme Parks
description: Before Reading Lionsgate Seeks to Build on Its Library of Film Properties With Theme Parks:

title: When Leaders of Taiwan and China Meet, Even Tiny Gestures Will Be Parsed
description: Xi Jinping has several titles: president of China, general secretary of the Communist Party and sometimes even Dada, a name that is translated as Uncle or Daddy. When he meets with President Ma Ying-jeou of Taiwan on Saturday in Singapore, he will simply be Mister.

title: Islamic Faith Healing in Indonesia
description: Antonio Zambardino considers himself to be neither religious nor superstitious, but when he stumbled across an exorcism while photographing in a remote area of Indonesia he was compelled to find out more about what he had witnessed.

title: The Weaponization of Truther
description: What does it mean to be a truther?

title: Mayor de Blasios Private Advisers: Who Gives the Money and Who Gets It
description: Some deep-pocketed interests top the list of contributors to the Campaign for One New York, which has paid large sums to the firms of several private consultants who advise the mayor.

title: The High Price of Delivery App Convenience
description: WHEN Emily Yang, a San Francisco tech worker, is running out of cat food, she taps an app called Instacart to order a new bag of kibble to be delivered to her door within hours. For dinner, she often orders through Sprig and Munchery, app-powered services that bring fresh organic meals to her home.

title: Adventures in Athleisure Clothing
description: What is athleisure?

title: Mayor de Blasios Hired Guns: Private Consultants Help Shape City Hall
description: On a wintry Sunday in February, Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York huddled at Gracie Mansion with a trusted adviser, John Del Cecato, to polish his marquee speech of 2015, the annual State of the City address.

title: How Well Do You Know Your Neighbors?
description: How well do you know your neighbors? Do they play an important role in your life or in your familys social network? Do you say hello to them in the driveway or as you walk down the sidewalk? Or do you really have no interaction whatsoever with the people who live nearby?

title: Living In TriBeCa
description: Fast-growing and affluent, the Lower Manhattan neighborhood has many loft-style apartments in old and new buildings.

title: TriBeCa: Not for Starving Artists
description: When Avi and Leigh Savar moved to TriBeCa about two years ago with their daughter, Evie, now 7, they knew it was family-friendly, but they were still surprised by just how welcome they felt. There are so many young families here, said Mr. Savar, the chief executive of Dreamit, a venture capital firm. Its pretty remarkable.

title: Victor Ponta, Romanias Premier, Steps Down After Outcry Over Corruption
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  Huge protests, some of the largest since the fall of communism, toppled the government of Romania on Wednesday, five days after a fire at a nightclub killed 32 people and set off a wave of outrage over corruption and ineptitude.

title: Jack Kemp: The Bleeding-Heart Conservative Who Changed America
description: If space aliens were to land a flying saucer on the Capitols West Lawn, one question they might ask is: Wherever did you get the idea that cutting taxes would increase revenue?

title: The Crime and the Silence, by Anna Bikont
description: On July 10, 1941, in Jedwabne, a town of roughly 3,000 inhabitants in northeastern Poland, a mob of Catholics murdered most of their Jewish neighbors. Estimates of the number of victims vary, from about 300 men, women and children to as many as 1,600. Whatever the correct figure, very few Jews survived. Using axes, clubs and knives, the mob first killed some 40 Jewish men. The remaining Jews  men, women and children, many of them infants  were herded into a wooden barn on the outskirts of the town. Then, as the jeering crowd watched, the murderers barred the doors, poured gasoline on the structure and lit the fire. Everyone inside died. Plunder of Jewish homes followed. Peasants from neighboring villages, who had begun arriving in Jedwabne at dawn on the day of the massacre, joined in the fun.

title: Jay Winiks 1944: FDR and the Year That Changed History
description: In 2001, Jay Winik scored a commercial and critical success with his best seller April 1865, a vivid account of the final month of the Civil War, which Winik convincingly argued was a crucial turning point in American history. Robert E. Lee and Ulysses S. Grant, among others, play major roles in April 1865, but Abraham Lincoln towers above all of them.

title: Killing a King Examines Assassination of Yitzhak Rabin
description: Twenty years ago, on Nov. 4, 1995, a man who was trying to beat swords into plowshares was shot as he left a peace rally. Yitzhak Rabin, the Israeli prime minister who signed a groundbreaking agreement with the Palestinians just a little more than two years earlier, was assassinated in Tel Aviv by a young right-wing law student who decided he had a divinely sanctioned duty to kill the premier.

title: Stand More at Work, Sit More at Home
description: Using a standing desk at the office may adversely influence how much time you spend lounging in a chair at home, according to a new study of sedentary behavior. The findings subtly underscore that, when it comes to health habits and exercise, we humans have a surprising capacity to be our own worst enemies.

title: Rand Paul Rode Tea Party Fervor to Washington, Then Yielded
description: It is rare to hear a candidate for the United States Senate so earnestly quote rock lyrics. Rarer still, lyrics from a Canadian progressive-rock band.

title: Suicide Bombing Kills at Least 4 Egyptian Police Officers in Sinai
description: CAIRO  At least four police officers were killed on Wednesday morning when a suicide bomber detonated an explosives-packed vehicle next to a police club in northern Sinai, according to the Egyptian state news media. The Islamic States local affiliate, called Sinai Province, claimed responsibility for the bombing in a statement distributed on social media accounts.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing: Election Results, Donald Trump, Takata Airbags
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Morning Agenda: Success of Goldman-Funded School Program Questioned
description: SUCCESS OF GOLDMAN-FUNDED SCHOOL PROGRAM QUESTIONED | Goldman Sachs announced last month that its investment in a Utah preschool program had helped 109 at-risk kindergartners avoid special education and delivered a $260,000 payout for the Wall Street firm. Gov. Gary R. Herbert of Utah hailed the investment as a model for financing public projects, but questions have emerged about the success of the program,Nathaniel Popper reports in DealBook.

title: Donald Trump Employs a Scowl to Help Sell His New Book
description: Donald J. Trump said that The Scowl was deliberate.

title: Two Hopi Traditions: Running and Winning
description: ORAIBI, Ariz.  Above the creased high-desert landscape of northeastern Arizona, the Hopi village Oraibi, continuously inhabited for nearly 1,000 years, sits atop a blond mesa crumbling at the edges.

title: OfferUp Takes On Craigslist With War Chest and Mobile Strategy
description: BELLEVUE, Wash.  The offices of OfferUp in the suburbs of Seattle are decorated with the kind of offbeat knickknacks that are easy to find on an online classifieds site like Craigslist.

title: New York Today: Counting the Votes
description: Updated 7:38 a.m.

title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: Burberry Puts the Nail in the Coffin of the Multiline Brand
description: On Tuesday, in a briefing just before Burberry unveiled its latest holiday ad campaign, Christopher Bailey, chief executive and chief creative officer of the brand, also announced what he suggested was a gift to consumers: the news that the three Burberry womens and mens wear lines would begin a consolidation process, so that by the end of 2016, there will be a single brand on offer in stores.

title: Taiwans Opposition Rejects Meeting
description: Tsai Ing-wen, Taiwans opposition leader, said on Wednesday that she opposed a planned meeting between the presidents of China and Taiwan in Singapore on Saturday.

title: At Paul Ryans Invitation, Image of Hastert Takes an Appropriate Leave From Speakers Lobby
description: Some facts about Representative Frederick H. Gillett: A Massachusetts Republican, he served as speaker of the House for six years in the early 1920s. He proposed an anti-polygamy amendment to the Constitution. He served in the Senate after the House, then apparently engaged in literary pursuits.

title: 2016 Legislative Calendars Leave Plenty of Room for Campaigning
description: Rank-and-file House Republicans have been demanding a greater role in legislating  and more amendments  which means longer debates and workdays at the Capitol. And Speaker Paul D. Ryan seems prepared to oblige. But election years also present their own special scheduling imperatives, given the need for lawmakers to defend their seats.

title: Remains of Nearly 2,750 Korean Wartime Laborers Found in Japan, South Says
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Summing up a search that has been underway for more than a decade, a South Korean government commission said on Wednesday that the remains of nearly 2,750 people believed to be Koreans who were forced to work in Japan in the World War II era have been found.

title: Judge John Hodgman on Rhymes With Rock
description: Lori writes: During a family game night, my husband drew a card that said, Find two things that rhyme with rock. He searched the house and returned with a sock and a tube of caulk. I immediately disputed the caulk, but he insisted it rhymes, shouting a mispronunciation of the word over and over in front of our 9-year-old.

title: How Much Can We Spend to Keep Our Dog Alive?
description: About 18 months ago, my husband and I adopted a dog who was seized as part of a cruelty/neglect investigation. He has serious skin issues and was recently diagnosed with lymphoma. Like most dogs, despite all he has been through, he has a sweet doggy spirit. He also has a team of specialists  a dermatologist, an oncologist and his regular vet. At the moment, he is comfortable and happy. When the time comes (most likely in the next year), we will see him through to a gentle death. We have the resources to take care of him, but he is expensive  think car payment, not mortgage payment. He doesnt look like a regular dog, and people know he has a medical routine. There is a lot of unsolicited judgment, mostly in three camps: those who think we should devote the same amount of resources to charitable animal-related organizations and not an individual dog, people who think it is wrong to put a dog through chemo and people who think its morally wrong to exert so much effort on an animal. We mostly just love our dog. What do you think? C. S., Portland, Ore.

title: Mark Bittmans Top 10 Columns
description: Our departing columnists most viewed articles about the practice and pleasure of cooking.

title: 5 Headphones for the Frequent Flier
description: The right set of headphones can make any trip  but especially air travel  a little more enjoyable. Although some of the latest choices have different features, all can be used with in-flight entertainment systems, cellphones and tablets, and to listen to music.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Magic-Flight Launch Box
description: For a year or two, I smoked pot out of a chimney-shaped wooden pipe. It came with a lighter, which was wrapped in a sort of braided-leather papoose. Papoose and pipe were handmade by a shaman-like fellow I met on the side of a highway in the Pacific Northwest. His wares were solid, but the smoke was harsh. So, not long ago, I switched to a vaporizer, or vape, the Magic-Flight Launch Box.

title: Hotel and Resort News: City Guides, and Healthier Menus
description: CITY GUIDES FROM PARK HYATT ...

title: Kenya Excels in Running but Lags in Antidoping
description: In case you havent noticed, Kenyas runners are good. Lately, they are better than ever.

title: A Slice of Heaven in Pittsburgh
description: Somehow, over the past few years, Neapolitan pizza  gooey, thin, soft-crusted, mozzarella-and-tomato-only  has become the ideal. In a way its understandable; pizza had strayed so far from its roots that the classical model was bound to come back.

title: How We Judge Those Who Served, or Didnt, in Vietnam
description: The first Democratic presidential debate once again raised the issue of military service during the Vietnam War. Senator Bernie Sanders was asked how he could be commander-in-chief, given that he applied for conscientious objector status during that war. (Though his application was rejected he was not drafted and did not serve.)

title: New Passport in Britain Puts Women in 2nd Class
description: LONDON  Britains newly designed passport was meant to celebrate the countrys creativity and innovation over the last five centuries, and officials have called it the latest step in an evolutionary process for passport security.

title: A Canada Ready to Share Again
description: Toronto  The resounding demand for change that saw the Liberal leader Justin Trudeau swept into the Canadian prime ministers office, and Stephen Harper out of it, also introduced other auspicious changes, setting the country on a different but familiar path. The 338-seat House of Commons now has more female representatives than ever before, and there are 46 members from minority groups (though African-Canadians are still underrepresented). The countrys first lawmaker born in Afghanistan was elected. The 10 members from Canadas indigenous population of about 1.4 million is also a record.

title: Bookshelf: Breakthrough Lives
description: New picture-book biographies recount the lives of the first computer programmer, an Alvin Ailey dancer and a blue-eyed singer from Hoboken named Frankie.

title: Lets Finally Close Guantnamo
description: INSTEAD of blocking President Obamas efforts to close the costly Guantnamo Bay detention facility, Congress should be working with him to finally shut it down.

title: Kicked Off a Plane? Heres How to Handle It
description: Seven passengers were removed from a Spirit Airlines flight on Monday before it left Los Angeles, bound for Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport. The incident appears to have started with a double-booked seat and escalated when other passengers questioned the conduct of the flight crew. The fliers, all African-American, and at least one fellow passenger using Twitter  have accused the airline of racism.

title: Losing It at KFC
description: Dear Diary:

title: Profile in Style: Hiroki Nakamura
description: The founder of cult workwear favorite Visvim shares his vintage inspirations.

title: Nilaja Sun Serves Up the Characters in Her One-Woman Pike St.
description: The golden age of the chameleonic solo show seems to have passed, and with it the days when there seemed to be a virtuoso new work by Eric Bogosian, Anna Deavere Smith, Danny Hoch, John Leguizamo or Sarah Jones opening every few months. But there is good news for fans of this fertile theatrical genre: One of its most gifted stars, Nilaja Sun, is making a long-awaited return with Pike St., a one-woman show that evokes a collection of characters on the Lower East Side, including a family dealing with a teenage daughter whose mysterious sickness has rendered her unable to move or breathe on her own.

title: Ann Dowd, a Late Arrival Worth the Wait
description: Ann Dowd is having a moment. That moment has taken its time arriving.

title: A Japanese Designer With a Rugged Western Aesthetic
description: Hiroki Nakamura, the founder of cult workwear favorite Visvim, lives the vintage life  carefully curated yet casually scuffed.

title: What You Get for  $3,000,000
description: A Jacobean house in Massachusetts, water views in Baltimore and an indoor pool in Minneapolis

title: $3,000,000 Homes in Massachusetts, Baltimore and Minneapolis
description: BROOKLINE, MASS.

title: Spreading the Word on Transcendental Meditation
description: Transcendental Meditation, the 1960s approach to what today we might call mindfulness, has long had celebrity advocates, starting with the Beatles, who followed its founder to India in 1967.

title: 1915: Panel in Defense of Armenians
description: WASHINGTON  Responding to a pressing appeal from Mr. Morgenthau, United States Ambassador in Constantinople, an American committee has been organized on behalf of the Armenians. Among its members are such men as Mr. Charles R. Crane, Mr. Samuel T. Dutton and Mr. Oscar Straus. The committee has just published a report giving conclusive evidence in regard to the atrocities against the Armenians on the part of the Turks. Witnesses of these horrors hold the Germans largely responsible for them because of tacit assent.  The New York Herald, European Edition, November 5, 1915

title: Netflix C.E.O. Says Hulu Is Detrimental
description: Speaking at the DealBook conference in New York, Reed Hastings says that cable networks should not let Hulu cannibalize their content.

title: A Perilous Crossing to Greece
description: Migrants continue to set off by boat from Turkey in hopes of reaching Greece. More than 600,000 have made the trip this year, testing the limits of the government and humanitarian response.

title: A Wintry Sea Seems a Safer Bet Than Life at Home for Refugees
description: MOLYVOS, Greece  The rubber dinghy rolled perilously on the waves and twisted sideways, nearly flipping, as more than three dozen passengers wrapped in orange life vests screamed, wept and cried frantically to God and the volunteers waiting on the rocky beach.

title: Morgan Stanley C.E.O. on Talent
description: At the DealBook conference, James P. Gorman says that Morgan Stanley has no trouble attracting talent despite decreased compensation.

title: Switching from Favorites to Likes
description: At the DealBook conference in New York, Chris Sacca, the well-known investor who has backed Twitter, explained why the company implemented a new heart/like icon.

title: Daily Report: Facebooks Turn to Show Its Earnings Report Card
description: Its Facebooks turn on Wednesday to present its report card.

title: Chris Sacca on Gender Inequality
description: At the DealBook conference in New York, the Silicon Valley investor criticized culture for failing to better groom women for leadership positions in tech.

title: A Modern Apartment in an Upscale Neighborhood of Madrid
description: Fully renovated, with three bedrooms and three baths in a 115-year-old building, it is on the market for $1.925 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Spain
description: A MODERN APARTMENT IN AN UPSCALE NEIGHBORHOOD OF MADRID

title: Al Gore Discusses Climate Change
description: At the DealBook conference in New York, the former vice president and current environmental activist said that he saw proof of global warming while visiting Miami recently.

title: Dozens Killed in Cargo Plane Crash in South Sudan Along Nile
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A cargo plane also carrying soldiers and civilians crashed Wednesday along the banks of the Nile minutes after taking off from South Sudans capital, Juba, killing most of those on board, according to United Nations and government officials.

title: Carl Icahn on Stopping Inversions
description: At the DealBook conference, the activist investor discussed his efforts to stop American companies from moving their profits overseas to take advantage of lower tax rates.

title: Heartland of Darkness
description: This new paper by Angus Deaton and Anne Case on mortality among middle-aged whites has been getting a lot of attention, and rightly so. As a number of people have pointed out, the closest parallel to Americas rising death rates  driven by poisonings, suicide, and chronic liver diseases  is the collapse in Russian life expectancy after the fall of Communism. (No, were not doing as badly as that, but still.) What the data look like is a society gripped by despair, with a surge of unhealthy behaviors and an epidemic of drugs, very much including alcohol.

title: An Easy Way to Use WhatsApp
description: Q. My daughter has been living in South America for the last year and we communicate daily via WhatsApp on our iPhones. Our text history is a wonderful diary of her experiences there and I would like to be able to save them to my computer and print them out for us to enjoy in the future. Is there a simple way to do this?

title: Punk Is Beautiful: Dickie Hammond (1965-2015)
description: Dickie Hammond, one of British punk rocks most gifted and revered guitarists, died last week. He was 50. Facebook and British and European blogs are filling up with tributes to Dickie  a legend, a lord and a lovely bloke  some of them calling him the best punk guitarist of all time. None of this is likely to make the obit pages outside North England.

title: Forty-Two Minutes With Jeb Bush on the Campaign Bus
description: RYE, N.H.  Jeb Bush needs a boost. Hes getting a bus.

title: Bevins Victory Speech in Kentucky
description: Matt Bevin of Kentucky spoke Tuesday night after he beat his Democratic opponent in the states gubernatorial race.

title: IoT and Cassandra: Topic Wildcards in Retained Storage
description: I recently presented at the 2015 Cassandra Summit on the Internet of Things (IoT) and our work at The New York Times, drawing on over fifty years of experience in computing.

title: Bonuses for Bank Executives Should Be Tied to Gender Diversity, Review Says
description: LONDON  The annual bonuses of financial services executives in Britain should be tied to targets to bring more women into senior roles, according to the preliminary findings of a government commissions review of gender diversity in the sector.

title: Angelina Jolie Pitt Is Behind Closed Doors in By the Sea
description: BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF.  During the filming of By the Sea, Angelina Jolie Pitt and Brad Pitt  who play a depressed former dancer and her blocked novelist husband  had a go-to method for lightening an often somber mood on the set. There were a lot of jokes about how nobody is ever going to want to be our neighbor again, said Ms. Jolie Pitt, referring to how their characters often spy through a peephole on two lovers in the hotel room next door.

title: Stressed, Tired, Rushed: A Portrait of the Modern Family
description: Children are much more likely than not to grow up in a household in which their parents work, and in nearly half of all two-parent families today, both parents work full time, a sharp increase from previous decades.

title: In Hondas Rebuke of Takata, a Rare Move for Business Partners in Japan
description: TOKYO  When a car manufacturer publicly questions the honesty of a business partner that supplies it with vital safety equipment, it is a sure sign that the relationship is in trouble.

title: New N.B.A. Faces Among Those Off to Fast Starts
description: N.B.A. teams have played only three to five games so far. But that has been plenty of time for the best players to assert themselves.

title: France to Lift Ban on Gay Men Donating Blood
description: PARIS  France will lift a ban on blood donations by gay and bisexual men starting next year, officials announced Wednesday, joining a growing list of countries that have loosened or scrapped such restrictions, which many see as outdated vestiges of the 1980s AIDS crisis.

title: Reaction to Houston's Vote on Anti-Discrimination Ordinance
description: Mayor Annise D. Parker of Houston and Lt. Gov. Dan Patrick of Texas spoke on Tuesday after the rejection of an ordinance that would establish protections for gay and transgender people.

title: Public Companies Trying to Mimic Private Firms
description: It was one of the biggest rebukes of the public markets in recent memory  and it may not be the last.

title: What to Watch in New Yorks Fall Art Auctions
description: It has been a banner year for the international art auction houses. Last November, the big fall auctions in New York saw sales at Christies and Sothebys top $2 billion in two weeks. In May, Christies sold $1 billion worth of art in just three days. Included in that total was a 1955 Picasso, Les Femmes dAlger (Version O), which went for $179.4 million with fees  a record for any artwork at auction.

title: Reader Contest: The Best Parenting Advice in Six Words
description: Made a threat? Carry it through.

title: 1940: Vichy Gives Assurances to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  The chances of early American intervention in Martinique were discounted today [Nov. 4] by Gaston Henry-Haye, French Ambassador, after he had delivered a note from the Vichy government to the State Department denying any intention of turning over French possessions and bases to the Germans.

title: Digital Transformation Going Mainstream in 2016, IDC Predicts
description: It is the time of year when the big technology research shops gaze into the near future to identify trends that will have the most impact on corporate America and the tech industry over the next few years.

title: Patricia Riggen, Director of The 33, on Shooting in a Mine
description: On the first day of shooting The 33, the Mexican director Patricia Riggen sat in her chair in the cave that served as the movies set. And bicckk! A stone falls on top of my head, she recalled. Fortunately, I had my hard hat on. But it makes me realize where I am and what it means to be there.

title: In The Hot Rock, Gems on View Before Their Time
description: Its never been clear why The Hot Rock, the New York caper comedy directed by Peter Yates, didnt get more love at its 1972 release. (Maybe because the city was simply an unfunny tableau of urban decline, not yet the object of nostalgic affection it would become.) Even so, the film, about unpolished jewel thieves trying to snatch a spectacular diamond for an interested buyer, is an embarrassment of riches: It featured William Goldmans script, adapted from the Donald E. Westlake novel, as well as a top-shelf cast  Robert Redford playing straight man to George Segal, Paul Sand and Ron Leibman, all eclipsed by vintage late-period Zero Mostel. And the city was virtually a featured character itself.

title: Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba Blends Dance Traditions
description: Its always a hot night in Havana wherever and whenever Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba performs. In her Cuba Vibra!, Ms. Alfonsos Havana-based company, in only 95 minutes, will celebrate the development of Cuban music and dance from the 1950s to the present with the aid of 18 dancers and an onstage big band. The troupe, founded by Ms. Alfonso in 1991 as an all-female group, now includes men.

title: A Beloved Bakery in Midwood
description: Isaacs Bake Shop is famous in Midwoods Jewish community, but also picks up customers tired of waiting at a celebrated pizza place nearby.

title: Q. & A. Why Are More Companies Passing on Going Public?
description: The United States stock market is thought to have played a heroic role in the countrys history. Over the decades, thousands of public companies have raised many billions of dollars in the markets  money that has propelled economic growth, innovation and employment. Without the public markets, corporate America would not have had a vast, cheap and powerful pool of capital.

title: Classical Playlist: Vaughan Williams and a Piano Nutcracker
description: VAUGHAN WILLIAMS: A Sea SymphonyKatherine Broderick, soprano; Roderick Williams, baritone; Hall Choir, Hall Youth Choir, Schola Cantorum of Oxford, Ad Solem; Hall Orchestra; Mark Elder, conductor(Hall)Manchesters Hall Orchestra continues its unbroken streak of valuable releases with this towering account of Ralph Vaughan Williamss first symphony. Written at the crest of the fashion for seafaring works that swept Britain at the start of the 20th century, and given its premiere just a month after Mahlers Eighth, its a full choral symphony lasting over an hour, a work that astonishes with ambition both compositional and (with texts by Walt Whitman) literary and philosophical. Mark Elder makes clear Vaughan Williamss debts to Charles Stanford and Elgar, Wagner and Ravel, carrying them along in a reading of tidal power, patient yet inexorable. (David Allen)

title: Secret Space Escapes Re-enacts Near Disasters on Past Missions
description: Were all familiar with Americas worst spacecraft moments, those that took a disastrous, fatal turn. But less well known are the almosts, the difficulties astronauts faced that could have been catastrophic.

title: Britain Announces Plan to Update Surveillance Laws
description: LONDON  Stirring a fraught debate about the balance between security and privacy, the British government on Wednesday proposed tougher scrutiny over snooping by spy agencies, but also said it wanted technology companies to store data about every Britons Internet use for a year.

title: Bali Travelers Stranded as Volcano Grounds Flights
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  A volcanic eruption has stranded thousands of airline passengers on the Indonesian island of Bali and led to the cancellation of hundreds of flights in and out of the popular resort destination, with no relief in sight until at least Thursday.

title: Statins May Dampen Response to Flu Vaccine
description: Statins, the cholesterol lowering drugs, may weaken the effect of the flu vaccine, two new studies suggest.

title: A Brooklyn Bakery Appeals to Observant Jews and Pizza Fans
description: Isaacs Bake Shop knows firsthand the power of the adage location, location, location. The humble kosher bakery happens to be directly across the street from Di Fara Pizza, one of the few destinations in Midwood that draws international tour guides. Di Fara is also known for its interminable waiting times. Thanks to the influx of hungry customers roaming up and down Avenue J looking for an in-the-meantime nibble, Isaacs has developed an unexpected following among those unaware of or indifferent to the laws of kashrut.

title: Christian Gerhaher at Park Avenue Armory, and Julia Bullock at the Met
description: Among chamber music fans, the baritone Christian Gerhaher is considered the uncontested heir to Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau at the helm of the German lied tradition. On Tuesday, Nov. 10, he and his longtime pianist, Gerold Huber, return to the elegant Board of Officers Room at the Park Avenue Armory, which they inaugurated with an all-Schumann recital two years ago. This time, they bring their probing musicianship to the Viennese tradition with a program spanning songs by Haydn, Beethoven, Schoenberg and Berg. (7:30 p.m., parkavenuearmory.org.)

title: Cargo Plane Crashes in South Sudan
description: Shortly after takeoff from Juba's airport, a cargo plane crashed into the banks of the White Nile River. Officials said three survived, but at least 25 have been reported killed.

title: Procession: The Art of Norman Lewis Is a Full Retrospective of This Artists Career
description: Last year, the art of Norman Lewis (1909-79) shared an exhibition at the Jewish Museum with that of another marginalized Abstract Expressionist, Lee Krasner (1908-84). Now the first full retrospective of Lewiss art since his death opens on Friday, Nov. 13, at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts in Philadelphia.

title: Takeaways from Tuesdays Election
description: It was a big night for Republicans, turnout matters, and other things you need to know.

title: House Tour | Thomas Flohr
description: The VistaJet chairman built a seven-story chalet in the Swiss Alps  fit for James Bond, and complete with a hidden grotto.

title: The Man Who Hates E.T.F.s
description: Bearded and tanned, Peter S. Kraus, the chief executive of AllianceBernstein, strode with assurance into a Midtown Manhattan conference room full of financial advisers from a large investment bank.

title: New Music From Nate Wooley, Alicia Hall Moran and Adam Larson
description: (DANCE TO) THE EARLY MUSIC

title: Prime Minister Ponta of Romania Resigns
description: Prime Minister Victor Ponta of Romania said he is resigning in the wake of public discontent after a fire killed 32 people in a Bucharest nightclub.

title: Britons Perturbed by a Troubling Shortage of Curry Chefs
description: LONDON  William Makepeace Thackeray, a 19th-century English satirist, was born in Calcutta and once penned an ode to curry. Tis, when done, he wrote, a dish for Emperors to feed upon.

title: Officers Death Stuns Illinois Town a Second Time
description: The shooting death of a police lieutenant made national news and brought a stretch of northern Illinois to a tense standstill with roadblocks, thudding helicopters and officers tramping with dogs through woods and over farmland, searching for the killers. The lieutenant, Charles J. Gliniewicz, was hailed as a hero, and some conservatives seized on this and other shootings as evidence that critics of the police were fueling a wave of violence against law enforcement.

title: The Beatles Video Collection 1: Baby, You Can Film My Song
description: On Nov. 23, 1965, the Beatles entered Twickenham Film Studios, on the outskirts of London, for a marathon session. But the biggest band in the world wasnt recording music  it was making promotional films for five of its singles.

title: A Jim Henson Thanksgiving, 47 Years in the Making
description: In 1968, a pre-famous Jim Henson and his frequent writing partner, Jerry Juhl, collaborated on a treatment for a one-hour Thanksgiving special called The Musical Monsters of Turkey Hollow. The outline called for Mr. Hensons puppets to exist in real-world environs, shot on location in and around an unspecified New England town. The title characters, small, shaggy monsters of extraterrestrial origin, would communicate via a rather unique musical sound  to be created on an electronic synthesizer by the pioneering musician Raymond Scott.

title: December Interest Rate Increase Is a Live Possibility, Janet Yellen Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve could raise its benchmark interest rate in December as long as economic growth continues, two senior Fed officials said on Wednesday, hammering that message in repeated public remarks.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: A Fall-Themed Veggie Burger
description: Bailey Rae, a food writer in Nashville, created a fall-themed veggie burger to star on her Thanksgiving table. The dish requires some prep time to bake, scoop and, well, squash, the acorn squash and caramelize the onions, but once those steps are out of the way, this is an easy dish to add to your Thanksgiving menu.

title: Enlisting Veterans to Remedy the Shortage of Farmers
description: American military veterans need work, and American agriculture needs farmers. So why not, figuratively, convert those who wielded swords into those guiding plowshares?

title: A Flawed Marijuana Legalization Effort Fails in Ohio [Updated]
description: Ohio voters did the right thing on Tuesday by overwhelmingly rejecting a deeply flawed marijuana legalization ballot initiative. The proposal would have amended the states constitution to grant a monopoly on commercial cultivation of cannabis to a small group of investors, which is a terrible idea.

title: Roosting Chickens and Fed-Bashing
description: So I look at Business Insider and see that Stanley Druckenmiller is issuing dire warnings that terrible things will happen unless the Fed hikes rates now now now. I guess this is supposed to be news. But wait; havent I heard this before? Why, yes: two and half years ago he warned that a crash worse than 2008 was coming unless we slash Social Security now now now.

title: Another Setback for World Trade Center Transit Hub: Leaking Water
description: Everywhere, the shopping season is about to begin. Everywhere, that is, except at the most complete retail destination in New York City, the most alluring retail landmark in the world, as the luxury Westfield World Trade Center mall describes itself.

title: Afghan Businessman Convicted in Kabul Bank Fraud Is Still Free to Make Money
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In a big day for development here, a notable Afghan businessman stood with top government officials on Wednesday as he signed the contract for a new township: 8,800 homes across 33 acres of prime real estate in the heart of the capital, with an initial investment of at least $95 million.

title: Migrants Rescued Near Greece
description: Greek authorities reported a deadly boating accident near the island of Lesbos involving migrants from Turkey, The Associated Press said. Rescue workers were able to save most on board.

title: Expectations Mount for Trustees in Higher Education
description: Rick White is a financial consultant in Boulder, Colo., but his heart is often 2,000 miles to the east, at Haverford College, the school on the Main Line outside Philadelphia that he graduated from in 1981. When he was tapped to be on its governing board, he was like a sub coming off the bench in a crucial game, ready to go all in.

title: Eight Edgy, Elegant Enamel Earrings
description: A bit Memphis, a touch mod, these graphic combinations of color and shape feel totally on the mark.

title: Trudeau Becomes Prime Minister of Canada
description: Justin Trudeau, the leader of the majority Liberal Party, was sworn in on Wednesday as the 23rd prime minister of Canada.

title: Navigating the Tax Rules on Charitable Gifts
description: Congress has been tightening the rules on charitable gifts for more than a decade, and following those rules is critical to getting the maximum deduction for gifts. Below, in time for year-end tax planning, are some common charitable giving pitfalls and how to navigate around them.

title: Margaret Cho Wants to Talk About Sex Work
description: It was the tweet heard round the sex-worker world. At 6:12 p.m. on Oct. 29, Margaret Cho, the 46-year-old comedian, disturbed the Twittersphere with an economical 109 characters: Sex work is simply work. For me it was honest work. I was a sex worker when I was young. It was hard but well paid. Theres no shame in it.

title: Steve Coleman, Toward a Sound That Defies Walls
description: The saxophonist and bandleader Steve Coleman is fascinated by tradition but doesnt seem to believe that any tradition is self-contained. Starting from his early training in the Chicago and New York jazz scenes during the late 70s and early 80s, he eventually created a music that could encompass everything he learned: Charlie Parker and James Brown; rhythmic practices from Africa and India and Brazil; ancient or esoteric theories about numbers, form, symmetry and multiplicity. Hes played and taught all over the world but never led a band at the Village Vanguard. That soon changes. On the first two nights of his engagement, hell play with a new chamber-like group, Natal Eclipse: horns, bass, piano (Craig Taborn), voice (Jen Shyu) and no drums. Then hell present the standard version of his long-running band, Five Elements  a great evolving machine  and through the weekend hell add a second drummer, the great Marcus Gilmore, to that group. Dont miss it. (8:30 and 10:30 p.m., Tuesday, Nov. 10, through Sunday, Nov. 15, villagevanguard.com.)

title: Justin Trudeau Is Sworn In as Prime Minister of Canada
description: OTTAWA  Justin Trudeau, the leader of the Liberal Party, was sworn in as prime minister of Canada on Wednesday morning, ending nearly a decade of Conservative dominance.

title: Lumber Liquidators Names John M. Presley as Chief
description: The discount flooring retailer Lumber Liquidators selected a new chief executive on Wednesday as the company struggled to recover from a major safety scandal that has badly damaged its stock price and sales.

title: Terry Collins Gets a Reward, and Sandy Alderson Gets a Scare
description: The Mets held a postseason news conference Wednesday that, for the first time in years, was celebratory in nature. Manager Terry Collins wore a teal dress shirt and black slacks and a satisfied expression. Sitting next to him, General Manager Sandy Alderson announced that the Mets had agreed to give Collins a two-year contract extension, a reward for leading the team to its first pennant in 15 years.

title: A $1,000 Day in New York City for $100
description: A budget doesnt hamper our Frugal Traveler on a romp through downtown, from a beloved West Village cheese shop to the top of the citys tallest tower.

title: Honda and Takata Officials React
description: Executives gave statements regarding Honda's decision not to use Takata's technology in its vehicles after the United States fined Takata for faulty airbags.

title: Activist Investors Get a Welcome Seat at the Table
description: For decades, corporate America rejected activist investors, accusing them of being corporate raiders out to make a quick buck. But these days, some of Americas biggest companies are trying to think more like them.

title: Risking Your Neck to Run With the Unicorns
description: In the world of Wall Street, where numbers are everything, one number is especially coveted: one billion. Technology start-ups that achieve $1 billion in valuation before going public  so-called unicorns  can attract the attention of prominent venture capital firms and draw rsums from top talent across the country.

title: An Anticorruption Plea in Kenya: Please, Just Steal a Little
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  When it comes to honesty, politicians here dont usually win many awards.

title: Britain, Concerned About Russian Crash, Halts Sinai Flights
description: LONDON  The British government on Wednesday suspended flights between Britain and the Egyptian resort of Sharm el Sheikh over concerns that a chartered Russian jetliner might have been brought down in the Sinai Peninsula by a bomb on board.

title: Review: Christian Tetzlaff Sharpens Mendelssohns Edge
description: A moment arose on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall when I thought that Christian Tetzlaff was going to play the Mendelssohn Violin Concerto straight.

title: Thomas Flohrs Fortress in St. Moritz
description: With a business that caters to modern-day 007 aspirants, the VistaJet chairman Thomas Flohr has created a house to match: a seven-story chalet in the Swiss Alps.

title: One Mans Mountaintop Fortress  and Playground
description: High above the Swiss ski resort of St. Moritz, where the royal and the merely rich break for caviar and champagne between downhill runs, is Thomas Flohrs James Bond-inspired home, ChesAivla (Eagles Nest in the local language, Romansh). A seven-story, 35,000-square-foot structure built into the Suvretta mountainside, it has a cinema, library, wine cellar, spa, squash court, billiard room, bowling alley and pizzeria and is filled with important contemporary art and a stream of mostly female staff. Parked in the garage gallery is a pristine silver Aston Martin DB5 (like the one in Goldfinger, Flohr says, brightly). Part of the home office is leather-padded like Ms at the MI6 headquarters in London, and theres a midcentury rosewood and chrome desk that was used in From Russia With Love and You Only Live Twice. On the wall hangs a rusted steel map of the world with the capitals and major cities identified by tiny lights, like when you have Dr. No in those meetings and they divide the world and look at the map, he says.

title: Saying No to a Cash Buffet in Start-Up World
description: SAN FRANCISCO  To fashion cognoscenti, Everlane is perhaps best known for its almost monastically plain button-down shirts and pants, stripped of excess.

title: Deutsche Bank to Pay $258 Million and Fire 6 in Settlement
description: Deutsche Bank agreed on Wednesday to pay $258 million and fire six employees to resolve investigations by state and federal banking regulators into its dealings with countries like Iran and Syria in violation of United States sanctions laws.

title: Marco Rubio Confronts New Scrutiny Over Use of Party Credit Card
description: A decade after he began using a Republican Party credit card for personal purchases like paving stones at his home, Senator Marco Rubio on Wednesday pledged to disclose new spending records from that account as he sought to inoculate himself against what could be his biggest liability as a presidential candidate: how he manages his finances.

title: Hillary Clinton on Gun Control
description: The Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Rodham Clinton discussed gun violence during a speech in Iowa on Tuesday.

title: Modern Tintypes of the American West
description: A look at Ian Ruhters stunning landscape photographs.

title: The Executive Paycheck Myth
description: Every religion has a creation myth.

title: The Bloggess Conjures Thousands of Cringes With One Tweet
description: After a decade of blogging, writing a best-selling memoir and dispatching clever tweets, the author Jenny Lawson is skilled in the art of self-deprecating humor.

title: Details on Police Officers Suicide
description: Police officials in Lake County, Ill., said that Charles J. Gliniewiczs death was a carefully staged suicide meant to cover up the lieutenants years of stealing and laundering money.

title: France Ending Ban on Gay Blood Donors
description: Marisol Touraine, France's health minister, says the country will end a taboo and a form of discrimination as it prepares to allow gay men to donate blood.

title: Readers React to Rising Death Rates of Middle-Aged White Americans
description: A front-page report on a study that found death rates rising among white, middle-aged Americans, tapped into deep roots of angst, compassion and frustration among readers. The article shot to the top of the most-emailed list, and attracted nearly 1,900 comments.

title: Quentin Tarantino Says All Cops Are Not Murderers
description: LOS ANGELES  Quentin Tarantino has broken his silence regarding a growing police boycott of his coming film, The Hateful Eight, telling The Los Angeles Times that his public remarks about police violence had been misinterpreted.

title: Police Kill California Student After Campus Stabbing of 4
description: A student wielding a hunting knife stabbed four people at the start of a class on Wednesday on the campus of the University of California, Merced, before he was shot and killed by university police officers, law enforcement officials said.

title: Holocaust Film That Roiled Cannes Gets First DVD Release in Germany
description: Night and Fog, a 1955 Holocaust documentary that caused an uproar at the Cannes Film Festival in 1956, has been released for the first time on DVD in Germany.

title: As Doors Close, Syrian Refugees Despair
description: Propelled by fear and desperation, Syrian refugees have faced one hurdle after another.

title: Yellen Speaks to Legislators
description: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, told the House Financial Services Committee that the economy was performing well and suggested that the Fed could raise interest rates.

title: Making a Picky Eater Project Last a Lifetime
description: Six weeks ago we started the Picky Eater Project, introducing a few key ideas we thought could change the eating preferences of Brooke, a sixth grader, and Hunter, a third grader, whose meal requirements (along with their parents Marlo and Coreys willingness to cater to them) were taking over the family dinner hour.

title: When a Photographer Is His Own Camera
description: For the photographer Ian Ruhter, whose first New York show opens tomorrow at Danziger Gallery, success has come from climbing into his work. The game-changing moment came when I realized I could be the camera. I could be the mechanics of it, Ruhter says. From inside the lens of a delivery truck converted into a camera, Ruhter becomes the machines very manual settings: the shutter and the processor, and also the film, which he makes from scratch on sheets of aluminum up to five feet wide. (Light-sensitive collodion plates, once wet, need to be exposed and developed in a matter of minutes, but the whole set-up takes about a day for a single image.) It takes so much time, he says, of choosing not to jump out of a car and take a selfie at a lookout. It really makes me sit there and be part of the environment, and suck it up and enjoy.

title: One Downside of an Up Economy: Employee Turnover
description: Most employees  no matter how many years they have been with a company or how much talent and hard work they bring to the table  feel disposable. And most employers do little to discourage that feeling.

title: Graying Firms Wrestle With Making Room for Younger Lawyers
description: Even the law firms nimble enough to overcome the economic turbulence in recent years are not feeling invincible these days. The revenue looks good because costly litigation and specialized legal work are flourishing. But a generational divide is percolating just under the surface.

title: Ted Cruz Has a Chance to Win. Heres the Path.
description: When Ted Cruz announced his run for the presidency, the big question was whether he had only a small chance to win or no chance at all. Since then, a lot has gone right for him.

title: Sylvie Guillem Prepares to End Her Ballet Career
description: MILAN  I am not nice, the ballerina Sylvie Guillem said. Seated in her dressing room in the Teatro Arcimboldi here, Ms. Guillem burst out laughing. That has gotten me into a lot of trouble.

title: Performa 15 Kicks Off With Katy Perry, Miuccia Prada and Others
description: Performance art is sometimes associated with malnourished artists suffering inside a sterile white gallery.

title: Plant Collapse Kills at Least 16 People in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least 16 people were killed and dozens wounded when a factory undergoing expansion collapsed into rubble Wednesday evening in an industrial park in eastern Pakistan, rescue workers and government officials said.

title: Shareholders Vote With Their Dollars to Have Less of a Say
description: In todays world of public companies, there are the haves and have-nots of corporate governance. How long can this last?
