description: LOS ANGELES  When Quentin Tarantinos The Hateful Eight is released in a special roadshow version (with overture, intermission and additional footage) on Dec. 25, it will represent a feat worthy of the heist in the directors Jackie Brown.

title: Model Ruth Bells Star-Is-Born Tale Comes With a Set of Clippers
description: Ruth Bell, 19, of Deal, England, wears her hair clipped close to her skull and bleached the color of creamed butter. Seen from behind, it gives her the aspect of a baby chick; from the front, coupled with her soft seaside accent, of a holdover from the Victorian era, a fever patient bravely accepting her cropping cure.

title: Serbia to Give $5.4 Million to Bosnian Town, Site of 1995 Massacre
description: LONDON  Serbias prime minister said Wednesday that his country was donating about $5.4 million to foster economic development in the Bosnian town of Srebrenica, where about 8,000 Muslim men and boys were massacred by Bosnian Serb forces in 1995.

title: Yankees Acquire Twins Aaron Hicks in Quest for Younger Lineup
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  When the Yankees were in Minnesota in late July, Twins center fielder Aaron Hicks ranged far into the spacious gaps to run down deep drives by Jacoby Ellsbury and Brian McCann. The next night, he belted a long home run off C. C. Sabathia in the first inning.

title: At Doc NYC, Womens (Film) Work
description: Thom Powers, the artistic director of Doc NYC, the largest festival of documentary films in the country, said he didnt realize what he had done until after this years lineup of 104 features was released. Someone else had to point out to him that his opening night, closing night and centerpiece selections were all directed or co-directed by women.

title: IAC/InterActiveCorp Offers to Buy Angies List
description: The Internet conglomerate IAC/InterActiveCorp offered on Wednesday to buy Angies List, the repository of online reviews for home repairs and other services, for about $512 million, taking its offer public after being rebuffed.

title: Review: Book of Hanging Gardens, Sung by Christian Gerhaher
description: Schoenbergs The Book of Hanging Gardens is an atonal song cycle based on poems by Stefan George that obsessively dissect a love affair in 15 feverish, labile verses. The German baritone Christian Gerhaher, who gave a vulnerable and intense performance of the work in the Park Avenue Armorys Board of Officers Room on Tuesday, has said that the cycle is like Christmas, 15 times over. In a book of conversations published in Germany earlier this year, Mr. Gerhaher notes how Schoenberg creates an entirely new set of colors for every emotional nuance, likening each stanza to a gift to the listener.

title: Review: On Free TC, Ty Dolla Sign Delivers Off-the-Cuff R&B
description: Free TC

title: Review: Aria, by Sullivan Fortner, Full of Assurance
description: Aria

title: Glenn OBrien Reinvents Himself (Yet Again)
description: It wasnt supposed to end this way. Glenn OBrien, GQ magazines Style Guy columnist, bolted in a huff in May after 16 years.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Review: Madam Phungs Last Journey Follows a Gender-Bending Troupe
description: The subject of Madam Phungs Last Journey describes herself and the carnival family in orbit around her as neither male nor female but half and half  citizens who have no place within the strictures of Vietnams official society and few opportunities for legitimate employment.

title: Mexicos Governing Party Vows to Stop Using Neuromarketing to Study Voters
description: MEXICO CITY  The leader of Mexicos governing party has said it will stop hiring neuroscience consultants to register voters brain waves and read their facial expressions, responding to a political outcry over its use of the tools of neuromarketing to shape its campaign and governing messages.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Africa, the West Bank and Elsewhere
description: The West Bank and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

title: Nov. 11, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from the West Bank, South Africa, Syria and the United States.

title: Review: Rock in the Red Zone Goes Beyond Music in a War-Torn Israeli Town
description: Long before the director inserts scenes from her own wedding video into Rock in the Red Zone, its apparent that shes grown quite close to her subject. A lack of critical distance isnt always fatal to a documentary. But here, that segment is just one more piece in an often scattershot project.

title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing: University of Missouri, Republican Debate, Israel
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: The G.O.P. Tax Debate: Low or Lower; Flat or Flatter?
description: At Tuesdays Republican debate, candidates discussed two main questions about taxes: Should they be lower than they are now, or should they be way lower? And should there be fewer tax rates, or just one single rate for everyone, rich and poor?

title: Young Caribbean Team Braces for Daunting Task in World Cup Qualifier
description: If Jurgen Klinsmann, the German coach of the United States national mens soccer team, thinks he is at his lowest ebb, Cornelius Huggins can offer him a startling reality check.

title: Nephews of Venezuelas First Lady Face Drug Charges
description: Two nephews of the wife of President Nicols Maduro of Venezuela were arrested this week in Haiti and flown to the United States where they will face drug trafficking charges, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

title: More Young Women Waiting to Leave Home
description: The share of young women living at home with their parents or other relatives has reached its highest level since the statistics were first gathered, according to an analysis of Census Bureau data.

title: Review: Chamber Music Society, Bilingual in Channel Crossing
description: Channel Crossing, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center called its program at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening, and the societys artistic directors, David Finckel and Wu Han, supplied information about the English Channel in an introductory note. At its narrowest, the channel is some 20 miles wide, they wrote; for the hardiest, its a seven-hour swim.

title: 106 Indictments Handed Down in Waco Twin Peaks Biker Shootout
description: AUSTIN  A biker shootout in Waco, Tex., that left nine people dead and nearly 20 wounded in May has resulted in 106 felony indictments, and Central Texas prosecutors say more indictments are likely in the protracted investigation.

title: Mizzou, Yale and Free Speech
description: On university campuses across the country, from Mizzou to Yale, we have two noble forces colliding with explosive force.

title: A Flurry of Holiday Pop-Up Stores and Other Shopping Events
description: On Thursday, the Dannijo designers Danielle and Jodie Snyder will open a holiday pop-up theyre calling Conversation Pieces near their showroom. There youll find jewelry designs like an oxidized silver-plate bib necklace with Swarovski crystals ($520) along with lingerie by Morgan Lane and vintage clothing from A Current Affair. At 68 Gansevoort Street.

title: Bob Dole Endorses Jeb Bush, and Knocks Ted Cruz
description: Former Senator Bob Dole of Kansas endorsed Jeb Bush for president on Wednesday, saying he believed that the former Florida governor was the best qualified candidate  and also making clear that he still held a grudge against Senator Ted Cruz of Texas.

title: T-Mobile Video Plan Could Test F.C.C.s New Net Neutrality Rules
description: A new plan from T-Mobile USA to allow unlimited streaming of some video services may become the first test of the federal governments rules to prevent favoritism on the Internet.

title: Republican Voters Slowly Begin to Rally Around Candidates
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa  At a Marco Rubio rally the day after the Republicans fourth debate, Scott Bell pressed through a crowd to deliver a direct message to the Florida senator. Im all in, he told Mr. Rubio.

title: Review: The Violinist Leila Josefowicz at Carnegie Hall
description: From child prodigy to go-to star for major commissions, the reinvention of the violinist Leila Josefowicz, just 38, is complete. Glance at her menu for the season and see a feast of new music: a garnish of Sibelius topping the meat of concertos by Thomas Ads, John Adams, Oliver Knussen and Sean Shepherd.

title: Review: Kyle Abraham, Sleekly Protesting Racial Injustice
description: Race and music are potent tools for Kyle Abraham, a Pittsburgh-born choreographer and dancer who grew up enmeshed in hip-hop culture. In his newest work, Absent Matter, Mr. Abraham takes inspiration from jazz and hip-hop to focus on racial injustice. Its a timely  and, for a dance, a huge  subject. Yet despite his status as a 2013 MacArthur Fellow, Mr. Abraham is not fully formed enough as a choreographer to tackle it.

title: Friends or Friendly? Sheldon Silvers Trial Focuses on Ties to Doctor
description: Their relationship seemed to pass the tests of friendship. Sheldon Silver and Dr. Robert N. Taub had mutual friends; their families had met, and even stayed at the same hotel during Passover celebrations.

title: No Easy Answers in Murder Charge Against 8-Year-Old
description: ATLANTA  With its unadorned language and matter-of-fact tone, the announcement on Tuesday by the authorities in Birmingham, Ala., at first read like nearly any other law enforcement statement about a homicide investigation.

title: Home Health Aide Becomes a Guardian and, He Hopes, a Father
description: As Marco Muoz speaks, recalling the past few years of his life, Jose Hernandez slips one of his shoes onto Mr. Muozs hand. It is an odd yet effective gesture that signals to Mr. Muoz that Jose wants to go for a walk.

title: Apple Plans Peer-to-Peer Payment Service
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple is working on a person-to-person payments service that may give iPhone owners another reason to use their Apple Wallets.

title: Racial Discrimination Protests Ignite at Colleges Across the U.S.
description: The passion that ousted the heads of the University of Missouri after protests over racial discrimination on campus is spreading to other colleges across the country, turning traditional fall semesters into a period of intense focus on racial misunderstanding and whether activism stifles free speech.

title: FanDuel and DraftKings Prepare for Court Fight in New York
description: The two largest daily fantasy sports operators acknowledged Wednesday that New York State was vital to the future of their businesses and said they would pursue all legal options to remain in operation there despite a demand by the state attorney general that they stop allowing residents to play because their games constituted illegal gambling under state law.

title: Andr Glucksmann, French Philosopher Who Renounced Marxism, Dies at 78
description: Andr Glucksmann, one of the most prominent of the French New Philosophers, a group of former radicals who broke with Marxism in the 1970s and became an intellectual counterweight to Frances political left, died on Tuesday in Paris. He was 78.

title: Review: Andrea Burns at Feinsteins/54 Below
description: Andrea Burns, who plays Gloria Estefans mother in the musical On Your Feet!, knows who she is: a Latina fish out of water who grew up in Miami, obsessed with Broadway. Ebullient and playful, Ms. Burns, 44, brought a breath of tropical air to Feinsteins/54 Below on Monday evening. She compared her parents 46-year relationship to a union between Jerry Seinfeld and Sofia Vergara. The person onstage had a little of both. I happen to be part Jewish, she added. I have the guilt.

title: Betsy Drake, 92, Actress Who Starred With (and Wed) Cary Grant, Dies
description: Betsy Drake, a film actress who starred alongside Cary Grant after bumping into him on the Queen Mary, eloping with him and remaining married to him longer than any of his other wives, died on Oct. 27 at her home in London. She was 92.

title: G.O.P. Fight Now a Battle Over What Defines a Conservative
description: MILWAUKEE  For months, the Republican presidential race has been animated by the partys inchoate anger about the state of the country and an equally undefined hope that a candidate would emerge who could usher in an era of civic renewal. But the debate here and its aftermath marked an abrupt transition from vague promises about making America great again, in Donald J. Trumps phrase, to a new season of the campaign shaped more by the glaring policy fissures that are dividing Republicans over what exactly to do about the nations problems.

title: Corporation to Oversee New Hudson Rail Tunnel, With U.S. and Amtrak Financing Half
description: Federal and state officials announced an agreement on Wednesday to create a corporation within the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to oversee long-awaited plans to build a new rail tunnel under the Hudson River.

title: Israeli Opposition Leader Withholds Judgment on Netanyahus U.S. Visit
description: Isaac Herzog, head of the political opposition in Israel, reserved judgment on Wednesday about Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus visit this week to Washington, saying the outcome was unclear despite what appeared to be an improved atmosphere created by the trip.

title: Labour Leader Jeremy Corbyn Pledges Loyalty to Queen, if Not to Tradition
description: LONDON  A lifelong republican and veteran leftist, Jeremy Corbyn, the new leader of Britains opposition Labour Party, caused consternation among traditionalists in September when he failed to sing the national anthem, God Save the Queen, at a ceremony to commemorate World War II.

title: Veteran Italian Diplomat at U.N. to Get Top Refugee Post
description: UNITED NATIONS  A veteran United Nations official who earned his diplomatic credibility in the Israeli-Palestinian crisis will take over the United Nations refugee agency amid the worlds worst migrant crisis in decades.

title: Shock and Few Leads After Murder of Lois Colley, Society Matriarch
description: NORTH SALEM, N.Y.  This pastoral playground in the northeast corner of Westchester County, laced with horse paddocks and stone walls, has long been a draw for the wealthy and well-connected. Among those who call it home are David Letterman, the composer Alan Menken and the financier Steven Rattner. Michael R. Bloomberg, who has many homes, also owns an estate here.

title: Facing Rex Ryans Bills, Foundation of Jets Defense Is Sagging
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  Once, there was a house.

title: A Bit of Housekeeping Removes a Confederate Flag in a U.S. Capitol Building
description: WASHINGTON  The guardians of the United States Capitol, with the serendipitous convenience of a modest renovation underway in the Rayburn House Office Building, have quietly removed the Mississippi state flag with its Confederate battle insignia from a well-traveled hallway.

title: Joes Crab Shack to Test No-Tipping Policy
description: Following in the footsteps of the Danny Meyer restaurant group, Joes Crab Shack, a Houston-based chain with more than 130 locations nationwide, announced on Wednesday that it would test a no-tipping system in one of the largest trials yet of the policy.

title: Giants Pass Rush Has High Hopes for Matchup With Tom Brady
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Cullen Jenkins is a 12-year N.F.L. veteran, an anchor on the Giants defensive line, and lavish praise for opposing quarterbacks does not often pass through his teeth four days before a big game.

title: Greensboro Puts Focus on Reducing Racial Bias
description: The police chief in Greensboro, N.C., has ordered his officers to stop pulling over motorists for minor infractions involving vehicle flaws like broken taillights, an action he called a first step toward eliminating alarming racial disparities in traffic stops.

title: Jacqueline Berrien, Head of E.E.O.C., Is Dead at 53
description: Jacqueline Berrien, a civil rights lawyer who was President Obamas chairwoman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, died on Monday in Baltimore. She was 53.

title: Scott Gomez Brings His Playoff Experience to the Blues
description: Scott Gomez was the first St. Louis Blues player to step on the ice at Madison Square Garden for practice Wednesday.

title: Carol Doda, Pioneer of Topless Entertainment, Dies at 78
description: Carol Doda, who was widely credited with triggering a nationwide topless revolution as a 26-year-old go-go dancer in 1964, died on Monday in San Francisco. She was 78.

title: Richard Horowitz, Timpanist and Craftsman of Conductors Batons, Dies at 91
description: In a Queens boiler room, armed with little more than a champagne cork and a length of wood, Richard Horowitz helped bring to life some of the foremost symphonic music in the world.

title: Review: Shear Madness, Where Getting a Haircut Is Murder
description: Only $30 for a womans haircut at a Manhattan salon? Thats what they charge at Shear Madness, a wacky little shop thats just opened on West 50th Street, though it looks as if it had been there forever. The walls are baby blue, the floor is linoleum, and isnt that a ficus tree in the corner, over near the exposed brick?

title: M.L.B. Considers Adjusting Rules on Slides and Replays
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Whether the slide that wiped out Mets shortstop Ruben Tejadas season will be outlawed when he returns next season remains uncertain.

title: Review: Henry IV, Donmar Warehouses All-Female Version
description: Leave it to an army of sharp-witted women to point out just how much Shakespeares Henry IV plays are  how shall we put this?  manhood-measuring contests. As embodied by a rousing all-female cast in this seriously entertaining Donmar Warehouse production, which opened on Wednesday night at St. Anns Warehouse in Brooklyn, Shakespeares soldiers, nobles and carousers seem to be forever engaged in vociferous argument as to who has the bigger .

title: Between Here and the Sun
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  This puzzle is a totally adorable salute to a very cute animal and I nearly failed miserably at it.

title: Square Sticks to the Script as It Prepares for Its I.P.O.
description: The hundreds of investors who attended Squares initial public offering marketing lunch on Wednesday could have asked management the tough questions.

title: Why Germans Loved Helmut Schmidt
description: Hamburg, Germany  HELMUT SCHMIDT, the former German chancellor and renowned postwar statesman who died Tuesday at 96, would have hated to read the adulatory obituaries that have poured forth over the last 24 hours. Henry A. Kissinger, one of his closest friends, once said he hoped Mr. Schmidt would survive him, because a world without him would be very empty.

title: Repeat Train Thief Steals Bus at Port Authority, Police Say
description: Darius McCollum, known for his obsession with buses and trains and his proclivity for taking them for joy rides, has been no stranger to law enforcement in New York City.

title: Researchers Say There May Be Undiscovered Tomb at Great Pyramid of Giza
description: Researchers in Egypt using advanced scanning techniques to study the Pyramids said this week that they had detected thermal anomalies within the Great Pyramid of Giza that could indicate the presence of an undiscovered tomb.

title: Northern Ireland: Ex-Soldier Is Released on Bail in Bloody Sunday Investigation
description: A former British soldier who was arrested Tuesday in connection with the 1972 Bloody Sunday massacre of unarmed civilians in Londonderry has been released on bail, the Police Service of Northern Ireland announced Wednesday. The former soldier, 66, has not been charged. A 2010 inquiry found that the British government was responsible for the massacre, and it prompted the police to open a criminal investigation. This was the first arrest in the case.

title: Knicks Are Finally Healthy, Besides Heartbreak at Buzzer
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Nine games into his N.B.A. career, with four double-doubles to his credit and greats like Magic Johnson already hinting at future greatness to come, the 7-foot wonder Kristaps Porzingis is the subject of good-natured ribbing by his Knicks teammates.

title: Senate Approves Research Into Combat Effects on Mental Health
description: Research into veterans suicide received a lift on Tuesday with Senate passage of a measure requiring an independent research program on the effects of combat service on suicide rates and other mental health issues among troops and veterans. A report by The New York Times in September found that monitoring of suicide was not coordinated between the Department of Veterans Affairs and Department of Defense, and many veterans fell through the cracks because the effect of combat exposure was poorly tracked.  After more than decade of war, neither department has the data to show whether troops exposed to combat have a higher risk of suicide, and how that risk changes over time. Because of this, veterans say suicide prevention programs do not fit their needs. We simply dont know enough about the effects of combat on mental health issues among service members and veterans both during and after service, said the amendments sponsor, Senator Michael Bennet of Colorado. The measure passed as part of the Military Construction and Veterans Affairs and Related Agencies Appropriations Act for fiscal year 2016.

title: In India, Many Voters May See Corruption as the Lesser Evil
description: NEW DELHI  What do Indians despise more: communal conflict or corruption?

title: Kurds, Backed by U.S. Air Power, Try to Regain Sinjar From ISIS
description: MOUNT SINJAR, Iraq  Kurdish forces aided by thousands of lightly armed Yazidi fighters began a long-awaited offensive early Thursday to reclaim Mount Sinjar and an accompanying town from the Islamic State, which seized the northern Iraqi territory last year and murdered, raped and enslaved thousands of Yazidis.

title: Hawaii Confronts Dengue Outbreak as 33 Are Infected
description: Health officials in Hawaii have confirmed at least 33 cases of dengue fever, a mosquito-borne tropical illness not usually found there, and warned that the entire Big Island is at risk for its spread.

title: Why Cutting a Crucial ISIS Route May Not Stop Flow of Fighters and Supplies
description: The ease of creating roads through the desert could limit the effectiveness of the offensive to cut off a key ISIS supply route.

title: Obesity Rises Despite All Efforts to Fight It, U.S. Health Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  Despite years of efforts to reduce obesity in America, including a major push by Michelle Obama, federal health officials reported Thursday that the share of Americans who were obese had not declined in recent years, and had edged up slightly.

title: Macys Sounds a Holiday Alarm, and Retailers Brace for Heavy Discounting
description: When Macys, a store closely associated with Christmas, says there is trouble brewing ahead of the holidays, it is enough to send the world of shopping into a tailspin.

title: Sale Offers a Reason for Relief at Sothebys
description: If art buyers were feeling a bit of auction fatigue going into Sothebys contemporary art evening sale on Wednesday  the sixth auction in seven days  they did not show it in their bidding for several major works.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | recumbent
description: recumbent  \ri-km-bnt\  adjective

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It can be exhausting feeling like youre speaking for your entire race.

title: 2 Arrested in Laser Strike on Helicopter
description: If he planned to avoid detection, a man who the authorities said wielded a laser that was pointed at a helicopter flying over Brooklyn on Wednesday night picked the wrong target.

title: What to Watch Thursday
description: As we slide toward the weekend, how about a little escapism  with a Shonda Rhimes night, pixie fashionistas or music from Hozier, Miguel or Sia? You choose.

title: Public Housing Nationwide May Be Subject to Smoking Ban
description: Smoking would be prohibited in public housing homes nationwide under a proposed federal rule announced on Thursday, a move that would affect nearly one million households and open the latest front in the long-running campaign to curb unwanted exposure to secondhand tobacco smoke.

description: FRONT PAGE

title: Organ Transplants Suffer Amid Chinas Transportation Delays

title: The Best of British at the Salon QP Watch Fair in London
description: The only fine watchmaking fair in London opens Nov. 12 at the Saatchi Gallery in Chelsea.

title: Mormons and Gay Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Refugee Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: Sparks From the Republican Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: G.O.P. Debate Doldrums
description: The bloom is coming off the rose for the Republican presidential debates.

title: A Lost Generation of Democrats
description: As Republicans never tire of pointing out, the Democratic candidates for president are old.

title: The Stealth Attack on Abortion Access
description: A YEAR ago, a mother and self-described God-fearing woman called me after she had an abortion. She said that earlier, when she found herself unexpectedly pregnant, she drove straight to what she thought was a comprehensive health care provider near her home in Columbus, Ohio. When she asked about abortion, the staff told her she shouldnt murder her child. Ohio requires an ultrasound before an abortion, so the woman listened to the staffs condemnations, taking them to heart, crying. She told me later, I didnt know where else to go.

title: Death Penalty and the Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Wow, More Terrifying Than Trump
description: Perhaps you didnt watch the Republican presidential debate this week. That in no way excuses you from having an opinion about it. Its the last one until December, and all youll have to work with if you want political conversation at Thanksgiving dinner.

title: Who Is Entitled to Be Heard?
description: SOME of the most potent threats to free speech these days come not from our government or corporations, but from our citizenry. Pitched battles being waged at Yale and the University of Missouri pit speech versus speech in a contest of who and what is entitled to be heard. These are only the latest examples: In recent years speakers have been disinvited, campus events disrupted and activists threatened for speaking their minds.

title: Judicial Energy and the Supreme Court
description: Terry Eastland, a Reagan-era conservative activist who now edits The Weekly Standard, wrote a book back in 1992 that he called Energy in the Executive: The Case for the Strong Presidency. He took to task both President Ronald Reagan, for whom he had worked in the Justice Department, and the first President Bush for having failed to use all possible levers of presidential power to advance the conservative agenda.

title: An Antidote to Cynicism in Canada
description: It has become common to bemoan the sorry state of politics, what with all the big money, dirty tricks, image molding, partisan gridlock and general cynicism. Yet voters seem never to cease longing for a leader who can restore pride to high office and rekindle the national spirit.

title: The Trouble With Fantasy Sports Gambling
description: The millions who play and lose on daily fantasy sports websites are engaged in gambling, plain and simple. Now, state and federal officials are finally starting to clamp down on this fast-growing online business.

title: Men Do More at Home, but Not as Much as They Think
description: Men today are much more committed to equality at home, sharing dinner-cooking and diaper-changing duties, than in previous generations. But even in families in which both parents work outside the home, the division of labor at home remains unequal.

title: On New Albums, Justin Bieber and One Direction Are Joyless Boys
description: You have not truly heard the trauma that a lifetime in the spotlight can cause until you hear Justin Bieber sing, What about the children?/Look at all the children we can change.

title: Leaked Emirati Emails Could Threaten Peace Talks in Libya
description: CAIRO  The United Arab Emirates was shipping weapons to favored belligerents in Libya over the summer in violation of an international arms embargo while simultaneously offering a highly paid job to the United Nations diplomat drafting a peace accord there, leaked Emirati emails show.

title: Uber Signs Digital Mapping Deal With TomTom
description: Uber, the ride-hailing service, agreed on Thursday to use digital maps provided by the Dutch technology company TomTom in its smartphone applications.

title: South Koreas Top Court Upholds Life Term for Captain in Ferry Sinking
description: SEOUL, South Korea  The Supreme Court of South Korea on Thursday upheld the life sentence of the captain of a ferry that capsized in 2014, killing more than 300 people, most of them teenagers trapped inside the ship as the crew fled.

title: News Qs | Saying Goodbye a Little Longer as Seattle Scrapes Off Its Gum Wall
description: Before Reading Saying Goodbye a Little Longer as Seattle Scrapes Off Its Gum Wall :

title: 1915: The World War I Diet
description: During World War I, the European edition of The New York Herald kept an eye on the state of food rations, from essential goods to the more upmarket items. Below are a few examples from 1915:

title: The East Village Scene for Two Theater Students
description: As students at New York University studying musical theater, Roberto Morean and Kelly Plescia have been best friends since they met in class freshman year.

title: Times Insider: Reporting Europe's Refugee Crisis
description: New York Times correspondents covering the migrant crisis in Europe share their experiences reporting on the forces irrevocably changing the Continent.

title: How Big of a Problem Is Sexting?
description: Recently a Colorado high school made national headlines after officials discovered that at least 100 students traded naked pictures of themselves. The revelation left parents outraged, administrators searching for missed clues, and the police and the district attorneys office debating how to handle the complex situation.

title: Indias Rising Tides and Temperatures
description: Jordi Pizarro had hardly reached the muddy banks of Ghoramara Island when he stumbled across a family struggling to hold up the dikes that protected their rice paddy from the Bay of Bengals brackish waters.

title: FIFA Ethics Review Clears 5 Candidates to Succeed Sepp Blatter
description: ZURICH  Five of the seven men hoping to succeed Sepp Blatter as president of FIFA, the governing body of world soccer, have passed an internal ethics review and have been formally cleared to run in a February election, the groups electoral committee announced on Thursday.

title: The House that Julia Built
description: La Pitchoune, the French cottage that Julia Child and her husband, Paul, spent time in while living in Provence.

description: Question:

title: Online Matchmaking, but With Dogs as Dates
description: I want a dog, but my landlady is a cat person.

title: David Vitters Race for Governor Could Bring the Senate Together
description: After a rough and highly personal debate in the Louisiana governors race on Tuesday night, all eyes in the Senate are on David Vitter, the Louisiana Republican who is in a pitched battle to win the governors mansion back home. Oddly enough, both Senate Republicans and Democrats have ample reason to want Mr. Vitter to win.

title: New York Today: Port of Entry
description: Updated 11:55 a.m.

title: Europe Nears Accord With Turkey to Stem Tide of Refugees
description: VALLETTA, Malta  The European Union appeared a step closer on Thursday to a deal with Turkey that would represent its most ambitious attempt yet in trying to regulate the flow of migrants to the Continent.

title: Morning Agenda: Square Sticks to Its Script
description: SQUARE STICKS TO ITS SCRIPT | The payments start-up isnt facing tough questions at the more public events in its initial public offering roadshow, but it is staying on message even in more intimate meetings, Leslie Picker reports in DealBook.

title: Malcolm Turnbull of Australia and Joko Widodo of Indonesia Seek to Mend Ties
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The new Australian prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, made a half-day visit to Indonesia on Thursday to hold talks with President Joko Widodo, a meeting intended to help mend diplomatic relations that plummeted this year over issues including human smuggling, refugee boats and the executions of Australian drug offenders.

title: Kurds Retake Strategic Highway in Iraqs North From ISIS
description: MOUNT SINJAR, Iraq  Sweeping down in hodgepodge convoys of trucks and buses, Kurdish forces and Yazidi fighters opened their offensive against Islamic State militants in northern Iraq on Thursday with a burst of initial success: The forces cut off the main highway the jihadists used as a supply line, and they moved in to begin fighting for the town of Sinjar.

title: Jeb Bush Offers a Chest Bump for Every Convert
description: WAUKEE, Iowa  After his final event of a busy Wednesday, Jeb Bush posed for selfies, shook hands with voters and  wait, was that just a chest bump?

title: Turkey Haunted by Its Ghosts
description: DIYARBAKIR, Turkey  We dont want Turkey to become Syria or Diyarbakir to become Aleppo.

title: Your Thursday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: On Minimum Wage, Ben Carson Is No Longer an Outsider Among Republicans
description: Among the many issues dividing the Republican and Democratic presidential candidates, few are as clear-cut as the minimum wage. While the Democrats support raising it, the Republican field has been overwhelmingly opposed, citing concerns about possible job losses.

title: Scottish Nurse Pauline Cafferkey Recovers From Ebola for 2nd Time
description: LONDON  A Scottish nurse who became critically ill last month  10 months after recovering from Ebola  has again recovered.

title: Shares of French Asset Manager Amundi Rise in Debut After I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Shares of Amundi, one of the largest asset managers in Europe, rose by about 4 percent in their debut on the Euronext stock exchange in Paris on Thursday after its initial public offering.

title: Greek Strike Shows Conflict Within Government Over Austerity
description: ATHENS  Hundreds of thousands of Greeks walked off their jobs on Thursday to protest austerity economics as officials of the leftist-led government wrangled with the countrys international creditors over the terms of Greeces third bailout. At least one Athens protest turned violent.

title: David Brat Thinks Congress Is Plenty Smart
description: What kind of speaker of the House do you think Paul Ryan will be? Im looking forward to working hand in hand with him to solve the biggest issues that our country faces.

title: Poll Shows Hillary Clinton Maintaining Lead Over Bernie Sanders
description: Despite a month of sharpened attacks, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has failed to significantly dent Hillary Rodham Clintons lead in the Democratic presidential race, according to a New York Times/CBS News survey released on Thursday.

title: Retracing a Mothers Path of Escape Along a Wintry Merrimack
description: A thick curtain of snow fell over the Merrimack River, obscuring the far bank. While my friend Chris Pierce and I searched for a place to launch our canoe, the flurries drifted away. Paddling carefully on the swollen expanse of the Merrimack, we passed a small island fringed with ice, and thus entered a forgotten chapter in American history.

title: Choose Your Own Adventure: A Conversation With Jennifer Egan and George Saunders
description: Jennifer Egan: I want to start by talking about how we define writing about the future. Some things that I think of as futuristic, when Ive looked at them again for this conversation, Im not sure they really are. So I guess my question would be: What leads you into territory that feels futuristic? How do you end up there? And what makes it the future?

title: Letter of Recommendation:The Death in   Books
description: This summer, two female bears, each with a set of twin cubs, took up residence along a tree-lined trail in Denver. Hikers in the park had proved themselves prone to snapping selfies with bears, sometimes by creeping within 10 feet of them, so in response, the city pre-emptively shut down the trail. This story circulated online as evidence of human stupiditys direct correlation with modern technologys advancement, but I thought that was unfair. People have been making mistakes in nature for a long, long time.

title: Review: In Angelina Jolie Pitts By the Sea, an Unhappy Mnage and Tear-Streaked Mascara
description: Meta with a vengeance, By the Sea stars Angelina Jolie Pitt and Brad Pitt as itinerant married artists who are suffering, beautifully, through a rough patch. Any resemblance to real life is strictly coincidental and completely intentional. At first luxurious blush its a jet-setting marital melodrama, one of those he-said, she-said (and wept) encounter sessions decked with designer shades, to-die-for digs and millionaire tears. More interestingly, the movie, which Ms. Jolie Pitt wrote and directed, is a knowing or at least a ticklishly amusing demonstration of celebrity and its relay of gazes from one of the most looked-at women in the world. Take, watch, she seems to say, this is my body.

title: Nancy Pelosi Made Rare Visit to Tibet, China Says
description: BEIJING  Nancy Pelosi, the Democratic leader of the House of Representatives, visited Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, this week and met with the Communist Party chief of the region, according to a Foreign Ministry spokesman and a report published on Thursday by the official Tibet Daily.

title: Paul Theroux: By the Book
description: The author, most recently, of Deep South says if someone must write his biography, I would suggest Hieronymus Karl Friedrich, Freiherr von Mnchhausen, a.k.a. Baron Munchhausen.

title: As Print Fades, Part 4: Native Advertising on The Rise
description: This is the fourth post in an occasional series looking at The Timess efforts to survive and thrive in the digital age.

title: Rights Lawyers in China Routinely Face Abuse, Report Says
description: BEIJING  Legal activists and those suspected of crimes in China are routinely abused and mistreated at the hands of law enforcement officials, a report released on Thursday by Amnesty International found, despite recent efforts by the government to crack down on inhumane judicial practices.

title: Looking for Carries Apartment
description: Dear Diary:

title: 1915: Winston Churchill Resigns
description: LONDON  Mr. Winston Churchill, the Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, who was First Lord of the Admiralty until the formation of the Coalition Ministry, has resigned office and will rejoin his regiment in France. Mr. Churchill, in tendering his resignation, said that his chief reason for resigning was that Mr. Asquith, who had promised six weeks ago to make him a member of the new War Council, had not seen his way to do so. Mr. Churchill, therefore, declined to remain any longer in well-paid inactivity.  The New York Herald, European Edition, November 13, 1915

title: A Mothers Hoarding, a Daughters Art
description: When a bicycle accident left her mother with severe brain damage, Stephanie Calvert began to reexamine what had been a difficult relationship. Her mother had been a hoarder  when the family moved to an isolated schoolhouse in Thatcher, Colo., she filled it with clothes, papers and other objects. Ms. Calvert was deeply embarrassed by her mothers habit  she became depressed and wanted to leave as soon as I could and move far away.

title: Coordinated European Raids Target Ring Supporting Terrorist Groups
description: ROME  The authorities arrested 15 people in four European countries on Thursday, breaking up what officials called a terrorist network that sought to overthrow the Kurdish government in northern Iraq and to recruit militants to fight in Iraq and Syria.

title: Adele Cries to Her Music, Too
description: LONDON  Im not going to cry, Adele said. She was practicing with her band at Music Bank rehearsal studios, an unglamorous warehouse space in South London, and had just finished When We Were Young, one of the torchiest ballads on her new album, 25. Its a song about running into an old flame that confesses, I still care and then, tentatively, asks, Do you still care?

title: Deutsche Bank Names Management Team for New Investment Division
description: LONDON  Deutsche Bank on Thursday named the management team for its new corporate and investment banking division. The move is part of an overhaul by John Cryan, the banks new co-chief executive, to simplify the structure of the lender and improve its returns.

title: In Run-Up to Olympics, Rios Property Market Already Looks Hung Over
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Home buyers in Rio de Janeiro used to get into intense bidding wars as they tried to secure even a modest apartment in one of the citys exclusive beachfront districts. Not anymore.

title: Daily Report: Imagining the Road Ahead
description: If predictions about the future are true, many of us will soon be riding around in self-driving cars. But a crucial part of making that prediction a reality is making sure that the car can see  or sense  the world around it.

title: 1965: Russians Send Probe to Venus
description: MOSCOW  The Soviet Union took another stab at inter-planetary space exploration today [Nov. 12]  a field in which it has been unsuccessful for four years  with the launching of what is called the Venus-2 spaceship to the earths cloud- covered sister planet. The 2,123-pound craft got off to a good start on its three- and-a-half-month flight to Venus, and then Tass, the government news agency, announced that it had been launched. Venus-1 was launched on Feb. 12, 1961, but its radios went dead about two weeks later. After that first failure, Soviet space engineers failed on at least four more occasions, according to American sources, to send rockets toward Venus. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 13, 1965

title: In Victoria, British Columbia, Where to Go on Trounce Alley
description: Trounce Alley, a tiny Euro-chic pedestrian passage connecting two busy downtown thoroughfares, has emerged as a diverse micro hub.

title: How #BlackOnCampus Convened a Twitter Debate on Race
description: The uproar that began over on-campus race relations at the University of Missouri and quickly spread to other campuses has found a new home on social media.

title: Review: Stacy Schiffs The Witches, a Reign of Terror in 17th-Century Salem
description: The feverish Salem witch hunts of 1692 have become a metaphor not just for anti-Communist mania in the 1950s but for the larger strain of what the historian Richard Hofstadter has described as the paranoid style in American politics, and for all manner of conspiratorial hate-and-fear mongering, inquisitional madness and communal hysteria.

title: The Danger of Knowing Just Enough Spanish
description: I speak just enough Spanish to be dangerous.

title: How a Company Can Be Both Downgraded and Upgraded
description: The ratings agency Fitch downgraded the Chesapeake Energy Corporations issuer default rating last week to BB- from BB. At the same time, Fitch upgraded the rating on the companys bank loan to BB+ from BB.

title: With Aung San Suu Kyis Rise, China and Myanmar Face New Relationship
description: BEIJING  Even though China has long supported the generals who have wielded most of the power in Myanmar, the government in Beijing prepared this year for the possible election victory of the opposition leader, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, by inviting her to the capital to meet with President Xi Jinping.

title: Pistons Andre Drummond Hits the Boards and Makes a Huge Leap
description: Andre Drummond pulled down 17 rebounds on Wednesday night, the eighth-highest total by any N.B.A. player this season. Yet his rebounding average for the year dropped.

title: Why Jeffrey Lacker Is Worried About Inflation
description: Jeffrey Lacker, the president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, was the only member of the Feds policy-making committee who voted to raise interest rates in September, and again in October. Mr. Lacker has long expressed skepticism about the benefits of the Feds stimulus campaign, and he has been concerned that inflation will begin to rise more quickly as the economy gains strength.

title: In Obama Era, G.O.P. Bolsters Grip in the States
description: LEXINGTON, Ky.  Young, telegenic and news media savvy, State Auditor Adam Edelen looked like a shoo-in for re-election when Democrats gathered in a horse barn here for a buffet dinner late last month. Most figured he would go on to challenge Senator Rand Paul, whose Republican presidential bid is faltering even as he seeks re-election.

title: Bright Lights, Strange Shapes and Talk of U.F.O.s
description: When strange things appear in the sky, many people cant help but turn their thoughts to extraterrestrials. But theres usually a more down-to-earth explanation.

title: American Horror Story Season 5, Episode 6: Impersonation of Love
description: What does it mean to fall in love in the world of American Horror Story? When the body count is this high, is there any room for such sentiment?

title: How Period Trackers Have Changed Girl Culture
description: My 18-year-old daughter knows exactly when it will be that time of the month. Since June, shes been plugging the dates of her menstrual cycle into a popular period tracking app called Clue, and has it programmed to send her an alert every month, two days before her next period is due.

title: Palestinian Dies as Undercover Israelis Raid a Hospital
description: JERUSALEM  About two dozen men wearing bulky jackets, woolen caps, hoodies and checkered kaffiyehs barged into a hospital in the West Bank city of Hebron before dawn on Thursday, pushing what appeared to be a very pregnant woman in a wheelchair.

title: Cola, a New Start-up, Introduces Ways to Do More in Text Messages
description: For better or worse, text messaging is the app people spend more time using than any other on their smartphones. A new start-up, Cola, believes it can make it a bit better.

title: Bringing iPhone-style Medical Research to the Android World
description: Since Apple introduced its ResearchKit software in March, scientists at leading medical schools across the country have written apps to study asthma, Parkinsons disease, autism, epilepsy, melanoma, breast cancer and other ailments. Medical experts are hopeful that using smartphones to gather health data from millions of people, with their consent, can open a window to new insights into diseases, treatments and lifestyle effects.

title: When Headlines Play Down Dads, All Parents Lose
description: Female readers, did you gravitate toward certain articles about a recent Pew Report (Raising Kids and Running a Household: How Working Parents Share the Load)? Maybe you clicked on a headline like Equal division of labor at home for working parents? Not exactly (CNN), or Who does more at home when both parents work? Depends on which one you ask (Pew Fact Tank), or lingered knowingly over the paragraphs in the many articles that described how mothers do more: more to manage childrens schedules and activities, more chores, more coping with sick days. Much of the reporting included a wry poke at the fun statistic: More fathers than mothers say they share equally in the work.

title: The House of Lords: The Constitutional Dinosaur Britain Cant Kill
description: LONDON  Imagine President Obama introducing a controversial welfare proposal that quickly became the contentious subject of many columns and talk shows  but was approved, nonetheless, by Congress.

title: Charges Against Nephews of Venezuelas First Lady
description: The two men, Efran Antonio Campo Flores and Francisco Flores de Freitas, are accused of conspiring to ship cocaine to the United States, to be sold in New York.

title: De Blasio Attends Flight 587 Memorial, and This Time, He Isnt Late
description: The announcement on his public schedule was simple enough: Mayor Bill de Blasio was to deliver remarks on Thursday at the annual memorial service for Flight 587, the American Airlines jet that crashed in the Rockaways.

title: Fantasy Football Week 10: Bills at Jets
description: Fantasy football analysis for Thursday nights game between the Buffalo Bills and the Jets. Check back Friday for analysis on Sundays games and Mondays matchup between the Houston Texans and the Cincinnati Bengals. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy.

title: What Would Gaud Do?
description: Abstract interpretations of fashions new lust for Catalan style, from sculptural ruffles to deliriously loping prints.

title: The Runways New Romance With Spanish Style
description: Abstract interpretations of fashions new lust for Catalan style, from sculptural ruffles to deliriously loping prints.

title: Kurds Launch Offensive Against ISIS in Mount Sinjar, Iraq
description: Kurdish-led forces gained control over a major jihadist supply line between Syria and the Iraqi city of Mosul as part of a broader offensive to reclaim the town of Sinjar.

title: 2 Said to Be Venezuelan First Ladys Nephews Charged in Drug Plot
description: Federal prosecutors in New York on Thursday charged two men  identified by a person briefed on the case as nephews of the wife of President Nicols Maduro of Venezuela  with conspiring to ship cocaine to the United States.

title: Marco Canora Gives Hearth a Healthy Tuneup
description: The chef Marco Canora has adopted a pro-fat, anti-processed-food, back-to-basics regimen over the last few years that has transformed his health and the way he views food. Now he wants his East Village restaurant, Hearth, to follow suit.

title: Review: The 33 Recalls a Chilean Mine Disaster and the Men Who Endured It
description: The ordeal of the 33 Chilean miners trapped deep inside the earth after the collapse of a mine shaft in August 2010 was both an intensely local story and a global phenomenon. As family members waited in a makeshift camp near the mines opening, viewers across the world followed the progress of the rescue efforts thanks to round-the-clock news media attention. We breathed sighs of relief and wept tears of joy when the men finally emerged, after more than two months in subterranean heat and darkness. And then, as is our habit, we moved on.

title: With a Hush, an American Lexus Plant Goes to Work
description: Last month, a switch was flipped at a sprawling auto factory in Georgetown, Ky., and with it, Toyota started building Lexus cars in the United States for the first time.

title: Russia Says Leak of Secret Nuclear Weapon Design Was an Accident
description: MOSCOW  The Kremlins chief spokesman has confirmed that a report broadcast on Russian television this week revealed the design of a secret nuclear weapon delivery system: a drone submarine that could attack coastlines.

title: Transgender, and Facing Prison or Deportation
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Ryan Stays Close to Home While Others Junketeer
description: RepresentativePaul Ryan, the new Speaker of the House, is by now a famous homebody who emphatically prefers family life to the back slapping, nice-to-see-you routine of lawmakers, even when they travel to exotic places abroad in the name of fact finding. In the last 15 years, Mr. Ryan, unlike many colleagues, has accepted only two privately financed trips overseas. The distinction might have been encouraging for Washingtons leading ethics watchdog groups last week in their call for the speaker to suspend the increasingly controversial foreign junkets paid for by private interests intent on swaying American lawmakers.

title: Empire Season 2, Episode 7: True Love Never
description: In an Empire season that has drawn its strength from the dizzying unpredictability of its moves, Episode 7 felt like a bit of a come down. Everyone mostly stayed put this week, and it was unnerving. The shows sole constant is deceiving appearances. In a week light on kidnapping, theft, murder and backstabbing, is the calm just a temporary comfort to snatch out from under us later?

title: The Third Trail
description: I just finished hiking 2,700 miles. No, it wasnt on one of those two trails. Not the Pacific Crest Trail of Reese Witherspoons movie Wild, nor Robert Redfords Appalachian Trail from A Walk in the Woods.

title: Elvis Costellos Unfaithful Music and Disappearing Ink
description: Life takes much longer than the average pop song, Elvis Costello writes in his uneven and bloated autobiography, in which life takes much, much longer. You wouldnt guess from this audiobooks 18 hours (Swanns Way read by Simon Vance is a mere 17) that Costello shot to fame with songs that could condense a great deal of feeling and literate expression into bursts of little more than three minutes.

title: Volkswagen, Offering Amnesty, Asks Workers to Come Forward on Emissions Cheating
description: Volkswagen, trying to get to the bottom of its emissions-cheating scandal, on Thursday pressured employees to tell what they know, announcing an amnesty program for informants that will expire at the end of the month.

title: Being An Inflation Hawk Means Never Having To Say Youre Sorry
description: Jeffrey Lacker, president of the Richmond Fed, is worried about inflation unless the Fed tightens quickly, ignoring the worriers. Heres what he just said:

title: A Tinder Turn Toward the Indifferent
description: I am newly single and enjoy meeting women on Tinder. Its often difficult to know if a Tinder match is worth meeting in the real world until after you have invested time chatting with the woman via the app. The number of matches can be overwhelming, making it a challenge to juggle multiple conversations. Sometimes these chats fizzle on their own. But often Im given a phone number just as my interest wanes. How should I deal with this?

title: Gimbels
description: For decades, Gimbels was a prototype of Americas middle-class, middle-price store, a strong competitor of Macys.

title: What David Carr Taught Us
description: As The Times seeks its first David Carr Fellow, six journalists remember his most important lessons.

title: ISIS Claims Responsibility for Blasts That Killed Dozens in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A fiery double suicide bombing terrorized a mostly Shiite residential area of southern Beirut on Thursday, ripping through a busy shopping district at rush hour. The Lebanese Health Ministry said at least 43 people had been killed and more than 200 wounded in the worst attack to strike the city in years.

title: Tumbling TV Ad Sales Pull Revenue Down More Than Forecast at Viacom
description: Viacom  reported on Thursday that its total revenue declined more than expected, by 5 percent, to $3.8 billion for the quarter that ended in September, dragged down by persistent weakness in TV advertising sales and a lackluster film slate.

title: Ted Cruz Steps Up Attacks on Marco Rubio on Immigration
description: Senator Ted Cruz continued to pound Senator Marco Rubio over his immigration record on Thursday, escalating the tension between the two rivals for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: 36 Hours in Luang Prabang, Laos
description: Low-key pleasures in this lovely, ancient royal city include textile galleries, dozens of temples and small cafes.

title: Donald Graham Steps Down as Chief of Family Company
description: Donald E. Graham, the longtime publisher of The Washington Post who sold the newspaper to the Amazon founder, Jeffrey P. Bezos, in 2013, is stepping down as chief executive of Graham Holdings, which houses a collection of businesses, effectively immediately.

title: Bago and Tito Kings Kitchen
description: Filipino snacks at two new restaurants in the East Village.

title: Tito Kings Kitchen and Bago Join a Filipino Feast in the East Village
description: Bonito flakes wave like tattered flags, great shreds of them over a heap of ground pork still agitated from the frying pan, riled up by fermented black beans and fish sauce. Japanese Kewpie mayonnaise brings scattered sweet high notes and a deeper tang than its Western cousins. Under it all, French fries lie in wait, with charred tips.

title: Apple Apologizes to Black Students Ejected From Store in Australia
description: Apple employees in Australia apologized Wednesday to a group of black students who were told to leave one of the companys stores in Melbourne because of fears they would steal something.

title: Further Speculations on White Mortality
description: I wrote my columnlast weekend on the much-discussedAnne Case/Angus Deaton paper on rising white mortality rates, and since thentheres been an important emendation to their data from Columbias Andrew Gelman: In a nutshell, Gelman argues that a finer-grained look at the numbers suggests that 1) the overall white mortality rate has re-stabilized, rather than continuing to rise, since the mid-2000s, that 2) the mortality increasewas actually more notable for thirtysomethings and early fortysomethings than for the 45-54 cohort, and that 3)its white women whose mortality rates have kept on increasing over the last decade, even as white men have seen their mortality rates fall a little once again.

title: Missy Elliott Releases New Video
description: A decade after her last album, Missy Elliott released a music video for her new single, WTF (Where They From) on Thursday morning.

title: More Virtual Reality Videos to Watch
description: Last weekend, The New York Times delivered 1.2 million Google Cardboard viewers to home-delivery subscribers and asked them to watch our new virtual-reality film, The Displaced, about three refugee children growing up in Lebanon, South Sudan and Ukraine. This is the first in a series of virtual-reality films the magazine intends to produce. (We also experimented with V.R. before this with a short film about the Walking New York issue.) V.R. is still an emerging medium but there have already been a number of important projects from a variety of creators that indicate the potential of this technology. Below are a few of our favorites.

title: The Web of Deals That John Malone Weaves
description: The media mogul John C. Malone is never one to shy away from complicated deals. Two announcements from his companies on Thursday  involving tracking stocks, spinoffs and tax efficiencies  exemplify how he can spin an intricate web of investments.

title: 1953 | Immersive Technology Debuts, in the Movie Ads
description: This month, Times readers were introduced to virtual reality as a new means of storytelling.

title: A Refugee Crisis in Lebanon Hides in Plain Sight
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  At first glance, evening on Beiruts neon-lit, bustling Hamra Street looks much as it did a few years ago. But slow down and look around.

title: Making a Museum Out of a Mountain
description: The only hiking Ive ever known or half-enjoyed has involved flat terrain, a swimmable body of water as a destination and at least one parent to whine to along the way. But in September, I found myself 5,000 feet up a mountain, lost, alone, without a working cellphone, not even close to where I was supposed to be going, and completely happy. As I gnawed my way up the Dolomite peak of Kronplatz mountain, I had to stop every 100 yards and catch my breath. It hadnt even occurred to me that the trek would be difficult or that I should bring water. But whatever panic and thirst and lung-burn I experienced was mitigated by the frosted clover and edelweiss and enzian, which I could see the sun thawing in real time as I walked. The air smelled sweetly of manure and cut grass; the tinkle of cowbells and the call of actual cuckoo birds echoed through the valleys.

title: One Bouquet of Fleeting Beauty, Please
Medal of Honor Awarded to Army Captain Who Tackled Bomber in Afghanistan
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama awarded the Medal of Honor on Thursday to a soldier who rushed a suicide bomber in Afghanistan in 2012 and saved perhaps dozens of American and Afghan lives at a devastating cost to his own.

title: Several Fed Officials Say They Are Ready to Raise Rates
description: Federal Reserve officials, poised to start raising the central banks benchmark interest rate in December, are turning from the question of whether to act to how quickly the Fed should raise rates thereafter.

title: Foster Child Taken From Gay Couple in Utah
description: A judge ordered this week that a young foster child of April Hoagland and Beckie Peirce, a married couple from Utah, be removed from their home.

title: Smoking Ban Proposal a Surprise to Some Public Housing Tenants
description: With more than 400,000 listed tenants and a backlog of repair requests at its sprawling properties, the New York City Housing Authority has often relied on police officers to enforce the rules governing those who live in its buildings.

title: U.S. Smoking Rate Declines, but Poor Remain at Higher Risk
description: WASHINGTON  Smoking, the leading cause of preventable death in the United States, continued to decline last year, federal health authorities reported Thursday, with the share of American adults who smoke dropping to 16.8 percent, down from 17.8 percent in 2013.

title: Footage of West Bank Hospital Raid
description: Closed-circuit surveillance footage released by Al-Ahli hospital in Hebron shows Israeli undercover forces conducting a raid late Wednesday.

title: The Undress Code
description: I WORE a sweater with holes in it.

title: Utah Judge Orders Lesbian Couple to Give Up Foster Child
description: Three months ago, April Hoagland and Rebecca Peirce welcomed a baby girl into their Utah home as foster parents. But this week, the couple was ordered by a state judge to give the baby up. The reason he gave, the couple said, is that they were lesbians.

title: Vatican Investigates 2 Journalists Over Leaked Documents
description: ROME  Two Italian journalists who wrote tell-all books about financial mismanagement in the Roman Catholic Church are now facing the wrath of the Vatican.

title: With Move to Red Sox, a Reliable Source of Yankees Trades Dries Up
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  A few hours before the start of the 2009 World Series between the Yankees and the Philadelphia Phillies, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman picked up the phone and called Dave Dombrowski, his counterpart with the Detroit Tigers. He wanted to see who might be available in a trade over the winter.

title: French Photographer Wins Prix Pictet
description: The French photographer Valrie Belinhas won the sixth Prix Pictet for photography, for her series Still life, 2014. The award was announced by Kofi Annan, the former secretary general of the United Nations and the honorary president of the prize, on Thursday at the Muse dArt Moderne in Paris, at the opening reception for an exhibition of work by the 12 finalists.

title: After a Mass Extinction, Only the Small Survive
description: From sharks to giraffes, many of Earths biggest and most magnificent species are threatened with extinction. A new study of the fossil record indicates that once large vertebrates disappear, evolution cannot quickly restore them  for tens of millions of years, most animals remain small.

title: Huge Valeant Stake Exposes Rift at Sequoia Fund
description: For more than four decades, the Sequoia Fund has been the envy of Wall Street, one of the rare funds to consistently beat the market. Known for its close ties to Warren E. Buffett, the fund at its peak managed more than $9 billion. It was in such demand that it closed to new investors in 2013, a move that enhanced its mystique.

title: A New York Opening For Gimbels
description: When it opens in 1910, Gimbels represents the first major department store to debut in New York at a full size.

title: Playing at Doc NYC
description: A look at some of the films at the Doc NYC festival, running from Nov. 12-19.

title: At Paris Photo, a Wide-Ranging Mix
description: Beginning today, 147 galleries and 27 art-book dealers and publishers will gather in Pariss enormous, glass-domed Grand Palais for Paris Photo, the worlds largest photography fair. With it come a slew of satellite events, including the independent publishing fair Offprint Paris, a Martin Scorsese exhibition at La Cinmathque Franaise and the photographer Alex Pragers first solo show in France at the Galerie Des Galeries. And inside Paris Photo itself, visitors often lose their bearings and entire days wandering among the endless rows of stalls. With that in mind, here are a few highlights from the fair.

title: Letters: On Fiction and Fracking
description: To the Editor:

title: In Star Wars and the Power of Costume, You Are What You Wear
description: However you feel about nudity in movies, walking through the new exhibition at Discovery Times Square will certainly lead you to one realization: A naked actor is a wasted opportunity. The right costume in the right circumstance can be as important a storytelling device as any line of dialogue or special-effects gimmick. It can become practically a character in and of itself.

title: The Secrets in Greenlands Ice Sheet
description: At one point several hundred thousand years ago, snow began falling over the center of the earths largest island. The snow did not melt, and in the years that followed, storms brought even more. All around Greenland, the arctic temperatures remained low enough for the snow to last past spring and summer. It piled up, year after year, century after century, millennium after millennium. Eventually, the snow became the Greenland ice sheet, a blanket of ice so huge that it covered 650,000 square miles and reached a thickness of 10,000 feet in places. Meanwhile, in Antarctica, a similar process was well underway. There, as snow fell upon snow for years without end, the ice sheet spread out over a much vaster area: 5.4 million square miles, an expanse far larger than the lower 48 states. By the start of the modern era, when power plants and electric lights began illuminating the streets of Manhattan, about 75 percent of the worlds freshwater had been frozen into the ice sheets that lay over these lands at opposite ends of the earth.

title: Thanksgiving Wine 2015
description: Bottles to enhance this years holiday feast.

title: Fret-Free Wine Options for Thanksgiving
description: Nothing ought to be simpler than selecting wines for Thanksgiving, right? You pick a few bottles that you like, open them and everybodys happy.

title: McDonalds C.E.O. on All Day Breakfast, Hourly Wages and Wall Street
description: A little more than eight months after he took the helm as chief executive of the McDonalds Corporation, Steve Easterbrook spent this week in New York trying to persuade investors that the company is pulling itself out of a prolonged slump. Below is an edited transcript of a brief interview with The New York Times.

title: Documento: Cargos por trfico de droga a dos venezolanos
description: Efran Antonio Campo Flores y Francisco Flores de Freitas son acusados de conspirar para enviar 800 kilos de cocana a Estados Unidos.

title: De Blasios Advocacy Group Pursues Ambitious Agenda Despite Setbacks
description: Shortly after Mayor Bill de Blasio of New York and his national advocacy group trumpeted plans last month to hold a presidential forum in Iowa, he took part in a conference call to rev up the liberal faithful.

title: Out Magazine Names Obama Its Ally of the Year
description: Out Magazine, noting the advances of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender people since 2008, has named President Obama its Ally of the Year, making him the first sitting American president to pose for the cover of a gay magazine.

title: Gimbel Opens
description: When it opens in 1910, it represents the first major department store to debut in New York at a full size.

title: LuPone and Ebersole to Star in New Musical, War Paint
description: Two of Broadways biggest stars, Patti LuPone and Christine Ebersole, will portray competing cosmetics industry executives in a new musical, War Paint, scheduled to premiere in Chicago next summer.

title: The Illustrated Interview: Richard Branson
description: The British entrepreneur, whose multibillion-dollar empire includes hotels, trains, airlines and the worlds first commercial spaceline, drew his answers to a brief questionnaire with a Sharpie while in New York for a recent panel discussion on criminal justice reform.

title: Amid Unrest in Missouri, University System Picks Michael Middleton as Interim Chief
description: The Missouri state university system on Thursday named as interim president an African-American who said he understood the complexity and nuance of the recent racially charged campus clashes, adding that while some people will hold his race against him, it probably also played a role in his getting the job.

title: An Unlikely Union: Tiffany and Dover Street Market
description: On a rainy afternoon earlier this week, with the Flatiron district in near-gridlock, Adrian Joffe, the president and C.E.O. of Comme des Garons and Dover Street Market, went for tea at Tiffany & Company. The occasion was Dover Streets new collaboration with the brand  and its new design director, Francesca Amfitheatrof.

title: U.N. Security Council Seeks to Head Off Mass Atrocities in Burundi
description: UNITED NATIONS  Spurred by fears of mass atrocities, the United Nations Security Council on Thursday unanimously passed a resolution that calls for a bolstered international presence in Burundi but stops short of sanctions against those who incite violence.

title: Vincent Asaro, Accused inLufthansa Heist, Is Found Not Guilty
description: Vincent Asaro, the reputed mobster charged in connection with the notorious 1978 Lufthansa robbery, walked out of federal court in Brooklyn on Thursday a free man after a jury cleared him of racketeering and other charges.

title: Anheuser-Busch InBevs Plan to Finance Beer Deal
description: Its rare that a big nonfinancial company arranges its own debt  and $75 billion worth is a first. That, though, is what Anheuser-Busch InBev has done with the five-part loan package backing its deal to buy SABMiller for more than $100 billion, which was formally announced on Wednesday.

title: Ohio Man Arrested After Social Posts Urging Killing of Military Members
description: WASHINGTON  The federal authorities arrested an Ohio hospital worker on a terrorism-related charge Thursday, accusing him of declaring his support for the Islamic State on social media and calling for the killing of United States service members.

title: 5 New Apple Varieties
description: Junami, Kanzi, RubyFrost, Opal and SnapDragon are a handful of the newest kind.

title: Arguments From Irrelevant Authority
description: One curious aspect of economic debate these past five years or so has been the extent to which people demanding fiscal austerity and/or higher interest rates rely on what I think of as spurious authority figures  people who are well-known for some reason that has nothing at all to do with expertise in the subject at hand. I remember being told that the deficit must be a terrible threat because Admiral Mullen, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said so; so, are we going to rely on Janet Yellen to set naval strategy?

title: N.F.L. Week 10 Previews and Picks
75 Years After Steinbeck Sailed, a Boat Is Readied to Go Back to Sea
description: PORT TOWNSEND, Wash.  Rule 1 in the world of working wooden boats, since the days of dugout canoes and fishing skiffs, has been that when they are no longer of use or they are lost at sea, people build new ones and move on. Sentimentality and fussy restoration are rarely in the tool kit.

title: Massachusetts Regulator Says Real Estate Affiliate Faked Proxy Votes
description: Massachusetts securities regulator is taking aim at an affiliate of American Realty Capital, accusing it of faking proxy votes for a September shareholder meeting that was crucial to the planned $378 million sale of American Realty businesses to the private equity giant Apollo Global Management.

title: John Steinbeck, Afloat
description: Boats and water figure prominently in John Steinbecks writing. They often appear as characters, like in The Log From the Sea of Cortez, but also as metaphors for mobility and transformation. Here are examples of Steinbecks nautical passages, literal and otherwise.

title: Kevin Barrys Beatlebone Wins Goldsmiths Prize
description: The Irish writer Kevin Barry won the Goldsmiths Prize on Wednesday for his second novel, Beatlebone, which imagines John Lennon visiting a small island off the west coast of Ireland in 1978. The prize, established in 2013, honors British and Irish writers for fiction that breaks the mold or opens up new possibilities for the novel form, and comes with an award of 10,000, or about $15,000.

title: Goldman Sachs Names 425 New Managing Directors
description: Nearly a third of the Goldman Sachs Groups 425 newly minted managing directors are millennials, or people born after 1980. Forty percent were hired as analysts. Roughly 21 percent are former summer interns.

title: France Says Climate Talks Must Produce Binding Deal
description: PARIS  French officials said on Thursday that any agreement at the coming climate conference in Paris would have to be legally binding, expressing alarm at comments by the American secretary of state that suggested the opposite.

title: When Office Chaos Threatens to Overshadow Customer Service
description: Send your workplace conundrums to workologist@nytimes.com, including your name and contact information (even if you want it withheld for publication). The Workologist is a guy with well-intentioned opinions, not a professional career adviser. Letters may be edited.

title: Republicans Mock Hillary Clintons Claim of Trying to Join the Marines
description: After a week of debate over whether Ben Carson really won a scholarship to West Point, Republicans have refocused the question of military service on Hillary Rodham Clinton, expressing doubts about her claim that she tried to join the Marines in the 1970s.

title: Republicans Sound Off on the Minimum Wage
description: Four of the eight Republican presidential contenders in the prime-time debate on Tuesday were asked their views on raising the federal minimum wage.

title: Sophie of Saks Fifth Avenue
description: For almost 40 years, Sophie Gimbel influenced American fashion as the head of the Saks custom department.

title: Myanmar Generals Set the Stage for Their Own Exit
description: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar  This capital, built from scratch by Myanmars former dictators, is filled with soldiers, police officers and civil servants. But even here, where most people work for the government, they voted to throw it out of power.

title: Ai Weiwei Debuts His First Jewelry Collection
description: Ai Weiwei is not the type of artist you expect to work small. His most celebrated installations have been created on an epic scale: works made from 99 tons of steel, say, or 8 million sunflower seeds. So the news that the 58-year-old Chinese artist and activist has been secretly working on a collection of jewelry, which launched in London this week, might come as something of a surprise. Is he going in a new direction?

title: Review: In James White, Facing Adulthood With Uncertainty
description: James White burrows so deeply into the consciousness of its title character, a flailing young Manhattanite played by Christopher Abbott (Girls), that his self-loathing and panic feel contagious. Who hasnt, at a certain point in life, faced a sink-or-swim moment when a promising future suddenly began to seem out of reach? James combats the terror of grown-up responsibility with copious amounts of booze and late-night carousing in which he picks fights in bars and behaves like a brat. But Mr. Abbotts performance makes you aware that Jamess bad behavior stems from fear; deep down he has a warm heart.

title: In Return to St. Johns, Chris Mullin Gets a Little Help From His Friends
description: The first call came for Barry Rohrssen while Kentuckys charter jet sat on the tarmac in Cleveland in the wee hours of March 29. The Wildcats had just outlasted Notre Dame to advance to the Final Four in mens basketball. Text messages poured into his phone like rain pelting a sidewalk. More than 120 still sit there today, unread, tiny red tokens reminding Rohrssen, a Kentucky assistant coach, of the feeling of being on top of the college basketball world.

title: Agatha Christies Mr. Quin Finds New Life as an App
description: LONDON Eighty-five years after its first publication, Agatha Christies ghoulish short story series The Mysterious Mr. Quin is getting new life  as an app.

title: Review: In You Us We All, a Symbolic Hope Writes to Pop Divas
description: The amusing Twitter account named Kim Kierkegaardashian mashes up the anguished writings of Soren Kierkegaard with the daffy public statements of Kim Kardashian: When the child must be weaned, the mother too is not without sorrow, but you and your toddler can still wear matching outfits.

title: This Weeks Movies | Nov. 13, 2015
description: The New York Times film critics review By the Sea, The 33 and James White.

title: Letter Surfaces at Sheldon Silver Trial Showing Potentially Lucrative Deal
description: In January 2012, Sheldon Silver, then the New York Assembly speaker, and a large real estate company signed a deal that promised to be beneficial to him.

title: Uterus Transplants May Soon Help Some Infertile Women in the U.S. Become Pregnant
description: CLEVELAND  Six doctors swarmed around the body of the deceased organ donor and quickly started to operate.

title: Masterpieces of Japanese Art at the Met
description: Has there ever been a more beautiful autumn than the one now on the wane in New York City, with our parks still looking like cloth-of-gold, and flocks of southbound geese calling over our rivers? We know there were just such seasons in centuries past in Japan. Artists tell us so. In a 16th-century hanging scroll, the painter Shikibu Terutada depicts fall leaves and flowers as last-chance blasts of color. In the 18th century, Maruyama Okyo fills an all-but-empty folding screen with the image of a single goose descending to withered reeds.

title: Uzbekistan Releases Political Prisoner After 21 Years
description: MOSCOW  An Uzbek detainee sometimes called the worlds longest-serving political prisoner by rights groups was released on Thursday, having spent 21 years behind bars on various pretexts and trumped-up charges.

title: A New Place to Celebrate Cool California Design
description: Running a gallery can be a little bit like an adoption agency, says Gerard OBrien. You want to find the right home for these things because they have intrinsic value. For more than a decade, his salon-style showroom, Reform Gallery, has been an insider resource for furniture by the post-G.I. Bill generation of West Coast artists, with pieces from the wire sculptor Ruth Asawa to the potter Doyle Lane.
