description: Read in Chinese |

title: How to Decrease Prices for an Expensive Class of Drugs
description: Competition among generic drug makers pushes drug prices downward. But such competition is weak for a growing and expensive class of drugs called biologics. A big reason has to do with the science that underlies them.

title: Les attentats  Paris rvlent les limites de Daesh
description: FLORENCE, Italie  Comme la dclar le Prsident Franois Hollande, la France est bien en guerre contre Daesh. La France considre le groupe Islamiste comme son ennemi numro un. Elle le combat en premire ligne avec les Amricains au Moyen-Orient, et comme seule nation occidentale dans le Sahel. Elle a engag dans cette lutte, commence au Mali en 2013, un pourcentage de son arme bien suprieur  celui des troupes amricaines.

title: Houston Texans at Cincinnati Bengals Preview
description: Texans (3-5) at Bengals (8-0)

title: Five Ways Your Smartphone Can Help Your Health
description: A doctor friend once told me the best thing I could do for my health was to turn off my cellphone. But that was before smartphone makers began building health and safety features into their phones. Here are five healthful tricks your phone can do.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | Nov. 16, 2015
description: Updated: Nov. 20, 2015

title: Israeli Soldiers Raid West Bank Refugee Camp, Prompting Deadly Clashes
description: QALANDIYA REFUGEE CAMP, West Bank  Armed clashes broke out during an Israeli military raid at the Qalandiya refugee camp in the West Bank before dawn on Monday, leaving two Palestinian men dead and several others wounded, according to the Israeli military and Palestinian residents.

title: Assessing the Fitness of Wearable Tech
description: Like many people who grew up long before personal computers and cellphones became ubiquitous, Ive never tried a fitness tracker. I already know I walk about five miles a day, in addition to my daily swim. My weight is stable within a range of two pounds. I prefer to remain accountable only to myself, not to a gadget.

title: Marriott to Buy Starwood Hotels, Creating Worlds Largest Hotel Company
description: When Marriott Internationals $12.2 billion bid for Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide was announced on Monday morning, investors and analysts were surprised.

title: Police Capture Armed Woman Barricaded Near the White House
description: WASHINGTON  Several blocks near the White House were shut down for most of Monday morning as an armed woman barricaded herself in an office building, adding to tensions in a city already at heightened alert after the terrorist attacks in Paris.

title: Collaborations 3.0: Lee Danielss Empire and Hood by Air Make a Fashion Statement
description: These days the high fashion designer/fast fashion collaboration has become so ubiquitous (Balmain x H&M, Lilly Pulitzer for Target, the North Face for J. Crew) that it is starting to feel like a calculated formula guaranteed to milk the most from a marketing budget. So its nice to see one based on an entirely different premise: fandom.

title: Jesse Tyler Ferguson Returns to Broadway in Fully Committed
description: Jesse Tyler Ferguson plays one half of one of televisions most memorable couples on Modern Family. But when he returns to Broadway in April, hell be all alone. Mr. Ferguson will star in the one-man show Fully Committed, a comedy about foodie culture by Becky Mode, starting April 2 at the Lyceum Theater.

title: Jazzmeia Horn Wins Thelonious Monk Institute International Jazz Competition
description: The winner of the 2015 Thelonious Monk Institute International Jazz Competition is Jazzmeia Horn. Originally from Dallas, Ms. Horn, 23, is a singer with a smart, steadfast connection to the jazz-vocal tradition, as defined by predecessors like Betty Carter and Sarah Vaughan. Since moving to New York in 2009 to attend the New School for Jazz and Contemporary Music, she has been a regular presence on the club scene, often with her band, the Artistry of Jazz Horn.

title: 1890: Honduras Slays Her Traitors
description: NEW YORK  The Honduras revolution has ended, and General Sanchez and all his principal leaders have been shot. Yesterday morning General Bogran opened fire on the barrack to which the insurgents had retreated. Sanchez and his comrades, knowing that death awaited them, fought desperately; but it was a hopeless struggle from the start. Bograns soldiers charged and soon all the rebels remaining alive were prisoners. Without the formality of a court-martial Sanchez and the leading officers were taken to one of the principal squares in the city, blindfolded and stood in line in the presence of hundreds of citizens. The word was given to the firing party, and a crash of musketry rang the death-knell of the revolution. The New York Herald, European Edition, November 17, 1890

title: Its Easy to Overestimate Effect of Paris Attacks on 2016 Race
description: Until last week, the threat from terrorism had received little attention from candidates or voters during the 2016 campaign. In one poll, just 3 percent of Americans rated it the most important problem facing the country.

title: Daily Report: IBM Embraces Its Inner Designer
description: IBM has been associated with many things over the years. But few people would ever connect Big Blue, as IBM is sometimes called, with a progressive attitude toward design.

title: Will Uterine Transplants Make Male Pregnancy Possible?
description: A reader writes, The Times reported last week that surgeons at the Cleveland Clinic expect to become the first in the United States to transplant a uterus into a woman who lacks one, so that she can become pregnant and give birth. Is there any reason doctors could not implant a uterus in a man, so that he could become pregnant?

title: Media General Rejects Nexstar Bid, but Will Negotiate
description: Media General, which operates 71 television stations in all but two states, has rejected a $4.1 billion bid from the Nexstar Broadcasting Group, saying the unsolicited offer undervalues the company.

title: 1940: King Inspects Coventrys Ruins
description: COVENTRY, England  As troops were being rushed to this stricken city, which suffered on Thursday night the worst raid to date in the German aerial war on Great Britain, King George VI and other government leaders visited today [Nov. 16] the injured and homeless and inspected the vast damage to Coventry, a Midlands industrial center, where 200 persons were killed and 800 injured by the Nazi air attack. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 17, 1940

title: 7 Inspiring Quotes From Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Gloria Steinem
description: Here are some noteworthy quotes from the two inspiring women.

title: Obama Says Strategy to Fight ISIS Will Succeed
description: ANTALYA, Turkey  Time after time, the question was essentially the same: Why isnt your strategy against the Islamic State working?

title: A Savory Alternative to Traditional Stuffing
description: Call this savory mix of wild rice, quinoa, mushrooms and greens a stuffing or a pilaf. Its not meant to go inside a turkey but it has the definitive herbal flavors I associate with and insist on when I make any kind of stuffing  sage mainly, but also thyme. They are forever stored in my bank of taste memories; I have looked forward to them every Thanksgiving since my first forkful of the packaged stuffing of my youth.

title: Devils Look Sharp, Even as They Shun Razors
description: NEWARK  Sporting five oclock shadows and mustaches  forbidden during the regular season by the former general manager Lou Lamoriello  the Devils have won 10 of their last 13 games, including two victories over the Chicago Blackhawks, the Stanley Cup champions.

title: Giants Receiver Victor Cruz, Gone 13 Months, Will Have Surgery
description: Victor Cruz was running pass routes on Saturday at the Giants practice complex hoping to finally be ready to make his season debut in a game on Nov. 29 against Washington.

title: The Coravin Proves Rob Moose Is Serious About His Wine
description: The light in Rob Mooses refrigerator wont turn on. This is intentional: Mr. Moose, a rangy, tumble-haired rock guitarist, violinist and producer who has spent much of the last decade working with the likes of Bon Iver and Sufjan Stevens, taped the switch down.

title: Were All About Pie
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears on nytimes.com. To receive the email, register here.

title: Jim Webb Joins In on Criticizing Hillary Clintons Marines Story
description: Jim Webb may have abandoned his bid for the Democratic presidential nomination, but the former senator from Virginia is not finished criticizing Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: The Challenges for Volkswagens Internal Investigation
description: Step 1 in the playbook for a company accused of misconduct is a promise of complete cooperation with the government. Step 2 is the key, because the company must then conduct a thorough internal investigation that will deliver the information necessary to assure regulators and prosecutors that the problem has been dealt with and those responsible have been identified.

title: Plea Discussions Sought in Skelos Trial, Prosecutor Says
description: A prosecutor at the corruption trial of State Senator Dean G. Skelos and his son told the judge on Monday that one of the defendants had sought to discuss a possible plea deal in the federal bribery and extortion case.

title: Taking Stock of the $10 Billion Washington Spent on Colombias War
description: The United States has spent more than $10 billion dollars beefing up Colombias security forces, supporting development and backing reform of the judicial system in an effort known as Plan Colombia. After playing an instrumental role in giving the Colombian government the upper hand in its decades-long war against the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, a Marxist guerrilla group, Washington has turned its attention to peacemaking. I talked withKevin Whitaker, the American ambassador in Bogot, by email about this evolution and Washingtons decision to sit down with leaders who are under indictment in the United States.

title: A Worlds Leading Puzzle Designer Shares an Early Original
description: Thisweeks puzzle is an original suggested byNaoki Inaba, theJapanese puzzle master and one of the worlds most prolific inventorsof original puzzles. Weve seen him before with Area Maze and Predator and Prey; this week he shares one ofhis earliest designs. Lets give it a try. Heres

title: Chip Credit Cards Give Retailers Another Grievance Against Banks
description: The employee perched on a stepstool by the checkout at Trader Joes in Union Square in Manhattan is like an air traffic controller: Register 6 for one customer. Register 9 for the next.

title: A Big Week for Long (or Were They Short?) Passes
description: The modern N.F.L. is defined by the short-passing game. And on Sunday, the short-passing game helped set a record for long plays. It might seem counterintuitive, but some of the longest pass plays of the season came from some of the shortest passes of the day:

title: Japans Economy Feels the Sting of Chinas Slowdown
description: TOKYO  In its small way, Tsutomu Nyuwas metalworking shop in Yasugi, Japan, has been feeding the economic boom 700 miles away in China.

title: Supreme Court Wont Hear Case Over Planned Parenthood Documents
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court on Monday let stand an appeals court ruling shielding the documents of a Planned Parenthood affiliate in New Hampshire from an anti-abortion groups request under the open records law. As is its custom, the Supreme Court gave no reasons for turning down the appeal in the case.

title: Instamoms, Curating a Photo-Worthy Childhood. Discuss.
description: The amateur child models of Instagram are already more famous on the Internet than most of your co-workers. Theres 4-year-old London Scout, with 105,000 followers; 2-year-old Millie-Belle Diamond, with 143,000; 4-year-old Michelle (154,000); Gavin (200,000); and the Mini Style Hacker (260,000). Then theres the prince of Instagram: Alonso Mateo, with more than 600,000 followers. He recently attended the Dior show at Paris Fashion Week.

title: Representative Steve King of Iowa Endorses Ted Cruz
description: DES MOINES  Representative Steve King of Iowa, a hard-right conservative in the state with the first nominating contest, threw his support behind Senator Ted Cruz for the Republican nomination on Monday, calling him the answer to my prayers.

title: Finding Cheap Flights and More on Black Friday
description: As every American knows, after the turkey comes the shopping. And not just for clothes and toys. In the days following Thanksgiving (Black Friday and especially Cyber Monday), scores of travel companies offer discounted hotel rooms, vacation packages, rail passes, rental cars, cruises and flights.

title: Making Lotus Root Croquettes
description: The rock-and-roll chef Kenji Koyama shares his recipe for a classic Japanese dish.

title: Nobel Winner Svetlana Alexievich Books to Be Published by Random House
description: Svetlana Alexievich, the Belarussian journalist and winner of the 2015 Nobel Prize in Literature, is about to expand her reach in the English-reading world.

title: The Japanese Chef Beloved by Lorde
description: Necco, a friendly, health-conscious Japanese small-plates restaurant in West L.A., is the kind of place in which Lorde fuels up on wholesome, unpretentious food when shes in town. Its helmed by chef Kenji Koyama, who opened it almost exactly one year ago.

title: A New Book Looks at the Koch Brothers Role in Politics
description: In a 2010 profile of the billionaire industrialist brothers Charles and David Koch, the New Yorker writer Jane Mayer described how, from 2005 to 2008, the brothers had vastly outspent ExxonMobil in financing organizations that fight legislation aimed at curbing climate change. Their company, the conglomerate Koch Industries, was also listed as one of the top 10 air polluters in the country, she wrote.

title: Carnegie Hall Stands Behind Clive Gillinson After Review of Ronald Perelmans Complaints
description: Carnegie Hall  whose former chairman, Ronald O. Perelman, stepped down last month after clashing with its executive and artistic director, Clive Gillinson  announced on Monday that a legal review that it commissioned had found no evidence to support allegations that Mr. Gillinson had tried to undermine Mr. Perelmans oversight responsibilities.

title: Where Ronda Rousey Goes From Here
description: It was Ronda Rouseys Buster Douglas moment. Those who watched it were stunned. Those who read about it the next morning did a double take. And more than a few people were wondering where it leaves her career.

title: Defense Rests in Trial of Ex-Coal C.E.O., Calling No Witnesses
description: Lawyers for Donald L. Blankenship, the former coal executive accused of conspiring to violate federal safety standards before 29 people were killed at the Upper Big Branch mine in West Virginia, rested their case on Monday without calling any witnesses.

title: Live and Kicking: Soccer Games to Watch
description: Tuesdays showcase friendly between France and England (3 p.m. Eastern time, Fox Sports 1) has surely morphed into something else by now, part somber memorial service and defiant celebration and group therapy session. The French journalist Philippe Auclair suggested Saturday that English fans join their guests at Wembley in singing the French national anthem, La Marseillaise, in solidarity when it is played before kickoff. (England Coach Roy Hodgson has endorsed the idea.) If you want to join in from wherever you are, the lyrics are here. The French probably wont mind if you fumble a word or two.

title: Serious Delusions
description: Greg Sargent mocks pundits declaring that the attacks in Paris will finally convince Republican primary voters that they need to get serious, and deflate the Trump/Carson bubble. This time it will really happen!

title: Monday Roundup: Paris Praise, Brookss Trip and Steinem-Ginsburg
description: The crush of news from Paris brought an impressive, all-hands response from The Timess newsrooms in New York and around the world over the weekend. While no other subject comes close in importance on this Monday, Ill include here, as addenda, a couple of other matters that came up over the past few days.

title: Marriotts Deal for Starwood Looks Defensive
description: Marriott Internationals $12 billion deal to buy its rival Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide opens a financial vacancy.

title: Thanksgiving, the Julia Child Way
description: At the height of Julia Childs fame in the 1970s and 80s, Thanksgiving guests often felt the need to tell her she should get her home number removed from the public directory. (This was an analog tool called a telephone book.)

title: Donald Trump Repeats Call to Inspect Mosques for Signs of Terrorism
description: Donald J. Trump issued another call for more scrutiny of mosques in the United States as fresh fears of terrorism, spurred by the attacks in Paris, dominated the presidential campaign conversation on Monday.

title: Taking the (Often Imprecise) Measure of Stress
description: Research has long shown that stress is bad for you, but many people are not even aware when they are feeling stressed.

title: Early Artworks by Lucian Freud Given to National Portrait Gallery
description: London  A rare collection of 162 childhood drawings; 47 sketchbooks from the 1940s to 2011; and letters and book cover designs by the artist Lucian Freud, who died in 2011, have been given to Britain in lieu of 2.9 million British pounds, or $4.41 million in inheritance tax by the Freud estate.

title: Paris Attacks Give Rise to Fakes and Misinformation
description: On Friday, as terror attacks unfolded across Paris, rumors were spreading on the Internet even as people remained trapped inside the buildings that were under siege.

title: AR Capital to Stop Creating Nontraded REITs
description: AR Capital, the real estate investment company built by Nicholas S. Schorsch and William M. Kahane, said Monday that it would stop creating new investment products and close existing ones to new investors to focus on managing the $19 billion it has in current investments.

title: Cancellation of College Production of Jesus in India Over Casting of White Actors Prompts Debate
description: The cancellation of a college production of Lloyd Suhs play Jesus in India over the casting of white actors as Indian characters has prompted a war of words over diversity in theater, with Mr. Suh arguing that the production could send a dehumanizing message to minority students and the school countering that the student actors on its rural, predominantly white campus were being punished for their race.

title: Measuring How Financial Advisers Handle Uncertainty
description: Remember how you felt during the financial crisis in 2008? People were scared. Even the professionals were uncertain about what might happen. I know, because I was scared, too.

title: John Kerry Arrives in Paris to Show Shared Resolve After Attacks
description: PARIS  Secretary of State John Kerry arrived in Paris on Monday evening, the first senior Obama administration official to visit France since the terrorist attacks on Friday shook the capital and prompted Western nations to re-evaluate their strategy for fighting the Islamic State.

title: After Paris Attacks, C.I.A. Director Rekindles Debate Over Surveillance
description: WASHINGTON  A diabolical range of recent attacks claimed by the Islamic State  a Russian airliner blown up in Egypt, a double suicide bombing in Beirut and Fridays ghastly assaults on Paris  has rekindled a debate over the proper limits of government surveillance in an age of terrorist mayhem.

title: In a Tooth, DNA From Some Very Old Cousins, the Denisovans
description: A tooth fossil discovered in a Siberian cave has yielded DNA from a vanished branch of the human tree, mysterious cousins called the Denisovans, scientists said Monday.

title: Liberty Global to Buy Cable & Wireless for $5.5 Billion
description: Liberty Global, the European cable and wireless operator controlled by John C. Malone, agreed on Monday to buy the British telecommunications company Cable & Wireless Communications for $5.5 billion.

title: Jawbone in Rock May Clear Up a Mammal Family Mystery
description: With technologies like CT scans and 3-D printing, a team of scientists reported on Monday that it had solved a mystery about the family tree of mammals that started with a single tooth a century and a half ago.

title: Danny Meyers Team Faces a No-Tipping World
description: Thanksgiving came early this year to the Modern. Not the holiday of turkey and cranberry sauce, but the custom of family members lovingly and contentiously coming together to talk (and talk) about the things that unite and divide them.

title: Europes Darkened Future
description: Before we talk about fighting ISIS, lets talk about the state of Europe. The first time I wrote about the European encounter with Islam in this newspaper was in December of 2009, around the publication of Christopher Caldwells Reflections on the Revolution in Europe,and the Swiss referendum banning minarets.In that column I wrote critically about the half-thought-out, deliberately un-democraticimmigration policies the continents leaders had pursued since the 1960s, but I also expressed skepticismabout the scenarios of dhimmitude and Eurabia floated, long before Michel Houellebecqs Submission, by certain voices on the American and European right. From where I stood, neitherdemographic projections nor existing patterns of assimilation nor the continents ideological currents seemed to support a vision of a Europewhere Shariah has as much clout as liberalism by, say, 2045.Instead, I argued that the European future would probably be like the present, only more so:

title: Museum of Modern Art Returns German Artwork to Heirs of Jewish Collector
description: A German Expressionist painting by Ernst Ludwig Kirchner at the Museum of Modern Art will be returned to the heirs of the German art collector Max Fischer, the museum announced Monday.

title: Homework Help, Pixel by Pixel
description: Parents often worry that technology interferes with a childs ability to finish homework, but a number of new tech tools are helping students do their homework faster.

title: Democrats Question Republican-Led Inquiry Into Hillary Clintons Aide
description: Members of the Senate Democratic leadership have raised questions about an inquiry led by Senator Charles E. Grassley into Hillary Rodham Clintons tenure as secretary of state, highlighting what one staff member called a fishy coincidence: that a former aide to Mr. Grassley now works for the State Departments inspector general.

title: Seven Things That Inspire Gaspar No
description: The French-Argentine director Gaspar No has built his career on the gleeful exploration of the fringes of human experience. Films like Irreversible, Enter the Void and the newly released Love plumb the depths of the uncanny, the impolite, the explicit  with an unflinching eye toward the human capacities for both care and cruelty. They are sometimes hard to watch, and always hard to forget. Love is no exception: Nos latest film centers on Murphy, an American living in Paris, and his erotically charged relationships; it features many minutes worth of unsimulated onscreen sex. (It was also filmed in 3D, and if theres anything youre imagining No might exploit that technology to depict, youre probably right.) Here, No shares seven of the artworks, films and people who have influenced his work, from Buuel to Travis Bickle.

title: That Perfume You Smell Everywhere Is Santal 33
description: Back in 2011, when the fragrance industry saw a rise in celebrity scents and relied on the allure of glossy marketing, the independent perfumery Le Labo proposed an antidote to the obsession with hype: quietly releasing its fifth fragrance in five years  completely unaware of the impact its new unisex perfume would have on a certain set (and generation) of style-conscious women. Like an under-the-radar It bag prized for its unidentifiable features and nondescript branding, Santal 33 quickly became a sort of cult secret, whispered through wafts of sandalwood and cedar, only detected by those in the know.

title: For French Team, Playing for Country
description: Hugo Lloris, captain of the French national soccer team, spoke about what it would be like to play Frances match with England on Tuesday in London.

title: Union President, Randi Weingarten, Defends Hillary Clinton on Charter Schools
description: Randi Weingarten, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, defended Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday over critical remarks she made about charter schools, saying the Democratic presidential candidate had voiced a view many hold about such schools.

title: An African King in Bolivia
description: A small-town farmer traces his lineage to a 19th-century African prince who was enslaved and taken to work in the silver mines of Bolivia.

title: Mushroom Essences and More Thanksgiving Helpers
description: It takes but a whiff of two new mushroom elixirs made in the Prigord region of France to understand their vibrant intensity. Added to pan sauces, turkey jus or a toss of sauted mushrooms and green beans, they would contribute depth of flavor. Morilles (morels), and cpes (porcini) are the varieties made by macerating fresh mushrooms in alcohol, then distilling the result, which is 36 proof: Mushroom elixirs by Distillerie du Prigord, 6.8 ounces, $21.98 at Zabars. $25 at earthy.com.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: France and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

title: Nov. 16, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from France, Belgium, the West Bank and Costa Rica.

title: Clashes Erupt During Raid in West Bank
description: Israeli troops killed two Palestinians after armed clashes broke out during a raid of the Qalandiya refugee camp in the West Bank.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Twice-Baked Squash
description: Caitlin Galer-Unti, a food writer, thought that baked butternut squash was so nice, she baked it twice.

title: Chris Stapleton Takes Top Spot on Album Chart Again
description: Sometimes Cinderella is 37 years old, has a scraggly beard and sounds like a cross between George Jones and Otis Redding.

title: Berlin Philharmonics Beethoven Marathon at Carnegie Prompts Some Head-Scratching
description: Taking on Beethovens nine symphonies in a concentrated marathon of concerts has long seemed almost a requisite undertaking for any conductor of stature  the ultimate public statement of artistic gravitas.

title: What Travelers Can Expect in Paris
description: France was the top destination for international tourists last year, in no small part because of Pariss allure. The fatal terrorist attacks in the city on Nov. 13 upended lives and a place that tourists hold dear. Below is information on how hotels and air carriers are accommodating travelers who are affected, when cultural sites are reopening, getting around town and the country and how tourists can do their part to help.

title: Jets Hope Fitzpatricks Thumb Will Be Ready for Sunday
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  After having surgery to repair a torn ligament in his left thumb, Jets quarterback Ryan Fitzpatrick will be ready to start at quarterback Sunday in Houston.

title: For-Profit College Operator EDMC Will Forgive Student Loans
description: The for-profit college operator Education Management Corporation will forgive loans to about 80,000 former students nationwide as part of an agreement with state attorneys general resulting from a multiyear investigation of the companys aggressive recruitment practices.

title: Prominent Iranian Cartoonist Reported Arrested in Tehran
description: A prominent press cartoonist in Iran was arrested at work on Monday by security agents who provided no explanation, according to an Iranian news website and rights activists.

title: Xian Zhang Takes New Jersey Symphony Podium
description: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestras next music director will be familiar to some concertgoers in the region: the orchestra announced Monday that the role would be filled by Xian Zhang, a rising Chinese-American star who was an associate conductor at the New York Philharmonic for several years before concentrating her recent career in Europe.

title: School of Rock and The Color Purple Off to Strong Starts on Broadway
description: Andrew Lloyd Webber and Alice Walker dont have all that much in common, but Broadway seems to be smiling on both of them this fall.

title: Scott Campbells Whole Glory
description: Over four days, the artist gave 23 participants mystery tattoos through a hole in a wall.

title: Painful Choices for Peyton Manning and the Broncos
description: The Denver Broncos and their quarterback Peyton Manning received another reminder on Sunday that Mannings illustrious career might be nearing an end.

title: I Got a Mystery Tattoo From Scott Campbell
description: This past Saturday morning, I got a tattoo from the artist Scott Campbell of Saved Tattoo. Thirty-six hours later, on Sunday night, we met face-to-face for the first time.

title: Paris in Mourning
description: As France observed a moment of silence on Monday, there were signs of communal grief and heightened security in the capial.

title: Prison Town in Colorado Doesnt Want Guantnamo Detainees
description: FLORENCE, Colo.  The Unabomber lives here. So do the men best known as the shoe bomber and the Boston Marathon bomber, as well as a Sept. 11 conspirator and 10,000 other inmates from the infamous to the obscure, sealed behind thick walls and razor-wire fences in the rolling high desert of southern Colorado.

title: Filings Show Rocky Quarter for Many Hedge Funds
description: Some of the richest investors on Wall Street on Monday gave the world a glimpse of how they make their money. Or, in the case of the last quarter, how many of them lost money for their clients.

title: Chris Christie, Taking Law-and-Order Stance, Sidesteps Bridge Scandal in 16 Race
description: Chris Christies voice was level, even soft, as he recalled his precise movements on Sept. 11, 2001. Addressing a Republican conference in Florida, he wove a tale that linked his background as a federal prosecutor to a current need for American resolve overseas, and to what he characterized as wavering leadership by a lawless president.

title: Amid Many Emotions, No Choice for France but to Play
description: LONDON  Sitting at a small table in the news conference room at Wembley Stadium on Monday afternoon, Hugo Lloris, the goalkeeper and captain of Frances national soccer team, listened to the question and frowned. Then he hesitated. Then he shrugged. It was clear he wanted to give the right answer, the supportive answer, the answer the French soccer federation would want him to give. But Lloris wanted to be truthful, too.

title: The Food Police in My Phone
description: It started with a stir fry. I ordered my usual at a nondescript cafe across the street from work: shrimp, tofu, broccoli and snap peas in spicy teriyaki sauce over brown rice.

title: China Bends Vow on Using Prisoners Organs for Transplants
description: BEIJING  When a senior Chinese health official said last year that China would stop using prisoners organs for transplants as of Jan. 1, 2015, human rights advocates and medical professionals around the world greeted the announcement with relief.

title: Governors Against Refugees' Entry
description: Several Republican governors said they opposed letting Syrian refugees enter their states after the terrorist attacks in Paris on Friday.

title: Rap Tees Catalogs Two Decades of Hip-Hop Merchandising
description: The new photo book Rap Tees: A Collection of Hip-Hop T-Shirts 1980-1999 by DJ Ross One documents 500 shirts, from hip-hops dawn  the first item is a Sugar Hill Gang shirt from 1980, a year after that group released Rappers Delight, widely considered the first commercial hip-hop single  to its turn-of-the-millennium ubiquity. All the shirts are advertisements, but they go about their job in vastly different ways: Some emphasize logos, others favor slogans or let photos do the talking; a rare few let artists have their way.

title: The Uncommon Resilience of Parisian Street Life
description: It must be a warm day on the Rue Bichat  a few people have their sleeves rolled up  and the cafes on both sides of the street are open for business, with tables and chairs neatly set up along the sidewalk for customers. Some vendors and deliverymen have left their small carts along the curb. A man, midstride, stares at the camera as he crosses the street, interested in the uncommon event of a photographer setting up his bulky apparatus. A horse-drawn carriage bears a driver and sacks of what appear to be flour or wheat down the Rue Bichat away from its intersection with the Rue Alibert.

title: Special Section: Wired Well
description: Once personal health technology meant little more than bathroom scales, thermometers and electric toothbrushes. Now, these devices and apps are everywhere: on our wrists, in our phones, the bedroom, the kitchen, even on our children and pets. In this special issue of Science Times, we explore the lives of newly wired consumers and the consequences, good and bad, that arise from our increasing reliance on trackers, monitors, guides and a vast array of other devices to better our health.

title: Review: Paul Lewis Powers Through a Beethoven Trilogy at White Light Festival
description: The English pianist Paul Lewis was to have more or less anchored the White Light Festival at Lincoln Center this fall, with major appearances early and late. But appendicitis  prevented him from joining the tenor Mark Padmore in three Schubert song cycles last month.

title: Obama Aims to Shore Up Asian Allies Against Chinese Might
description: ANTALYA, Turkey  President Obamas arrival in the Philippines on Tuesday morning will kick off five days of presidential diplomacy aimed at bolstering Americas allies in the region against Chinas economic and military might.

title: The Designers Behind Building Block Travel to Taiwan
description: Nancy and Kimberly Wu find inspiration  and eat good food  on their recent trip to the country.

title: The Designers Behind Building Block Visit Taiwan
description: Since 2011, the designers Kimberly and Nancy Wu have operated Building Block  an L.A.-based design studio that focuses on minimal accessories: handbags, shoes and goods comprised of leather, rubber and wood. Their studio  a whitewashed room (and former feminist art space) in Chinatown  reflects their attitude toward design: simple, clean, not overdone.

title: More States Are Initiating Programs to Encourage Retirement Savings
description: Nearly 68 million workers do not have access to work-based retirement plans like 401(k)s for companies and 403(b)s for nonprofits and government employees. But that is now changing as more states have begun exploring different ways to create savings vehicles for those not covered by existing tax-deferred savings programs.

title: Pandora Plans to Acquire the Assets of Rdio
description: Since it began 10 years ago, Pandora Media has been focused on one corner of the digital music universe: Internet radio. Now, it is also moving into the world of on-demand music, competing directly with outlets like Spotify and Apple Music.

title: Review: Sinatra: The Chairman, His World, His Way
description: He was Americas greatest vocalist: a consummate artist who redefined the possibilities of popular music, bringing to it an intimacy, an urban swagger and an emotional vulnerability that stamped songs as indelibly his own. A voice  no, the Voice  who could deliver In the Wee Small Hours of the Morning and Ive Got the World on a String with equal authority and self-knowledge. A tough guy with Bond-like sophistication and savoir-faire, who sang with uncommon tenderness about loneliness and yearning. A ring-a-ding-ding Vegas showman, rarely without his posse, who could articulate the heartache and existential solitude of the human condition with more conviction than any singer on the planet.

title: Review: Professor Brenner, a 1911 Play About a Generation Gap
description: The New Worlds Theater Project, which presents English adaptations of Yiddish plays, has an intriguing find in Professor Brenner, a 1911 work by David Pinski that explores a May-December romance. The production isnt great, but the historical perspective has some value.

title: C.I.A. Director Discusses Paris Attacks
description: John O. Brennan, the C.I.A. director, said that the attacks in Paris showed a sophisticated operation and that surveillance internationally had become challenging.

title: Review: The Formulaic Chicago Med Extends an NBC Franchise
description: Most days, Chicago is only the third-largest city in the United States, but beginning this week it may seem as if its the dominant one on Tuesdays, as Chicago Med joins Chicago Fire on NBCs schedule for that night. If Dick Wolf didnt have himself a Chicago franchise before, he certainly does now; hes behind those two shows as well as Chicago P.D. on Wednesdays.

title: Review: Jrme Bels Ballet (New York), an Exercise in Changing Locations
Review: Carol Lipnik, a Bewitching Blend of Comedy and Mysticism
description: Welcome to the sance! the singer, songwriter and performance artist Carol Lipnik exclaimed to a packed house on Sunday evening at the East Village restaurant and cabaret Pangea.

title: Review: Yefim Bronfman Plays Prokofiev at Carnegie, Channeling Rage and Grief
description: Before the pianist Yefim Bronfmans concert on Friday evening at Zankel Hall, Clive Gillinson, executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall, requested a moment of silence in honor of the victims of the terrorist attacks in Paris.

title: Review: David Rabes Good for Otto Introduces a World of Pain
description: CHICAGO  The sound of an orchestra tuning up signals the start of Good for Otto, the new play by David Rabe having its premiere at the small Gift Theater here. Its a smart touch from the director, Michael Patrick Thornton, for Mr. Rabes moving drama does have a symphonic quality, although an apt analogy would be mournful Shostakovich rather than something jubilantly lyrical from, say, Schubert.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Paris, Refugees, Peyton Manning
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: Heidi Latsky Dance and Axis Dance at Skirball Center
description: Anyone walking down LaGuardia Place in Greenwich Village on Sunday night could glimpse Heidi Latskys On Display through the tall glass doors of the Skirball Center for the Performing Arts. That was just one inclusive dimension of this hourlong movement installation, which was the prelude to an evening shared by Heidi Latsky Dance and Axis Dance Company honoring the 25th anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act. Both troupes are made up of dancers with and without disabilities, and reject the notion that disability is a limitation, exploring the potential of many kinds of bodies.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day, including updates on the Paris attacks.

title: Plan for New Stock Exchange Stirs Furious Debate
description: A proposal to create the first new American stock exchange in five years has set off a fierce debate over how to solve problems created by increasingly complex and high-speed stock markets.

title: After Paris Attacks, La Marseillaise Echoes Around the World in Solidarity
description: It rang out at the Metropolitan Opera, with Plcido Domingo conducting, and before performances by the Philadelphia Orchestra, the Lyric Opera of Chicago, the Detroit Symphony Orchestra and others. Muslim leaders sang it in Paris at the scene of one of Fridays deadly terror attacks. Londons Wembley Stadium will display its lyrics on large screens to help English-speaking soccer fans muddle through it Tuesday when England plays France.

title: Amid Tabloid Reports, Charlie Sheen Plans Revealing Personal Announcement
description: LOS ANGELES  As tabloid reports proliferated on Monday that the troubled television star Charlie Sheen plans to soon reveal his HIV-positive status, one of Hollywoods top crisis public relations experts confirmed that representatives for Mr. Sheen had in recent months sought his assistance in disclosing the diagnosis.

title: Paris and Europes Anti-Refugee Backlash
description: Berlin  IN Europe, it took the right and the extreme right just hours to turn the terrible events of Paris into political fodder: On Saturday afternoon in France, Laurent Wauquiez, secretary general of the Republicans, the conservative party of former president Nicolas Sarkozy, demanded detention camps for some 4,000 people in France considered potential terrorists by the authorities.

title: Baltimore Police Assailed for Response After Freddie Grays Death
description: BALTIMORE  The first independent review of the Baltimore Police Departments response to riots in April found major shortcomings and said officers were unprepared and untrained for the scale and scope of the unrest.

title: After Paris Attacks, a Darker Mood Toward Islam Emerges in France
description: PARIS  November is not January. That thought has been filtering through the statements of most French politicians and the news media, and most people seem to understand.

title: Bronx Program Encourages Fathers to Talk About Sex
description: By the time Victor M. Garcia talked to his father about sex, he himself was already a father of four sons.

title: Justice Antonin Scalia Questions Logic Behind Gay Rights Protections
description: The Supreme Courts decisions protecting gay rights were not rooted in the Constitution, and their logic could as easily apply to child molesters, Justice Antonin Scalia told a room filled with first-year law students at Georgetown University on Monday.

title: Artificial Intelligence Draws New Connections for Personalization
description: An effort to get people better boots may say much about the future of artificial intelligence in the business world.

title: Minnesota: Federal Inquiry Sought Into Shooting
description: Mayor Betsy Hodges of Minneapolis called Monday for a federal civil rights investigation into an officer-involved shooting early Sunday. The man who was shot, identified by activists as Jamar Clark, who is African-American, remained hospitalized Monday evening. His father, James Hill, said his son was brain-dead. Neighbors quoted in the local news media said Mr. Clark was handcuffed at the time of the shooting, but the authorities said he was not. The Minneapolis police, who have not publicly named Mr. Clark, said the man was a suspect in an assault who disrupted paramedics treating his victim and then fought with officers. The shooting prompted protests. Federal officials did not immediately issue a public response to Ms. Hodgess request.

title: U.S.T.A. Responds to Eugenie Bouchards Suit Over a Head Injury
description: In response to a lawsuit filed a month ago by Eugenie Bouchard seeking damages for a head injury sustained from a fall during the United States Open, the United States Tennis Association contends that the player did not follow protocol and refused offers of medical attention.

title: Plan to Close Nuclear Plant in Upstate New York Rattles Its Neighbors
description: SCRIBA, N.Y.  The huge concrete cooling tower standing near the shore of Lake Ontario might give chills to visitors catching a first glimpse of it. But to many residents of this semirural section of Oswego County, the two nuclear power plants in town have been a comforting presence.

title: Utah Judge Withdraws in Lesbians Foster Case
description: DENVER  A judge in Utah who drew national scrutiny for ordering a lesbian couple to give up their infant foster child withdrew from the case on Monday.

title: Long Island Family Sues Catholic Order and Diocese in Molestation Case
description: In 2009, Augusto Cortez, a Roman Catholic priest, pleaded guilty to forcible touching of a 12-year-old girl in Brooklyn. He was sentenced to six years of probation but was allowed to remain a member of his religious order.

title: Christopher Kimball, Founder of Americas Test Kitchen, to Leave the Company
description: Christopher Kimball, the face of the public television show Americas Test Kitchen and of the magazine Cooks Illustrated, is leaving the company he helped found after a contract dispute.

title: The Hidden Costs of Terrorism
description: What is the economic cost of terrorism?

title: Lobbyist Cites Unease Over Payments to Sheldon Silver
description: The meeting at the State Capitol in Albany took place nearly four years ago, but Richard Runes, a lobbyist who oversees government relations for Glenwood Management, a major real estate developer in New York, recalled his unease at what he had discussed with Sheldon Silver, then the speaker of the Assembly.

title: Diary of a Food Tracker
description: Research shows that people who keep track of what they eat and weigh on a regular basis are more likely to succeed at losing weight and keeping it off. But as the food diary of Steve Lochner shows, food tracking and weight loss is far from simple.

title: TIAA-CREF, U.S. Investment Giant, Accused of Land Grabs in Brazil
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  As an American investment giant that manages the retirement savings of millions of university administrators, public school teachers and others, TIAA-CREF  prides itself on upholding socially responsible values, even celebrating its role in drafting United Nations principles for buying farmland that promote transparency, environmental sustainability and respect for land rights.

title: Rookie Honors Follow Playoff Trips for Cubs Kris Bryant and Astros Carlos Correa
description: The Houston Astros and the Chicago Cubs combined for 197 losses in 2011. No National League teams were worse, and by December of that year, both teams would have new people running their baseball operations. Jeff Luhnow started fresh in Houston, like Theo Epstein in Chicago, both with the necessities for a methodical rebuild: high draft picks and patience.

title: Martin OMalley Moving Some Campaign Staff to Iowa
description: Martin OMalley is shuffling his presidential campaign, sending some staff members from his Baltimore headquarters to Iowa as he tries to climb out of single digits in the polls, a campaign aide said.

title: Car-Scent Rivals Fight in Trademark Suit
description: In the legal battle of the hanging automotive air fresheners, all that is little are the trees.

title: Trails End Restaurant, Like Much of Montauk, Changes Hands
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.  By many measures  mobbed surf lines, outrageous liquor tabs, noise violations, illegal short-term rentals  this was the biggest summer here  since Carl Fisher failed to turn it into Miami Beach North in the 1920s.

title: G.O.P. Governors Vow to Close Doors to Syrian Refugees
description: Republican fury over illegal immigration and border security took on a new dimension Monday as a growing number of governors, presidential candidates and members of Congress rushed to oppose or even defy President Obamas plan to resettle 10,000 Syrian refugees.

title: Encrypted Messaging Apps Face New Scrutiny Over Possible Role in Paris Attacks
description: WASHINGTON  American and French officials say there is still no definitive evidence to back up their presumption that the terrorists who massacred 129 people in Paris used new, difficult-to-crack encryption technologies to organize the plot.

title: Tree-Shaped Air Freshener Lawsuit
description: Car-Freshner Corporation is suing a competitor that it says used similar packaging, scent names and logos.

title: A Fathers Love of Sports Inspires a Daughters Career
description: Zbigniew Macur, 1933-2015

title: Before Paris Attack, the Bataclan Had Long History in Music and Politics
description: PARIS  Crowds gathered on Monday to place flowers and candles and pay their respects to the 89 people killed at the Bataclan, as speculation swirled about why the legendary music hall was the target of the most brutal of the terrorist attacks on Friday.

title: Marco Rubio Criticizes Ted Cruz on Security Issues
description: Marco Rubio of Florida criticized his Senate colleague Ted Cruz of Texas on Monday night, accusing him of being weak on national security as the presidential race takes a sharper focus on how safe Americans are from attack.

title: Parties Split on Response but United Behind France
description: WASHINGTON  Congress has come a long way from freedom fries.

title: Seizing a Second Chance After a Bout With Cancer
description: In the months after Karen Watson learned she had breast cancer, she tried to shield her three daughters from the daily pain and uncertainty she was living with.

title: Hey, Mister
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  Paula Gamache is back. Are you listening? I said, Paula Gamache is back. And shes all EARs today, so make sure you leave a comment on her Tuesday puzzle.

title: Jane the Virgin Season 2, Episode 6: Jumping Ahead
description: One of the most interesting elements of Jane the Virgin is the pacing. Its always been pretty quick  after all, it is mimicking the style of a telenovela  but in a way that never confuses viewers or feels rushed. Chapter Twenty-Eight uses this rapid-fire approach to its advantage by fast-forwarding through entire months without dropping any important story points. The episode begins the day after the events of last week, immediately reassuring us that baby Mateo is O.K. before jumping into this weeks big plots. Jane is officially starting her life with Michael  and starting graduate school  while getting closer to Rafael, even as the two disagree on finances. Petra has her hands full with Miloss surprise grenades, Michael is on a strange road trip with Nadine, and Rogelio is trying to figure out what his future will be after his television show ends.

title: Study Strongly Links Baltimore Mortgage Denials to Race
description: The black population of Baltimore is double that of the white population. Yet in 2013, banks made more than twice as many mortgage loans to whites in the city as they did to blacks.

title: New York Public Library Acquires Archive of The New York Review of Books
description: The archive of The New York Review of Books has been sold to the New York Public Library, which praised the material in an announcement as providing unique evidence of intellectual life in the United States in the second half of the 20th century.

title: The Paris Attackers: Who Were They?
description: A snapshot of seven men suspected in Fridays terrorist attacks in Paris, including Abdelhamid Abaaoud, a Belgian who is believed to have been the architect of the assaults.

title: In Suspects Brussels Neighborhood, a History of Petty Crimes and Missed Chances
description: BRUSSELS  Just eight days before Ibrahim Abdeslam blew himself up in Paris as part of an elaborate terrorist operation that killed 129 people on Friday, the authorities in the heavily immigrant Brussels district of Molenbeek already had the future terrorist in their sights.

title: In Mexico, Mennonite Farmers Struggle With Water Shortage
description: Underground reservoirs have been drained by thirsty crops, like corn, that are the mainstay of the Mennonites success.

title: Mennonite Farmers Prepare to Leave Mexico, and Competition for Water
description: RIVA PALACIO, Mexico  On the edge of a high plain fringed by craggy sandstone hills, Johan Friesens small farm is a testament to the rural providence of his Mennonite people.

title: Aaron Shikler, Portrait Artist Known for Images of Americas Elite, Dies at 93
description: Aaron Shikler, an artist whose portraits of Americas economic, political and social elite included a brooding John F. Kennedy, a sorrowful Jacqueline Kennedy and a buoyant Ronald Reagan in jeans and work shirt, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.

title: Waiter Killed in Paris Attacks Is Remembered as a Bon Vivant
description: PARIS  A few months ago, when Annabel Mouraud, a waitress, was feeling depressed after losing an uncle to cancer, Guillaume Le Dramp, a fellow waiter, arrived at the restaurant where they worked with a small gift and a wide smile: a childrens book titled Little Miss Lucky.

title: Video of an Arrest in San Francisco Triggers Investigations Into Deputies Use of Force
description: LOS ANGELES  The video footage is grainy, but the violence is clearly visible: When sheriffs deputies catch the suspect fleeing down a San Francisco street, they tackle him, then begin hitting him. First, they use fists, then batons, swinging the clubs down with both hands as the man lies on the ground, moaning.

title: Where ISIS Claims It Has Struck, and Why
description: The attacks in Paris amounted to the boldest coordinated assault claimed by the Islamic State against a Western country, and showed how the radical militant group has expanded from its beginnings as a Sunni terrorist group in Iraq.

title: Fargo Season 2, Episode 6: Defending the Common Man
description: The turf war between the Gerhardts and the Kansas City syndicate  incidentally, the Kansas City Syndicate sounds like another prog-rock band  continued to escalate in Rhinoceros, an action-packed hour that seems of a piece with last weeks episode, which found the show shifting to backstretch payoff mode. It even begins on the Blumquists porch, reversing the angle of last weeks final shot of Luverne policemen coming for Ed.

title: Donald Trump Questions Whether Syrian Refugees Are a Trojan Horse
description: Donald J. Trump questioned whether Syrian refugees are part of a Trojan horse plot, suggested buying land in Syria to create a safe space and said that in 2000 he could feel that terrorists were going to strike in the United States, as he rallied a large crowd of supporters in Tennessee on Monday evening.

title: Paris Attacks Complicate Europes Already Strained Border Controls
description: The news that one of the Paris attackers entered Europe with a Syrian passport last month, amid the hundreds of thousands of refugees fleeing war and persecution, has alarmed leaders and reinvigorated talk about tightening border controls.

title: Yankees Hire Bullpen Coach
description: The Yankees hired Mike Harkey as their bullpen coach, completing their coaching staff for next season. Harkey, 49, who served in the same role for the Yankees from 2008 to 2013, was fired as the Arizona Diamondbacks pitching coach after the season. He replaces Gary Tuck, whom the Yankees fired last month.

title: A Survivors Story: Im Coming Home
description: Franois Granier, 24, went to the Bataclan concert hall in Paris on Friday night. After gunfire erupted, he grabbed a bloodied drumstick from backstage. I know its pathetic, but this was one of the things that allowed me to try to keep some hope, he said.

title: Casper Hopes Its One for All Concept Translates to One Pillow
description: Jeff Chapin, the chief product officer at Casper, has 30 prototype pillows strewn around his bedroom. One of them, the end result of a design and testing process that lasted more than a year, is what Casper hopes will be the holy grail of bedding: one pillow, perfect for all sleepers.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | floe
description: floe  \flo\  noun

title: Texas: Tornado Rips Through Halliburton Plant
description: A tornado ripped through a Halliburton plant an hour northeast of Amarillo on Monday, causing a chemical leak that emergency crews were working to contain, the authorities said. The Gray County Sheriffs Office said two deputies who were exposed to the chemical, which was unspecified, refused medical treatment. There were no reports of injuries. Lt. Zach Kidd said no one was inside the building, in Pampa, Tex., when the tornado struck, and several vehicles parked outside were unoccupied. Radioactive material housed at the site was not affected, he said. The tornado was one of four that touched down in the county as a severe weather system moved across the region, according to the sheriffs office. Two homes and several businesses sustained damage ranging from minor to severe, officials said.

title: Syria: Iran Reaffirms a Role for Assad
description: An Iranian official said Monday that President Bashar al-Assad of Syria should remain in power and be included in elections as part of any diplomatic negotiation aimed at ending the civil war. The statement, by Hossein Amir Abdollahian, a deputy foreign minister, was not a new position for Iran, Mr. Assads regional ally. But it reinforced the deep divide that remains over Mr. Assads future in the international talks on Syria, even as pressure has intensified for a solution. Diplomats participating in the talks in Vienna over the weekend represented more than a dozen countries, including the United States, which has said Mr. Assad cannot be part of any final settlement. Mr. Abdollahian was quoted by Irans Fars News Agency as saying Iran ensured that a statement issued at the meetings conclusion excluded any language that would limit Mr. Assads role in a postwar government.

title: What to Watch Tuesday
description: Dick Wolf adds more Windy City bluster to the Tuesday night lineup; Frontline looks at tots in terrorist training; and Valery Gergiev takes on Prokofievs five piano concertos  all at once.

title: Presidential Candidates on Allowing Syrian Refugees in the United States
description: The campaign shifted focus to national security after the Paris attacks.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Terrorism will not destroy the republic, because it is the republic that will destroy it.

title: Corrections: November 17, 2015
description: NATIONAL

title: Stephen Colbert, Jimmy Fallon and Other Late-Night Hosts Respond to the Paris Attacks
description: Reacting to the Paris terrorist attacks presented a particular challenge for Americas late-night TV entertainers. On the one hand, their programs thrive on topicality, offering nightly national forums where current events are assessed in comforting, lighthearted tones. On the other hand, these shows are often careful to avoid tragic subjects where seemingly no comedy can be found.

title: With Modigliani Purchase, Chinese Billionaire Dreams of Bigger Canvas
description: BEIJING  Even as the cost of his quarry pulled away from the $100 million mark, Liu Yiqian remained calm.

title: Finding Peace Within the Holy Texts
description: Its easy to think that ISIS is some sort of evil, medieval cancer that somehow has resurfaced in the modern world. The rest of us are pursuing happiness, and here comes this fundamentalist anachronism, spreading death.

title: Bad Debt Collectors and Their Prey
description: All states have laws that are intended to prevent debt collectors from driving families into destitution. But those laws, some of which date to the distant past, have been rendered ineffective by debt collectors using new and devious ways to win court judgments that allow them to seize debtors paychecks or bank accounts.

title: After Paris Attacks, Vilifying Refugees
description: Battening down the hatches is often an impulsive and politically expedient response to terrorism attacks. Predictably, the harrowing scenes of carnage in Paris on Friday are fueling calls to shut down borders and halt the resettlement of Syrian refugees in Western nations.

title: How to Help Save the Mentally Ill From Themselves
description: MY older son, Matthew Ornstein, died at age 34 on Jan. 3 from carbon monoxide poisoning. It was accidental  he fell asleep in a tent with a propane lantern  but his death was shaped by a lack of judgment driven by a 10-year struggle with mental illness.

title: Inadequate Transportation Bills in Congress
description: Congress could approve a six-year transportation bill by the end of this week, when authorization for federal transportation programs expires. Unfortunately, the legislation will not do nearly enough to improve aging bridges, fix highways or expand the capacity of mass transit and rail systems. Worse, it could make traveling on American roads and railways less safe.

title: Were Living Longer. Thats Great, Except for Social Security.
description: I wrote last week about rising life expectancy: Children born today will most likely live on average to their late 80s, well above the current average life expectancy of 79. You probably think of this as good news, and from most perspectives, it is.

title: In Bangladesh, a Half-Century of Saving Lives With  Data
description: NABAKALASH, Bangladesh  Sufia Khatun wears a green sari around her thin 76-year-old frame. Round gold-rimmed glasses perch on her wizened face. When she smiles, she reveals teeth stained brown from betel nut. She has lived all her life in this village in Matlab, a sub-district in central Bangladesh.

title: The Invisible Power of Tchotchkes
description: One of the joys of being a psychotherapist is the opportunity to weave creativity into the healing process. In my practice, for example, I learned by accident the power of fiddling with small toys.

title: Is the Fight Against ISIS the West's Fight?
Heavy Gunfire Erupts as French Police Seek Suspects in Raid
description: PARIS  The police stormed the northern Paris suburb of St.-Denis before dawn Wednesday morning in a raid aimed at capturing at least two fugitives suspected in the terrorist attacks that killed 129 people in Paris on Friday.

title: Russia Allies With France Against ISIS, Saying Jet That Crashed in Sinai Was Bombed
description: MOSCOW  Russia on Tuesday said that it was coordinating with the French military in sharply ratcheting up attacks on Syrian territory, especially areas held by the Islamic State, as the government for the first time acknowledged that a bomb had destroyed a Russian charter jet  that crashed more than two weeks ago in Egypt.

title: Frances War Within
description: PARIS  Sunday was a lovely, sunny day in Paris. People ventured out in the morning to buy the papers and a baguette. Some, more numerous than usual, went to church. By midday, Parisians were out in droves, enjoying this unusually mild weather  joggers, families with strollers, groups of friends meeting up for lunch, couples sipping ros on caf terraces.

title: News Qs | Anne Franks Diary Gains Co-Author in Copyright Move
description: Before Reading Anne Franks Diary Gains Co-Author in Copyright Move:

title: Recent Setbacks Cast Harsh Light on Cyrus Vance, the Manhattan Prosecutor
description: As the district attorney of Manhattan, Cyrus R. Vance Jr. enjoys the spotlight of being a top prosecutor in the nations financial capital.

title: Street-Style Star Linda Rodin on Growing Older
description: Linda Rodin began her beauty empire in 2007 with a single product. Rodin Olio Lusso, a blend of essential oils, with sleek Art Deco-inspired packaging, was an instant hit in fashion and beauty circles. In turn, Ms. Rodin, a former model, boutique owner and stylist, became a kind of street-style icon, with her signature gray hair, oversize glasses and red lipstick. Ms. Rodins first cleanser was introduced last month. She spoke about finding the perfect formula for it, a fondness for clumpy mascara and her philosophy on aging.

title: Microsoft Sheds Reputation as an Easy Mark for Hackers
description: REDMOND, Wash.  Microsoft was once the epitome of everything wrong with security in technology. Its products were so infested with vulnerabilities that the companys co-founder, Bill Gates, once ordered all of Microsoft engineers to stop writing new code for a month and focus on fixing the bugs in software they had already built.

title: Brazils Marcelo Melo Rises to No. 1 in Mens Doubles
description: LONDON  Only eight nations have captured the World Cup in mens soccer in 85 years of competition, with Brazils five titles topping the leaderboard.

title: What Role Should the Police Have in Schools?
description: Last month a police officer was called in after a student refused to leave a classroom in a South Carolina school. What happened next made national headlines because of viral videos that showed the officer grabbing an African-American student by the neck, flipping her backward as she sat at her desk, then dragging and throwing her across the floor.

title: Block by Block | Jackson Heights
description: The Queens neighborhood of Jackson Heights combines ethnic diversity with private gardens and still-affordable apartments.

title: Block by Block: Jackson Heights
description: Jackson Heights, Queens, is the focus of the next video in our monthly series, Block by Block. Watch for future installments from neighborhoods around the city.

title: Paris Attacks Complicate Hillary Clintons Alignment With Obama
description: In her pursuit of the Democratic nomination for president, Hillary Rodham Clinton has emphasized her ties to President Obama. She regularly tells the story of how he wooed her into serving as his secretary of state and recites, typically to a roar of applause, the line, President Obama doesnt get the credit he deserves.

title: An African King in Bolivia
description: Tucked away in an isolated part of Bolivia, there is a royal family whose existence is as surprising as it is humble. Despite his title, King Don Julio I and his wife live in a small apartment atop a small store in Mururata, Bolivia, where he farms coca leaves and other crops.

title: How They Dress Up for the Non-Office
description: At NeueHouse, a co-working space in Manhattan, the dress code is creative and personal.

title: Sarah Vowells Lafayette in the Somewhat United States
description: The full name was Marie-Joseph-Paul-Yves-Roch-Gilbert du Motier, which was quite a mouthful for Yankee sensibilities, but the Marquis de Lafayette became one of the first American celebrities anyway. (The new nation had a sweet tooth for the flattery of Frenchmen. Thats also how Tocqueville managed to freeload his way across the Northwest Territories.) Lafayette came over the Atlantic to fight in the American Revolution when he was 19. He went home to France and tried to be a centrist politician during that countrys upheaval. This was rather like aspiring to be a pot roast in a den of wolverines. But he survived the Revolution and the Terror, turned down a job in Napoleons government, and in 1824, he returned to the United States at the invitation of James Monroe. He visited all 24 of the states at the time. The tour took more than a year, and Lafayette was cheered at every stop. He survived the sinking of his steamboat in the Ohio River, and lived to help lay the cornerstone of the Bunker Hill Monument in Charlestown, Mass. He also survived an oration by Daniel Webster on that same occasion.

title: Chicagonomics and Economics Rules
description: He believed that government had a crucial role to play in a well-functioning economy. It should finance and run good schools, as well as build roads, bridges and parks, he argued. It should tax alcohol, sugar and tobacco, all of which impose costs on society. It should regulate businesses to protect workers. And it should tax the rich  who suffer from indolence and vanity  to help the poor.

title: Aung San Suu Kyi, Long a Symbol of Dignified Defiance, Sounds a Provocative Note
description: NAYPYIDAW, Myanmar  For two decades, Daw Aung San Suu Kyi was a radiant symbol of dignified nonviolent resistance, most of that time confined to house arrest by the generals who have governed Myanmar for half a century.

title: Cease-Fire and Political Transition in Syria Crucial to Defeating ISIS, Kerry Says
description: PARIS  The United States, France and Russia must step up their coordination in striking the Islamic State in Syria after the Paris terrorist attacks, Secretary of State John Kerry said on Tuesday, but he insisted that cooperation cannot begin until there is a cease-fire and a political transition.

title: Diary of a Supertracker
description: Ever since the 17th-century physician Santorio Santorio created an elaborate weighing chair and recorded all that he ate for next 30 years, people have been tracking their diets.
