description: Gov. John R. Kasich of Ohio takes the stage at the National Press Club in Washington on Tuesday to talk foreign policy, and his remarks are likely to showcase how quickly the national security landscape has shifted in just a couple of months.

title: Morning Agenda: The Economic Cost of Terrorism
description: THE ECONOMIC COST OF TERRORISM  | After the horrific attacks in Paris, it is an issue that policy makers are grappling with,Andrew Ross Sorkin writes in the DealBook column.

title: With China in Mind on a Visit to Manila, Obama Pledges Military Aid to Allies in Southeast Asia
description: MANILA  Standing in front of a former United States Coast Guard ship that is now the flagship of the Philippine Navy, President Obama on Tuesday sent a message intended for a single country: China.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: Paris Attacks Complicate Obamas Guantnamo Plans
description: Syrian refugees are not the only possible new arrivals that Republicans want to keep out of the United States. The terror detainees remaining at the prison in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, are also not welcome, and Republicans say the Paris attacks will keep them that way.

title: Saving the World, Startup-Style
description: In 2010, not long after the earthquake hit Haiti, I was about an hour north of Port-au-Prince, standing under a mango tree. Its owner, a woman named Jelen, was telling me that she had two daughters but could afford to send only one to school. She knew this meant the other would be poor, like her, for the rest of her life. She said she was choosing the younger one because she was smarter. She then pointed at her mango tree. It was huge, bigger than a family home, and grew hundreds of mangoes each year. She knew that those mangoes could sell for several dollars each in America, but there was no easy way to get them there. So she sold most of them down the road at a local market for pennies. If she could find a good way to get those mangoes down the highway to the capital and then on a ship to America, she was confident that she could make enough money to send both her girls to school.

title: Poll Watch: U.S. Public Uneasy With ISIS Strategy Even Before Paris Attacks
description: The terrorist attacks in Paris last week have renewed criticism of President Obama for his strategy in fighting the Islamic State. But a New York Times/CBS News poll released just before the attacks found that Americans were already unhappy with the presidents approach to the radical Islamist group, also known as ISIS or ISIL.

title: Making Bathrooms More Accommodating
description: The clearest visual markers of sex difference many of us see in the course of the day are the signs on public bathroom entrances: MEN on one door, WOMEN on the other. Restrooms are public conveniences, freely available in most places and in principle open to all, but the terms for entering them have been fixed. Theyre fundamentally fraught spaces, where we undress and obey the dictates of our bodies and therefore feel vulnerable. If people think youve confused male and female and walked through the wrong door, you risk discomfort, or even real trouble. This can lead to the spectacle of women standing in line for what feels like forever while the mens room is empty. Now transgender people, most prominently, are asking society to rethink all of this, from signs to design to who gets to enter where.

title: Don Lemon Doesnt Get Offended
description: You have asked some of the most memorable questions in cable-news history, I would say. So what would you ask yourself? I would ask: Why on earth would anyone want to do this job?

title: In Iceland, a Literary Tour Explores Rich History
description: Standing in the dark outside the Reykjavik public library in the relentless damp chill that comes with a light rain at 40 degrees, I kept trying to zip up my jacket. The charcoal sky was a shade lighter than the inky ocean a few blocks away, but it was noon, not twilight. I had a few minutes to bundle up before an outdoor walking tour on literary Iceland began. As if on cue, the zipper snapped off in my hand.

title: Andrew Lloyd Webber: Lord, Baron, Rocker
description: At a recent rehearsal for his new Broadway musical, School of Rock, Andrew Lloyd Webber came striding down the aisle of the Winter Garden Theater and onto its stage. He was there to give adjustments to a quartet of adolescent musicians playing a tweenage heavy-metal band in this adaptation of the 2003 Jack Black comedy.

title: U.S. Navy Ship, Bearing Message of Good Will, Docks in China
description: SHANGHAI  The sister ship of an American guided missile destroyer that sailed last month in waters claimed by China is in Shanghai for a weeklong port visit, in a sign that although the United States strongly disagrees with actions by China in the South China Sea, their two navies still value good relations.

title: Earnest, Fueled by Growth in Student Loans, Raises $275 Million
description: At the start of this year, Earnest was an intriguing but small entrant in an emerging field of start-ups using new tools of data and software to analyze credit risk and make consumer loans. Its loans were typically a few thousand dollars for things like relocation expenses and professional training.

title: UBS Agrees to Buy Santanders Private Banking Arm in Italy
description: LONDON  UBS said on Tuesday that its Italian wealth management arm had agreed to acquire the private banking unit of the Spanish lender Banco Santander in Italy.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 10-16, 2015
description: Have you been following this weeks news? If you have, youll understand why much of this quiz is devoted to the Paris attacks. Here are more teaching resources that may help.

title: The Farce Is Strong In This One
description: And that one, and that one, and, well, across the board.

title: What Early Job Later Informed Your Work as a Writer?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Francine Prose and Leslie Jamison discuss early jobs that later influenced their work.

title: After Paris, Who Passes the Commander in Chief Test?
description: Ordinary observers dont need to try to explain the consequences of the attacks in Paris that killed 129 people on Friday night. But presidential candidates do.

title: Close but Not Quite
description: For the polished prose we seek, precision in word choice is just as important as sound grammar. Here are a number of recent missteps, most of them familiar. Not sure? Look it up!

title: Win in Todays N.F.L.? Lend Me a Tight End!
description: Tight ends have become the keys that unlock a modern N.F.L. defense. Dont lend me a tenor  lend me a tight end!

title: Charlie Sheen Says He Has H.I.V. and Has Paid Millions to Keep It Secret
description: The troubled television star Charlie Sheen revealed his H.I.V.-positive status on Tuesday, saying that he had paid people upward of $10 million to keep quiet about his condition and that he wanted to put a stop to this onslaught, this barrage of attacks and of subtruths and very harmful and mercurial stories that are about me.

title: Verbatim: Obama Says Race vs. Trump Wouldve Been Fun
description: President Obama, in an interview with GQ magazine.

title: Belles Are Still Ringing
description: Dear Diary:

title: Court Filing on Mortgage Fraud Case
description: Apparent missteps by the office of the district attorney of Manhattan, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., involving a Chinatown bank raise questions about the trial readiness of his prosecutors.

title: How They Dress Up for the Non-Office
description: No one works in PJs here. NeueHouse, a shared office space for creative freelancers, bills itself as a home for the ambitious and the curious. In a loftlike space on East 25th Street, this location of the members-only club was buzzing with fashion editors, art consultants and other solopreneurs on a recent lunch hour. They revealed how they got dressed for work that day. See the photos.

title: Terrible Defense Leads Saints to Fire Rob Ryan
description: Late Monday, the New Orleans Saints finally parted ways with defensive coordinator Rob Ryan. The move was a reaction to a historically poor defensive performance on Sunday in Washington. Against a mediocre Redskins offense, New Orleans allowed over 300 passing yards and over 200 rushing yards, while giving up 8.9 yards per offensive play. The Saints defense is just the sixth since 1970 to allow an opposing offense to hit those three marks in a single game.

title: Are We at a New Stage in the Age of Celebrity Brand Ambassadors?
description: New York magazine has released its Most Valuable Stars of 2015 list, and it makes for interesting reading  both from a where are the women? point of view (of the top 50, only 15 are women, although Jennifer Lawrence is No. 1) and for anyone considering the fashion-beauty-Hollywood nexus.

title: Strong Sales at Walmart, Home Depot and TJX
description: Robust sales numbers from Walmart, Home Depot and TJX on Tuesday are helping to ease concerns over the American consumers health in the countdown to the Black Friday sales.

title: The Wals and the Marts
description: Walmart, Walgreens, Kmart  they all sound slightly related.

title: Nomura Hires Six Bankers in Effort to Expand in Americas
description: The Japanese financial firm Nomura has hired yet more deal makers for the Americas, as it continues to push for a share of the investment banking pie in the region.

title: When TV Turns Itself Off
description: Must the show go on? After Fridays terrorist massacre in Paris, as often happens after violent tragedies, a few shows didnt. CBS announced that it would replace scheduled Monday episodes of Supergirl (whose plot concerned a series of urban bombings), and NCIS: Los Angeles (involving a possible terrorist recruitment scheme). TNT, likewise, pulled a Monday episode of the F.B.I. drama Legends, which reportedly depicted a terrorist shooting in Paris.

title: Daily Report: Microsoft Finds Its Security Groove
description: It was a given in the technology industry for many years that if you wanted to find a company that excelled at computer security, you ought not look for it in Redmond, Wash., the home of Microsoft.

title: Blindspot Season 1, Episode 9: Dressing Up
description: Forget the dress-up-night fun; the first 58 minutes of Monday nights Blindspot on NBC were blown right out of our heads by the last two minutes. David? One of the shows best characters? Killed? Heartbreaking. I couldnt quite tell if Guerrero was also killed in those final moments or merely wounded, but either way, the series certainly woke us all up, didnt it?

title: Robert Califf, F.D.A. Nominee, Queried on Industry Ties
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas nominee to lead the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Robert M. Califf, coasted through a confirmation hearing on Tuesday, with most members of a Senate committee  including some who have been skeptical about his ties to the pharmaceutical industry  seeming set to support his candidacy.

title: Caeden, a Wearable Tech Start-Up, Introduces a Smart Bracelet
description: Just about every major tech company, like Apple and Microsoft, has some sort of wearable computer. Caeden, a wearabletech start-up, thinks that with most of these smartwatches and fitness accessories, an important first step was skipped: They dont look like something youwouldwant to wear.

title: Terrorists and Aliens
description: The Great Depression wasnt ended by the intellectual victory of Keynesian economics; in fact, the publication of The General Theory was followed by the great mistake of 1937, when FDR tried to balance the budget too soon and send the U.S. economy into a severe recession. What put a decisive end to the slump was World War II, which led to deficit spending on a scale that was politically impossible before.

title: Goldman Sachs Casts Focus onMillennial Women
description: Goldman Sachs bankers are trying to crack the secret habits of a potentially lucrative species of retail shopper: millennial women.

title: In Las Vegas, a Lucky Streak for Developers
description: It wasnt too long ago that the Las Vegas Strip resembled a red-hot craps table right after the dice came up seven, sweeping all the chips to the house. When the financial crisis shut off capital, billions of dollars wagered on casino resort and high-rise condominium developments vanished from the Strip.

title: 10 U.F.C. Fighters Vying to Fill Gap Left by Ronda Rousey
description: The queen is dead. Long live ... who?

title: Ask Well: Eye Twitches
description: Question:

title: 1940: Italians Bomb Foes
description: ROME  New triumphs for Italys aviators were reported today [Nov. 17] by the army high command, which said that in Greece, where attacks and counter-attacks were especially fierce in the sector of the 9th army, Italian aviation bombed roads, railways, enemy positions and artillery posts, causing fires and explosions. The port of Alexandria and the harbor of Suda, in Crete, have again been bombed, it was said, as well as British bases in Egypt. In Egypt, it was announced, our aviation has bombed bases at El Daba and Maaten Bagush, equipment at Mersa Matruh and the railroad from there to Bir Amasin.  New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 18, 1940

title: A Birthday With a Foster Family, and Away From a Birth Family
description: Mommy! I need to ask you something! My 5-year-old biological son, Ryan, runs over to me in the kitchen and furiously motions for me to lean over so he can whisper in my ear.

title: Pakistan Military Expands Its Power, and Is Thanked for Doing So
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The most popular man in public office in Pakistan does not give speeches on television, rarely appears in public and rejects news interviews.

title: 1965: Youths Spit at Rusk and R.F.K.
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Leftist youths spat at both Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Sen. Robert F. Kennedy yesterday [Nov. 16] in two separate incidents. Mr. Rusk, on his way to an inter-American conference here, had stopped in Montevideo, when he was attacked by an 18-year-old youth who shouted: This is in the name of my people. The youth, who spat toward Mr. Rusk, was quickly subdued by police. Sen. Kennedy was spat upon by University of Chile students, who also threw eggs and stones at him in Conception. Sen. Kennedy controlled his anger. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 18, 1965

title: Dana Cowin Stepping Down as Food & Wine Editor
description: Dana Cowin, who has been the editor in chief of Food & Wine magazine for 21 years, is stepping aside. But she will maintain a connection with Food & Wine.

title: Review: Boston Lyric Operas In the Penal Colony, a Surreal Exploration of Injustice
description: BOSTON  Philip Glass has rewritten his Civil War opera, Appomattox, for the Black Lives Matter era. But the troubled Boston Lyric Operas enthralling new site-specific production of his In the Penal Colony, a 2000 chamber opera with a libretto by Rudolph Wurlitzer, takes a different approach to making Mr. Glasss work relevant to contemporary debates.

title: Review: The Astronaut Love Show, Tales of Not So Magnificent Obsession
description: The German cannibal who ate his willing victim rang only a distant bell for me, and Im pretty sure Id never heard of the besotted blonde who may or may not have kidnapped a Mormon missionary. But the astronaut who raced 900 miles to Florida to challenge her romantic rival in an airport parking lot  well, who doesnt remember her?

title: Hong Kong Soccer Fans Celebrate Draw With China
description: Before he boarded a flight to the Philippines on Monday for a meeting with other Asia-Pacific leaders, Hong Kongs chief executive, Leung Chun-ying, read a statement to reporters explaining the purpose of his trip. Bilateral talks. Trade agreements. More bilateral talks.

title: Early Prostate Cancer Cases Fall Along With Screening
description: Fewer men are being screened for prostate cancer, and fewer early-stage cases are being detected, according to two studies published Tuesday in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

title: Anger and Doubt Rise After Idaho Mans Fatal Encounter With Deputies
description: COUNCIL, Idaho  The Yantis family was at dinner when the telephone rang. A bull owned by Jack Yantis, 62, had been struck by a vehicle on Route 95, which cuts through Yantis land. He needed to come down.

title: Frances Anthem, La Marseillaise, Unites Soccer Rivals
description: As Michael Cooper noted in The New York Times, the French national anthem, La Marseillaise, has emerged as a symbol of defiance and hope in the wake of the terrorist attacks in Paris last week.

title: Racism on Campus: Stories From New York Times Readers
description: Student demonstrations at the University of Missouri after months of protests over racial issues led to the resignations of the university systems president and the chancellor of the main campus. Those protests and others have provoked a debate over racism and free speech at colleges across the United States.

title: 1923: The Hitchhiker Hits the Road
description: This feature looks at some of the earliest mentions of famous names or terms in The Times.

title: Lunch With Ruth Bader Ginsburg and Gloria Steinem? You Bet
description: It starts as a parlor game. Name two famous people youd love to take to lunch. And dont be shy about swinging for the fences. Make them people you really admire: writers, politicians, actors, musicians, athletes. (They should probably have something in common  or as my editors, Stuart Emmrich and Laura Marmor, put it: A picture of them together should make intuitive sense to readers, even if theyre not sure exactly why.)

title: Billions of People Depend on Water From Shrinking Snowpacks
description: Snowpacks are a vital source of water for humans, but they may shrink in some regions as the climate warms. A new study estimates how changes in showfall will affect water supplies.

title: Failed 2008 Cooling Prediction Shows Short-Term Climate Forecasts Remain a Bad Bet
description: The basics of global warming science remain robust  more greenhouse gases will continue to heat the planet, erode ice, raise seas and present challenges to many human and ecological communities.

title: Montereys New Popularity Means New Hotel Deals
description: Monterey County, spanning Californias central coast from Moss Landing to Big Sur, is seeing more tourists in the winter months, once a slow season for the region. According to the Monterey County Convention and Visitors Bureau, hotel occupancy in the area increased an average of 17 percent from 2011 to 2014 from December to February.

title: Museum of the City of New York Names New Director
description: The Museum of the City of New York has selected a new director, its board announced on Tuesday.

title: Republicans Call for Halt to Syrian Refugee Program
description: WASHINGTON  Seizing on the terrorist attacks in Paris, congressional Republicans on Tuesday demanded the suspension of a program to accept Syrian refugees in the United States, but along with Democrats, they continued to shy away from explicit authorization of military force to confront the Islamic State.

title: Only a Decade to Go on the New Hudson Tunnel
description: After a slow start, a series of unhelpful political squabbles and an early fumble by Governor Chris Christie of New Jersey, a massive $20 billion tunnel project under the Hudson River may finally be underway. Prodded by Senator Charles Schumer, the disparate parties have agreed to step one: They have set up a corporation to oversee this ten-year project. This is good news, even if there are still plenty of years and hurdles to go.

title: Hillary Clinton Gets Important Labor Backing From S.E.I.U.
description: The Service Employees International Union, one of the largest and most politically influential unions, threw its support behind Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday, the latest indication that she is consolidating support among the institutional pillars of the Democratic Party.

title: From Sedona to the Breakers, Spas With a Sense of Place
description: Sylvia Sepielli firmly believes that a spa should channel the history, culture and spirit of a region. Im very sensitive when something feels out of place, she said. If you dont have a visceral memory of a place that includes the sights and sounds and smells and feels and textures, it doesnt really stay with you very long.

title: Twyla Tharp on Tour: The Right to Assemble
description: Twyla Tharp is writing about rehearsing, touring and creating new work, 50 years after her first dance concert.

title: One Parent, on Paris: They Might Have Guns, but We Have Flowers
description: Standing in Paris, his toddler in his arms, one dad answers the question we all ask: How do I talk to my child about terrorism? About bad guys with guns? About war and death and tragedy?

title: Dance This Week: From Modern to Tango to Flamenco
Guinea, Last Nation With Ebola, May Soon Be Declared Free of Virus
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The worst Ebola outbreak in history took a big step toward ending on Tuesday when Guinea, the only nation where the virus had been lingering, began its official countdown to being declared free of the disease.

title: New Radio Ad Hammers Marco Rubio Over Immigration, on Ted Cruzs Behalf
description: The newest super PAC supporting Senator Ted Cruz will run a radio commercial in Iowa excoriating Senator Marco Rubio by describing his work to pass a comprehensive immigration reform bill in 2013 as an amnesty scheme and part of a pact with President Obama.

title: City Center Encores! Unscripted': A Talk Show About Musical Theater
description: City Center Encores!, the program that stages revivals of rarely seen but beloved Broadway shows, is partnering with the Jerome L. Greene Space at WNYC to create a new talk show about musical theater.

title: Review: In Crackles The Art of More, the White Gloves Come Off
description: We love to despise absurdly rich people and revel in their misfortunes, but have we spent enough time doing the same for the enablers of absurdly rich people  sellers of yachts, operators of polo clubs, designers of $10,000 gowns? Probably not. The Art of More, a tasty new drama on Crackle, is determined to make up for this oversight.

title: International Center of Photography Gets Grant from Mellon Foundation
description: The International Center of Photography, which is in the process of reinventing itself in a new home scheduled to open next year on the Bowery, has received a $750,000 grant from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation that will be used to create what the organization calls a Center for Visual Culture, a specialized program focusing on how photographic imagery functions in 21st-century life.

title: Afghan Jobs Program Aims to Stem Exodus of Young
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Ashraf Ghani on Tuesday began a modest jobs program to try to stem an exodus of young Afghans to Europe and restore some faith in the struggling government and economy.

title: A Proposed Smoking Ban in Public Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Greece and Eurozone Creditors in Deal to Unlock $13 Billion
description: ATHENS  Greece and its international creditors said on Tuesday that they had reached agreement on the countrys next round of economic changes, a deal that is meant to unlock as much as 12 billion euros, or about $13 billion, in loan money.

title: Hiroji Kubota, Photographer
description: Hiroji Kubotas path to Magnum started in Japan when he worked as a fixer and translator for members of the legendary agency.

title: City to Pay $5.3 Million to End Suits Over 2 Rikers Inmates Deaths
description: The city has agreed to pay a total of more than $5 million to settle separate lawsuits brought by the families of two Rikers Island inmates who died while in custody at the jail complex, officials said on Tuesday.

title: Prosecutors Outline Corruption Trial for Senator Skelos and His Son
description: A prosecutor told jurors on Tuesday in the federal corruption trial of State Senator Dean G. Skelos and his son that they would hear the age-old tale of abuse of political power to satisfy personal greed, while the pairs lawyers suggested that the government was trying to criminalize both legitimate politics and a father-son relationship.

title: Tempura Matsui
description: A Japanese kaiseki meal with a focus on fried food in Murray Hill.

title: Germany-Netherlands Match Canceled Over Security Concerns
description: Germanys exhibition soccer match against the Netherlands was canceled less than two hours before kickoff on Tuesday, becoming the second marquee game called off in two days in increasingly edgy Europe.

title: China Faces Sharp Questioning by U.N. Panel on Torture
description: GENEVA  China faced robust questioning from United Nations human rights experts on Tuesday as it sought to defend its record on torture and to make the case that it had achieved important progress promoting human rights and with government based on the rule of law.

title: At Tempura Matsui in Murray Hill, the Pleasures Lie Within
description: After looking over the menu at Tempura Matsui, the woman at the end of the counter made an announcement that would turn out to be catastrophic for her dinner plans.

title: Univision Names a Chief Digital Officer
description: The Spanish-language broadcaster Univision Communications announced Tuesday that it had named Isaac Lee to the new position of chief digital officer.

title: N.H.L. This Week: Kane and Rangers Aim to Keep Streaks Alive
description: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot  or not so hot  teams and players.

title: Victims of VW Scandal May Be Eclipsed by Lawsuit Underwriters
description: The real victims of Volkswagens diesel-emissions scandal may end up being eclipsed in court.

title: The Vile Politics of the Syrian Refugee Crisis [Updated]
description: Since 1975, the United States has resettled more than three million refugees. They have contributed to the economy and culture of all 50 states.As hundreds of thousands of Syrians have fled their war-ravaged homeland, a growing number of American politicians  including more than half of the nations governors are responding with unspeakable cruelty.

title: Greer Love Letter to Amis Sheds Light on Relationship
description: LONDON  An academic and journalist at the University of Melbourne has unearthed a book-length love letter from the feminist author Germaine Greer to the novelist Martin Amis.

title: Gold-Tone Makeup Glitters for the Holidays
description: If theres ever a time to gild the lily, the holiday season is it. No wonder that luxury makeup companies are unveiling a trove of gold products for nails, lips, eyes and the face. And while they are surely festive, most are not too extreme for day, in finishes that lean more toward a shimmery flourish than a bold statement.

title: Art That Blurs the Line Between Painting and Sculpture
description: Anthony Pearson works in carving  perhaps one of the most ancient artistic mediums  but his practice puts heavy emphasis on new technologies. In his warehouse-sized studio in Los Angeles last month, ahead of his eponymous show opening this week at Marianne Boesky in New York, Pearson explained how he pours gypsum cement into a frame, strings the hardened material to a jig and cuts patterns into it with a carbide-tipped rug-cutting blade. Other times, he just slices at the smooth cement canvases with an angle grinder.

title: Gawker to Retool as Politics Site
description: Gawker.com, a site that pioneered the knowing, irreverent tone that has come to define web journalism, will switch from covering New York and the media world, as it has done since its founding in 2003, to focus on politics.

title: First Same-Sex Marriage Ceremony Held in Ireland
description: DUBLIN  Irelands first same-sex marriage ceremony was held Tuesday in County Tipperary after the new marriage legislation became official and after a historic referendum on the issue in May.

title: Nol Wells on Master of None and Her Plan B
description: Nobody gets into comedy because they feel like theyre cool and funny, said Nol Wells, who was named class clown in her Texas kindergarten. If they do, theyre megalomaniacs.

title: Israel Outlaws Islamist Group
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Tuesday that Israel has outlawed the northern faction of the Islamic Movement, blaming the group for contributing to a surge in violence in Jerusalem

title: Richard Linklaters Everybody Wants Some Will Open SXSW Film Festival
description: The latest work from a popular Austin filmmaker will open a popular Austin film festival. Richard Linklaters comedy Everybody Wants Some, will be the opening-night film of the 23rd South by Southwest Film Conference and Festival, organizers announced Tuesday.

title: Giulio Adriani Turns a Gas Station Into Service Station
description: Service Station  The lubricant is now olive oil, not motor oil, at a former Exxon Mobil station that has been repurposed as a pizzeria, garage doors and all. Giulio Adriani, the consulting chef and a pizza master known for his fried montanara pie, is in charge of the domed oven that also turns out Neapolitan-style versions. Rounding out the menu are appetizers like arancini and fried calamari, and entrees that include lamb chops, skirt steak and lasagna. Bratislav Glisic, a consultant at Employees Only, has the same role here, and hell recommend a barrel-aged Negroni with the pizza, or a new-wave margarita with the margherita. Ive dreamed of pairing great pizza with great cocktails, said Mr. Adriani, who added that he was planning to add more crunch to his Neapolitan pizza. The charcoal gray restaurant has a big bar, communal tables and a spacious terrace that may even be comfortable on a sunny day in late fall. (Opens Thursday): 500 East 62nd Street, 212-751-7860, servicestationnyc.com.

title: Romanian Parliament Approves New Government
description: BUCHAREST, Romania  Romanias Parliament on Tuesday approved the government of Dacian Ciolos, who was nominated to replace Victor Ponta as prime minister last week.

title: YouTube Offers More From Merce Cunningham
description: When the Merce Cunningham Dance Company closed in 2011, two years after Cunninghams death, people wondered how his dances would live on. A YouTube channel was not among the expected preservation modes, but today, the Merce Cunningham Trusts YouTube page is one of the most engaging, accessible troves of his work, with nearly 100 (and counting) entries, from 60-second archival clips to 90-minute videos of company class.

title: Ben Carson Is Struggling to Grasp Foreign Policy, Advisers Say
description: Ben Carsons remarks on foreign policy have repeatedly raised questions about his grasp of the subject, but never more seriously than in the past week, when he wrongly asserted that China had intervened militarily in Syria and then failed, on national television, to name the countries he would call on to form a coalition to fight the Islamic State.

title: Unforgettable, Apparently Forever
description: Plenty of decent television shows dont survive for one reason or another  bad time slot, wrong network, lackluster promotional effort. Its too bad more of them dont have the resilience of Unforgettable, a good crime show that keeps finding ways to stay on the air. For its fourth season, which begins Friday, Nov. 27, that has meant moving to a new network, A&E.

title: John Kasich Urges Obama to Not Accept Syrian Refugees, For Now
description: Gov. John Kasich of Ohio conceded Tuesday that he did not have the power to block the flow of Syrian refugees into his state, but he still urged President Obama to stop accepting them until the United States can ensure that terrorists are not making their way into the country.

title: At Carnegie Hall, Students Share Varied Sounds
description: Two student orchestras, featuring young players at very different stages of development, will appear this week at Carnegie Hall.

title: Israel Outlaws Northern Branch of Islamic Movement
description: JERUSALEM  The Israeli security cabinet announced on Tuesday that it had outlawed the northern branch of the Islamic Movement in Israel, accusing it of collaborating with Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza.

title: Electing to Ignore the Poorest of the Poor
description: The first few primary debates of the presidential election season are in. We can see where the economic policy discussion is going.

title: Perfectly Reasonable Question: Trending
description: A Times reader, Janet Kriseman of Cape Town, South Africa, has noticed a new feature attached to the online version of some stories: a list called Trending. And shes puzzled by it. She wrote:

title: Who Wrote The Diary of Anne Frank?
description: Copyright law is meant to give authors and their heirs a temporary monopoly over books, songs and other creative works. In practice, however, such monopolies can last indefinitely. The latest example of this phenomenon comes from the Swiss foundation that owns the rights to The Diary of Anne Frank.

title: Xian Zhang Is New Jersey Symphonys New Music Director
description: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestras next music director will be familiar to some concertgoers in the region: The orchestra announced on Monday that the role would be filled by Xian Zhang, a rising Chinese-American star who was an associate conductor at the New York Philharmonic for several years before concentrating her recent career in Europe.

title: Air Liquide to Acquire Airgas for $10.3 Billion
description: The French industrial gas company Air Liquide said on Tuesday that it had agreed to buy Airgas for $10.3 billion in a deal that would swell the companys presence in the United States.

title: Tribute to Lennon at Symphony Space Endures in 35th Year
description: Tuned to Monday Night Football on his transistor radio, Joe Raiola nearly wrecked his taxi on Queens Boulevard when he heard the somber news on Dec. 8, 1980: John Lennon had been shot and killed that evening outside his home in Manhattan.

title: In Berlin, a Space for Design Experiments
description: In 2005, the Canadian architect Omer Arbel and his business partner Randy Bishop launched Bocci, a contemporary design and manufacturing company, out of a red barn surrounded by hayfields and farms in White Rock, British Columbia. Now based in Vancouver, Bocci has become known for its ethereal lighting products and large-scale installations. And its just opened an exhibition space and satellite fabrication laboratory in Berlin.

title: Whooping Cough in Infants Tied to Epilepsy Risk
description: Whooping cough in infancy is associated with an increased risk for epilepsy, a new study has found. The findings underscore the importance of vaccination for whooping cough, also known as pertussis, in childhood.

title: Pictures of the Day: France and Elsewhere
description: France and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

title: Nov. 17, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from France, Greece, Syria and India.

title: On Invading Iraq, Bernie Sanders Takes a Cue From Howard Dean
description: When it comes to Saddam Hussein, Senator Bernie Sanders appears to have learned a lesson from another Democratic presidential candidate from Vermont: former Gov. Howard Dean.

title: American Airlines Revises Its Rewards Program
description: Its not how far you fly, its how much you spend, that may determine how many frequent flier points youll get under American Airlines new AAdvantage loyalty program next year.

title: Engineer Accused of Failing to Assess Manhattan Building Where Falling Debris Killed Girl
description: Six months after a terra cotta windowsill crumbled and fell some eight stories, fatally striking 2-year-old girl on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, investigators announced on Tuesday that they had found a trail of problems with the buildings facade and that the engineer who was hired to inspect the facade did not follow the required protocols in his assessment.

title: French President Says Way of Life Intact
description: President Franois Hollande, speaking on Tuesday, said the French way of life would not be interrupted by the barbarity of terrorism.

title: Bill Clinton to Appear for Super PAC Backing Hillary Clinton
description: Former President Bill Clinton will appear as the main attraction at a meeting on Dec. 1 with prospective donors to Priorities USA Action, the super PAC that is supporting his wifes presidential campaign  the first such event he will do for the group.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Pumpkin Ravioli With Sage Walnut Pumpkin Butter
description: Over the last seven years of collecting new vegetarian Thanksgiving recipes on Well, we have learned that inviting a vegetarian or vegan to your holiday table creates more opportunity than challenge. Readers have seen that by making flavorful vegetarian and vegan dishes, they end up enhancing everyones meal.

title: Review: In SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome, Mary Beard Tackles Myths and More
description: Mary Beard is well known in England, so much so that when the magazine The Oldie  that countrys vastly more sophisticated version of our AARP magazine  named her its 2013 pinup of the year, no one had to ask: Who?

title: Explaining Terror to Children
description: Why a French newspaper for kids refuses to sugarcoat the horror of the Paris attacks.

title: How to Talk to Children About Terrorism
description: Paris  THE day after the terrorist attacks in Paris was one my children wont soon forget: They got to watch kids television all day long.

title: How to Fight ISIS
description: The mass murder of civilians in Paris has inevitably reignited the debate over using military force in the Middle East to attack the Islamic State. The debate, like anything that gets tangled up in American presidential politics, is divorced from reality. The United States, and other nations, is already engaged in military action with some ground forces in Iraq and Syria.

title: What Were Reading: Special Edition
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Review: Abyss Follows Characters Named He, She and I in Love and War
description: When the cast list for a play identifies its characters only by pronouns, it might as well have a warning sticker attached, reading, Whimsy alert: severe artiness ahead. These days, surely only dramatists of Edward Albees generation, which came of age in the absurdist shadows of Ionesco and Pirandello, can be forgiven such universal nomenclature, and even they can irritate in that regard.

title: Marine Le Pens Anti-Islam Message Gains Influence in France
description: PARIS  Well before the attacks that killed 129 people in Paris on Friday, Marine Le Pen, the president of the far-right National Front party, was parlaying fear of Islam, migrants and open borders into political support. Now, with France angry and in mourning, she is seizing the opportunity to expand her appeal and show her clout, underscoring how far-right messages are resonating across Europe.

title: A Tour of Fortuny
description: The century-old design house welcomes T onto its grounds in Venice.

title: Inside a Century-Old Venetian Design House
Manhattan Psychic Admits Taking Over $550,000 From Lovelorn Client
description: A Manhattan psychic admitted taking more than $550,000 from a customer whom she promised to reunite with a dead woman, in pleading guilty to grand larceny on Tuesday.

title: James Welling, Now in Technicolor
description: In the past three decades, the postmodern artist James Welling has made abstract photographs, more normative pictures and experimented with different processes, he says. But for the last 10 years, Ive been very interested in thinking about color. He captured Philip Johnsons Glass House in the late aughts through a set of colored filters and he digitally altered his 2009 pictures of Pariss Maison de Verre. However, with Choreograph, on display starting tomorrow at David Zwirner, Welling has developed a more physical way of deconstructing color: feeding three black-and-white images into Photoshops red, green and blue color channels, and dragging the adjustment sliders until he creates one serendipitous, psychedelic composition.

title: James Wellings Choreograph
description: The photographers latest show to experiment with color opens tomorrow at David Zwirner.

title: Lets Kick Boots on the Ground to the Curb
description: In the aftermath of the Paris terror attacks, boots on the ground, Vietnam-era shorthand for ground troops, has become the rhetorical equivalent of camouflage fashion. Tossing out the term gives politicians a battle-toughened air, while distancing them from the fact that theyre calling for the United States to send young Americans into battle.

title: Review: Leif Ove Andsnes Gives a Thoughtful Recital at Carnegie Hall
description: Putting together a thoughtfully varied recital program can be as difficult as playing your chosen pieces beautifully. The Norwegian pianist Leif Ove Andsnes demonstrated how to pull off both feats in his superb recital on Monday evening at Carnegie Hall.

title: Grimes, a D.I.Y. Indie Sensation, Ramps Up Her Sound
description: If Grimes is selling out, more musicians should do it her way.

title: Review: Democrats, Chronicling Politics in Zimbabwe
description: To be called a sellout in Zimbabwe is to be condemned to death. This observation delivered with a dry, matter-of-fact tone comes late in the director Camilla Nielssons outstanding, unsettling documentary Democrats, a film that chronicles recent efforts to put a constitution into place in that country.

title: Chris Stapleton Rides His Own Country Music Wave
description: LOS ANGELES  A few minutes before showtime on Monday night, there was a hubbub outside Chris Stapletons tour bus, parked just around the corner from the El Rey Theater here. A few people jumped off and began to make their way to the entrance. One of them fixed his attention on a mannequin in a store window, loudly encouraging his friends to look.

title: Review: A Journey Through Time With Anthony Adapts a Chinese Young-Adult Novel
description: The harmless confection A Journey Through Time With Anthony, an adaptation of a popular young-adult novel in China by Ma Liang (under the pseudonym Anthony), offers mild youthful rebellion and even milder youthful ardor.

title: Canadian Pacific Takes Its Merger Bid to Norfolk Southern
description: Canadian Pacific said on Tuesday that it had sent an offer letter to the Norfolk Southern Corporation, proposing a merger that would reshape the North American rail industry.

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: Paris, Charlie Sheen, Refugees
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: France Steps Up Airstrikes in Syria
description: France is using multiple airstrikes to fight back against the Islamic State, or Daesh, which claimed responsibility for the attacks in Paris.

title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: RECENT SALE

title: Review: Juilliard415 Plays Haydn and Telemann, Evoking the Suns Arc
description: The sun rose twice on Monday evening during Juilliard415s concert at Alice Tully Hall: first in Haydns Symphony No. 6 (Morning, 1761), then in Telemanns cantata Die Tageszeiten (The Times of Day, 1757). This was a fascinating juxtaposition of works finished only four years apart and similar in means and expression, by composers generally taken to represent distinct eras (Haydn the Classical, Telemann the Baroque).

title: Review: Pike St., Where One Woman Speaks for All
description: Evelyn, the principal character in Nilaja Suns terrific new solo show, Pike St., had her hands full even before news came of the hurricane bearing down on New York. Her 15-year-old daughter, Candi, is severely disabled and needs constant care. Four years ago, Candi had an aneurysm  or some similar catastrophic brain malfunction  and now she can barely speak and cannot feed herself. She also requires a respirator.

title: New Yorker Staffers (and Their Boss, David Remnick) Just Want to Rock
description: Were the Sequoias. Were going to play some songs from the book, John Seabrook announced from the stage at Bowery Electric in Lower Manhattan last Friday night. The bands set list, he added, would consist of Britney Spears, Katy Perry, that kind of stuff.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day, including updates on the Paris attacks..

title: A Haunting Film Explores the Perilous Interface Between Tigers and People in the Sundarbans
description: Deep in the Sundarbans, a vast mangrove maze where the Ganges and two other great rivers weave their way to the coast in India and Bangladesh, the big-cat conservationist Alan Rabinowitz plays a video clip on his laptopfor a cluster of men and women in an impoverished village where tigers  in one of their last big refuges  regularly kill or maim people scouring the shorelines for meager hauls of fish and crabs.

title: Is This the Most Influential Hairstylist in the World?
description: The fall months should have been a bonanza for beauty trends as global fashion weeks set the aesthetic of the season in dramatic runway gestures. But arguably the most influential hair arbiter of our time was nowhere near the fog of hair spray that clouds the backstage areas.

title: End Sought to Fantasy Sites in New York; Yahoo Is Said to Be Added to Inquiry
description: The New York State attorney general has expanded his investigation into daily fantasy sport sites, with measures including the issuance of a subpoena to the online media company Yahoo, according to a person familiar with the inquiry.

title: Jeb Bush Urges Caution on Accepting Syrian Refugees
description: FLORENCE, S.C.  On a swing through South Carolina on Tuesday, Jeb Bush waded into the debate over Syrian refugees that is roiling the nation after the terror attacks in Paris, saying he would take a cautious approach to accepting any refugees into the country.

title: Storm System Batters Colorado and Texas
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  A winter storm brought more than 100 flights to a standstill in Denver as it moved through eastern Colorado on Tuesday, while parts of the central and southern Plains recovered from power failures and a series of tornadoes.

title: Bobby Jindal Quits Republican Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana, a onetime rising Republican star whose popularity has plummeted in his own state, dropped out of the presidential race on Tuesday, conceding that he was unable to find any traction.

title: Estefan and La Bamba Cover Only Part of Americas Latin Culture in the 1980s
description: My favorite sound to come out of the Miami Sound Machine goes something like this: Hhhwoo! That happens toward the end of the chorus for Rhythm Is Gonna Get You, which kicked off the second side of the bands album Let It Loose. It was 1987, and most of us had to flip something over  an LP, a cassette  to hear it. The song stalked summer radio back then.

title: Full Results of The New York Times/Siena College Poll
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio's overall approval rating is at 44 percent, down from 52 percent last December.

title: France-England Game Is a Friendly in Every Sense of the Word
description: LONDON  One of the great joys in soccer is its vocabulary. Only in soccer are there dummies and extra time and backheels. Only in soccer are there offside traps and toe pokes. Depending on what country youre in, there may also be gaffers (managers) or howlers (embarrassing errors) or fixtures (games).

title: Strikes on Raqqa in Syria Lead to More Questions Than Results
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  First France and then Russia answered Islamic State attacks on their citizens with a strategy of direct reprisal: intensified airstrike campaigns on Raqqa, the militants de facto capital within Syria, meant to eliminate the groups leadership and resources.

title: Mayor de Blasio Has Lost Support of White New Yorkers, Poll Finds
description: Nearing the midpoint of his term, Mayor Bill de Blasio is confronting a city that is deeply divided about his ability to lead, with his efforts to create a more liberal New York overshadowed by growing worries about homelessness and crime, a new poll finds.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The New York Times/Siena College Poll of New York City residents consisted of telephone interviews with 1,961 adults throughout the city, conducted between Oct. 29 and Nov. 11.

title: A Conversation WithDavid S. Winter
description: Mr. Winter, 38, is a founder and co-chief executive of Winter Properties, the real estate arm of 40 North Management, a diversified investment company based in New York. Winter Properties, formed in 2014, is an outgrowth of the Winter Organization, which was started in the early 1900s by Mr. Winters great-grandfather Benjamin Winter Sr.

title: Senate Votes to Block Obamas Climate Change Rules
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate voted on Tuesday to block President Obamas tough new climate change regulations, hoping to undermine his negotiating authority before a major international climate summit meeting in Paris this month.

title: Drone Maker DJI Adds Technology to Limit Where Its Machines Can Fly
description: Maybe drone makers can ease some of the pressure on themselves by building limits on their own machines.

title: John Cooks Memo to Gawkers Staff
description: Gawker.com has covered the news and gossip of Manhattan and the media world since the site started in 2003. On Tuesday, the sites founder, Nick Denton, announced that it was changing its focus to politics. In a memo to the staff, John Cook, the executive editor of the sites parent company, Gawker Media, laid out what that shift in focus would entail:

title: Nick Dentons Memo to Gawkers Staff
description: Gawker.com has covered the news and gossip of Manhattan and the media world since the site started in 2003. On Tuesday, the websites founder, Nick Denton, announced that it was changing its focus to politics. He outlined the changes to Gawker.com and its parent company, Gawker Media, in a memo to the staff:

title: Veronique Hakim Is Named President of New York City Transit
description: Veronique Hakim, the head of New Jersey Transit, is leaving the agency to lead New York City Transit as the subway system struggles with chronic delays brought on by booming ridership and aging infrastructure.

title: Kentucky and Duke Are Looking More Alike All the Time
description: CHICAGO  As Kentucky hurtled toward an unprecedented 40-0 record last March while Duke less loudly entered the Final Four, the tournament conversation was dominated by a perceived clash between the programs and between their head coaches  national championship-winning, generational talents who are now both in the basketball Hall of Fame.

title: Promoting Environmental Awareness Among Practicing Hindus
description: On an overcast morning this month, a dozen or so people, most of them Hindus, gathered in a circle on the shore of Jamaica Bay and bowed their heads as a priest invoked the deities.

title: Makers of Nutritional Supplements Charged in Federal Sweep
description: A yearlong federal investigation into the dietary supplement industry has resulted in a widespread crackdown on the sale of tainted or misleading products.

title: Songs From Coming Adele Album Appear to Be Leaked Online
description: Three days before the release of Adeles highly anticipated new album, 25, brief snippets of what appeared to be songs from the album were leaked online, although where they came from was unclear.

title: A Black History Museum Introduces Itself on the National Mall
description: A new Smithsonian museum dedicated to telling the history of African-Americans lit up the National Mall on Monday night as historical images related to the Civil War, the abolition of slavery and the passage of the Voting Rights Act were projected onto the facade of the five-story building. Called the National Museum of African American History and Culture, it is slated to open next fall.

title: Review: Captive Audience, Seven Plays by David Ives by New York Deaf Theater
description: Theres little middle ground in Captive Audience, a collection of short works by David Ives: Each play here either sinks onstage or is wonderful to watch. Though, to the credit of the cast, even the pieces that wane dont lack for trying.

title: Lyft Said to Seek $500 Million in Funding
description: Even as questions swirl over the fund-raising environment for hot young start-ups, the ride-hailing sector is barreling into new funding talks at top speed.

title: Large Banks Postpone Debt Sale as Investor Appetite for Riskier Loans Wanes
description: Although the biggest leveraged buyout of the year is still set to be completed on time, some of the banks involved in the financing have postponed plans to sell several billion dollars worth of debt meant to support the transaction, people briefed on the matter said on Tuesday.

title: Amherst Mascot Gets Thumbs Down From Faculty
description: Lord Jeff, Amherst Colleges unofficial mascot, tarnished by his dealings with Native Americans more than 200 years ago, has become the latest casualty of the protest movement against racial insensitivity on college campuses.

title: Mass Surveillance Isnt the Answer to Fighting Terrorism
description: Its a wretched yet predictable ritual after each new terrorist attack: Certain politicians and government officials waste no time exploiting the tragedy for their own ends. The remarks on Monday by John Brennan, the director of the Central Intelligence Agency, took that to a new and disgraceful low.

title: Minnesota: Man Shot by Police Dies
description: An unarmed black man shot Sunday by the Minneapolis police died on Monday evening, state investigators said. The police said that the man, Jamar Clark, 24, was an assault suspect, and that he had been shot after interfering with paramedics trying to treat his victim and fighting with two officers. The police disputed witness accounts that said Mr. Clark was handcuffed when he was shot. Though no police camera footage captured the episode, other cameras showed parts of the encounter, said Superintendent Drew Evans of the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, which is investigating the case. Protesters have demanded the release of video evidence and the names of the officers. Mayor Betsy Hodges has requested a federal civil rights investigation.

title: Spike Seen in Reported Cases of Sexually Transmitted Diseases
description: Syphilis, gonorrhea and chlamydia are rising at alarming rates, according to figures released Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Syphilis infections reported by doctors rose 15 percent from 2013 to 2014; cases of gonorrhea increased 5 percent, and chlamydia 3 percent. The agency called the diseases a substantial health challenge. Syphilis cases have more than tripled since 2000, and 91 percent are in men  mostly gay and bisexual men. Dr. Gail Bolan, the agencys director of prevention of sexually transmitted disease, said there was no single answer for the increase, but noted several factors. State and local spending on prevention and treatment has shrunk as screening of gay men has picked up. Many gay men start antiretroviral drugs as soon as they are infected with H.I.V., and others take Truvada to prevent infection; there have been reports that condom use has dropped in this population as a result. Although those drugs prevent H.I.V. infection and transmission, they do not prevent the spread of syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydia, human papilloma virus, herpes or trichomoniasis.

title: Timeline of Bobby Jindals Presidential Campaign
description: Once billed as a rising star in the Republican Party, Gov. Bobby Jindal of Louisiana had his 2016 presidential bid fail to make it out of 2015 as a flat message and flagging poll numbers plagued his campaign. Mr. Jindal remained fiery on stump until the end, but his conservative message did not resonate in this cycles crowded field.

title: Cubs Joe Maddon and Rangers Jeff Banister Win Manager Awards
description: As National League finalists appeared on MLB Network for the Manager of the Year Award announcement on Tuesday night, Chicago Cubs Manager Joe Maddon looked on comfortably from an Italian restaurant in Tampa, Fla. His gray hair swept across his head like a wave. He had his sleeves rolled up, his shirt splayed open, a silver chain sticking out.

title: Boko Haram Is Suspected After Explosion in Nigeria Kills 32
description: DAKAR, Senegal  A blast in the northeastern Nigerian city of Yola on Tuesday night tore through a marketplace, killing 32 people and wounding 80 others, according to the local authorities and witnesses.

title: Jury Gets Case Against Ex-Chief of West Virginia Coal Mine on Safety
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va.  More than five years after a powerful explosion ravaged the Upper Big Branch mine and killed 29 men, a federal jury on Tuesday began considering whether the former chief executive of Massey Energy Company could be held criminally responsible for a corporate culture that prosecutors said pursued profits more than safety and integrity.

title: Out of a Shelter, a Single Mother Studies to Be a Paramedic
description: Shareda Waldron has a five-year plan. She wants a home in New Jersey, a car and to be a paramedic for the New York Fire Department.

title: Government to Expand Program to Forgive Student Loan Debt
description: The Department of Education announced Tuesday that it would expand its program to forgive federal student loan debt to thousands more students who attended programs of Corinthian Colleges, once one of the nations largest for-profit education companies.

title: A Martha Stewart Store Makes a Leap to Amazon
description: Martha Stewart has ditched eBay, taking her American Made store to Amazons Handmade marketplace, as the e-commerce giant flexes its muscle in the burgeoning online market for handcrafted goods.

title: Letter Directing Indiana Organization to Send Syrians Elsewhere
description: A letter from an Indiana state agency requesting that the refugee resettlement look to other states to place incoming Syrians.

title: 11th-Hour Detour Puts Family in Connecticut as Indiana Bars Syrian Refugees
description: A Syrian refugee family, after waiting for three years in Jordan to be approved to come to the United States, was finally set to land in Indianapolis on Wednesday.

title: A Manhattan Hardware Store Welcomes Refugees as Governors Vow to Shut Them Out
description: Chris Christie of New Jersey and at least 25 other governors have said they do not want Syrian refugees to come to their states.

title: Maryland Campus Closed as Police Continue Search
description: CHESTERTOWN, Md.  On the second day of a two-state manhunt for a student believed to be carrying a rifle, the college he attended shut down Tuesday, as officials described the student as being despondent after getting into trouble for drunkenly brandishing a gun on campus last month.

title: Red Sox David Ortiz Is Suited for a Send-Off
description: As the final month of his final season played out, Paul Konerko relished the peaceful ending to his proud career. There was enough hoopla out of the public view, anyway, and he did not want the parting gifts and ceremonies bestowed on other stars.

title: French Return to Cafes in a Show of Defiance
description: PARIS  At 6 p.m. sharp on Tuesday, Mickel Dagdalar and Maxence Lezeau squeezed behind a tiny bistro table at Le Baromtre, a casual neighborhood hangout on the Boulevard Voltaire. They each lit a cigarette and began sipping at glasses of beer, as the crowd around them swelled.

title: An ISIS Militant From Belgium Whose Own Family Wanted Him Dead
description: BRUSSELS  When the family of Abdelhamid Abaaoud received word from Syria last fall that he had been killed fighting for the Islamic State, it rejoiced at what it took to be excellent news about a wayward son it had come to despise.

title: Rick Nash Knows the Score: Rangers Pay Him to Do More
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The Rangers occasionally call on Rick Nash to kill penalties, and he is pretty good at using his long arms and stick to knock pucks the other way for the third-best unit in the N.H.L.

title: New York State Accuses Utica School District of Bias Against Refugees
description: For years, the authorities say, administrators for an upstate New York high school turned away refugee children because of their age and their unsteady English while covering up discriminatory enrollment policies.

title: How to Beat ISIS: Use Arab Armies to Fight the Group
description: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with J.M. Berger, a scholar at the Brookings Institution and a co-author of ISIS: The State of Terror.

title: Watching the Attacks, With Two Daughters
description: When violence strikes outside a family's dinner in Paris, a mother is torn between leaving to assist victims and consoling her daughters.

title: Its Superman!
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  Its a bird! Its a plane! Its  a puzzle debut!

title: College Football Playoff Committee Keeps Top Teams in Place
description: The top four teams remain unchanged as the College Football Playoff selection committee released its third set of rankings on Tuesday night.

title: Minnesota: U.S. Will Investigate Police Shooting of Unarmed Man
description: Justice Department officials said Tuesday that they would start an inquiry into whether the shooting of an unarmed black man by the Minneapolis police violated civil rights laws. The man, Jamar Clark, 24, who was shot Sunday, died Monday night. The police said that Mr. Clark was an assault suspect and that he had been shot after interfering with paramedics trying to treat his victim and fighting with two officers. The police have disputed witness accounts that said Mr. Clark was handcuffed when he was shot. Though no police camera captured the confrontation, other cameras showed parts of it, said Superintendent Drew Evans of the Minnesota Bureau of Criminal Apprehension, which is investigating the case. Superintendent Evans said releasing that footage now could compromise the investigation. Protesters, including dozens who were arrested Monday night for blocking highway traffic, have demanded the release of video evidence and the names of the officers. The protesters and Mayor Betsy Hodges requested the Justice Department investigation.

title: Hans Mommsen, 85, Dies; Documented Volkswagen Slave Labor in Nazi Era
description: Hans Mommsen, considered the leading German historian of the Third Reich, whose work encompassed the origins of the Holocaust as well as a widely publicized report documenting Volkswagens wartime use of slave labor, died in Tutzing, near Munich, on Nov. 5, his 85th birthday.

title: How to Beat ISIS: Destroy the Groups Economy
description: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with Boaz Ganor, the director of the International Institute for Counter-Terrorism at the Interdisciplinary Center in Herzliya, Israel.

title: How to Beat ISIS: First Deal With Assad
description: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with Emile Hokayem, a senior fellow for Middle East security at the International Institute for Strategic Studies who has personal roots in Beirut, Lebanon, and in Paris.

title: Soccer Match in Germany Is Canceled Over Security Concerns
description: BERLIN  The German authorities called off an exhibition soccer match between Germany and the Netherlands in Hanover on Tuesday, less than two hours before kickoff, after the authorities received what they called a concrete security threat.

title: How to Beat ISIS: Counter Recruitment of Young People
description: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with Imam Mohamed Magid, the spiritual leader of the All Dulles Area Muslim Society, a large Muslim community in Sterling, Va. He has been working with other Muslim leaders and government agencies on countering radicalization. This year, he traveled to Nigeria, Sudan, Kenya and Ethiopia to discuss counterrecruitment and deradicalization strategies with religious and government leaders in those countries.

title: How to Beat ISIS: Russia and the United States Should Join Forces
description: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with Kirill V. Kabanov, a member of Russias Human Rights Council and a former domestic intelligence agent. Mr. Kabanov has advocated an alliance between the United States and Russia to take on the Islamic State.

title: How to Beat ISIS: Reform Islamic Teaching
description: The following excerpts are from an interview about how to defeat the Islamic State with two former jihadists: Maajid Nawaz, a former recruiter for the radical Islamist group Hizb ut-Tahrir, and Mubin Shaikh, a former extremist from Canada who spent time with the Taliban before turning away from radical Islam.

title: P. F. Sloan, Enigmatic Writer of 60s Hit Eve of Destruction, Dies at 70
description: P. F. Sloan, a singer and songwriter of somewhat enigmatic repute, whose apocalyptic anthem Eve of Destruction, written when he was just 19, was a seminal protest song of the 1960s, not to mention a No. 1 hit for the singer Barry McGuire, died on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 70.

title: Silver Made Misleading Comments About How He Disclosed His Income, U.S. Says
description: Sheldon Silvers voice was finally heard in a federal courtroom on Tuesday, but not because he took the witness stand.

title: Porzingis Gives Knicks, and Fans, a Charge
description: After he had dazzled and dunked, after he had sealed the win with a rebound and two free throws, and after the crowd had filled Madison Square Garden with the sound of his name being chanted over and over, as if he were a rock star being called for an encore, Kristaps Porzingis carried an armful of towels for his teammates.

title: 2Air France Planes Are Diverted From Paris
description: Two Air France flights bound for Paris from the United States were divertedTuesdaynight over threats telephoned to a reservations center, the airline said.

title: Britain: Couple Found Guilty of Keeping a Nigerian Man Captive Since 1989
description: A British couple was found guilty Tuesday of keeping a Nigerian immigrant enslaved for more than two decades, forcing him to work for no pay and threatening him with deportation if he tried to escape, prosecutors said. Dr. Emmanuel Edet, 61, and Antan Edet, 58, held their victim captive from the time he was brought to Britain when he was 14 years old, the Crown Prosecution Service said. The Edets were convicted at Harrow Crown Court in northwest London on charges of child cruelty, slavery and assisting in illegal immigration. They told their captive  whom the BBC identified as Ofonime Sunday Inuk, now 40  when they brought him from Nigeria in 1989 that they would pay him and give him an education, prosecutors said. Instead, he was forced to cook, clean, garden and care for the couples children without pay for up to 17 hours a day, they said.

title: Joel Elkes, Who Cast Light on Brain Chemistry and Behavior, Dies at 101
description: Dr. Joel Elkes, who published the first scientific trial of a medication for schizophrenia and became a foundational figure in modern psychiatry, describing a framework to understand how brain chemistry shapes behavior, died on Oct. 30 in Sarasota, Fla. He was 101.

title: Experts Explain How Global Powers Can Smash ISIS
description: Much of the world agrees that the Islamic State needs to be crushed.

title: Two Are Shot at a Brooklyn Subway Station
description: A person opened fire into a crowd of passengers leaving the Utica Avenue subway station in Brooklyn on Tuesday, wounding one man who appeared to be fleeing a dispute at a nearby bodega and another who was getting off a train, the police said.

title: Yale Will Strengthen Teaching on Race and Ethnicity, Its President Says
description: Responding to student demonstrations and demands related to the racial climate at Yale University, its president, Peter Salovey, introduced a host of initiatives and promises in a letter to alumni on Tuesday.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | dismiss
description: dismiss  \dis-mis\  verb

title: White House Affirms Syrian Refugee Plan Despite Paris Attacks
description: WASHINGTON  As Republicans call for blocking Syrian refugees from coming to the United States in the wake of the attacks in Paris, the Obama administration said on Tuesday that it was confident that it could weed out any migrants posing a terrorism threat before they entered the country.

title: Syria Accused of Attacks on Medical Facilities and Personnel
description: UNITED NATIONS  A New York-based human rights organization is accusing the Syrian government of flouting international law by killing health workers, bombing hospitals and blocking lifesaving aid from entering a strategic city in northern Syria that was held by the opposition groups.

title: Flames Knock Off the Devils
description: Bobby Farnam scored 4 minutes 1 second into the second period, and Jordin Tootoo added a power-play goal at 8:06, but it was not enough as the Devils fell to the host Calgary Flames, 3-2.

title: What to Watch Wednesday
description: Lock the doors before watching In Cold Blood, part of the Turner Classic Movies spotlight on Southern writers. Then double the chill with Philip Seymour Hoffmans tour de force in Capote. Meanwhile, Empire declares a war of words.

title: Shifting Boundaries, France Redraws Its Map
description: REIMS, France  France is about to redraw its map again, reducing its number of mainland regions to 13, from 22, and producing tongue-twisters like the new geographic entity known as Alsace-Champagne-Ardenne-Lorraine.

title: Culture Shock in the Promised Land of Germany
description: BERLIN  When one of Berlins most popular gay clubs recently held a fund-raising party for refugees, Vivien Roos took along a group of young Afghans and Syrians.

description: Jonah Lomu, one of rugbys greatest players, has died in Auckland, New Zealand. He was 40.

title: Cabs, Camels or ISIS
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates  Today, Ill talk about the Paris attacks, but before I do I want to share two news stories here, in case you missed them: The first calf to come from a cloned camel was born at a research center in Dubai and a local taxi start-up is taking on Uber in the Arab world.

description: To the Editor:

title: Why I Provide Abortions
description: IN public health, you go where the crisis is. If there is an outbreak and you have the ability to relieve suffering, you rush to the site of the need. This is why, a year and a half ago, I returned to my hometown, Birmingham, Ala., to provide abortions.

title: Euro-Trump
description: The morning after the Islamic State attacks on Paris, Donald Trump approvingly retweeted the words of one of his supporters: THE WORLD IS PLAYING EVERYTHING RIGHT FOR TRUMP! EVERY DAY HIS POINTS ARE PROVEN.

title: Is Any Place Safe?
description: Paris  FRIDAY night, after the terrorist attacks in Paris, I went out into the streets. I was confused and afraid, of course. But the terrible things that had happened  I wanted to see them for myself, breathe them in, walk among them. It was a little past 11 and the streets were deserted, silent. Paris no longer existed. Paris had fallen.

title: France Unsure if Raid Killed Top Suspect in Paris Attacks
description: ST.-DENIS, France  The assault began before dawn Wednesday at a decrepit squat in a close suburb of Paris when scores of French police officers stormed a third-floor apartment in search of their elusive quarry: Abdelhamid Abaaoud, a Belgian suspected of organizing last weeks deadly attacks in Paris by the Islamic State.

title: Can Crime Be Ethically Predicted?
Starwood Devotees Greet Marriott Merger With Dread and Anger
description: Frequent customers of Starwood Hotels & Resorts are reacting emotionally to the news that Marriott International is acquiring Starwood, which owns the Westin, Sheraton and W hotel chains. It seems less like a company they do business with is merging and more like their mother is marrying a man they disapprove of.

title: Rewatching the Theismann Injury
description: There has perhaps never been a more memorable play in football  or even all of American sports  than the one that ended the career of the Washington Redskins quarterback Joe Theismann, 30 years ago today. Since that play, N.F.L. quarterbacks have attempted nearly half a million passes, and we have never again seen (or heard) such skeletal trauma.

title: Pitfalls for Proxies
description: Of the many factors that affect the experience of dying, the one thatpatients and families often have the greatest control over is making decisions that are in the patients best interest. I recently participated in research on barriers to quality end-of-life care as part of a study released today in the Journal of Palliative Medicine. Some of the hurdles we identified, such as financial limitations or access to top doctors, may require societal change. But I am focusing here on the personal part of the puzzle that all patients, whatever their socioeconomic status, should have the potential to influence.

title: An Early-Morning Raid North of Paris
description: The French police raided an apartment building in St.-Denis on Wednesday morning.

title: Obama Calls on Beijing to Stop Construction in South China Sea
description: MANILA  President Obama called on China on Wednesday to halt its construction on reclaimed islands in the South China Sea, raising the contentious issue at the start of a two-day economic summit meeting at which he and other Pacific Rim leaders also discussed trade and climate change.

title: News Qs | Andrew Lloyd Webber: Lord, Baron, Rocker
description: Before Reading Andrew Lloyd Webber: Lord, Baron, Rocker:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: The message to the West is clear: We have bought their buildings, we have bought their companies, and now we are going to buy their art.

title: In Rise of ISIS, No Single Missed Key but Many Strands of Blame
description: By the time the United States withdrew from its long bloody encounter with Iraq in 2011, it thought it had declawed a once fearsome enemy: the Islamic State, which had many names and incarnations but at the time was neither fearsome nor a state.

title: Assailants in Bangladesh Attack Catholic Missionary
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Unidentified assailants wounded an Italian missionary working in northern Bangladesh early on Wednesday, in the third attack on foreigners there since late September.

title: Annadale, Staten Island: A Suburban Outpost in the City
description: Palma Gutekunst was looking to buy a starter home on Staten Islands North Shore when she found herself drawn to the more suburban, tranquil South Shore neighborhood of Annadale.

title: From Financial Guru to Brooklyn Ceramist
description: When John Mosler enthuses about clay bodies, glazes and kiln design, it is easy to forget he was once a shaper of global financial markets. But after a nearly 25-year career as a pioneer in the derivatives market, he made a clean break from finance to become a ceramist.

title: How Amazons Long Game Yielded a Retail Juggernaut
description: To study the graph of Amazons stock performance in 2015 is to witness a series of stepwise lurches toward commanding new heights. Over all, the stock market has been flat this year, and technology companies, as a group, havent fared much better.

title: On Fake Instagram, a Chance to Be Real
description: For a certain generation, Instagram has become a calling card, a life rsum of sorts: This is me. This is my life. Jealous?

title: Embracing French Art and Fashion as a Counterattack
description: On Tuesday and Wednesday of this week, The New York Times was to have held our luxury conference in Versailles, France. Last Friday, as the tragic events in Paris unfolded, we made the decision to postpone the event.

title: Inside the Gould Memorial Library
description: The architect Stanford Whites dazzling, decaying structure on the Bronx Community College campus.

title: An Opulent Bronx Library in Decay, and in Search of a Purpose
description: To reclaim Gould Memorial Library at Bronx Community College, Stanford Whites most dazzling extant structure in New York, its admirers must invent new uses for a building that was intended by a much different institution  New York University  to serve a now-antiquated form of scholarship, using riches of which the community college could only dream.

title: Hiroji Kubota, Photographer
description: Hiroji Kubota sounds a little over-the-top when he insists his life is meaningless without photography. But a glance at his latest  and 19th  book will convince you he is absolutely right, given how his life has been intertwined with some of Magnums legendary photographers, like Ren Burri, Burt Glinn and my father, Elliott Erwitt. He started out working with some of them as a fixer and translator, even though he refused payment at first. I was brought up comfortably and didnt need it, he said.

title: Donald Trump Bolsters Lead in New Hampshire, Poll Shows
description: Donald J. Trump has regained the initiative in New Hampshire, according to a new poll that demonstrates his enduring popularity in the face of more aggressive rivals and a fraught national security landscape.

title: Would You Share an Embarrassing Story Online?
description: Earlier this month, the author Jenny Lawson posted the embarrassing moment at the airport, shown in the tweet above, with the 445,000 followers of her account The Bloggess.

title: Tai Chi and Psychotherapy for Better Sleep and More
description: Poor sleep is associated with increased inflammation, which may contribute to heart disease and a variety of other ailments. A new study has shown that cognitive behavioral therapy and tai chi, the Chinese exercise technique, may reduce both insomnia and inflammation.

title: Brawn and Brains
description: Sturdy legs could mean healthy brains, according to a new study of British twins.

title: After Myanmar Election, Few Signs of a Better Life for Muslims
description: YANGON, Myanmar  A few months before the general elections here, the military-backed government struck hundreds of thousands of Muslims from the voter rolls. To be reinstated, they would have to prove their citizenship, but without using their government-issued ID cards, which the government had voided.

title: Resort and Hotel News: Pods for Meditation; Jazz in New York
description: AT HOTEL SPAS, PODS TO REDUCE STRESS

title: Morning Agenda: Lyft Is Said to Seek $500 Million
