description: Take the Quiz

title: In Melbourne, a Colorful and Quirky Retreat
description: Rooms from 160 Australian dollars, about $117 at 1.36 Australian to the U.S. dollar.

title: Obama Seizes Chance to Shake Off Summit Meeting Constraints
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  The young man vaulted to his feet as the end of the town hall approached, and yelled out for President Obamas attention.

title: LArabie saoudite, un Daesh qui a russi
description: Daesh noir, Daesh blanc. Le premier gorge, tue, lapide, coupe les mains, dtruit le patrimoine de lhumanit, et dteste larchologie, la femme et ltranger non musulman. Le second est mieux habill et plus propre, mais il fait la mme chose. LEtat islamique et lArabie saoudite. Dans sa lutte contre le terrorisme, lOccident mne la guerre contre lun tout en serrant la main de lautre. Mcanique du dni, et de son prix. On veut sauver la fameuse alliance stratgique avec lArabie saoudite tout en oubliant que ce royaume repose sur une autre alliance, avec un clerg religieux qui produit, rend lgitime, rpand, prche et dfend le wahhabisme, islamisme ultra-puritain dont se nourrit Daesh.

title: Why My State Wont Close Its Doors to Syrian Refugees
description: Olympia, Wash.  OVER the last week, a growing number of governors, representatives, senators and presidential candidates have demanded that America slam shut our borders to refugees who are fleeing unspeakable horrors at the hands of the Islamic State. On Thursday the House passed a bill containing impossibly onerous vetting procedures for new refugees from Syria.

title: VW Cuts Its R.&D. Budget in Face of Costly Emissions Scandal
description: WOLFSBURG, Germany  Scarred by an emissions-cheating scandal, Volkswagen on Friday said it would need to cut its budget next year for new technology and research  a reversal after years of increased spending aimed at becoming the worlds biggest carmaker.

title: Change Needed for Commenting That Favors the Verified
description: In emails, in online comments and even in that wonder of our time called face-to-face conversation, I hear a lot about Times readers frustration with the existence of verified commenters.

title: Emperor of the North and Wind Across the Everglades: Fighters in Nature and Showbiz
description: The best of those studio directors who, more or less the same age as Orson Welles, began working in movies within a decade of Citizen Kane (1941) represent Hollywoods greatest generation. Survivors of the Great Depression and often veterans of World War II, they fought the good war against assembly-line filmmaking. Robert Aldrich (1918-83) and Nicholas Ray (1911-79) were two.

title: Andris Nelsons to Conduct Five Programs at Tanglewood
description: Andris Nelsons will conduct the Boston Symphony Orchestra in performances of Mahler, Beethoven and the first two acts of Verdis Aida, with the soprano Kristine Opolais, who is married to him, in the title role. A battery of famous pianists will descend on the Berkshires. And George Benjamins new song cycle, Dream of the Song, will get its United States premiere.

title: A Murderer  and Also a Victim of Place
description: Last month I read for the first time my fathers killers version of what happened on the afternoon of Jan. 4, 2011. My father, Salman Taseer, was the governor of Punjab, in Pakistan, when he was shot dead by his own bodyguard in Islamabad. He was at the time defending a Christian woman accused of blasphemy.

title: Ebola Cases in 3 Family Members Confirmed in Liberia
description: MONROVIA, Liberia  Three members of a family in Liberia have contracted Ebola, two months after the country was declared free of the virus for the second time, health officials said on Friday.

title: Jonathan Pollards Long Journey From Spying to Freedom
description: WASHINGTON  Jonathan J. Pollard was released on parole from federal prison on Friday after serving 30 years of a life sentence for violations of the Espionage Act.

title: Movie Review: Carol
description: The Times critic A. O. Scott reviews Carol.

title: Movie Review: Mockingjay Part 2
description: The Times critic Manohla Dargis reviews The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2.

title: Eros and Identity Meet Again in Copenhagen, in The Danish Girl
description: In one scene in The Danish Girl, due in theaters Friday, Nov. 27, the 1920s Danish artist Gerda Wegener (Alicia Vikander) gazes intensely at her canvas as she paints a portrait of a nude woman stretched out languidly in a classical pose.

title: Dating a Literary Snob
description: Dear Diary:

title: The Fashionable Adele
description: While the singers public wardrobe has tended toward LBDs, she recently has been seen in other stylish selections.

title: With the Release of 25, Adele Flexes Some Fashion Muscles
description: Now that the Adele juggernaut has officially begun with the release of 25, and as we all prepare to be inundated with her image in related videos, marketing and events, it is hard not to wonder if this album will be the one that finally delivers her place in the fashion power structure, along with peers like Beyonc, Rihanna and Taylor Swift.

title: Final Vote Tally Confirms Rout by Myanmar Opposition
description: BANGKOK  Myanmars election commission on Friday announced the final tally of the countrys Nov. 8 landmark election, a rout by the opposition, led by the Nobel Peace Prize laureate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi.

title: The Annotated Reacher
description: Explore the opening of the latest Jack Reacher novel with its author, Lee Child.

title: The Professor on Lee Childs Shoulder
description: THE tough-guy hero Jack Reacher first appeared 18 years ago in Lee Childs novel Killing Floor. On Sept. 1, 2014, Mr. Child started writing Make Me, the 20th in his best-selling Reacher series. But for once he was not alone in his office in Manhattan. He was being observed by Andy Martin, a longtime Reacher fan and University of Cambridge lecturer, sitting a few feet behind him and shadowing the creative process all the way from the first word (Moving) to the last (needle).

title: Just Get Us in the Room: Our Favorite Quotations From the Women of Hollywood
description: Maureen Dowd interviews dozens of women working in Hollywood on the sexism that pervades the film and television industries.

title: Gear VR Offers a Preview of Virtual Reality in the Home
description: When a friend asks what you did over the weekend, you may soon say, I stood 15 feet away from a dinosaur  and you will not be bluffing.

title: Martian Trailer in Virtual Reality Is Released
description: LOS ANGELES  20th Century Fox made good on its promise of a free peek at its The Martian-themed virtual reality experience, releasing on Friday a VR trailer for viewing on Samsung phones.

title: Leasing Begins for New Yorks First Micro-Apartments
description: New Yorkers are used to living in shoe box apartments. Now, more of them can see what it is like to live in something even smaller. Leasing begins Monday at Carmel Place, the citys first micro-unit development, a nine-story, modular building at 335 East 27th Street with 55 studios ranging from 260 to 360 square feet.

title: Danger at the Ballpark, and in a Baseball Tickets Fine Print
description: Umbrellas.

title: Mali Hotel Attack: Look Back on How the Hostage Crisis Unfolded
Whats on This Week Around the World
description: Sydney, Australia

title: LivingSocial Offers a Cautionary Tale to Todays Unicorns
description: WASHINGTON  The first thing you see when walking into the headquarters of LivingSocial is row upon row of mostly empty desks, broken up by small street signs that employees once needed to find one another when the office teemed with people.

title: WWII Hero Credits Luck and Chance in Foiling Hitlers Nuclear Ambitions
description: ALESUND, Norway  For a man who saved the world, or at least helped ensure that Adolf Hitler never got hold of a nuclear bomb, 96-year-old Joachim Ronneberg has a surprisingly unheroic view of the forces that shape history.

title: Daily Report: Google Gets Serious About Competing in Cloud With Amazon Web Services
description: One of the great mysteries of the tech industry in recent years has been the seeming disinterest of Google, which is now called Alphabet, in competing with Amazon Web Services for corporate customers.

title: 1940: Coventry Lays Dead to Rest
description: COVENTRY, England  Thin wisps of smoke still rose from the ruins of central Coventry today [Nov. 20], and rescuers still were searching for further victims, as a thousand men and women silently watched their loved ones laid to rest in a common grave. The dead  there were 200  were the victims of German bombs showered ruthlessly and indiscriminately last Thursday night  a night Coventry will never forget. Some of them mothers, some children and some of them the men who manned the factories vital to Great Britains prosecution of the war, they now lie in plain pine coffins, placed end to end and tier upon tier in a deep, narrow trench hastily dug by steam shovels borrowed from a construction job.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 21, 1940

title: Chinas President Praises Hu Yaobang,a Fallen Party Reformer
description: Chinas staunchly traditionalist Communist leader, Xi Jinping, paid tribute on Friday to a predecessor, Hu Yaobang, who was in many ways his opposite in temperament and politics.

title: In Defense of the Personal Crowdfunding Campaign
description: I cant even believe Im writing this, or asking for this, but this is the reality.

title: A Day (and Night) at the Opera With Stphane Lissner
description: PARIS  Stphane Lissner swept briskly into his enormous glass-fronted office at the Bastille opera house, one ear clamped to his cellphone, talking at top speed while motioning at a visitor to sit down. I tell you, its nonsense, he said impatiently into his cell. We are not taking them off. We are making them removable. Its entirely different.

title: Photo-Poetics: An Anthology Features 10 Artists at the Guggenheim
description: As photography disperses in an ever more granular way into daily life  through phones, social media, ubiquitous screens  artists are hauling the medium back into the studio to see if it can be reconstituted into something more tangible. Sara VanDerBeek once described how she created an object, captured its image and then, through the process of making a final print, framing it and hanging it on the wall, rendered the image an object again.

title: When Youre Named Isis for the Goddess, Not the Terror Group
description: A womans Facebook account was disabled. A bookstore was vandalized. And one company, moved by the attacks on Paris, just doesnt want the association anymore.

title: Donald Trumps Call for Muslim Registry Denounced by Democrats
description: NEWTON, Iowa  Donald J. Trumps remarks Thursday that he would absolutely institute mandatory registration of Muslims drew broad condemnation from Democrats Friday and several of his Republican rivals even as some candidates have moved further to the right on national security in the wake of the Paris terror attacks.

title: Israelis React to Pollards Release
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and other Israeli citizens applauded Friday's release of Jonathan J. Pollard, an American convicted of spying for Israel in the 1980s.

title: 1890: The Indian Troubles
description: NEW YORK  The warlike attitude of the Indians in the North-West has undergone a marvelous change within twenty-four hours, owing to the Governments prompt measures to prevent an outbreak. Several hundred braves have disappeared from the Standing Rock Agency, and though it is barely possible that they may have galloped across the country to incite the Northern Cheyennes against the whites, it is more likely that they are running away from what they regard as an impending calamity to the aged warriors and women.

title: Small Residences for the Elderly Provide More Personal, Homelike Care
description: KAY LARMOR, 71, was in and out of conventional nursing homes. Then she found Green House homes at Porter Hills, in Grand Rapids, Mich., which is helping to remake long-term care.

title: Stopping WhatsApp Wont Stop Terrorists
description: IS the ability to send encrypted messages making it hard to stop terrorists? Thats what many intelligence officials and politicians have been saying about rumors that the terrorists in France communicated using encrypted services like WhatsApp or Apple iMessage.

title: Lionel Messi May Return for Clsico Showdown at Real Madrid
description: After almost two months on the sidelines, Lionel Messi could be ready to return to the field for Barcelona  perhaps even in time for a Clsico showdown at Real Madrid on Saturday.

title: Battling the Gods: Atheism in the Ancient World, by Tim Whitmarsh
description: The philosopher Sidney Morgenbesser, beloved by generations of Columbia University students (including me), was known for lines of wit that yielded nuggets of insight. He kept up his instructive shtick until the end, remarking to a colleague shortly before he died: Why is God making me suffer so much? Just because I dont believe in him? For Morgenbesser, nothing worth pondering, including disbelief, could be entirely de-paradoxed.

title: Popcast: The Return of Adele
description: Jon Caramanica and Jon Pareles discuss her new album, 25.

title: 40 Years of Independence
description: When Bill Henderson started the annual Pushcart Prize anthology 40 years ago, he did so from an apartment north of New York City. I was the Yonkers literary establishment, he said in a phone interview.

title: Lois Smiths Year of Working Constantly
description: In 1952, when Lois Smith was 22, she made her professional debut, playing the middle sister, an aspiring actress, in a frothy Broadway comedy called Time Out for Ginger. Brooks Atkinson called her characterization bubbly and enchanting. At the last performance, as she made her final exit, the veteran actor Melvyn Douglas closed the door behind her and ad-libbed, Shes going to be a great actress, that kid.

title: Review: In Neighborhood 3: Requisition of Doom, Video Game Horrors
description: The homey voice of Mister Rogers can be heard chirping that its a beautiful day in the neighborhood shortly before the latest production at the Flea Theater begins. But the audience knows that beautiful days are unlikely to be on the menu. The title of the show is Neighborhood 3: Requisition of Doom, and everyone is happily braced for the campy scarefest that would seem to be signaled by the contrast between the neighborhoods of a childrens television song and those of this plays reality.

title: Stuff We Liked: Tackling Inequality and Measuring Free Speech
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: Lets Make a Plan
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears on nytimes.com. To receive the email, register here.

title: Batman and Rubio? The Drawback of a Youthful Look
description: This article was initially published as a letter to subscribers of The Upshots newsletter. You can sign up for the email here to get this and all of the best of The Upshot.

title: New Technique Can Classify a Fingerprint as Male or Female
description: A simple test performed at a crime scene may help forensic scientists determine whether a fingerprint belongs to a man or a woman, a new study reports.

title: Letters: Jack Kemp and Reaganomics
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the List
description: Beautiful Music: Almost six years ago, when Inside the List asked a handful of authors to declare their literary New Years resolutions, Mitch Albom pledged to read more books about hope and less about angst. It was no surprise, frankly. Can anybody picture Albom  whose heartwarming and slightly gooey best sellers include Tuesdays With Morrie and The Five People You Meet in Heaven  settling in for the night with, say, a dyspeptic Thomas Bernhard novel? Now Alboms back with The Magic Strings of Frankie Presto, about a supernaturally gifted guitarist who influences musicians as diverse as Hank Williams and Wynton Marsalis and Kiss; its new on the hardcover fiction list at No.4. A musician himself, Albom plays keyboards with the Rock Bottom Remainders, where his bandmates include Amy Tan on vocals and Stephen King on rhythm guitar, among assorted other best-selling authors. (We mostly listen to Dave Barry telling booger jokes, Albom has said.) The theme I was trying to build on for this book was that everybody joins a band in life, he told The Philadelphia Daily News this month. Everyone joins a band. We may not think we do, but we do. Somebody plays the lead. Somebody is the rhythm. Somebody holds down the beat. Somebody gets to solo and go all over the place, while the other person gets stuck playing the chords. Thats pretty much how it is in a family. Thats how it is in the Army. Thats how it is in a workplace. Everybody has a role that they play.

title: Not So Fast, 1 Percent Whippersnappers
description: Wealth in America has never looked so young  at least on its face.

title: Paperback Row
description: CHINA 1945: Maos Revolution and Americas Fateful Choice, by Richard Bernstein. (Vintage, $17.) In the span of a year, Americas friendly rapport with Chinese leaders devolved into fraught antagonism. Here, Bernstein, a former New York Times correspondent, argues that the longstanding diplomatic strain between the two countries can be traced to Chinas political disintegration at the end of World War II.

title: Taking a Rational Look at the Risk of Threats
description: THE terrorist attacks in Paris last week that killed 130 people and injured hundreds more instilled fear in millions of people who werent anywhere near the attacks. That, of course, is the point of terrorism.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review: David Hares Memoir
description: This week, David Hare discusses The Blue Touch Paper; Alexandra Alter has news from the publishing world; Sarah Vowell talks about Lafayette in the Somewhat United States; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

title: Donald Trumps Horrifying Plan for American Muslims
description: To say that it is hard to figure out what Donald Trump is talking about is to state the obvious. But sometimes I have to try because he is in fact running for president and hes addressing important issues, or at least sort of talking about them.

title: Editors Choice
description: LETTERS TO VRA, by Vladimir Nabokov. Edited and translated by Olga Voronina and Brian Boyd. (Knopf, $40.) For more than half a century, Nabokov told his wife about his writing, his meals and his observations in exquisite and evocative detail.

title: Chrissie Hyndes Reckless: My Life as a Pretender
description: As the title indicates, Reckless is intended to be a cautionary tale. For 35 years, Chrissie Hynde has carried herself as a keeper of the rock n roll flame, fearless and invulnerable; while the other members of her band, the Pretenders, continually change, she has never wavered from the punk spirit and pop songcraft, nor the signature bangs and eyeliner, that made her one of musics great frontwomen.

title: Thirteen Ways of Looking, by Colum McCann
description: Colum McCann has an old-school belief in the capabilities of literature. Even as au courant novelists all around him grow skeptical of the artifices of character and plot, and embrace the self as the fiction writers only truly accessible subject, McCanns work continues to assert that nothing human is alien to him, that the empathetic imagination can and should go where it pleases. He has written eight previous books in which he fearlessly simulates identities dauntingly remote from his own  including the identities of real-life figures both dead and living  and in which plot performs a function that might fairly be described as redemptive. From the perspective of academic fashion it is a hoary, virtually benighted approach to narrative art; yet to judge by the enormous success of his work, most notably the panoramic novels Let the Great World Spin and TransAtlantic, its appeal to readers somehow endures.

title: Umberto Ecos Numero Zero
description: Umberto Ecos early novels gained a reputation as intellectual entertainments, dense with esoterica and dotted with Latin, of a heft youd rather not drop on your toe. By contrast, his new conspiracy thriller is a fleet volume, slim in pages but plump in satire about modern Italy.

title: 10 Ways to Make an All-Star Game Memorable (Some Better Than Others)
description: After years of sloppy, defense-free hockey in its All-Star Game, the N.H.L. has decided to try something new this season Nashville: a four-team tournament played three-on-three.

title: Intel Lawsuit Questions Place of Hedge Funds in Retirement Plans
description: We push the boundaries.

title: Custers Trials, by T. J. Stiles
description: Is it possible to read a biography of George Armstrong Custer without thinking about his death from the first page? One hundred and thirty-nine years after the Battle of the Little Bighorn, we still cannot say his name without picturing the mutilated bodies of his men or being overwhelmed by the sharp, lingering shame of the Plains Wars and the wholesale slaughter of Native Americans. While we cannot forget how Custer died, however, few of us remember how he lived. Who he was, what he hoped to leave behind, even what brought him to that fateful day in 1876, these questions we cannot answer, and rarely ask.

title: Desperately Seeking Consensus
description: The good people at Vox EU are engaged in a laudable effort to clear the ground for euro reform, starting with the formulation of a consensus narrative about the origins of the euro crisis. This is a very good idea: How you think about the past plays a very large role in how you think about what should be done next.

title: Roasted Squash Salad
description: The sweetness of delicata squash complements the bitter arugula and radicchio in this colorful salad.

title: Squash Gives This Winter Salad a Satisfying Twist
description: Summer salads have it easy. With a bounty of greens in season for the taking, its easy for them to be fresh, bright and pretty.

title: Simon Winchesters Pacific
description: Over the decades, the British-born Simon Winchester has emerged as one of those increasingly rare geographic generalists, migrating from region to region, sharing with his readers an almost tactile sense of the earth, its history and its peoples. His narratives exist within that depressingly vast space between the hairsplitting nuances and abstractions of academia and the vulgar simplicities of cable news pundits. A highbrow out to educate middlebrows, Winchester writes books like someone telling a good yarn around the fireplace, whether about volcanoes, Indian slums or the 19th-century American West. He is an outdoorsman who knows about such things as geology and ocean sailing, which invigorates his prose in the same way as that of another journalistic travel writer, William Langewiesche, who flies planes and also sails. And he certainly has the knack for comparison. When Winchester writes that Hawaii, deep down, in its perceived cultural essence, still evokes what was felt by Gauguin during his time in the Marquesas, it is reminiscent of the British travel writer Jan Morris describing in 1960 how the smells and landscape of the Lido in Venice ignite thoughts of Carthage and Marrakesh.

title: At Parigot in SoHo, Parisians Reflect on Terror Attacks
description: Who knows if its their own sensuality or the sensuous nature of their city, but some Parisians can live abroad for decades and still describe, as though they had smelled it only yesterday, that precise, blended odor of baking baguette and rainy sidewalk that hovers outside their favorite bakery on the Rue Lamarck. One imagines that this sensorial attachment to Paris was never stronger than in recent days, after the city suffered terrorist attacks that killed more than 120 people. At Parigot, an authentically cozy French bistro on Grand Street in SoHo, a trio of Parisians mourned, talked, worried, remembered and toasted one another, both missing their city and at the same time perhaps feeling glad that they were far away.

title: Winnie-the-Poohs Skull: Relic of Inspirational Bear Goes on Display
description: LONDON  The skull of Winnipeg, the bear who inspired Winnie-the-Pooh, has gone on display for the first time at the Hunterian Museum in London.

title: Kurt Vonneguts Breakfast of Champions, Read by John Malkovich
description: Forgive me for starting with an obvious point, but its one I hadnt really considered before I was asked to review an audiobook, or as they used to be called, books on CD, and before that, books on tape, and before that, readings, and before that, storytelling. The point is this: All reading is a form of reading aloud, even when the reading is done in silence. The very act of transferring the words of another into the brain activates the inner voice, the voice that we hear when we read to ourselves. All reading is therefore a vocal performance, generally just for an audience of one. Consider how much the language of reading and writing supports this notion: We talk about an authors voice and tone and rhythm. We ask, What is the author trying to say?

title: Popcast: Adele Returns
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | RSS | Stitcher

title: Terrorism and Refugees Dominate Week in Presidential Race
description: Heightened fears about terrorism and a growing refugee crisis have put presidential candidates on the spot this week, requiring them to come up with harried, and sometimes radical, proposals on how they would handle the new threats facing America. The following is a handy recap of where the leading candidates stand:

title: Obama Administration Asks Supreme Court to Save Immigration Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday asked the Supreme Court to rescue the presidents overhaul of the nations immigration system.

title: A Quiet End to the Death Panels Debate
description: It seemed like a logical idea, the congressman told me, and not a particularly radical one.

title: Movie Studios Turn to Athletes to Create a Buzz
description: On a brisk night last week, a group of Nets players and staff members walked seven blocks from their hotel in downtown Sacramento to a multiplex on the second floor of a sleepy shopping mall.

title: These United States, by Glenda Elizabeth Gilmore and Thomas J. Sugrue
description: This admirably ambitious book seeks to distill a generations worth of scholarship into a fresh history of the long 20th century from the 1890s to the present  the epoch triumphally heralded by Henry Luce in 1941 as the American century.

title: Mary Beards SPQR and Tom Hollands Dynasty
description: How on earth did they do it? The Greek historian Polybius, writing in the second century B.C., was the first to ask the question: Who could be so indifferent or so idle that they did not want to find out how, and under what kind of political organization, almost the whole of the inhabited world was conquered and fell under the sole power of the Romans in less than 53 years? It was not as if Rome was a promising spot: a swampy piece of ground up a barely navigable river surrounded by scrubby hills, its few thousand inhabitants alternately flooded out and ravaged by malaria.

title: Augustine: Conversions to Confessions, by Robin Lane Fox
description: Mihi quaestio factus sum. This Latin phrase bounces around the screen of my sleeping laptop, reminding me of something I know only too well: I have become a problem to myself. It comes from St. Augustines Confessions, his powerful spiritual autobiography that has shaped how Christians and non-Christians in the West have conceived of their life journeys for over 1,500 years. So successful is the book in making readers identify with the author that it has never gone out of print and never seems to age.

title: Soda Politics and Saving Gotham
description: A single can of soda, I think we can all agree, will do you no harm. Twelve ounces of carbonated, sugar-sweetened liquid wont send you spiraling into metabolic syndrome. All it takes, in fact, is 23 minutes of cycling to burn off the 140 calories from all that scary sugar  the very same sugar, its worth pointing out, thats found in healthy foods, such as apples, pears and strawberries.

title: Carrie Brownsteins Hunger Makes Me a Modern Girl
description: Last February, Sleater-Kinney took the stage at Terminal 5 in New York City for the first time in nearly 10 years. Carrie Brownstein, stage right as always, was all our rock-star dreams come true, her arms windmilling, her legs high-kicking, brandishing her guitar above her head, her voice a rough demand. It blended with and crashed against the preternatural wail of her bandmate, the guitarist Corin Tucker, backed with the insistent drums of Janet Weiss; three women making a noise we felt all through our bodies. Playing with them again, Brownstein writes in Hunger Makes Me a Modern Girl, was like being home.

title: The Money Makers, by Eric Rauchway
description: In 2008, the international economy came within weeks of catastrophic collapse. Concerted action by the worlds monetary authorities staved off disaster. Although stagnation continues to plague much of the globe, especially Europe, a major depression was avoided.

title: Magna Carta: The Birth of Liberty, by Dan Jones
description: Modern liberal democracy, we hear, began 800 years ago in England on a marshy field near London. Pressed by his aggrieved subjects, a hated king accepted strict new limits on royal power. The pact, named Magna Carta (Great Charter), became entrenched in British law. A bulwark against oppressive rulers, it inspired 17th-century Englands parliamentarians and 18th-century Americas revolutionaries. It remains a founding text of Western constitutional government.

title: Lights Out, by Ted Koppel
description: The possibility that terrorists or a hostile foreign state could take down the American power grid either by a cyberattack or by an electromagnetic pulse attack is one of those haunting possibilities that keep strategic planners from sleeping peacefully at night. In Lights Out: A Cyberattack, a Nation Unprepared, Surviving the Aftermath, Ted Koppel, one of Americas most experienced and best-known journalists, has attempted to show readers why the danger is real, the degree to which the authorities are unprepared and the steps we can take now to be ready when the power goes down.

title: Aural Sex
description: Last month I finished recording an audio version of my new book in four days  a full day ahead of schedule  and I was feeling pretty good about it. It helped that the audio technician at DuArt, a film and recording studio in Midtown Manhattan, could hear like a bat and caught every stomach gurgle. As I was about to leave, I jokingly asked the audiobook studio director if he could make the book a runaway audio best seller.

title: Joe Kleins Charlie Mike
description: Kenneth Harbaugh, a former Navy pilot, believes that humor can be wrung from the most awful things. As he recalls, one of his fellow veterans, a double amputee, used to laugh about losing $300 worth of tattoos. But the joke turned somber when Harbaughs friend added that what he regretted most wasnt the loss of his tattoos or limbs; it was that he didnt stop enough shrapnel with his own body to save his squad mate from getting hit.

title: Faction
description: MRS. ENGELSBy Gavin McCrea389 pp. Catapult, paper, $16.95.

title: The Expansionary Austerity Zombie
description: The doctrine of expansionary austerity  the proposition that cuts in government spending would actually cause higher growth despite their direct negative impact on demand, thanks to the confidence fairy  was all the rage in policy circles five years ago. But it brutally failed the reality test; instead, the evidence pointed overwhelmingly to the continued existence of something very like the old-fashioned Keynesian multiplier.

title: Hostages Seized at Hotel in Mali
description: Reports say dozens were killed on Friday morning after an unknown number of gunmen stormed the Radisson Blu in the countrys capital.

title: The Fashion News to Know This Week
description: Conscious Gooping

title: Thieves Steal 17 Artworks From Verona Museum
description: ROME  Masked bandits broke into one of Veronas most important museums and stole 17 paintings, including works by Mantegna and Rubens, and five pieces by Jacopo Tintoretto. The museum estimated the total value at between $10.7 million and $16 million.

title: CNN Sets Polling Requirements to Make Main Stage at Next G.O.P. Debate
description: CNN is broadening its criteria for next months Republican presidential debate, including polling from Iowa and New Hampshire to determine which candidates make the main stage.

title: A Panic Button for the Phone
description: Samantha Nelson was only 32 when she died after a heart attack in 2010. Ms. Nelson, who had been on the phone with her mother and sister just a couple of hours before she died, had pledged to call back after she took a bath, but had not been heard from. Then the call came. Ms. Nelson was frantic; she had just awaked in a tub filled with scalding water with little clue as to how she got there.

title: Millennials Investing in Rental Properties
description: Travis Killian, a business owner in Austin, Tex., is a typical 27-year-old in that he doesnt own his own home  he is a renter. But unlike many of his peers, he can afford to buy. In fact, he owns nine single-family rental properties in various cities around the country, and is in the process of buying eight more.

title: Online Support Grows for Missing Maryland College Student
description: The search for a Maryland college student who was last seen on Monday and may have a rifle has taken a more personal turn as people reached out through social media posts addressed to Jacob.

title: Cable & Wireless Looks Past John Malones Complex Deal
description: The deal to acquire Cable & Wireless Communications undercuts one of John C. Malones favorite and most fiendish pieces of financial engineering.

title: In Jordan Matters Photos, Dancers Make All the World Their Stage
description: It is hard not to feel buoyant looking at the images in Dancers Among Us: Photographs by Jordan Matter, at the Hudson River Museum. Dancers leap through the air, extending their limbs into gravity-defying poses that combine exuberance, grace, virtuosity and whimsy.

title: T City Guides: London
description: Five leaders in creative fields share their favorite places to eat, drink, shop and play.

title: Politely, Ted Cruz Demurs From Donald Trumps Idea for a Muslim Registry
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa  As Republicans grapple with how to respond to Donald J. Trumps caustic comments about Muslims, Senator Ted Cruz seems to be groping for a middle way.

title: Urban Charter Schools Often Succeed. Suburban Ones Often Dont.
description: Charter schools are controversial. But are they good for education?

title: My 10 Favorite Books: John Waters
description: For his bookshop installation, One Grand, the editor Aaron Hicklin asked people to name the 10 books theyd take with them if they were marooned on a desert island. The next in the series is the cult film director and writer John Waters. He shares his list exclusively with T.

title: College Football Games to Watch on Saturday
description: No. 9 Michigan State at No. 2 Ohio State

title: A Lesson at Harvard Law
description: To the Editor:

title: Greece Presents 2016 Budget and Revamps Recession Prediction
description: ATHENS  Greece on Friday presented an optimistic budget for 2016, predicting a recession milder than expected in previous forecasts.

title: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in the New York region:

title: On the Market in the New York Region
description: This weeks homes include a seven-bedroom in Pelham Manor, N.Y., and a three-bedroom in Bridgeport, Conn.

title: Going Soft on White-Collar Crime
description: Jennifer Taub is a professor at Vermont Law School. Her financial crisis book Other Peoples Houses was published in 2014 by Yale University Press.

title: Jiehae Parks Peerless to World Premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater
description: If there were standardized tests for emerging playwrights, its a good bet that Jiehae Park would ace them. Her darkly comic play Peerless, which relocates elements of Macbeth to an American high school in the Midwest during college admissions season, opens on Nov. 27 at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven. This major, highly esteemed credit now joins a long list of brand-name honors, grants and play-development workshops on her sterling rsum.

title: Manhattan Dentist Is Arrested on Drug and Pornography Charges
description: John Wolf, a dentist in the Chelsea section of Manhattan, is well known in the neighborhood  not only for his popular, light-filled offices, but also for his AIDS activism. He studied the disease in dentistry school, according to his Google profile, and as a practicing dentist in the 1980s he brought, and won, a prominent lawsuit against a landlord who did not want him to treat patients with AIDS.

title: Fidelity Joins Growing Field of Automated Financial Advice
description: Fidelity Investments is flirting with the investment robots.

title: 5 Tips for Potential Corporate Whistle-Blowers
description: Jordan Thomas is chairman of the whistle-blower representation practice at Labaton Sucharow and was a former assistant director in the enforcement division of the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Paris: One Week Later
description: Life in Paris is slowly returning to normal, but people are still recovering from the terrorist attacks of Nov. 13. Here, four Parisians discuss the attacks and what has followed.

title: Escape Rooms Bring New Attractions to New Jersey
description: Eric Rama and Teresa Pulcrano were strangers when they walked into Exit Strategy in Montclair recently. An hour later, when they emerged, Mr. Rama was praising Ms. Pulcranos sports trivia knowledge.

title: What We Know and Dont Know About the Terrorist Attack in Mali
description: Gunmen seized a hotel in Bamako, the capital of Mali, on Friday, taking about 100 people hostage and killing more than two dozen. The attack is the latest eruption of violence in Mali, a former French colony in West Africa that has been racked by an Islamist insurgency for the past three years.

title: How Nicole A. Taylor, Cookbook Author, Spends Her Sundays
description: In college, a friend of Nicole A. Taylors called her the black Betty Crocker, which is not a bad catchphrase to recall when youre promoting a new cookbook during the holidays. A Georgia native, she is the author of The Up South Cookbook: Chasing Dixie in a Brooklyn Kitchen and the host of the podcast Hot Grease, in which she tells stories related to Southern food. Ms. Taylor, 37, who said Southern cooking didnt become part of her career until she moved to New York City in 2008, lives with her husband, Adrian Franks, 39, an artist and a user-experience design director at IBM, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn.

title: For Woman Dead in French Police Raid, Unlikely Path to Terror
description: LONDON  When about 100 heavily armed police officers and soldiers took position shortly after 4 a.m. Wednesday outside the building in the Paris suburb of St.-Denis where the presumed ringleader of the Paris attacks was holed up, a young woman appeared in a window.

title: Iowa Coach Kirk Ferentz Guides Undefeated Hawkeyes to Unfamiliar Heights
description: IOWA CITY  In the early 1970s, amid the Iowa football teams 19-year streak without a winning season, the former University of Iowa president Willard Boyd arrived early to a Big Ten meeting and made small talk with his friend Novice Fawcett, the president of Ohio State.

title: A Tender, Intimate Video by Dash Snow
description: The exhibition Dash Snow: Freeze Means Run, on view now at the Brant Foundation Art Study Center in Greenwich, Conn., was conceived as a labor of love. The career-spanning retrospective was organized in part by three of the late artists best friends: Dan Colen, Hanna Liden and Nate Lowman. Their mission to honor the memory of their comrade and (sometimes literal) partner in crime is evident throughout the show, which comprises many of the artists best known and most controversial works  including the front pages of newspapers he infamously decorated with his own bodily fluid  but which is more striking in its inclusion of more personal work from Snow. Among the more than 100 previously unexhibited Polaroids on display are many that depict Snow and his friends drinking and drugging, or in lithe, louche repose  windows on a moment in time that seems, in retrospect, inevitably brief.

title: Thanksgiving Leftovers Go Beyond the Turkey Sandwich
description: Some cooks prefer the Thanksgiving meal proper, with its generous platters and long, festive table. Others are impatient for the after-party, the prospect of raiding the fridge at midnight, or the anticipated snack the next day, when the bounty is neatly packed away.

title: Jessica Jones Episode 1: The Worst in People
description: While immediately engaging, A.K.A. Ladies Night, the first episode of Jessica Jones, sometimes leans too hard on its title characters alienated, hyper-cynical worldview. The pilots pseudo-hard-boiled (read: moodily under-lit) style and intricate narrative, with multiple overlapping subplots integrating by episodes end, is mostly an effective continuation of the Hells Kitchen-focused, adult-oriented brand of drama that Marvel Comics and Netflix first tried with Daredevil earlier this year.

title: An Eerie New Sound Installation, Made From Broken Instruments
description: When visitors enter the Duveen galleries in Londons Tate Britain this weekend, theyll be greeted by the sound of bugles that once played at the battle of Waterloo and the Charge of the Light Brigade. The breathy, rasping tones  which are broadcast from 14 large, horn-shaped speakers  are part of War Damaged Musical Instruments, a new work by the sound artist Susan Philipsz.

title: Bobbing and Weaving With New Yorks Bravest
description: Susan Merlucci Reno coaches the Fire Departments boxing team ahead of its annual bout with Police Department fighters at Madison Square Garden.

title: Draining ISIS' Coffers
Poll Watch: Democrats, Even Clinton Supporters, Warm to Socialism
description: Senator Bernie Sanderss speech on Thursday explaining his democratic socialist ideology carried little risk among supporters and other Democrats: A solid majority of them have a positive impression of socialism, according to a New York Times/CBS News poll released this month.

title: Fantasy Football Week 11: Rankings and Matchup Analysis
description: Fantasy football analysis for N.F.L. Week 11 games and Mondays matchup between the New England Patriots and the Buffalo Bills. You can also follow the Sablich brothers on Twitter at @5thDownFantasy and see their complete Week 11 player rankings.

title: More Trump and Carson on Syrian Refugees
description: While the G.O.P. hopeful Ben Carson walked back his rabid dog statement about Syrian refugees, Donald J. Trump said it is easier for Syrian Muslims to get into the United States than Christians.

title: Inside The New York Times Book Review Podcast: David Hares Memoir
description: Listen to this weeks podcast | Subscribe: iTunes | Stitcher

title: Donald Trump Steps Back From Calling for Muslim Registry
description: Donald J. Trump drew back Friday from calling for a national database to keep track of Muslims in America, saying that the suggestion had come from a reporter.

title: Homes for Sale in Brooklyn and Manhattan
description: Click on the slide show to see this weeks featured properties in New York City:

title: On the Market in New York City
description: This weeks properties are in Park Slope, Brooklyn, and in Manhattans Kips Bay and Upper West Side neighborhoods.

title: Lighting a Fire Under New Yorks Bravest Boxing Squad
description: New York City firefighters are known for rushing to emergencies, but getting to boxing practice, at least according to Susan Merlucci Reno, is another story.

title: Experience the Vigils in Paris in Virtual Reality With NYT VR
description: Our newest virtual reality film looks at Paris in the aftermath of the Nov. 13 terror attacks. Use the free NYT VR mobile app, with your headphones and optional cardboard viewing device, to experience it.

title: For Transgender Rights Opponents, Houston Wasnt Enough
description: The Houston Equal Rights Ordinance wouldve granted those who visit, live or work in Houston protection from discrimination based on sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, familial status, marital status, military status, religion, disability, sexual orientation, genetic information, gender identity or pregnancy.

title: A West Village Penthouse for $25.49 Million
description: The latest in a flurry of sales at the Greenwich Lane, an almost blocklong condominium complex on the site of the former St. Vincents Hospital campus in the West Village, was filed with the city this past week  a spacious duplex penthouse with a private rooftop terrace that sold for $25,489,849.99 and was the most expensive closed sale, according to public records.

title: British Police Apologize for Undercover Officers Intimate Tactics
description: LONDON  They lived together, traveled abroad on vacation and, for five years, behaved like any other couple. Then one day the man, who called himself Mark Cassidy, disappeared, leading his bewildered ex-partner to eventually discover that she had been living with a married police spy.

title: In Los Angeles, Jewelry Mingles With Midcentury Design
description: It took some convincing to get Tommy Perse, the owner of the L.A. boutique Maxfield, to agree to the jewelry installation Nomad 1957. But Lisa Eisner is nothing if not persuasive. A longtime patron of the Los Angeles fashion institution, Eisner, a jewelry designer (and sometime artist, stylist, photographer and publisher), began selling pieces at Maxfield earlier this year. Three months ago, the store approached her to do an out-of-the-box installation with her pieces. Eisners first instinct was to ask about Structure Nomade  a large, prefab space designed by the French architect Jean Prouv in 1957 that sits just outside Maxfields entrance, which had never been used for anything.

title: Funeral in Pakistan for Militants Killed in U.S. Strikes Draws Hundreds
description: LOWER DIR, Pakistan  A mass funeral on Friday for as many as 20 local militants said to have been killed by American airstrikes in neighboring Afghanistan drew hundreds of mourners in the northwestern Pakistani district of Lower Dir, according to local residents and participants.

title: TheDivergent Styles of Jane Freilicher and Jane Wilson
description: The artists Jane Freilicher and Jane Wilson had a lot in common besides their first names. Both were painters, both worked in the East End of Long Island starting in the late 1950s, both lived at the same address for a time and both died recently at age 90, within five weeks of each other.

title: Who Turned My Blue State Red?
description: IT is one of the central political puzzles of our time: Parts of the country that depend on the safety-net programs supported by Democrats are increasingly voting for Republicans who favor shredding that net.

title: Why It Takes Two Years for Syrian Refugees to Enter the U.S.
description: Syrians must pass through many steps of security clearances before being admitted to the United States.

title: Miguel Cotto Nears Retirement Fighting Canelo Alvarez, and the W.B.C.
description: LAS VEGAS  Miguel Cotto sat expressionless on the dais, arms crossed, as he listened to Oscar De La Hoya speak at a prefight news conference on Wednesday.

title: Deforestation May Threaten Majority of Amazon Tree Species, Study Finds
description: Deforestation threatens more than half of all tree species in the Amazon, a new study suggests.

title: Yahoo Restricts Ad-Blocking Software for Some Email Users
description: Millions of people swear by the ad blocker, software that lets you browse the web free of online advertising. The companies who want you to see the ads are starting to push back.

title: Review: Anthony de Mare Introduces the Last of His Sondheim Project
description: Its all in the details. That could almost be a motto for Stephen Sondheim, who works so hard to get the details right in his songs.

title: Review: Saints & Strangers, a Thanksgiving Story Told in a Native Tongue
description: In Saints & Strangers, National Geographics compelling two-part film about the Mayflower settlers and the first Thanksgiving, the cast members playing American Indians speak their lines in an almost extinct language called Western Abenaki. Its a bold choice, both because of the challenge for the cast and because it means much of the film is subtitled. But its strikingly appropriate, since in this story, the language barrier is everything.

title: Review: Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba Brings Precision to a Fusion
description: Hamstrings cant be the only strained body parts for a member of Lizt Alfonso Dance Cuba. They must also need to ice their jaws. These dancers smile so hard that after the third or fourth number, your own mouth may start to ache in solidarity.

title: First Draft Focus: The Week in Political Pictures
Caring for Premature Babies, With a Little Help From Beyonc
New Rentals Steps From St. John the Divine
description: Although luxury apartment towers and revered religious buildings might seem like awkward neighbors, the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Morningside Heights will soon welcome the second residential development to its 11.3-acre campus.

title: What Were Reading
description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

title: Roanoke Mayor Apologizes for Japanese Internment Remarks
description: The longtime mayor of Roanoke, Va., who faced criticism this week for citing Japanese internment camps in his defense of limiting Syrian refugee assistance, apologized on Friday.

title: Michael Skolnik Taps His Social Network to Fight for Civil Rights
description: In mid-September, in the enduring boil of the national debate over race and the police, President Obama appeared one afternoon in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building to host a screening of a new documentary from Vice magazine on the criminal-justice system. It was one of those carefully organized Washington affairs: There were speeches, panel talks and a curated guest list that included Senator Cory A. Booker of New Jersey, the hip-hop artist Ludacris, the actor Tim Robbins, the Rev. Al Sharpton, an activist from Ferguson, Mo., some former prison inmates and Shane Smith, the chief executive of Vice.

title: Home Sales Around the New York Region
description: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Daisy Prince on Her Greenwich Village Apartment
description: When Daisy Prince and her husband, Hugh Chisholm, returned to New York in 2009 after eight years in London, they moved to Greenwich Village, where she had wanted to live since she was a college student in the 1990s. I attended Barnard, and you spend most of your time trying to go downtown to a club or hear music, she said. And then when we moved downtown, I was like, wait a minute, I missed the memo  when did everyone move to Brooklyn?

title: What I Love | Daisy Prince
description: Daisy Prince, the editor of Avenue magazine, which just published its 40th anniversary issue, lives in Greenwich Village with her family.

title: Hillary Clinton Proposes Middle-Class Tax Cut Tied to Health Care
description: MEMPHIS  Hillary Rodham Clinton on Friday proposed a tax credit for families and individuals who face excessive and unexpected health care costs, the first part of multipronged approach to giving middle-class Americans tax relief that she will unveil in the coming days, according to her campaign.

title: Why Cool Is Still Cool
description: THE word cool has been cool for a long time. Originally associated with temperature, by the 16th century the term had evolved to describe not just the atmosphere, but also an internal state of calm, almost icy composure. And by the late 1800s it began to signify style and hipness and some of the other meanings with which it is associated today. Now cool is used as a synonym for almost anything good. Music can be cool and restaurants can be cool. Every so often even a minivan seems cool.

title: Review: Julia Murney in Honesty Mode at Feinsteins/54 Below
description: Julia Murney doesnt mince words. The high point of her untitled opening-night show at Feinsteins/54 Below on Thursday was a sing-along rendition of Sara Bareilless Sweet as Whole. It was prefaced by an anecdote about a man urinating in a New York subway station, Ms. Murneys disgust and another observers mean-spirited reaction.

title: My Life as a Muslim in the Wests Gray Zone
description: Some months ago, I gave a reading from my most recent novel in Scottsdale, Ariz. During the discussion that followed, a woman asked me to talk about my upbringing in Morocco. Its natural for readers to be curious about a writer theyve come to hear, I told myself. I continued to tell myself this even after the conversation drifted to Islam, and then to ISIS. Eventually, another woman raised her hand and said that the only Muslims she saw when she turned on the television were extremists. Why arent we hearing more from people like you? she asked me.

title: Friday Night Music: The Lone Bellow Cover The Rolling Stones
States Urged to Review Health Insurer Mergers
description: Consumer advocates and antitrust experts are urging state regulators to closely examine the proposed mergers of major health insurance companies, saying they threaten to leave consumers with fewer choices and higher prices.

title: Pictures of the Day: Greece and Elsewhere
description: Greece and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Nov. 20, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Greece, Mali, Israel and India.

title: Review: More Up a Tree, Performance Art Through the Looking Glass
description: Ten minutes before the start of More Up a Tree, if you had walked into the Fishman Space, the black-box theater within BAM Fisher, you would have first seen the performers themselves, the dancer Claudia de Serpa Soares and the drummer Jim White, both in the middle of a wood-framed glass enclosure in the center of the room. You had nothing else to look at  except the other members of the audience, free to walk around the enclosure before and during the performance.

title: Americans View Paris Attacks With Empathy, Fear and Resolve
description: DENVER  It made parents worry for their children studying abroad. It sent a shiver of fear into plans for vacations to France. Cafes and nightclubs in Miami and Los Angeles felt newly vulnerable, not so different from the bloody scenes unfolding on peoples phones and televisions. For Americans accustomed to tuning out foreign conflicts, it brought the world crashing in.

title: Fox Drops Ratings for Live Viewership
description: Fox became the first broadcast network to declare that it no longer would acknowledge or release ratings for its shows that measure only live or same-day viewing, calling the figures irrelevant as viewers increasingly stream shows or watch on DVRs or on demand.

title: Greek New Testament Papyrus Is Discovered on eBay
description: Last January, Geoffrey Smith, a scholar of early Christianity at the University of Texas, noticed something startling: an eBay listing for an ancient Greek papyrus fragment of the Gospel of John  with an opening bid of only $99.

title: What Was That Above Ohio?
description: People in Ohio, Kentucky and Indiana reported a fireball in the sky on Thursday night. A security camera in Cincinnati captured footage of the reason: a meteor.

title: Syrian Refugees Biking to Safety
description: Syrian refugees seeking safe haven in Europe have taken to the Arctic Circle, where they cycle the final stretch across the border from Russia into Norway.

title: Review: Resurrecting a Pair of Rachmaninoff Flops
description: The New York Philharmonic played two famous failures on Thursday: the pieces that brought Rachmaninoff perhaps the most excoriation when they were new.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing: Mali, Adele, Donald Trump
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Bill Cunningham | City Blues
description: A surprise: blue among the autumnal foliage. It was all over the city, from Storefront Academys 1890s rowhouse porches in Harlem to, for the first time, morning glories that cascaded over the Fifth Avenue fence of the 1914 Frick home that now houses Henry Clay Fricks art collection. Some wearers added burgundy hats to their outfits that were the shade of some of the closed morning glories in the evening.

title: A Dutch ISIS Fighter Takes Questions on Tumblr
description: Usually, by the time the public learns the names and biographies of Islamic State militants, or radicals from other groups who attack civilians, they are already dead, and so unable to speak for themselves, except occasionally in the ritualized form of martyrdom videos or manifestoes posted online.

title: For Gregg Turkingtons Character, Theres No Success Like Failure
description: In the film Entertainment, Gregg Turkington plays a comedian grinding through a surreally low-level gig circuit and beginning to suffer delusions and near-catatonia.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Celebrities Will Evade Fans and Photographers at Los Angeles Airport Lounge
description: LOS ANGELES  Kanye West has had words (and more) with photographers chasing him at Los Angeles International Airport; a friend of the actor Jared Leto tangled with one in August, and the list goes on and on.

title: An Ancient Stream Under a Manhattan Building Leads to a Dispute
description: With New York Citys overheated real estate market showing no signs of cooling, disputes over developments tend to sprout like weeds. Many feel familiar: A project is too big or too unsightly and will blight a neighborhood or force out people of modest means or end the long run of a beloved mom-and-pop shop.

title: Bipartisan Bill Would Protect Service Members Right to Avoid Arbitration
description: Two senators have introduced a bill aimed at preserving the rights of military service members to go to court.

title: Ta-Nehisi Coates: I Dont Want to Be Anybodys Expert
description: As he accepted the National Book Award for nonfiction for Between the World and Me on Wednesday, Ta-Nehisi Coates took a moment to marvel that he had written the book at all.

title: Russian Newspapers Scoop? Based on Fake Letters, U.S. Says
description: MOSCOW  When reporters at Russias government-leaning newspaper Izvestia found an archive of letters, supposedly written by State Department employees to a prominent Russian gay, bisexual, transgender and intersex activist, they thought they had stumbled upon an extraordinary trove.

title: Adam Johnson, Inspired by Holograms, Humor and Escape
description: When Adam Johnsons short-story collection Fortune Smiles won the National Book Award for fiction on Wednesday night, Mr. Johnson joined an elite group of literary greats who have won that honor and the Pulitzer Prize in quick succession, a club that includes Philip Roth, Wallace Stegner, Saul Bellow and Eudora Welty.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Plans 2-Month Paternity Leave From Facebook
description: Facebooks chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, said he planned to take two months of paternity leave after his daughter is born this year, amid a debate about work-life balance at technology companies.

title: With Permanent Squad, New York Police Step Up Fight on Terrorism
description: In January, several days after heavily armed terrorists attacked Charlie Hebdo, a satirical newspaper in Paris, top officials with the New York Police Department held a drill to test the citys response to such an attack and found they had a problem.

title: Mexicos Participation in 16 Olympics Imperiled by Intramural Dispute
description: MEXICO CITY  A dispute between Mexicos government and the nations sports federations over how public money is spent and how athletes will be selected for the 2016 Olympics could result in Mexicos being barred from participating as a team at the Games.

title: U.N. Security Council Approves Resolution Urging Countries to Combat Islamic State
description: The United Nations Security Council on Friday adopted a resolution, drafted by France, calling on countries around the world to take all necessary measures to fight the Islamic State.

title: Argentina Considers Shift as Upstart Rises in Presidential Race
description: HUMAHUACA, Argentina  Winding down a presidential campaign that is upending this countrys politics, Mauricio Macri dutifully chewed on coca leaves, a symbol of the resilience of indigenous culture in this remote corner of northern Argentina. Raising his voice barely above a murmur, he asked Mother Earth for the wisdom to guide Argentina down the righteous path.

title: Benjamin Clementine Wins 2015 Mercury Prize
description: Benjamin Clementine, a pianist, poet, singer-songwriter and former Paris busker, was awarded the 2015 Mercury Prize on Friday in London for the best British or Irish album of the year. The prestigious award, which calls itself the music equivalent to the Booker Prize for literature and the Turner Prize for art, comes with a cash prize of 20,000 pounds, or about $30,500.

title: Syrian Family Diverted From Indiana Feels Welcomed in Connecticut
description: NEW HAVEN  The couple from Syria arrived at Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday only to face one more shock in a four-year journey of loss, anxiety and upheaval. They had no idea they had landed in a political maelstrom.

title: F.D.A. Takes Issue With the Term Non-G.M.O.
description: Lost in the news about the Food and Drug Administrations approval of genetically engineered salmon on Thursday was its long-awaited guidelines on labeling food with or without genetically altered plant ingredients.

title: Administration Is Seeking Ways to Keep Prescription Drugs Affordable
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration began building a political case Friday for government actions to protect people against high pharmaceutical costs, saying millions of Americans were unable to afford lifesaving prescription drugs.

title: John E. Zuccotti, Urbanist, Financier and Would-Be Mayor, Dies at 78
description: John E. Zuccotti, a street-smart urbanist who was an unsung hero of New York Citys fiscal crisis in the 1970s, died on Thursday in Brooklyn. He was 78.

title: Donald Trumps Take on de Blasio? The Worst Mayor in the U.S.
description: Donald J. Trump tore into Mayor Bill de Blasio on Twitter on Friday, accusing New York Citys top elected official of ineptitude and calling him the worst Mayor in the U.S., & probably the worst Mayor in the history of #NYC.

title: After Unusual Stumbles, Rafael Nadals Year Ends in Hope
description: LONDON  On the eve of the year-end ATP World Tour Finals, Rafael Nadal mused, In the work, always there is a solution, no?

title: A Plague of Bucks and Does on Staten Island
description: Last month, a stag reportedly gored a German shepherd named Sprocket, puncturing the dogs lung with an antler. Two days later, one jumped through a window at a T.J. Maxx store, then bounded bloodied up and down the aisles of clothes.

title: Workers Ratify U.A.W. Contracts With General Motors and Ford
description: Bringing to a close a tumultuous bargaining season with American vehicle manufacturers, the United Automobile Workers ratified contracts Friday with General Motors and Ford Motor.

title: Groups Claiming Responsibility in Mali Attack Have History of Resilience
description: WASHINGTON  The two Islamic extremist groups that claimed responsibility for the assault on the Radisson Blu hotel in Mali on Friday are among the most dangerous and resilient in a hodgepodge of terrorist organizations in northwest Africa that have ties to nomadic tribesmen as well as Al Qaeda.

title: Tom Buckley, Versatile and Colorful Times Reporter, Dies at 87
description: Tom Buckley, a versatile reporter for The New York Times who covered the United Nations and the war in Vietnam, wrote columns about New York City and articles for the Sunday magazine, and as a television critic panned Hill Street Blues, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87.

title: Legos Success Leads to Competitors and Spinoffs
description: When Paul Hollingsworth tried to recreate Jurassic Park in a video using Lego bricks, he ran into a roadblock. Lego offers plenty of T. rexes, velociraptors and other dinosaurs, but not Richard Attenborough or Jeff Goldblum, who played characters in the movie.

title: Paris and Mali Attacks Expose Lethal Qaeda-ISIS Rivalry
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Before the hostage crisis at a Malian hotel was over, before the gunmen had even been identified, admirers of Al Qaeda and the rival Islamic State started jostling on social media over which of the jihadist organizations was more righteous and more prominent.

title: Donald Trump Sets Off a Furor With Call to Register Muslims in the U.S.
description: Under assault from Democrats and Republicans alike, Donald J. Trump on Friday drew back from his call for a mandatory registry of Muslims in the United States, trying to quell one of the ugliest controversies yet in a presidential campaign like few others.

title: Paris Attacks Force European Union to Act on Border Controls
description: PARIS  If Europes system of passport-free travel was not under enough pressure after a summer of chaotic migration, then last weeks attacks in Paris have fortified doubts over how much longer that freedom of movement  one of the most cherished accomplishments of the European Union  can survive.

title: What the Saudis Miss When They Focus on Iran
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  It doesnt take long in Saudi Arabia to see evidence of an obsession with Iran, the Shiite foil to this Sunni country. In recent conversations, government officials, analysts and members of the royal family were quick to describe how incensed they were that President Obama hadnt found a way to remove Bashar al-Assad, the Syrian president and Irans close ally, from power.

title: Iowas Climate-Change Wisdom
description: Iowa City  NEGOTIATORS en route to the United Nations conference on climate change in Paris, scheduled to begin later this month, should take a detour on rural roads here in Johnson County. A new climate narrative is emerging among farmers in the American heartland that transcends a lot of the old story lines of denial and cynicism, and offers an updated tale of climate hope.

title: Jury Orders Washington to Pay Wrongfully Convicted Man $16.65 Million
description: The government of Washington, D.C., has agreed to pay $16.65 million to a man after a federal jury found that two police detectives had framed him for the 1981 rape and murder of a college student, a crime for which he was wrongly imprisoned for 27 years.

title: Brinkmanship in the South China Sea
description: Few issues are more important to Asia than the free flow of navigation through the South China Sea, a channel for some $5 trillion in annual trade. And no threat to that trade is as grave as Chinas claim to indisputable sovereignty over fully 90 percent of the sea. It is no surprise that President Obama and several other leaders were giving the issue high priority this week during back-to-back summit meetings in the region.

title: The Price of Fear
description: After the attacks in Paris, the world is again challenged by fear. With every bombing, beheading and mass shooting, the dread spreads, along with the urgency of defeating this nihilism.

title: Coalition Pushes for Memorial to the Triangle Fire
description: A block east of Washington Square, not far from the neighborhoods boutiques and chic restaurants, was the site of one of the nations worst industrial disasters. Many New Yorkers might be unaware of this.

title: Fighting Scoliosis, and Dreaming of Having Her Own Business Again
description: After her lifelong disability worsened, Carmen Gonzalezs hard-fought professional, personal and financial successes started to crumble rapidly. To improve her health, she underwent surgery, which left her with 22 screws in her back and in perpetual pain.

title: You Cant Please Everyone
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  I say this a lot, but if this is where you get off the weekly crossword carousel, so to speak, get back up on that horsie and ride again. You wont be sorry.

title: Pregnant Woman Killed in Stabbing in the Bronx
description: A baby girl, only a few minutes old, swaddled in a blanket or clothes, was breathing on the hood of a car in the Wakefield section of the Bronx. Inside a two-family home nearby, her 22-year-old mother lay on the floor in a pool of blood, fatally stabbed several times in her torso and neck, the authorities said. She had been close to nine months pregnant.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:
