description: To the Editor:

title: For an Ethics Bill in Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and French Responses to Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Laffoley, Painter Inspired by Time Travel and Aliens, Dies at 80
description: Paul Laffoley, whose annotated diagrammatic paintings, with their kaleidoscopic representations of abstruse philosophic systems, made him one of the most distinctive and cerebral of the outsider artists, died on Nov. 16 at his home in Boston. He was 80.

title: 7 New York City Schools Will Reserve Slots for Disadvantaged Students
description: Taking a small step to address segregation in New York City schools, the Education Department announced on Friday that it would allow seven schools to reserve slots for children from low-income or non-English speaking families.

title: U.S. Victimof Mali Attack Worked on Womens Health
description: Anita Ashok Datar, an American public health worker from the Washington suburbs, was killed Friday when gunmen attacked a luxury hotel in Malis capital, Bamako, killing at least 19 people and taking as many as 100 more hostage.

title: Skeloss Son Wanted C.E.O. Removed in Failed Takeover Bid, Witness Says
description: It was a request that would have been extraordinary and unreasonable, no matter who had made it.

title: Islanders Are Adjusting Faster to Their New Home Than Their Fans Are
description: The Islanders have a winning record. They are coming off a 101-point season and are playing at a level that should keep them in the playoff race all season.

title: Knicks Win, Surviving Late Rally by Thunder
description: In their not-so-distant past, road trips were the stuff of nightmares for the Knicks. Opposing crowds loved seeing them come to town. Things have changed. The Knicks ventured to Oklahoma City on Friday and sent another message in a month full of them by defeating the Thunder, 93-90.

title: Paris Victims, Remembered
description: At least 130 people were killed Nov. 13. They included an architect, an American college student, an Algerian violinist and many, many music fans. Here are some of their stories.

title: Yankees Lose Whitley
description: The right-handed pitcher Chase Whitley, who is recovering from Tommy John surgery, was claimed off waivers from the Yankees by Tampa Bay. The Yankees also added pitchers Johnny Barbato and Rookie Davis, as well as outfielder Ben Gamel, to the 40-man roster, which had to be finalized by Friday.

title: Republicans Discuss Geopolitics at Thanksgiving Table in Iowa
description: DES MOINES  Seven Republican candidates sat around a mocked-up Thanksgiving table here on Fridaynight, gathered to discuss issues of hearth and home before an audience of more than 1,000 Christian evangelicals.

title: Seeking Remedies From Home
description: Immigrants turn to stores known as botanicas that sell plant-based medicines and herbs for cures to what ails them.

title: What to Watch Saturday
description: Get your Saturday night jollies with the turkeys, whether Fifty Shades of Grey or a couple of movies starring the actual bird. Then fall asleep to bittersweet lullabies from Adele.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: There was no plan. We were just hoping for the best.

title: Corrections: November 21, 2015
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: 9 Foreigners Killed in Mali Are Identified
description: BEIJING  Three senior executives of a Chinese state-owned rail construction company and six Russian employees of a cargo company were among the 19 victims of the gunmen who attacked a hotel in the capital of the West African nation of Mali.

title: Cate Blanchetts Oscars Looks
description: With Carol, the actress is back in the Oscar race and with it the inevitable red carpet question: Who are you wearing?

title: Unilever Finds That Shrinking Its Footprint Is a Giant Task
description: Hellmanns mayonnaise is known for many things  making egg salad delicious, being loaded with fat, that old bring out the best jingle. To date, however, it hasnt been associated with sustainability. Mayo is a processed food made by huge conglomerates, not a symbol of environmentalism.

title: The Nanny Factor in Hollywood Marriages
description: When Jennifer Schuur Herbert passes a rack of tabloid magazines in her Los Angeles neighborhood, she is often reminded of what can happen in even the most glamorous Hollywood marriages.

title: Why Snapping Is the New Clapping
description: Christian Bailey, a 58-year-old physicist who works for a manufacturing company in Elkton, Md., was attending a conference on progressive health care issues when he began to feel self-conscious. He would look around and notice a key difference between himself and nearly everyone else in the room.

title: The True Story of Sergeant Goosby and His 19 Dogs
description: LOS ANGELES  If they ask you to wear the bite suit, say no.

title: Lee Millers Journey From Model to War Photographer
description: London  In 1927, a chance encounter on a New York sidewalk with the media mogul Cond Nast made the gamine beauty Lee Miller a magazine cover girl and modeling sensation. Later, as the lover and muse of the artist Man Ray, her face and body were preserved in some of the most striking solarized portraits of the Surrealist age.

title: Cate Blanchett and Her Red Carpet Journey
description: It was shortly after 8 a.m. on Wednesday and Cate Blanchett was 15 minutes late to breakfast.

title: Are Squirrels Able to Enjoy the Changing Colors of Fall?
description: Q. Do squirrels see the colorful fall display of red, yellow and brown leaves?

title: Inside Raqqa, the Capital of ISIS
description: A bustling city has been transformed under the groups brutal rule.

title: The Week on Instagram
description: Photos posted this week on @nytimes took followers from scenes of mourning on the streets of Paris to the stage at the David H. Koch Theater.

title: Refugees Must Not Be Turned Away, Obama Says
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  President Obama vowed on Saturday to keep Americas borders open to the worlds refugees as long as Im president, even as he met with child migrants and refugees here and his administration refused to yield in a long-distance feud with his critics over the issue.

title: ISIS Women and Enforcers in Syria Recount Collaboration, Anguish and Escape
description: SOUTHERN TURKEY  Dua had only been working for two months with the Khansaa Brigade, the all-female morality police of the Islamic State, when her friends were brought to the station to be whipped.

title: Brussels Placed at Highest Alert Level; Subway Is Closed
description: BRUSSELS  Warning of a serious and imminent threat of a Paris-style terrorist attack, the authorities in Belgium on Saturday shut down the Brussels subway system, canceled soccer games and advised citizens to avoid public places amid a security lockdown across the Belgian capital.

title: FIFA Ethics Committee Recommends New Sanctions for Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini
description: Ethics investigators for FIFA, the ruling body of world soccer, have recommended sanctions be imposed on Sepp Blatter, the organizations longtime president, and Michel Platini, the head of soccers European confederation, the organization said on Saturday.

title: Farhad and Mikes Week in Tech: Turkeys, News and News Turkeys
description: Each Saturday, Farhad Manjoo and Mike Isaac, technology reporters at The New York Times, review the weeks news, offering analysis and maybe a joke or two about the most important developments in the tech industry.

title: When the Noisy Neighbor is a Church
description: Ask Real Estate is a weekly column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

title: The Knick Season 2, Episode 6: A Circus Sideshow
description: Early 20th-century medicine often looks like a circus sideshow on The Knick, but never as literally as in this weeks episode. Haunting the dime-museum arcade, John Thackery took in a not-very-convincing hypnotist and a very persuasive pair of conjoined Russian sisters. Both put ideas into his head. Hypnotism seemed like a possible answer in his search for a cure to addiction, though an experiment involving Tom Cleary didnt go so well. The sight of the twins inspired his pure medical curiosity, and soon, with Clearys help, he was kidnapping them from their manager and pimp and preparing to surgically separate them, with the help of his trio of protgs, Bertie Chickering, Algernon Edwards and Everett Gallinger. (The pimp was played with understated grotesquerie by Fred Weller of In Plain Sight, while the sisters were played by Miranda and Rebecca Gruss and an armature of artificial flesh.)

title: Hyundai Cars Are Recalled Over Faulty Brake Switch
description: Hyundai is recalling about 305,000 of its 2011-12 Sonata models because the automatic transmission could possibly be moved out of park without pressing the brake pedal, allowing the car to roll or drive away, according to a report from the automaker posted this week on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administrations website.

title: A Cherished Custom at Penn, Any Way You Slice It
description: University of Pennsylvania fans have a peculiar way of displaying school spirit at home games. They throw toast.

title: Breaking a Toshiba Laptop Owners Cycle of Repair
description: Now and then, the Haggler is called a cynic. Invariably, it is by horrible people who are motivated by selfishness and greed  just like every human being on the face of the earth.

title: U.A.W. Vote at Ford and G.M. Ends Painful Process for Big Three
description: DETROIT  After five months of bargaining and divisive ratification votes, the United Automobile Workers on Friday completed new labor contracts covering more than 140,000 workers at the three largest American automakers.

title: Variety: A Tough Cryptic
description: VARIETY PUZZLE  Before we get started, I wanted to take a moment to mention the passing of Rosalie Moscovitch, who contributed cryptics and other variety puzzles to The New York Times. I never had a chance to meet her in person, but we corresponded behind the scenes. Ms. Moscovitch died Nov. 10 and she will be missed. If you would like to try her last variety puzzle that she co-wrote with Joe Cabrera, you can find it here.

title: Jessica Jones Episode 2: The Devil Did
description: Control is everything in another thoughtfully character-driven, albeit tonally wonky episode of Jessica Jones. We are constantly reminded of the shows thematic concern with control through dialogue that underscores the way that everyone, from supervillain Kilgrave to good guy Luke Cage, struggles to stay on top of their lives. Jones knows that struggle well, as we see when she nurses a drink while investigating Kilgraves case. She snaps at her upstairs neighbors for the same reason: She cant see the world beyond her own problems, and therefore despises people she imagines cant handle their own private lives  in private.

title: Mali Hotel Attackers Are Tied to an Algerian Qaeda Leader
description: A member of Al Qaeda in Africa confirmed Saturday that the attack Friday on a hotel in Bamako, Mali, had been carried out by a jihadist group loyal to Mokhtar Belmokhtar, an Algerian operative for Al Qaeda.

title: Pentagon Expands Inquiry Into Intelligence on ISIS Surge
description: WASHINGTON  When Islamic State fighters overran a string of Iraqi cities last year, analysts at United States Central Command wrote classified assessments for military intelligence officials and policy makers that documented the humiliating retreat of the Iraqi Army. But before the assessments were final, former intelligence officials said, the analysts superiors made significant changes.

title: Finding Ways to Thwart the Jerk at Work
description: Most of us have days at work when we walk around with a spring in our step and perform our tasks with gusto  and other days when our feet drag and we just cant seem to get motivated. A new study encourages employees to look more closely at the people around them as one reason for that disparity.

title: Bored to Tears by a Do-Nothing Dream Job
description: More than a decade ago, I was in the type of job where, if I had sat down at my desk and worked for 100 hours straight, I would be only slightly less behind than when I started. I was a newspaper editor, stuck in the type of never-ending grind that caused me to begin having a regular daydream.

title: Wall St. Ties Linger as Image Issue for Hillary Clinton
description: John Wittneben simmered as he listened to Hillary Rodham Clinton defend her ties to Wall Street during last weekends Democratic debate. He lost 40 percent of his savings in individual retirement accounts during the Great Recession, while Mrs. Clinton has received millions of dollars from the kinds of executives he believes should be in jail.

title: The Refugees of Roanoke
description: ROANOKE, Va.  ON Friday, David Bowers, the Democratic mayor of Roanoke, apologized for comments in which he called for halting the resettlement of Syrian refugees and suggested that our situation was similar to the one Franklin D. Roosevelt faced when he imprisoned Japanese-Americans.

title: Computing by Design
description: To the Editor:

title: Hotel Attack in MaliReverses Gains in Fight Against Extremism
description: BAMAKO, Mali  The terrorists chose carefully: There are nearly always French, Russian and even a few American visitors to be found in the hotel restaurant, around the pool, in the health club or on the thin black-leather sofas of the glass-fronted lobby, now shattered by gunfire.

title: Vocal Strain Poses Long-Term Risks for Coaches. Anyone Have a Lozenge?
description: Some college basketball coaches protect their voices with daily cups of tea. Others gargle with salt water in the morning and before games. Others stick with Life Savers and cough drops. Or at least they try.

title: Bert Olmstead, Hall of Fame Passer in Canadiens Dynasty, Dies at 89
description: Bert Olmstead, a Hockey Hall of Fame wing who played on five Stanley Cup championship teams, four times with the Montreal Canadiens of the 1950s, died on Tuesday in High River, Alberta. He was 89.

title: Gay Marriage Derailed in Northern Ireland
description: It was Oscar Wilde, Irelands peerless playwright and essayist, who suffered imprisonment for his homosexuality but wryly advised, The proper basis for marriage is mutual misunderstanding.

title: Uncertain Journeys
description: Our resolve to help refugees should be stronger than ever after the attacks in Paris.

title: Are Good Doctors Bad for Your Health?
description: PRETTY regularly, I receive an urgent call from a distraught friend or friend of a brother. Zeke, Mom was at home and her heart stopped. The E.M.T.s are rushing her to XYZ hospital in Miami. Can you help me find the best cardiologist there for her?

title: Dont Let Progress on Tobacco Evaporate
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported this month that the adult smoking rate in the United States has fallen to a new low, a testament to the decades of education about the dangers of tobacco and measures to discourage its use. Now Republicans in the House are seeking to slash the very government programs that have helped to achieve such remarkable success.

title: Searching for Richard Nixon
description: ITS a truth universally accepted that every Republican who runs for president wants to be Ronald Reagan, and that every Democrat wants to be either Franklin Roosevelt or (God help us) John F. Kennedy.

title: How ISIS Defeats Us
description: I DONT know how we win the war against ISIS.

title: The Danger of Placing Your Chips on Beauty
description: Paris  MEMORIES, the French poet Guillaume Apollinaire wrote, are like the sound of hunters horns fading in the wind. I have loved in Paris, had children, dreamed, wandered, gotten lost, found myself again. At every intersection there is an invitation, on every bridge a recollection. The carnage, in this city, feels like a personal matter.

title: The Statue of Liberty Must Be Crying With Shame
description: AS anti-refugee hysteria sweeps many of our political leaders, particularly Republicans, I wonder what they would have told a desperate refugee family fleeing the Middle East. Youve heard of this family: a carpenter named Joseph, his wife, Mary, and their baby son, Jesus.

title: The Strip
description: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

title: Pacific Trade and Worker Rights
description: President Obama says that the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade agreement his administration negotiated with 11 other countries, will help raise labor standards in developing nations like Vietnam, Malaysia and Mexico. The deal, the text of which was published earlier this month, could deliver on that promise, but much will depend on factors beyond Mr. Obamas control, like how T.P.P. countries and future presidents carry out  the pact.

title: Ann Ravel
description: Ann Ravel is the chairwoman of the Federal Election Commission, the agency that governs the financing of federal elections. Previously, she was the chairwoman of the California Fair Political Practices Commission, which also oversees the regulation of campaign finance.

title: Choose to Be Grateful. It Will Make You Happier.
description: TWENTY-FOUR years ago this month, my wife and I married in Barcelona, Spain. Two weeks after our wedding, flush with international idealism, I had the bright idea of sharing a bit of American culture with my Spanish in-laws by cooking a full Thanksgiving dinner.

title: Ruling From the Shadows
description: WEVE come to expect bickering from our politicians. Were often exasperated by this state of affairs and sometimes we yearn for a quieter, gentler age, when compromise wasnt a dirty word. But the raucous rivalry in Washington has its benefits: a political process thick with competition. By contrast, political competition in other important parts of our democracy is worrisomely thin.

title: Why Are Student Protesters So Fearful?
description: THE message coming out of recent student protests on college campuses, from Princeton and Yale to the University of Missouri, couldnt be clearer: Students are rightly pained by the racist and sexual abuse still shockingly common into the 21st century, and for good reason they are indignant that institutions they trust  or wish to trust  fail to stop the culprits, or even to acknowledge publicly the harm they do.

title: Debates on Campus
description: Readers discuss the controversies over free speech and safe spaces on college campuses.

title: Herbert Scarf, an Economists Mathematician, Dies at 85
description: Herbert Scarf, a Yale mathematician who never took an economics course but whose groundbreaking theories were embraced by businesses and governments, died on Nov. 15 at his home in Sag Harbor, N.Y. He was 85.

title: Whiff of Suspicion Keeps the Hall of Fame Far Away
description: The most important number to remember, when considering the evolving process of voting for the Baseball Hall of Fame, is the figure that remains constant: 75. That is the percentage that candidates must reach to be elected by the writers, and it is truly an overwhelming majority.

title: How to Host Thanksgiving: Dos and Don'ts
description: The Timess Florence Fabricant gives etiquette advice for entertaining on Thanksgiving.

title: In Argentina, a Quiet Data Cruncher Aims to Bring Sense to a Raucous Election
description: BUENOS AIRES  With his fusty corduroy blazer, diffident mien and unpolished website, Andy Tow, an anonymous civil servant with a flair for data crunching, is emerging as an unlikely rock star of Argentinas election season.

title: Are Banks Europes Problem?
description: For those of us who worried a lot about Japan in the late 1990s and now find the whole advanced world facing similar problems, deja vu comes so often that we get deja vu about getting deja vu. A case in point is the rise and fall of European bank-blaming  that is, the argument that the weakness of banks is whats holding European recovery back.

title: Game Management Humbles Even the Best N.F.L. Coaches
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  As the coach of the Baltimore Ravens, Brian Billick would devote part of his Friday practices to play-calling oddities. If the moment called for an intentional safety or a hurried field-goal try while the final seconds of a half ticked off, he wanted his players to feel prepared  and they were, he said.

title: Sundays Matchup: Jets at Texans
description: 1 p.m., CBS

title: Grassley Says His Former Aide Is Not Source for Huma Abedin Disclosures
description: Aides to Senator Charles E. Grassley, the Iowa Republican whose committee is reviewing issues surrounding Hillary Rodham Clintons tenure at the State Department, are trying to quell questions raised by Democrats about who has provided him with previously undisclosed information.

title: Woman Charged in Grisly Death of Pregnant Mother Left a Cryptic Trail
description: A woman charged with fatally stabbing an expectant mother and cutting a baby from her womb in the Bronx on Friday had been telling people for months that she herself was pregnant, according to interviews on Saturday.

title: Op-Photo: Unjustly Convicted, Robert Jones Is Free (for Now)
description: The case of Robert Jones, the editorial board wrote in October, is only the latest example of misconduct out of New Orleans. Mr. Joness conviction in a 1992 kidnapping, rape and robbery was vacated after prosecutors revealed evidence calling their case into question evidence they had before Mr. Joness trial but failed to share with the defense.

title: Heats Hassan WhitesideProves Value While Playing at Bargain Price
description: When the little-known defensive specialist Hassan Whiteside unexpectedly became a borderline star with the Miami Heat in the second half of last season, the big question was whether he was a one-season wonder or a player at the beginning of a special career.

title: A Long-Awaited Homecoming, Marred by Multiple Tragedies
description: It was supposed to be a joyous, overdue reunion. Instead, Katimi Bouares homecoming unexpectedly coincided with tragedy.

title: Fighting Evictions, a Single Mother Draws Strength From Her Children
description: Gardenia Valerios two-bedroom apartment in the Soundview section of the Bronx, steps from the Bruckner Expressway, was welcoming and calm.

title: Philippine Grandparents, Struggling to Start Fresh in a New Homeland
description: When Fortunato Dilan first felt a lump on the crown of his head five years ago, he did his best to keep it a secret from his wife, Adelaida. He wore a baseball cap or tilted his face upward when they spoke.

title: A New Life, New Challenges and a Firm Resolve
description: New Yorks immigrant population numbers about 3.1 million people, a record high, according to a 2013 city report, The Newest New Yorkers. Foreign-born residents make up about 37 percent of the overall population of 8.2 million, according to the report.

title: Fire at Chicagos John Hancock Center Injures 5
description: CHICAGO  A fire broke out Saturday afternoon on the 50th floor of the John Hancock Center, one of this citys tallest skyscrapers, but was quickly brought under control. Chicago Fire Department officials said five people, including a police officer, sustained minor injuries.

title: Long Way for a Snub in a Qualifying Match
description: Justin Meram apologized in advance for any yawns that might occur during the interview. He had just endured a 27-hour journey from Taiwan that had included two layovers, 13 time zones and one very troublesome, existential question:

title: Both Poised and Playful, Lydia Ko Finds Her Winning Balance
description: NAPLES, Fla.  Lydia Kos mother, Tina, was walking the first hole of Tiburon Golf Club during the second round of the L.P.G.A. season finale when two men stopped her in her tracks. Your daughters awesome, one said as the other nodded enthusiastically. The speaker expounded his thought. She hits a bad shot and seconds later shes laughing. She is so relaxed.

title: Evening Hours | Fall Swing
description: Parties for holiday windows, the arts and the elderly.

title: Martin Truex Jr. Embraces a Shot at Nascars Championship
description: MIAMI  Far from the Nascar hotbed of Charlotte, N.C., sits a nondescript auto shop with no sign out front, smack in the middle of the Colorado Rockies. It is the last place a race fan would expect to find Martin Truex Jr., one of four drivers competing Sunday for the 2015 Sprint Cup Championship at Homestead-Miami Speedway in Homestead, Fla.

title: Chinas Nuclear Vision Collides With Villagers Fears
description: HUBIN VILLAGE, China  This placid, leafy hamlet tucked beside a dam in the countryside hardly seems like the next testing ground over Chinas efforts to cut smog and greenhouse gases. But here among cornfields and crumbling stone homes skirted by persimmon trees, the government intends to build a nuclear power plant.

title: Massachusettss Rejection of Common Core Test Signals Shift in U.S.
description: BOSTON  It has been one of the most stubborn problems in education: With 50 states, 50 standards and 50 tests, how could anyone really know what American students were learning, or how well?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Turn Off Your Devices? Sometimes Plays Turn Them On
description: Heres a recipe for a terrible play: Characters are rarely in the same room as one another; conversations are typed rather than spoken; one side of a dispute cant be heard by the audience.

title: Bangladesh Hangs 2 Leaders Convicted of War Crimes
description: NEW DELHI  The Bangladeshi authorities on Sunday hanged two senior opposition leaders convicted of atrocities dating to Bangladeshs 1971 war for independence from Pakistan.

title: Right On, Right On!
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  I know. You thought this was going to be another one of those themes where the entry drops off and makes a sharp turn somewhere and that would be it, right? Thats so ho-hum. Theres something more in store for you today.

title: Five Indicted in Leak of Confidential Vatican Documents
description: ROME  Vatican prosecutors on Saturday formally indicted five people in connection with the theft of confidential documents used to write two tell-all books describing purported mismanagement in the Roman Catholic Churchs bureaucracy.

title: Chicago Set for Protests Over Shooting by the Police
description: CHICAGO  For months, leaders here watched as other cities faced angry demonstrations over police conduct, shootings and relations with black people, often captured in painful videos. As cities like Ferguson, Mo., Baltimore and New York have been consumed by fatal encounters involving the local police that have fueled national attention since 2014, this city managed to keep a lower profile.

title: Afghan Kidnappers Prey on Hazaras
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A campaign of kidnappings against the Hazara ethnic group intensified on Saturday as gunmen stopped a number of buses along Afghanistans main highway and separated out the Hazara passengers, officials said.

title: Kim Young-sam, South Korean President Who Opposed Military, Dies at 87
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Kim Young-sam, the former president of South Korea who replaced the last of the countrys military leaders, purged politicized generals and introduced a landmark reform aimed at transparency in financial transactions, died on Sunday in Seoul. He was 87.

title: Michigan State Stuns Ohio State With a Late Field Goal
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Michael Thomas and Jalin Marshall, Ohio States best wide receivers, both had inexplicable drops on what should have been simple throw-and-catches against Michigan State on Saturday. The drops came on two of the staggering six three-and-out drives the No. 2 Buckeyes had.

title: Cutting Water Use, but Still Getting Soaked
description: Amid drought in California, a disparity has emerged in who gets fined for excessive water use, with many wealthier residents getting off scot-free.

title: In California, Stingy Water Users Are Fined in Drought, While the Rich Soak
description: APPLE VALLEY, Calif.  Outside her two-story tract home in this working-class town, Debbie Alberts, a part-time food service worker, has torn out most of the lawn. She has given up daily showers and cut her familys water use nearly in half, to just 178 gallons per person each day.

title: Donald Trump Calls for Surveillance of Certain Mosques and a Syrian Refugee Database
description: Donald J. Trump said Saturday that he would order surveillance of certain mosques to combat terrorism after the Paris attacks and claimed to have watched as thousands and thousands of people were cheering while the World Trade Center towers fell on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: John Bel Edwards, Democrat, Defeats David Vitter in Louisiana Governors Race
description: NEW ORLEANS  With a victory that defied political geography and near universal predictions from just months earlier, a previously little-known Democrat, State Representative John Bel Edwards, soundly defeated United States Senator David Vitter in a runoff election on Saturday to become the next governor of Louisiana.

title: Missing Maryland College Student Is Found Dead in Apparent Suicide
description: A troubled student whose disappearance with a rifle case on Monday led his college in Maryland to shut its doors until the end of the month was found dead from a self-inflicted gunshot Saturday at a bird sanctuary in Pennsylvania, the police said.

title: Ilissa Samplin, Michael Behr
description: Ilissa Stacy Samplin, a daughter of Caren L. Samplin and Marc L. Samplin of Merrick, N.Y., was married Saturday evening in Miami Beach to Michael Scott Behr, the son of Debra L. Behr and Glenn S. Behr of Longwood, Fla. Rabbi Steven W. Engel officiated at the Miami Beach Edition, a hotel and resort.

title: Naomi Kaplan, Eric Morris
description: Naomi Dena Kaplan, a daughter of Amy K. Kaplan and Dr. Barnard A. Kaplan of Voorhees, N.J., was married Saturday evening to Eric Charles Morris, a son of Nancy A. Karr and Howard J. Morris of Needham, Mass. Rabbi Aaron Krupnick performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth El in Voorhees.

title: Thomas Donovan, Raj Raghavan
description: Thomas Arthur Donovan and Raj Vardan Raghavan were married Saturday at the couples home in Los Angeles. The officiant was Catherine Parry Creedon, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion.

title: Cameron Levkoff, Joseph Molinaro
description: Cameron Blair Levkoff and Joseph Thomas Molinaro were married Saturday evening at Canoe Studios, a photography studio and event space in New York. Rabbi Melissa Buyer officiated.

title: Zoe Grunebaum and Andrew White
description: Zoe Louise Grunebaum, a daughter of Laurie B. Grunebaum and Andrew M. Grunebaum of Woodbridge, Conn., was married Saturday evening to Andrew Jesse White, the son of Mindy S. White and Gregory A. White of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Alvin Wainhaus officiated at Weylin B. Seymours, an event space in the former Williamsburg Savings Bank building in Brooklyn.

title: Lindsay Porter and Robert Miller Jr.: Two First Dances, Two Decades Apart
description: Lindsay Elizabeth Porter and Robert Singleton Miller Jr. were married Saturday at the First Presbyterian Church in Waycross, Ga. The Rev. Dr. Samuel D. Tonge, an Episcopal priest, officiated, with the Rev. Robert A. Cushing, a Roman Catholic Priest, participating.

title: Alyssa Spano, Sipho Simela
description: Alyssa Amy Spano, the daughter of Susan C. Spano and James A. Spano of Chicopee, Mass., was married Saturday to Sipho Dubuya Simela, a son of Veronica J. Simela and Dr. Ernest D. Simela of North Woodmere, N.Y. Michael Davis, a cousin of the bride who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Liberty Hotel in Boston.

title: Mark Phariss, Victor Holmes
description: Mark Alan Phariss and Victor Lamont Holmes were married Saturday at the Westin Stonebriar Hotel & Golf Club in Frisco, Tex. The officiant was Charles A. Gonzalez, a former Texas State District Court judge and a former Democratic congressman from Texas.

title: Jennifer Agiesta, Paul Hortenstine
description: Jennifer Jean Agiesta and Paul Andrew Hortenstine were married Saturday by the Rev. Dr. Luis Len, an Episcopal priest, at St. Johns Episcopal Church at Lafayette Square in Washington.

title: Leize Gaillard, Benjamin Buckley-Green
description: Mary Leize Simons Gaillard and Benjamin Longwood Buckley-Green were married Saturday evening at the French Protestant (Huguenot) Church in Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Philip C. Bryant, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony.

title: Jennifer Adams and Andrew Nicoll
description: Jennifer Lynne Adams, a daughter of Sandra W. Adams and Robert W. Adams of Pinecrest, Fla., was married Saturday to Andrew Forbes Nicoll, the son of Mary F. Nicoll and the Rev. Thomas E. Nicoll of Greenville, S.C. The grooms father, who retired as the rector of St. Johns Episcopal Church in Larchmont, N.Y., officiated at South Seas Island Resort on Captiva Island in Florida. The grooms maternal grandfather, Canon David R. Forbes, also an Episcopal priest, participated.

title: Julianne Michelle, Karl Reeves
description: Julianne Michelle, a daughter of Joycelyn Engle and Joseph A. Di Palma of Manhattan, was married Saturday to Karl Christian Reeves, the son of Charlotte D. Revesz of Suffern, N.Y., and Karl Revesz of Manhattan. The Rev. Daniel G. O'Hare, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in Manhattan.

title: Anna Balch, Adam Sullivan
description: Anna Caroline Balch and Adam Francis Sullivan were married Saturday at the Cathedral of St. John the Baptist in Savannah, Ga. The Rev. Douglas Clark, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Shaunte Otey and Antoine Kinch
description: Shaunte Arraine Otey and Antoine Kenroy Kinch were married Saturday evening at the Chrysler Museum of Art in Norfolk, Va. The Rev. Carretta Murray, a Baptist pastor, officiated.

title: Ashley Collins and Francisco Roldn
description: Ashley Wren Collins and Francisco Jos Roldn were married Saturday evening at the Upper Crust, an event space in Manhattan. Heather R. Eudy, a friend of the couple and a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Jessica Tran and Tony Cicio
description: Jessica ThongNhung Tran and Tony Michael Cicio are to be married Sunday at the Metropolitan Building in Long Island City, Queens. The Rev. Barbara Ann Michaels, an ordained interfaith minister, is to officiate.

title: Xochitl Hinojosa and Eloy Martinez: Texans Find Love Near the Potomac
description: Xochitl Hinojosa and Eloy Martinez were married Saturday evening at the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center in Austin, Tex. Bob Perkins, a senior District Court judge in Austin, officiated.

title: Lily Scott and David Trager
description: Lily Anne Marie Scott and David Edmund Trager are to be married Sunday evening at the Ancient Spanish Monastery in North Miami Beach, Fla. Carolyn Trager Kliman, the grooms sister who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, is to officiate at a ceremony that will incorporate Jewish wedding traditions.

title: The Best Moments in College Football This Week
description: NATE SUDFELD The Indiana senior, above, threw for 385 yards and four touchdowns, and the Hoosiers rallied from an early 18-point deficit to top host Maryland, 47-28, for its first Big Ten win of the season. Sudfeld completed 23 of 35 passes and also ran for a score.

title: Sal lvarez Wins W.B.C. Middleweight Title, Beating Miguel Cotto
description: LAS VEGAS  The fans, many of whom sported red, white and green attire, roared when the Mexican boxing legends Marco Antonio Barrera and Julio Csar Chvez were shown on the big screen at the Mandalay Bay Events Center on Saturday night.

description: For me, it was about power and money, mostly power. Since my relatives had all joined, it didnt change a great deal to join. I just had more authority.

title: Crimea in Dark After Power Lines Are Blown Up
description: MOSCOW  Saboteurs blew up the main power lines leading into Crimea early Sunday, plunging the disputed peninsula into darkness and prompting the Russian government to impose a state of emergency there.

title: Obama Orders Inquiry Into Intelligence on ISIS
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  President Obama said on Sunday that he had ordered his senior defense officials to find out whether intelligence reports had been altered to reflect a more optimistic assessment of the American military campaign against the Islamic State.

title: 1915: War Hospital In Paris Becomes Prey To Flames
description: Fire yesterday practically destroyed the annex of the Bon March, the great store on the left bank of the Seine so well known to all residents in the American Quartier Latin of Paris. The upper floors of the annex, which is situated at the corner of the rue de Svres and at the rue du Bac, were used as a war hospital, nearly 200 wounded soldiers being tended there. Exciting scenes occurred during the rescue of these helpless heroes, and the doctors and nurses of the hospital showed remarkable devotion.

title: States Lead Effort to Let Pharmacists Prescribe Birth Control
description: Groundbreaking laws in two Western states will soon make access to birth control easier for millions of women by allowing them to obtain contraceptives from pharmacists without a doctors prescription.

description: Bengals (8-1) at Cardinals (7-2)

description: Cowboys (2-7) at Dolphins (4-5)

title: At Boucheron, the Bleu de Jodhpur Collection
description: Gaj Singh II, the maharaja of Jodhpur, and Claire Choisne, Boucheron creative director, add the feel of India into the jewelry houses collection.

title: 1940: Fascists Driven From Key City in Greece
description: ROME  Capture by the Greeks of Koritza, Italian base eight miles inside the Albanian frontier, was announced today [Nov. 22] by the Italian high command. It said two Fascist divisions which since the opening of hostilities with Greece had held defensive positions on the Greco-Albanian frontier near Koritza had retired, after eleven days of fighting, to a line west of the city.

title: Barbara Taylor Bradford: An Authors Collection
description: Ms. Bradford has a story for almost every piece of her jewelry.

title: From Barbara Taylor Bradford: A Life Story That Dazzles
description: The best-selling novelist Barbara Taylor Bradford had 40 pieces from her jewelry collection auctioned in 2013.

title: I Want to Be a Boy Scout. Theres Just One Hitch.
description: SANTA ROSA, Calif.  Five girls wearing makeshift scout uniforms stood before top Boy Scout brass this month and made an announcement: We want in.

title: With Ben Carson, the Doctor and the Politician Can Vary Sharply
description: When he was not in the operating room at Johns Hopkins Hospital, performing one of his 400 surgeries a year, Dr. Ben Carson could often be seen walking slowly through the hallways, hands behind his back, nodding, smiling and speaking softly to co-workers and students who approached.

title: The 2015 N.F.L. Playoff Picture: Simulate the End of the Season for Any Team
description: How can my team make the N.F.L. playoffs? Its a simple question, but answering it can be devilishly complicated. This interactive simulator walks you through the scenarios.

title: From Vaccines to Creationism, Ben Carsons Views Perplex Some
description: As a surgeon for three decades, Ben Carson carefully balanced his responsibilities as a physician with his deeply religious personal philosophy.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears on nytimes.com. To receive the email, register here.

title: Practicing the Art of Misdirection, With Unsavory Intent
description: The three Colombians worked as a team, the police said, with polished coordination and improvisation, like a criminal jazz combo. Until they aimed too high.

title: 7 Feet, 7 Blocks: Kristaps Porzingis Looms Ever Larger
description: Kristaps Porzingis is a player who inspires many debates. The arguments include what nickname best suits him  Godzingis and Three-Six Latvia are gaining traction after he said he was not a fan of Zinger  and his potential as a player.

title: For Auto Enthusiasts, the Right to Tinker With Cars Software
description: Car owners in the United States can soon play Volkswagen engineer, courtesy of the federal government.

title: Storied Brooklyn Church to Lose Its Keeper of History
description: The woman in the lavender jacket sat carefully on a bench beneath a portrait of a 19th-century preacher with bushy sideburns. They were almost as bushy as those on the more famous preacher she would spend the next 90 minutes talking about  the one for whom Beecher boats, Beecher bibles and the Beecherama were named.

title: Jason Rezaian of Washington Post Said to Be Sentenced to Prison
description: A spokesman for the Iranian judiciary announced on Sunday that the jailed Washington Post reporter Jason Rezaian had been sentenced to prison, an Iranian news agency reported.

title: Defiance and Necessity Spur Mali Back to Normal After Attack
description: BAMAKO, Mali  On a sunny weekend morning, one day after gunmen went on a murderous rampage at the Radisson Blu hotel, a local dignitary sped across town in his official government S.U.V.

title: What to Watch Sunday
description: Its Singalong Sunday, with contemporary hits at the American Music Awards, a sequel to a Disney favorite and some rock n roll classics from the women who made the men sound great. Also, Trevor Noah flaunts his worldview.

title: Our Simulator Can Assess Your N.F.L. Teams Playoff Chances
description: How can my team make the N.F.L. playoffs? Its a simple question, but answering it can be devilishly complicated.

title: CNN Shows Sex Assault Film Despite Legal Threat
description: LOS ANGELES  In the face of threatened legal action from the football star Jameis Winston, CNN did not back away from broadcasting The Hunting Ground, a documentary about sexual assault on college campuses that has stirred controversy since its January debut at the Sundance Film Festival.

title: Addicted to a Fantasy
description: Josh Adams owed $30,000 to friends and family when he finally decided to face his gambling addiction. Then he discovered fantasy sports.

title: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2 Opens Big, but Not Big Enough
description: LOS ANGELES  It was one of those weekends when a movie opened to massive ticket sales and still disappointed: The Hunger Games: Mockingjay Part 2, the finale of one of the decades biggest film franchises, took in about $101 million at North American theaters, a 17 percent decline from initial sales for Part 1.

title: Thinking About the Trumpthinkable
description: Alan Abramowitz reads the latest WaPo poll and emails:

title: 16 Arrests in Belgium Terrorism Raids
description: BRUSSELS  After a dramatic security sweep late Sunday marked by the deployment of soldiers in the historic center of the Belgian capital, the authorities here announced early Monday that 16 people had been arrested in a joint police and military operation to try to head off what the prime minister earlier described as a serious and imminent threat of a Paris-style terrorist assault.

title: VSPs and the Case of the Disappearing BPEA
description: Brad Delong has nice things to say about my old Brookings Papers on Economic Activity on the liquidity trap, and asks why central bankers still dont seem to get some of the basic points I made way back then, especially about the desirability of a higher inflation target. I actually have a few thoughts, which are inevitably mostly  but not entirely!  self-serving.

title: Pfizer and Allergan Reach $150 Billion Merger Deal
description: Pfizer has clinched a blockbuster merger with a fellow drug maker, one worth more than $150 billion, that can best be described in superlatives.

title: Donald Trump Again Insists He Saw Celebrations in New Jersey on Sept. 11
description: Its a scene that, as Donald J. Trump describes it, would seem to be seared into the American consciousness.

title: Cartoon: Heng on the Asia Pacific Summit
description: President Obama has called on China to halt its construction on reclaimed islands in the South China Sea.

title: Donald Trump Says He Supports Those Who Roughed Up Protester at His Event
description: Donald J. Trump said on Sunday he was in favor of the actions of his supporters who reportedly punched and kicked a protester from the Black Lives Matter movement who interrupted Mr. Trumps campaign rally the previous day in Birmingham, Ala.

title: Israeli Woman and 3 Palestinian Attackers Killed in West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  Three Palestinians who each attacked Israeli Jews in separate episodes across the occupied West Bank on Sunday, were shot dead by Israeli civilians and soldiers, officials and witnesses said. One Israeli woman was killed in the attacks.

title: Marco Rubios Campaign Unveils First Television Ad
description: Marco Rubios campaign is hitting the airwaves, releasing its first television ad on Sunday.

title: Five Touchdowns for Cam Newton as the Panthers Remain Undefeated
description: Cam Newton spent the week dealing with the publics debate of his ostentatious dancing. After he threw a career-high five touchdown passes Sunday, while helping his team reach 10-0, the public should talk about his ability to play football instead.

title: Pearsons Big Paydays Defy the Odds Against Print Media
description: It has been tough sledding for print media. More than 150 newspapers have closed or converted to digital-only offerings in the last two years. Recently the magazine giants Cond Nast and Time Inc. have both cut employees and closed magazines.

title: Lack of Enthusiasm From Supporters May Undermine Clintons Lead
description: Theres cause for concern in Hillaryland, the constellation of Democratic advisers, supporters and politicians counting on the former secretary of state to lead the party to a sweeping victory next November.

title: Cowboys Still Alive After Tony Romos Return
description: Tony Romo was not exactly the cure-all that the Dallas Cowboys were hoping for, but the star quarterback did enough in his much-anticipated return from injury to get his team its first win since Week 2, beating the Miami Dolphins, 24-14.

title: Q. and A.: Jindong Cai on Beethoven in China
description: Jindong Cai, 59, is an orchestra conductor and a professor at Stanford University. He has conducted many orchestras in China and has been a guest conductor at numerous orchestras in the United States since moving there in 1985. With his wife, the writer Sheila Melvin, he has written numerous articles on China and two books on music in China: Rhapsody in Red: How Western Classical Music Became Chinese and their latest, Beethoven in China: How the Great Composer Became an Icon in the Peoples Republic.

title: Paris Attacks and Other Assaults Seen as Evidence of a Shift by ISIS
description: WASHINGTON  The recent attacks in Paris and Beirut and the downing of a Russian airliner in Egypt were the first results of a centrally planned terrorism campaign by a wing of the Islamic State leadership that oversees external targets, according to American and European intelligence officials.

title: Adeles 25 on Track to Break Sales Records
description: When Adele released her new album, 25, on Friday, it was sure to be an instant hit. The only question was how big.

title: Jets Drop Ball, andJ. J. Watt Drops Jets
description: HOUSTON  The Jets tried holding on to their playoff aspirations Sunday, but they dropped them, like the deep balls botched by their rookie receiver. The Jets tried sustaining those aspirations, but they were depleted by every sack they allowed, every interception they threw, every dose of gadgetry that stunned them into mediocrity.

title: Skys the Limit for Porzingis, and Hes Closer to It Than Most
description: When Mike Breen and Walt Frazier, announcing on television, discussed how Kristaps Porzingis had tied the Knicks rookie single-game mark of seven blocked shots, Butch Beard had a flashback to the player who had set it.

title: Once Again, the Big 12 Looks to Be on the Outside Looking In
description: In the third quarter of Saturday nights game between Texas Christian and Oklahoma, with T.C.U. trailing by a manageable 23-13, Horned Frogs quarterback Foster Sawyer heaved a throw downfield right into the arms of Sooners safety Ahmad Thomas. Trevone Boykin, who had thrown 29 touchdown passes and accounted for nearly 3,500 yards in the air in a Heisman Trophy-worthy campaign before injuring his ankle in the previous weeks victory against Kansas, might have done better.

title: Review: In Beasts, BalletX Explores Nature and Nurture
description: PHILADELPHIA  There are many dance styles around America that arent to be found in New York, from local brands of hip-hop to individual subsections of ballet  and this is good for the dance health of the whole nation. Recently, when Ballet Memphis came to the Joyce Theater in New York, the sheer non-New-York-ness of its choreography and dancing struck many observers. I like to think that around the country there are many other such companies that New York audiences never see.

title: Review: Jeremy Denk and Stefan Jackiws Lessons in IvessNostalgic Sonatas
description: A concert offering all four of Charles Ivess craggy violin sonatas might seem at first more a music history lesson than an engaging program. If not quite rarities, these fiercely original works are pretty close.

title: Review: JACK Quartet and Anthony McGill Perform a Menu of American Delicacies
description: The Wind in High Places is a string quartet by John Luther Adams that uses only open strings and natural harmonics. Written in 2011 in memory of a friend and hiking companion, it evokes the glassy stillness of the Alaskan wilderness that for decades was Mr. Adamss home and inspiration.

title: Review: Max Emanuel Cencic and Il Pomo DOro Bring Baroque to the Met
description: How a singer conveys the text is usually an integral part of a vocal performance, assuming the listener understands the words and story or can rely on subtitles. Deciphering unfamiliar lyrics when syllables are elongated and ornamented can be a challenge in any language: Subtitles are often provided even for English librettos.

title: Review: In Beatlebone, an Imagined Trip With John Lennon
description: Beatlebone, the strange and exhilarating new novel by the Irish writer Kevin Barry, is about John Lennon  kind of. It follows him closely for around 200 pages, through a few comically calamitous days in 1978, as he travels through western Ireland to an island off its coast, bought on a lark 11 years earlier. Hes nearing 40 here; past drugs, past scream therapy, far past the Beatles, and stripped raw emotionally, tired but not for sleeping, full of large sad warmish feelings.

title: Nepal Police Kill 3 Protesters in Clashes Over Constitution
description: KATHMANDU, Nepal  Violence flared in southern Nepal when the police open fire on protesters who had been blocking the countrys main highway, an official said on Sunday. The shootings threatened to deepen a political crisis over the countrys new Constitution.

title: Review: A Beethoven Cycle From Simon Rattle and the Berlin Philharmonic
description: Claudio Abbado. Herbert von Karajan. Wilhelm Furtwngler. You are weighed upon golden scales, if you are the chief conductor of the Berlin Philharmonic. And for good or ill, the balance tilts hardest in what is still thought of as classical musics core repertoire: Mahler, nowadays; Brahms, naturally; Beethoven, forever.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for the Week of Nov. 23
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Dark Knight III: The Master Race Comic Book Prompts Reflection and a Look Ahead
description: The opening panels of Dark Knight III: The Master Race depict a break-in at the Batcave. A display case containing the imposing costume of Batman, the DC vigilante, is smashed open and his emblematic cape and cowl are stolen, leaving only a bare mannequin.

title: Persistence Pays Off
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  When last we saw Parker Lewis, he had constructed two New York Times puzzles in 2011. Before, Mr. Lewis had spent a couple of years in Namibia as a member of the Peace Corps, teaching MATH to middle school learners, as they are called in Africa.

title: Review: Thomas Ads Calls for Complexity at City Center
description: When did dance audiences last see and hear a composer perform his own works with the revelatory mastery shown by Thomas Ads? Because the quadruple bill of his works Thomas Ads: Concentric Paths  Movements in Music came over the weekend to New York City Center, the mind flew to Stravinsky.

title: Review: In Beyond Time, U-Theater Dances and Drums With Precision
description: A solar eclipse and a torrential downpour descended on the stage of the Howard Gilman Opera House at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday night. Those were among the natural phenomena digitally conjured in Beyond Time, a production by the Taiwanese dance and drumming company U-Theater that was having its American debut.

title: Review: Paco Peas Troupe Flaunts Its Inventive Flamenco Style at Town Hall
description: The Paco Pea dance troupe, based in London, passes through New York about once every two years, usually for a one-night-only concert. For anyone with a taste for flamenco at its most exciting, that isnt nearly enough.

title: Heroin, Survivor of War on Drugs, Returns With New Face
description: United States military operations in Afghanistan, now in their 15th year, are routinely described as Americas longest war. For overseas combat, that is true. But nothing tops the domestic war on drugs that an American president declared more than four decades ago. The casualty rate has been exceedingly high.

title: Thanksgiving, With College Students: Fantasy, Reality, and Getting It Right
description: Here is the fantasy: After months of missing our college kids we eagerly await their return for Thanksgiving. In our dreams we spend cozy hours in the kitchen listening to them recount their experiences and marveling at the newly mature teen who sits before us. Our kids have looked forward to these days of rest and reunion and are thrilled to come home to the embrace of their families. Food will be abundant and family time sacred.

title: Panels Advise Bolstering W.H.O. for Crises Like Ebola
description: In recent months, numerous groups of health experts have gathered to debate how to prevent another crisis like the Ebola epidemic in West Africa, which jumped borders, spread fear across the globe, and directly killed more than 11,000 people. Many more died as hospitals and clinics closed for months.

title: Petco Nears $4.7 Billion Sale to CVC and Canadian Pension Plan
description: Petco is near an agreement to be acquired by CVC Capital Partners and the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board for $4.7 billion, a person briefed on the matter said on Sunday.

title: Bahrain Abuses Continue Despite Kings Pledge, Rights Group Says
description: CAIRO  Bahrains security forces torture detainees using electric shocks, beatings and sexual abuse, despite a public pledge by the king of Bahrain four years ago to end such practices, according to a report released on Monday by the New York-based Human Rights Watch.

title: Saeed Jaffrey, Actor in Gandhi and The Man Who Would Be King, Dies at 86
description: Saeed Jaffrey, an Indian-born character actor known internationally for his work in films like Gandhi, The Man Who Would Be King and My Beautiful Laundrette, died on Nov. 14 in London. He was 86.

title: On Foreign Trip, Obama Yet Again Contends With Events Elsewhere
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia  President Obama traveled more than 12,000 miles last week to shower attention on Asia. But he spent most of the trip in grim consultations about the attacks in Paris and Mali and in a long-distance war of words with Republicans.

title: Churchbell Swapping
description: Dear Diary:

title: American Music Awards 2015 Red Carpet
description: Zendaya, Selena Gomez, Gigi Hadid and more at the American Music Awards on Sunday night in Los Angeles.

title: Towering, Teeming Hong Kong Where the Buffalo Roam
description: HONG KONG  A water buffalo grazes in a lush open field, an egret standing sentinel on its back. A herd of wild cattle bathes in the sunshine along the side of a winding road.

title: American Music Awards 2015 Red Carpet
description: Zendaya, Selena Gomez, Gigi Hadid and more at the American Music Awards on Sunday night in Los Angeles. See photos from the red carpet.

title: Gov. Cuomo to Order Large Increase in Renewable Energy in New York by 2030
description: Frustrated by the pending shutdown of two nuclear power plants on Lake Ontario, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo plans to order state regulators to mandate that, by 2030, half of all power consumed by New Yorkers be generated from renewable sources that emit much less carbon dioxide, people briefed on the matter said.

title: Artists Death Sentence Follows a String of Harsh Punishments in Saudi Arabia
description: SANLIURFA, Turkey  For years, Ashraf Fayadh, an artist and poet, has served as an unofficial ambassador for Saudi Arabias small contemporary art scene, organizing shows and working to introduce Saudi art to the world.

title: Religious Liberty and Conservative Christians
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping Our Young Children Prepare for Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Bias Against the Unattractive
description: To the Editor:

title: Louisianas John Bel Edwards Overcame Big Obstacles to Win Governors Race
description: NEW ORLEANS  One evening in 2013, two weary Democratic legislators sat at their desks in the State Capitol, stared across the emptying House chamber and considered another unsuccessful day of fighting the governor. Sam, said one of the men, Representative John Bel Edwards, Im not staying in the House. Im not doing this anymore.

title: Mondays Matchup: Bills (5-4) at Patriots (9-0)
description: 8:30 p.m., ESPN

title: A New Definition of Masculinity?
description: To the Editor:

title: Kyle Busch Wins First Sprint Cup Championship
description: HOMESTEAD, Fla.  Jeff Gordon did not have the storybook finish that he had hoped for to end his 24-year career, but he still had a day to remember.

title: In Rebuke to Kirchner, Argentines Elect Opposition Leader Mauricio Macri as President
description: BUENOS AIRES  Argentine voters handed a victory to Mauricio Macri in the countrys presidential election on Sunday, delivering a mandate to an opposition political figure seeking to roll back some of the protectionist economic measures of the departing president, Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner.

title: At End of Sheldon Silvers Corruption Trial, the Law Guys Take Over
description: As the public corruption trial of State Assemblyman Sheldon Silver heads to closing arguments on Monday, the clash in the courtroom has been handled largely by well-staffed government and defense legal teams, each with a wealth of experience in handling corruption cases.

title: Black Friday, a Test for Pixar and HP Earnings
description: With a host of contentious issues to discuss, American and Chinese trade officials are scheduled to conclude three days of top-level talks on Monday. The talks, known as the United States-China Joint Commission on Commerce and Trade, are being held in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou and are being led by Commerce Secretary Penny Pritzker and Wang Yang, the vice premier of China in charge of trade. Against the backdrop of the recently unveiled Trans-Pacific Partnership, which has been championed by the Obama administration but excludes China, the annual bilateral talks are expected to address issues like market access, particularly for agricultural companies. Neil Gough

title: For Addicts, Fantasy Sites Can Lead to Ruinous Path
description: AUBURN, Ala.  A giant cardboard picture, tattered by time, rests against a wall in Joshua Adamss home. It shows a radiant young woman with an Auburn University corsage hugging the universitys mascot, a tiger. She is Auburns homecoming queen  and Mr. Adamss mother.

title: The Ad Council Adapts to Stay Relevant in an Age of Social Action
description: Could an eye emoji become as beloved  and recognizable  as Smokey Bear?

title: Bob Foster, Whose Left Hook Decimated All but the Heavyweights, Dies at 76
description: Bob Foster, a devastating puncher who was one of boxings most dominant light-heavyweight champions but failed in his quest to capture a heavyweight title when he was knocked out by Joe Frazier and Muhammad Ali, died on Saturday in Albuquerque. He was 76.

title: Start-Up Leaders Embrace Lobbying as Part of the Job
description: WASHINGTON  Last year, the personal butler service Hello Alfred won a top prize in Silicon Valley created for promising new technology start-ups, putting the company on a path toward millions of dollars in investment.

title: Checkpoints Isolate Many Immigrants in Texas Rio Grande Valley
description: BROWNSVILLE, Tex.  Elizabeth Lopez swam across the Rio Grande 19 years ago to come to America, where she began cleaning houses and raising three daughters in this city of swaying palm trees at the southern tip of Texas.

title: Creditors Signal Potential Support for Overhauling Puerto Rico Debt
description: Some of Puerto Ricos most influential creditors are for the first time signaling support for the broad outline of a government proposal to overhaul the islands crushing debts.

title: To Cam Newton, the Only Numbers That Matter Are 10 and 0
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Cam Newton is the perfect answer to those who say that numbers dont lie.

title: At Princeton, Woodrow Wilson, a Heralded Alum, Is Recast as an Intolerant One
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Few figures loom as large in the life of an Ivy League university as Woodrow Wilson does at Princeton.

title: Virginia Commonwealth Coach Leads by Example, One Mile at a Time
description: Will Wade has started every day since January the same way: with a run of a mile, often more.

title: Duke Gets 32 Points From a Guard, and a Narrow Victory Over Georgetown
description: A brilliant second-half performance by Grayson Allen lifted No. 5 Duke over Georgetown, 86-84, in the championship of the 2K Classic at Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon.

title: Review: Naomi Wallaces Night Is a Room Unfurls a Complex Reunion
description: There are gifts the giver comes to regret  the costly bauble that isnt worth the expense, or the squawking toy that brings on a splitting headache. Then theres the present that the well-meaning Liana has planned for the 40th birthday of her husband, Marcus: a surprise meeting with his biological mother.

title: The Walking Dead Season 6, Episode 7: Glenns Fate Is Revealed
description: Reminder: This recap (obviously) contains spoilers for this weeks episode of The Walking Dead.

title: Homeland Recap: Season 5, Episode 8, All About Allison
description: Season 5, Episode 8 Recap: All About Allison

title: The Leftovers Season 2, Episode 8: Stop Thinking in Straight Lines
description: Some of the best television series of the past 25 years have given us at least one mind-scrambler episode: a slice of brazenly surreal storytelling that dazzles, confuses, amuses or  ideally, when all the pots on the weirdo stove are really cooking  accomplishes all three at the same time.

title: Game of the Week: Heat at Knicks
description: Jeremy Lin signed with the Knicks on Dec. 27, 2011. The team played the Miami Heat that night, but Lin was not on the floor, and there was not much heard from him for a couple of months. Then, in February, Lin started putting together big games. Twenty-five points, 7 assists and 5 rebounds against the Nets. Thirty-eight points against the Lakers at Madison Square Garden. A winning 3-pointer to down the Raptors on the road. Jeremy Lin had officially arrived, and the tabloids spouted neologisms in approval.

title: Review: The Second Mrs. Wilson: A Faltering President and His Steadfast Wife
description: Edith Bolling Galt, a comely widow, met President Woodrow Wilson in spring 1915, when he was mourning the recent loss of his beloved wife, Ellen. A romance blossomed, and they wed that December.

title: New Orleans Park Shootout Injures 16
description: NEW ORLEANS  At least 16 people were injured, 10 of them hospitalized, after a shootout on Sunday night in a park here where hundreds of people had gathered for the filming of a music video, the New Orleans Police Department said.

title: Sickened in Rubble After 9/11, a Lost Soul Longs for Her Old Life
description: Construction sites, ubiquitous in New York City, set off pangs of loss within Susan Bentley.

title: Mandolin Brothers on Staten Island Angles for Graceful Exit
description: Eric Jay carried a newly delivered guitar case into a display room inside Mandolin Brothers, a musical instrument store on Staten Island. As his mother, Bea Jay, and his sister, Alison Reilly, watched, he unclasped the case and lifted the lid. There, resting on plush, purple lining, was a white Gretsch G7593T Billy Duffy Falcon guitar, named after the guitarist for the Cult.

title: The Affair Season 2, Episode 8: This Guys Hopeless
description: Noah, Noah, Noah.

title: What to Expect in Week 4 of Sheldon Silvers Trial
description: Issues that could arise in the fourth week of the trial of Sheldon Silver, 71, the former speaker of the New York State Assembly.

title: Endangered White Rhino Nola Dies at San Diego Zoo Safari Park
description: Nola, one of only four known northern white rhinoceroses, died on Sunday at the San Diego Zoo Safari Park, the park said in a statement. The park said that Nola, 41, had a bacterial infection, as well as age-related health issues, and that officials made the decision to euthanize her after her condition worsened overnight on Saturday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: It would be akin to an alcoholic finding out about a whole new street of bars that he never knew about  exciting, great bars. For an addict, it wasnt what I needed.

title: No Corrections: November 23, 2015
description: No corrections appeared in print.

title: Word of the Day + Quiz | bludgeon
description: bludgeon  \bl-jn\ noun and verb

title: The Best of Week 11 in the N.F.L.
description: Jameis Winston threw five touchdown passes in the Buccaneers rout of the Eagles, tying the N.F.L. rookie record for the most in a game. Winston, who completed 19 of 29 passes for 246 yards over all, had four touchdown throws in the first half, to four receivers. He tied Matthew Staffords rookie mark from 2009 in the third quarter on an 8-yard pass to Cameron Brate, the fifth Tampa Bay receiver with a scoring catch on Sunday. Entering the day, Winston had not thrown for more than two touchdowns in a game.

title: After Deliberate Search, Dodgers Are Said to Be Hiring Dave Roberts as Their Manager
description: The Dodgers are expected to announce Monday that they have filled the last opening for a manager in the major leagues with the hiring of Dave Roberts, according to multiple media reports. Roberts, 43, whose parents are African-American and Japanese would be the Dodgers first minority manager and the third in baseball, along with Fredi Gonzalez of the Atlanta Braves and Dusty Baker, recently hired by the Washington Nationals.

title: Police Name Suspect in Shooting of New Orleans Medical Student
description: The New Orleans police identified a suspect on Sunday in the shooting of a Tulane University medical student who had tried to help a woman being dragged down a sidewalk toward a vehicle in the pre-dawn hours on Friday.

title: What to Watch on Monday
description: Mondays grab bag features the funny and the not so, with Eddie Murphy skewering Bill Cosby and corporate public relations firms diluting science with spin. And another intriguing British whodunit is available to stream.

title: A Year After Democracy Protests, Hong Kong Vote Reflects Split on China
description: HONG KONG  Voters here went to the polls on Sunday, choosing hundreds of neighborhood representatives in the first election since concern about Chinas influence over the electoral process set off immense sit-in protests last year.

title: Syrian Refugees Biking to Safety
description: Amid all the dramatic stories of terrified Syrian refugees seeking safe haven in Europe, one odd detail struck Alessandro Iovino: People were riding bicycles along a new path to freedom through the Arctic Circle. Their choice of transport was an ingenious response to a vexing 390-foot final stretch along the border between Russia and Norway. The Russians banned foot traffic, while the Norwegians prohibited vehicles carrying people without visas.

title: The Politics of Paid Time Off to Have a Baby
description: In 1980, when Hillary Rodham Clinton was about to become a mother, she was working as a partner at Rose Law Firm in Arkansas. At the time, paid maternity leave, or leave at all, was a rare benefit. Her firm, she has said, had no maternity leave plan until she told her partners she would be taking four months off, thus establishing its first policy. Just five of the top 30 employers for women, as selected by Working Mother magazine when it first started the list in the 1980s, offered paid maternity leave, and those that did gave between one week and eight, often only at partial pay.

title: Health Reform Lives!
description: To the rights dismay, scare tactics  remember death panels?  and spurious legal challenges failed to protect the nation from the scourge of guaranteed health coverage. Still, Obamacares opponents insisted that it would implode in a death spiral of low enrollment and rising costs.

title: Giving Billions to the Rich
description: ITS that time of year again, when Republicans and Democrats put aside their differences to dole out gifts of corporate welfare to a lucky few.

title: Anti-Muslim Is Anti-American
description: There seems to be no bottom to the cesspool of Islamophobic rhetoric coming from Republican candidates.

title: Cut Sentences for Low-Level Drug Crimes
description: Now that Congress is within sight of passing the most significant federal sentencing reforms in a generation, its worth taking a closer look at where the legislation falls short.

title: Moral Dispute or Cultural Difference?
description: The word relativism tends to generate strong reactions. This is odd, given that the word is not generally used with a clear and agreed upon meaning. I want to offer a specific proposal about what it means, with a view to navigating the following real-world problem, discussed by Alex Rosenberg here at The Stone in July: What should we do when we face what are often described as irresolvable moral disagreements?

title: The 911 System Isnt Ready for the iPhone Era
description: IN 1999, Congress established 911 as the nationwide emergency number, and called for a system that would use the best technology available to deliver emergency assistance. Now, 16 years later, our emergency response system faces an emergency of its own in the form of outdated technology. To fix this, our emergency responders  police, fire and ambulance  urgently need the help of government leaders at all levels.

title: Senator Rubios Stealthy Donors
description: Of all the abuses involving hidden political money sloshing through the presidential race, one of the most brazen is being perpetrated by campaigners for Senator Marco Rubio, the Republican candidate who has been rising lately in opinion polls.

description: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich.  In late 2011, as killings, kidnappings and sectarian strife crept across the battle-scarred city of Homs, Syria, the family of four made a sorrowful decision: to flee.

title: The Future Has No Gender: Readers Debate a Feminist T-Shirt

title: Empire of Self: A Life of Gore Vidal, by Jay Parini
description: Easily the best, most entertaining book about Gore Vidal is his 1995 memoir Palimpsest. But with the possible exception of In Bed With Gore Vidal, Tim Teemans 2013 tell-all, Palimpsest is also the least reliable of the Vidal books. Vidal was a tireless self-mythologizer, and as his title suggests, that book is a layering of rememberings, re-rememberings and mis-rememberings. In his new, much sounder biography, Empire of Self, Jay Parini suggests that even the account of Vidals idyllic romance with his high school friend Jimmie Trimble, one of the touchstones of Palimpsest  the story of a love so perfect and unearthly that it could never be duplicated  was most likely a fabrication.

title: The Complete Works of Primo Levi
description: Primo Levi studied chemistry at Turin and worked as a chemist until, at 24, he joined the Italian partisans resisting the Nazi occupation of northern Italy in 1943. He was arrested by Italian Fascists and turned over to the Germans, who sent him to Auschwitz  he called it the Lager, the German word for a concentration camp  where he survived partly by luck, partly because he was put to work in a synthetic-rubber factory that used prisoners as slave labor. Returning to Italy, he wrote his memoir of Auschwitz, If This Is a Man (1947), and worked 30 years for a paint factory while writing stories, poems, memoirs, essays, a novel and The Periodic Table (1975), his idiosyncratic autobiography in which each chapter was named for a chemical element and some chapters were short stories.

title: With Googles Offline Maps, Getting Around Gets Cheaper
description: Using your smartphone to look up a museum address or get turn-by-turn directions on a street in a foreign city can end up costing a small fortune in data charges. Those who download Google Mapss new Offline Maps wont have to pay a dime.

title: China Cuts Mobile Service of Xinjiang Residents Evading Internet Filters
description: HONG KONG  The Chinese government is shutting down the mobile service of residents in Xinjiang who use software that lets them circumvent Internet filters, escalating an already aggressive electronic surveillance strategy in the countrys fractious western territory.

title: For Third Day, Brussels Is Paralyzed by Terror Dragnet
description: BRUSSELS  On what would normally have been a busy Monday, this city in the heart of Europe remained shut down for a third straight day. Everything was closed  the schools, museums, government offices, public transportation, markets, shops, everything.

description: Have you ever felt disconcerted? It is a terrible feeling, the worst in the world.

title: 1940: Yugoslavs Fear Isolation
description: BELGRADE  As the procession of statesmen from central and southeastern Europe flies by in the direction of Adolf Hitlers reception room, many Yugoslavs are watching nervously, and with a growing conviction that their country is being isolated. Every time one of these statesmen signs on the dotted line, the iron ring forged around the countries on the Yugoslav border is tightened. This fact is brought out by a glance at a map of Yugoslavia. Reading from left to right, this countrys neighbors are Benito Mussolinis Italy, Hitlers Germany, a Hungary which has just joined the totalitarian three-power pact, Iron Guard Rumania, where German soldiers stand ready, a Bulgaria which is making territorial demands on Yugoslavia, and finally Greece and Albania.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 24, 1940

title: Twitter Cats to the Rescue in Brussels Lockdown
description: As the hunt for terrorism suspects intensified in Brussels, the authorities requested that Belgians refrain from posting messages on Sunday that might expose or interfere with police operations.

But to many, the tears of 23-year-old Esraa el-Taweel most poignantly captured the grinding misery of life under the military-backed regime of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi.

title: Frozen Lion Cubs Still Have Their Fur 12,000 Years Later

title: 1965: Russia Shifts Position on A-war
description: MOSCOW  The weight of Soviet military thinking is apparently shifting toward the position that nuclear weapons would not inevitably be used in a future war, qualified sources reported today [Nov. 23]. This departure from the opposite view identified with Nikita S. Khrushchev, that the immediate or early use of nuclear arms had to be expected, was cited as the most meaningful change in Soviet strategy in the year since the former premier fell. It is a welcome change to the United States, which made a similar shift itself about five years ago. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 24, 1965

A countdown clock on the bands website hit zero at midnight on Monday, revealing a free download of Saint Cecilia, along with a link to donate to victims of the violence in Paris.

title: F.D.A. Targets Inaccurate Medical Tests, Citing Dangers and Costs

Should you drape the banisters with balsam fir, or is boxwood more current? Which breed of artificial bird is trending to clamp among the boughs? And will you be able to hold your head up if you have not personally raised from poulthood the turkey that graces the holiday table (as Martha Stewart suggests) or hand-pressed the apple cider with which you braised the brisket?

title: After a Horrid Start, the Chiefs Are Making a Playoff Run
description: The 1970 Cincinnati Bengals have been widely credited with bringing the West Coast offense to the N.F.L. The teams coach, Paul Brown, and offensive coordinator (and future San Francisco 49ers coach), Bill Walsh, were faced with a challenge, as quarterback Virgil Carter was a smart player with a weak arm. Under Walshs tutelage, the Bengals operated a short-passing game that was effective in those run-heavy days. A year later, Carter led the N.F.L. in completion percentage.

Now, in the first study of its kind, an international team of scientists has found that after agriculture arrived in Europe 8,500 years ago, peoples DNA underwent widespread changes, altering their height, digestion, immune system and skin color.

Leave Me Alone, out Jan. 8, traces the phases of love, from falling hard for the wrong guy to avoiding him in public. Though recorded in southern Spain, the lo-fi tracks, with lyrics in English, have a distinctly American garage-rock feel: The women cite postpunk revivalists the Strokes as a major influence.

The arrival of late autumn here signals the season of the olive harvest, as it has since the 1300s, when the citys noble families first built vacation homes with farms and groves on the fertile slopes of the province, supplying their households with olive oil, wine and firewood throughout the year.
