title: Jessica Jones Episode 3: Youre a Good Person
description: This episode of Jessica Jones, which picks up seconds after the previous one, feels like a corrective for every little imperfection in the first two. Jones finally seems to be taking active strides to regain control of her life. For example: Jones doesnt treat Hope Schlottman, the latest victim of Joness arch-nemesis Kilgrave, like a client that she also happens to care personally about. Instead, Jones does her best to protect Hope because she primarily wants to stop Kilgrave, and summarily feels obligated to protect people from him.

The theater and Weinstein Live Entertainment announced Monday that Singin in the Rain, which opened at the Chtelet in March and returned on Nov. 7 for a six-week run, would transfer to Broadway in the fall of 2016. It follows An American in Paris, which Chtelet co-produced and which transferred to Broadway in April, receiving glowing reviews and earning 12 Tony nominations.

title: How the Pfizer-Allergan Deal Ranks

description: As Donald J. Trump heads to Ohio to woo voters on Monday, Gov. John Kasich is not exactlyrolling out the red carpet.

title: Babushkas of Chernobyl Finds Life Thriving in Scarred Land
description: As we walked among the empty houses of Zalesye, the last thing I expected to see was an inhabitant. But suddenly there she was. Striding from her cottage in heavy boots, a scarf tied on her head, Rosalia greeted us in Ukrainian and proudly showed us her potato patch.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Artichoke Torte
description: For a simple but substantive vegetarian entree this Thanksgiving, try this easy Artichoke Torte. Although artichokes arent a typical November vegetable, they freeze well and can be enjoyed any time of year. This recipe from Carol Lamont of Palo Alto, Calif., uses frozen artichokes to make a simple but delicious torte for your holiday table.

title: A Step Closer to the Defeat of Polio
description: Three years have passed since a case of Type 3 wild polio virus has been detected in the world, which means that particular viral subtype has most likely disappeared forever, the World Health Organization announced this month.

title: After Thanksgiving, Turkey Sandwiches for the Leftover-Deprived
description: What happens if you do not come away with leftovers from Thanksgiving dinner at someones home or a restaurant? Banish day-after cravings with a pulled turkey sandwich by Ratha Chaupoly and Ben Daitz from Num Pang thats slathered with hoisin barbecue sauce, brightened with pickled cranberries and garnished with chile mayo, cucumber and carrots: Pulled turkey pang, $8.50, Num Pang, 75 Broad Street (South William Street) and other locations, numpangnyc.com.

title: Engineering Mosquitoes Genes to Resist Malaria
description: In a basement on the Irvine campus of the University of California, behind a series of five protective doors, two teams of biologists have created a novel breed of mosquito that they hope will help eradicate malaria from the world.

title: When a Bag Is Based on Math
description: Adrin Salvador Candela hesitates to call himself fed up, but hes certainly frustrated; its a common refrain in fashion these days. The creative director of the Spanish womens ready-to-wear brand Siemprevivas (and a former designer at J. Mendel, Peter Pilotto and Adolfo Dominguez) mentions the hectic calendar, the multiplying number of collaborations, the never-ending game of musical chairs  and, sometimes, a lack of rationale. Fashion is an industry, so it needs to be sustainable, he says. The shows should have a reason, the campaigns everything should have a reason.

title: Bricklaying, a Nearly Lost Art, Makes a Comeback in Luxury Buildings
description: A neat little row of bricks and stone blocks sits on a worktable inside the TriBeCa offices of the development firm DDG. Some are classic red, others ivory white; a few resemble smoke, a ghost of their birth in the kiln.

description: For Monday nights British Fashion Awards, more than 800 fashion insiders voted for the 16 winners in categories representing womens wear, mens wear, red carpet design, model of the year and more. This year the ceremony will also honor Karl Lagerfeld with an Outstanding Achievement award and Alessandro Michele of Gucci with an International Designer award, as well as provide stellar red-carpet moments from guests like Lady Gaga, Kate Bosworth and more.

title: Syrian Refugees Rejected, Rerouted and Resettled
description: They moved from street to street in Syria, dodging bullets and bombs. Finally, they fled to Jordan, where they lived an anxious existence as unwelcome refugees. And then, after three years of interviews and security checks, a Syrian family  a 33-year-old man, his 23-year-old wife and their almost 5-year-old son  were granted refugee status in the United States.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Barry Dillers Business Model Bears Fruit
description: Pop quiz. Which company has created more value for shareholders over the last two decades: Disney, Microsoft or IAC/InterActiveCorp?

title: Pictures of the Day: Belgium and More
description: Belgium and Elsewhere: Pictures of the Day

title: Review: Rachmaninoff Chemistry at the 92nd Street Y
description: There was something a bit perverse about the chamber-music program presented by the New York Philharmonic at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday, part of its three-week Rachmaninoff festival. Sure, the promise of the breathtaking pianist Daniil Trifonov joining forces with the violinist Sheryl Staples and the cellist Carter Brey in the seething Trio lgiaque (Op. 9) was all it took to fill the Kaufmann Concert Hall. But to round out the program with two unfinished string quartets  works that Rachmaninoff abandoned, surely with good reason  when there is a luscious, masterly cello sonata begging to be played?

title: Breast-Feeding Is Good for Mothers, Not Just Babies, Studies Suggest
description: Breast milk may provide the ideal nourishment for an infant, but two recent studies are putting a different spin on the bottle-versus-breast debate, suggesting it is mothers, and not just babies, who may have much to gain from breast-feeding.

title: Review: In The Pilgrims, Ric Burns Looks at Mythmaking
description: First there was Saints & Strangers, a pretty good dramatization of the Pilgrims story on the National Geographic Channel. Now comes the PBS take on the same subject, The Pilgrims, an episode of American Experience on Tuesday night.

title: Investigation Into Emissions to Take Months, VW Chief Says
description: FRANKFURT  Volkswagen is still several months away from being able to clarify who was responsible for installing emissions-cheating software in millions of diesel vehicles and plunging the company into crisis, the automakers leader said on Monday.

title: Nov. 23, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Belgium, Greece, Israel and South Korea.

title: New York Opens Inquiry Into Electronic Trade Spoofing
description: New Yorks attorney general is in the early stages of investigating manipulative tactics in the electronic trading of emerging markets currencies, a person familiar with the matter said on Monday.

title: Mauricio Macri Took Detour From Life as Scion to Argentine Presidency
description: BUENOS AIRES  When he was just 32, the president-elect of Argentina, Mauricio Macri, thought his life would follow the predictable pattern of the son of an industrial tycoon, marked by luxury and privilege as he followed his fathers path into business inside the cocoon of this nations elite.

title: Germany Will Not Send the Singer Xavier Naidoo to Eurovision
description: The singer Xavier Naidoo will not represent Germany in the Eurovision Song Contest in 2016, it was announced this weekend.

title: Returning From War Wounded
description: Michael Stokes, a photographer, takes portraits of amputee veterans, a project that has helped him raise $30,000 for the Semper Fi Fund.

title: Review: Ian Flemings James Bond Letters in The Man With the Golden Typewriter
description: Ian Fleming adored women, fast cars, golf, martinis and cards, and he cheerfully assigned these same hobbies to his most famous fictional creation, Agent 007. But The Man With the Golden Typewriter: Ian Flemings James Bond Letters is much less about Flemings glamorous cavorting than it is about his brazen hustle to become a famous commercial novelist. This will come as a disappointment, perhaps, to anyone who dives into this collection and expects an orgy of vice. But to anyone who has ever worked on a book  writing one, editing one, marketing one, publishing one  or, heck, even just read one, this volume is a giant stalk of catnip.

title: Miamis Art World Sets Sights on Little Haiti Neighborhood
description: MIAMI  Everybodys always looking for the next art neighborhood, mused Tony Cho, standing amid the scrum outside Gallery Diet. Taking in the scene at its opening night party here, he motioned to another new gallery across the street, its neon sign punctuating an otherwise darkened stretch of this citys Little Haiti neighborhood. Its going to happen here.

title: Pastured Eggs From Roaming Hens
description: Blake and Stephanie Alexandre, dairy farmers, bought 150 laying hens for their sons to teach them responsibility. Today they sell five million eggs a year from pastured hens.

title: Putting the Chicken Before the Egg
description: CRESCENT CITY, Calif.  A decade ago, a couple running a dairy business in Northern California visited a Mennonite farm where the owner had used a flock of laying hens to teach his children business principles and instill values like responsibility and care for nature.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing: Brussels, Pfizer, David Cameron
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Review: In Shadowland Opening the Makeup Case and Unleashing a New World
description: The protagonist in Shadowland, the latest evening-length work from the athlete-illusionists of Pilobolus, is really down on her luck. A teenage girl lost in a dark dream, shes at the mercy of a mysterious giant who, with the rustle of one imposing hand, turns her into a dog from the waist up. Both before and after this transformation, she is chased, threatened, prodded, eaten, humiliated, even tied up and whipped. Whos the target demographic here?

title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on 4 in Burundi Violence
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The United States imposed sanctions Monday against four men connected to a wave of violence in Burundi that has destabilized the central African nation and raised fears of all-out civil war.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: Flower Power Blooms in the Lab
description: A bedside light powered by the houseplant sitting next to it? It may be possible.

title: Donald Trumps Hosting of S.N.L. Means Equal Airtime for Rivals
description: NBC viewers in Iowa, New Hampshire and South Carolina should be prepared to see a lot of four Republican presidential candidates over the Thanksgiving weekend.

title: From New York Youth Symphony and the Chamber Music Society, Odes to Experience
description: Passing on experience from one generation to another, not just by formal teaching but through mentoring and coaching, is crucial to endeavors as unalike as medicine and baseball, and certainly to classical music. There are some things about this art that can only be learned by decades of doing it.

title: Paris Attacks Spur Emergency Edict and Intense Policing in France
description: PARIS  All over France, from Toulouse in the south to Paris and beyond, the police have been breaking down doors, conducting searches without warrants, aggressively questioning residents, hauling suspects to police stations and putting others under house arrest.

title: A Field Guide to Civilian Drones
description: As consumer and commercial drones increase in popularity, the government is taking more steps to address safety concerns and regulate the aerial vehicles.

title: Fantasy Sites vs. Congress: A Matchup That Could Be Bruising
description: WASHINGTON  Early in 2008, I had a casual hallway conversation in the Capitol with Senator Arlen Specter, about his pick to win the Super Bowl, that ended up touching off a furor right before the kickoff between the New England Patriots and the New York Giants.

title: BenjaminNetanyahu Plans Separate Bypass Roads for Israelis in Parts of West Bank
description: JERUSALEM  Under pressure from Israeli settlers in the occupied West Bank, who are demanding better security after weeks of attacks by Palestinians, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said on Monday that his government would establish bypass roads for Israeli drivers in certain areas and revoke the work permits of attackers extended families.

title: Luxembourg Goes in for an Image Makeover
description: Luxembourg, the country once known as the European Death Star of financial secrecy, is looking to improve its image.

title: Austin Kiplinger, Co-Founder of a Personal Finance Magazine, Dies at 97
description: Austin H. Kiplinger, who with his father started what is now Kiplingers Personal Finance magazine and expanded the familys financial publishing company into a $100-million-a-year enterprise by the late 1990s, died on Friday in Rockville, Md. He was 97.

title: Iran Sentences an American Journalist
description: Authorities in Iran announced on Sunday that the American journalist Jason Rezaian, a Washington Post reporter held by the government for 16 months and charged with espionage, had been sentenced to prison.  The Iranian government made the announcement with as much transparency as it has shown in this case all along: none.

title: Deliveroo, an On-Demand Food Delivery Service, Raises $100 Million
description: From San Francisco to Paris, there are hints that the worlds booming tech industry maybe be slowing down.

title: Terror Politics
description: Update: Yes, I know theres a cat in the picture; I took it from Slate, The Cats of War. Ive used that image before, to lighten things up slightly. Apparently I didnt succeed.

title: With a Home or Without, Childrens Schooling Is Front and Center
description: Shelter is temporary.

title: A Year Without Tamir
description: Cleveland  On a cold, dreary Sunday morning, grayness envelops the city. Tiny pellets of snow and ice fall like crumbs of Styrofoam.

title: China and U.S. Say Theyve Made Strides in Trade Talks
description: GUANGZHOU, China  In their first top-level trade talks since President Obama hosted Chinas leader in September, the United States and China said on Monday that they had made progress on sticking points, including preventing the theft of trade secrets and opening the Chinese market more broadly to American multinationals.

title: Whats It Like to Get Sick on the New York Subway? Readers Share Their Stories
description: About 3,000 subway trains in New York are delayed each month because of sick passengers, as Emma G. Fitzsimmons writes in a New York Times article published on Monday. Readers, some of whom had gotten sick on the train themselves, wrote in to share their stories.

title: Elliott Management Appoints Jonathan Pollock as Co-Chief Executive
description: For most of its 38 years, Elliott Management has been a lucrative hedge fund run solely by its founder, the billionaire Paul E. Singer, a man known for his hard-nosed trades and outsize influence in politics.

title: Future Ford Cars Wont Use Takata Airbag Parts
description: Ford Motor on Monday became the fourth automaker to announce that it would stop using certain airbag components made by the Japanese supplier Takata in future vehicles.

title: William Ackman Raises Valeant Stake to 9.9% From 5.7%
description: The billionaire investor William A. Ackman has sharply increased his position in Valeant Pharmaceuticals, the embattled drug company that has come under scrutiny.

title: Nestl Reports on Abuses in Thailands Seafood Industry
description: WASHINGTON  The seafood industry in Thailand suffers from widespread labor and human rights abuses, exposing virtually all American and European companies that buy seafood from there to the endemic risk of having these problems as part of their supply chain, according to a report released on Monday by the food giant Nestl.

title: Ken Johnson, Only Loser of 9-Inning No-Hitter, Dies at 82
description: Baseball, that statistics-mad enterprise, has served up its share of rare performances by individual players. Fifteen fielders have turned unassisted triple plays. Thirteen hitters have hit two grand slams in a game, including one, Fernando Tatis, who in April 1999 did so in the same inning, which may be the games most remarkable anomaly, though Don Larsens perfect game for the Yankees against the Dodgers in 1956  the only no-hitter thrown in the World Series  is better known and better remembered.

title: Edible, but Ugly
description: To combat food waste, Imperfect Produce, a San Francisco Bay Area start-up, sells fresh fruits and vegetables that never make it to grocery store shelves.

title: Fed Official Expects Test for Big Banks to Be Stricter
description: Every year, the largest banks have to undergo a theoretical test to assess how they might fare in a period of extreme stress in the markets and the economy.

title: Lawyers Battle Over Conduct in 2003 Murder Case in Brooklyn
description: It was lawyer versus lawyer Monday, as a top Brooklyn homicide prosecutor took the stand in a hearing revisiting a murder conviction in a 2003 killing.

title: Afghan Leaders Try to Halt Exodus, but Pleas Ring Hollow
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  President Ashraf Ghani took a stage here last week and urged the crowd of young people before him not to join a huge exodus from Afghanistan, despite rising insecurity and economic hardship.

title: Jessica Jones Episode 4: Think About Me
description: Any forward momentum that the previous episode gave to the shows Kilgrave-vs.-Jones plot is lost in A.K.A. 99 Friends, a pedestrian investigation-of-the-week episode that only laterally expands Joness story.

title: Civilian Review Board Criticizes Arrest of Thabo Sefolosha
description: New York Citys Civilian Complaint Review Board ruled on Monday that the police had no right to arrest Atlanta Hawks basketball player Thabo Sefolosha outside a nightclub in April, but that officers had not used excessive force when they knocked him to the ground and broke his leg.

title: Donations Help the S.S. United States Fend Off the Scrapyard
description: For now, at least, the next port of call for the S.S. United States  the fastest oceanliner ever built  will not be the scrapyard, thanks to an outpouring of donations from ship lovers around the world.

title: Carl Icahn Takes 7.1% Stake in Xerox
description: The billionaire and activist investor Carl C. Icahn took aim at another famous American company on Monday, the Xerox Corporation, and he stepped up pressure on the insurance giant American International Group.

title: Joyce Carol Oates on Twitter: Is Nothing Joyous in ISIS?
description: Joyce Carol Oates, the author of more than 50 books, faced a spirited backlash on Twitter after she posed a question Sunday about whether anything is celebratory & joyous within the Islamic State.

title: Jets Stick With Ryan Fitzpatrick at Quarterback, if Not Enthusiastically
description: Ryan Fitzpatrick was asked an obvious question, and he responded in kind.

title: Planned Parenthood Sues Texas in Dispute Over Funding for Clinics
description: HOUSTON  Planned Parenthood sued Texas officials in federal court in Austin on Monday, seeking to block the state from cutting off its Medicaid funding, the latest in a series of lawsuits it has filed against Republican-led states after the controversy over its use of fetal tissue.

title: John Kerry Adds Voice to Those Urging Bigger Push Against Islamic State in Syria
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  With the Obama administration under mounting pressure from some of its own top former officials to take a more aggressive approach to combating the Islamic State, Secretary of State John Kerry said Monday that he would like to see the American-led military and diplomatic effort in Syria go faster.

title: Bill Blocking Plan to Reduce Mute Swans Is Vetoed
description: It was always destined to bring public relations misery: a state agencys campaign, approved by experts but undeniably unpleasant, to exterminate the lithe-necked, snow-white mute swans of New York State, in the name of ecological health.

title: Adele Mailer, Artist Who Married Norman Mailer, Dies at 90
description: Adele Mailer, an artist and actress who made headlines in 1960 when her husband, the novelist Norman Mailer, stabbed and seriously wounded her at a drunken party in their apartment, died on Sunday in Manhattan. She was 90.

title: Chris Christies Bid Gains New Life as He Invokes 9/11 Amid Fear
description: STRATHAM, N.H.  In the course of a two-hour campaign stop here, Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey brought a handful of men and women to tears describing the deathbed wishes of his cancer-ridden mother, cracked them up with the declaration that his presidency would be golf-free and riveted them with his remembrances of the family friends he lost on Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Buckeyes, Shaken by Loss, Have Shot at Redemption
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  On a roster posted on the back wall of the Ohio State football teams meeting room, each players name is accompanied by the number of Buckeye Leader Awards he has earned from each game.

title: Washington Is Next on Franois Hollandes Tour to Press Allies for Anti-ISIS Coalition
description: PARIS  President Franois Hollande of France heads to Washington on Tuesday as a self-described wartime president, with his political future at stake.

title: David Cameron Says He Will Increase Britains Military Spending
description: LONDON  In a significant reversal of British government policy, Prime Minister David Cameron promised on Monday to bolster military spending, ending years of cutbacks that had prompted critics to claim that Britain was retreating from its global role.

title: Pfizer-Allergan Merger Reignites Tax Reform Discussion
description: WASHINGTON  For almost four years, Congress and the White House have done little to make their long-promised overhaul of the corporate tax code a reality. Now the blockbuster pharmaceutical merger of Pfizer and Allergan has put new pressure on all sides to act.

title: U.S. Issues Travel Alert
description: In the wake of the terrorist attacks in Paris, the State Departmentissued a worldwide travel alert on Monday for American citizens, particularly during the holiday season, until Feb. 24.

title: Appeals Court Rules Memos on Targeted Killings Can Stay Classified
description: WASHINGTON  A federal appeals court ruled in a decision unsealed on Monday that the Justice Department could continue to conceal internal documents related to targeted killings in the fight against Al Qaeda.

title: Condemning Terror
description: The speech by President Franois Hollande of France after the attacks on Paris showed many parallels with George W. Bushs speeches after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Appeals Court Rules for Transcripts in Eric Garner Case to Remain Sealed
description: New York States highest court declined on Monday to hear an appeal from several groups seeking the public release of transcripts from the grand jury that considered evidence in the death of Eric Garner at the hands of city police officers.

title: FanDuel, Facing Opposition, Maintains Its Visibility in New York
description: As FanDuel braced for a court hearing that could determine the fate of daily fantasy sports in New York, the company demonstrated that it remained committed to advertising its website there.

title: Review: In Important Hats of the Twentieth Century, Saggy Jeans and Sweatshirts Make a 1930s Incursion
Washer Action
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  There comes a time in every homeowners life when it becomes necessary to make a sacrifice to the god of home appliances in the form of large amounts of money. I encountered that moment shortly after moving into my current house, when I tried to track down the mysterious sounds emanating from my basement, only to discover my washing machine performing a conga across the floor in mid-SPIN CYCLE.

title: Heat Defenders Swarm Porzingis, Who Cant Save Knicks
description: MIAMI  Heat players pledged before Mondays game to learn from the mistakes of their predecessors. They would actually defend Kristaps Porzingis, the newly minted wunderkind of the Knicks. They would roam with him to the perimeter, denying him open looks at 3-pointers. They would challenge him.

title: Holiday on Thursday: Thanksgiving
description: NEW YORK

title: Executive Says Dean Skelos Provided Valuable Business Intelligence
description: The founder of the struggling environmental services company at the heart of the federal corruption case against State Senator Dean G. Skelos and his son testified at their trial on Monday that days after Hurricane Sandy hit in 2012, the senator provided valuable business intelligence that the company felt would be helpful.

title: Blindspot Season 1, Episode 10: All Your Idea
description: Monday nights episode of NBCs Blindspot certainly hit this recapper close to home. More on that later. First, kudos to Martin Gero, the shows creator, and his crew for managing a startling final flourish two episodes in a row.

title: Fargo Season 2, Episode 7: This Family Deserves the Ground
description: This family deserves the ground.

title: Egypt: Forces Kill 5 Sudanese at Border
description: Egyptian security forces on Monday shot and killed at least five Sudanese migrants who were trying to cross the border from Egypt into Israel, the military said in a statement. The deaths came eight days after Egyptian border guards were accused in the fatal shootings of at least 15 Sudanese migrants trying to cross the frontier. Human rights groups have for years criticized the Egyptian authorities as resorting too quickly to lethal force against migrants and asylum seekers, mostly from East Africa, who travel through the Sinai Peninsula to reach Israel. In the latest episode, the military said the border guards fired warning shots and were moving to arrest the migrants when the Egyptian guards came under fire. In addition to the five migrants who were killed, six others were injured, the statement said.

title: Admissions Quota Proposed in Brooklyn School Rezoning
description: Responding to concerns that a plan to redraw two Brooklyn school zones would fill an elementary school with affluent white children that currently serves mostly low-income minority children, Education Department staff members said on Monday that students receiving free or reduced-price lunches would be given admissions priority for half the seats in each class at the school.

title: Documentary About Rape at Colleges Draws Viewers in Key Demographic
description: The Hunting Ground, a documentary about rape on college campuses, attracted an average of 179,000 live and same-day viewers Sunday night in the 25-to-54 age group, the highest average for cable news networks during the nearly two-hour period that began at 8 p.m. Eastern.

title: Researchers Track Tricky Payment Theft Scheme
description: Cybersecurity experts are on the hunt for a sophisticated payment theft scheme unlike any that has been used before.

title: Jack Ma of Alibaba in Talks to Buy Hong Kong Newspaper
description: HONG KONG  Jack Ma, chairman of the Internet giant Alibaba Group, is in talks to buy The South China Morning Post, an influential English-language newspaper based in Hong Kong, according to a person with direct knowledge of the discussions.

title: Albert Einstein and Relativity in the Pages of The Times
description: When Albert Einstein and his work first became known to the broader public, articles in The Times often seemed to alternate between exasperation and fascination.

title: Space, the Frontier Right in Front of Us
description: With the publication of his general theory of relativity a century ago, Albert Einstein swept aside traditional notions of a static and unchanging space and instead gave us the stretchy, supple miracle fabric of the space-time continuum.

description: PRINCETON, N.J.  By the fall of 1915, Albert Einstein was a bit grumpy.

title: Who Wins in Photo Contests?
description: As the holiday season approaches, many photographers turn to reviewing their years work and entering photography contests. These competitions run the gamut: Some spotlight local achievement, while others honor photographers from all over the world. There are contests by nonprofits that are free to enter and many others whose business plan depends on entry fees from photographers wanting to be noticed.

title: Mr. Trumps Applause Lies
description: America has just lived through another presidential campaign week dominated by Donald Trumps racist lies. Heres a partial list of false statements: The United States is about to take in 250,000 Syrian refugees; African-Americans are responsible for most white homicides; and during the 9/11 attacks, thousands and thousands of people in an unnamed Arab community in New Jersey were cheering as that building was coming down.

title: Can Democrats Make Running for Office Seem Cool?
description: Under normal circumstances, the weirdness of this presidential cycle  the historically large and fragmented Republican field, the dominance of outsider candidates and the slow-rolling revival of nationalism in the conservative base  would be enough to make Democrats giddy. But they shouldnt feel too smug; they have their own party leadership problem. Its not as visible, but it is potentially more disastrous.

title: Should Woodrow Wilsons Name Be Erased at Princeton?
description: To the Editor:

title: Force-Feeding: Cruel at Guantnamo, but O.K. for Our Parents
description: THE practice of forced feeding has been highlighted by its use on hunger strikers in Guantnamo Bay and, more recently, in Israel, where a vigorous debate about the ethics of such a practice is taking place. But you dont have to be in prison to have a feeding tube jammed up your nose. Millions of elderly Americans are fed through tubes despite a lack of substantial evidence pointing to any clinical benefit.

title: What Woodrow Wilson Cost My Grandfather
description: OVER the last week, a growing number of students at Princeton have demanded that the university confront the racist legacy of Woodrow Wilson, who served as its president before becoming New Jerseys governor and the 28th president of the United States. Among other things, the students are demanding that Wilsons name be removed from university facilities.

title: Pfizers Big Breakthrough: Global Tax Avoidance
description: The $160 billion deal to combine Pfizer and Allergan, the maker of Botox, does not appear to be illegal. But it should be. This merger is a tax-dodging maneuver that enriches shareholders and executives while shortchanging the public and robbing the Treasury of money that would pay for a host of government programs  including education, scientific research and other services that also benefit corporations.

title: Amid Failure and Chaos, an Ebola Vaccine
description: Ebola lingers. A 15-year-old boy in Monrovia, Liberia, his father and his brother are sick with the disease, the first cases in Liberia since June. How the boy caught Ebola is a mystery, but it is likely he had contact with an Ebola survivor. The virus also lingers in the body  and can sicken its host and infect others even months after recovery.

title: Which U.S. Infrastructure Is in Most Need of Attention?

description: This interview, the latest in a series on political topics, discusses philosophical issues concerning the criminalization of drug use. title: Militants Attack Hotel in Egypts Sinai Peninsula, Killing at Least 7

title: Photographing Veterans Back From War
description: The photographs are riveting: Scantily clad men with impossibly chiseled torsos, stomachs rippling, biceps bulging. Only upon second glance do you realize that something is different, that these are not your basic beefcake shots. Some of the men are missing an arm, or a hand, or a leg. Others have hooks or metal rods where their limbs should be.

description: Given the warnings the drug maker Pfizer provides with its products such as Lipitor and Viagra, the company had to know there was a risk of serious political side effects to its $160 billion merger with Dublin-based Allergan, a deal that has upset Democrats.
