title: A Dream of Secular Utopia in ISIS Backyard
description: One of the safer crossings into Syria is at a small town called Fishkhabour, in the far northwestern corner of Iraq. In a whitewashed shack on the shore of the Tigris River, an official from Iraqs Kurdistan Regional Government pointed out the window toward a pontoon bridge that bobbed in the cola-colored water. A year ago, 30,000 refugees fleeing an Islamic State massacre in Syria walked for 30 hours before crossing it in the opposite direction, half-starved, half-dead, terrorized. The official told me and my interpreter, Mohammed Ismael Rasool, that a few days before we arrived, an Italian volunteer was arrested by a border patrolman while trying to swim back toward Iraq. Dont change your mind, he said, wagging a finger.

title: The Serial Swatter
description: Early one weekend morning in January 2014, Janet was sleeping fitfully in her parents home in Toronto. A junior studying elementary education at a nearby college, she had gone home for the weekend in a state of nervous collapse. For months, someone going by the name Obnoxious had been harassing her online. He had called her cellphone repeatedly and sent her threatening texts. Worst of all, he had threatened to swat her at school  to make a false emergency call to the police and lure a SWAT team to her door.

title: Bob Mankoff Thinks Cats Are Funnier Than Dogs
description: Youre the cartoon editor of The New Yorker and the subject of a new HBO documentary, Very Semi-Serious. In it, cartoonists often try to explain their cartoons to you if you arent initially sold. Does that ever work? Im not infallible. I might be the king of cartoons; Im not the pope. But what I say to cartoonists is that there is often something to get in New Yorker cartoons  anyway, we hope so  but it should never feel like a puzzle to the reader.

title: Poll Watch: Low Marks for Obama on Fighting Terrorism
description: Less than two weeks after Islamic State terrorists killed scores of people in Paris and Beirut, fewer than one in four Americans say they think President Obama has a clear plan for combating the terrorist group, according to a new CBS News poll.

title: Ted Cruz Makes a Big Leap in Iowa, Poll Says
description: Ted Cruzs long-anticipated Iowa surge came a step closer on Tuesday with a new poll showing him just behind Donald J. Trump and leaping ahead of Ben Carson, as terrorism and foreign policy now drive the 2016 nominating race.

title: Actors of The Big Short Talk About the Debt Crisis, in Beverly Hills
description: BEVERLY HILLS, CALIF.  Besides starring in The Big Short  the forthcoming comic drama about the Wall Street outsiders who anticipated the subprime mortgage collapse and made a mint betting against the American economy  Steve Carell, Ryan Gosling and Finn Wittrock all have something else in common. Basically, how little they actually understood about the recent housing and credit bubble before researching their roles. I thought I knew, but I didnt really know anything at all, Mr. Gosling said.

title: RenaultEspace Exceeds Pollution Limits, German Environmental Group Says
description: FRANKFURT  A German environmental group said on Tuesday that a diesel passenger van made by Renault produces up to 25 times as much pollution as allowed, a further indication that Volkswagen may not be the only company that has flouted emissions rules.

title: Weekly News Quiz | Nov. 17-23, 2015
description: Have you been following this weeks news? Take our quiz to see what you know and to learn more.

title: Letter of Recommendation: Kitchen Timer
description: It began, as many habits do, in desperation. In my first year of working from home, I had discovered how crucial it was that I stay fastened to my desk. This sounded simple, but it was, in fact, as difficult to accomplish as it would have been at a desk on a ship caught in a typhoon. Never before had I felt so many gusts of trivial desire: I needed to buy stamps at the post office, to dust the window sills, to locate the jump-rope I was fairly sure Id left in the back of the closet.

title: The Winter Hat Trick
description: Here they come now, winter hats, making their annual flight from the recesses of our closets to the crests of our persons. The plain-spoken stocking caps, the trapper hats, the rabbit-fur fantasia  to watch these and a hundred other designs re-enter circulation is at once to witness the most natural thing in the world and to size up something strange. Hats seem essential in frigid air, but many seem impossible to wear with a straight face, given the cultural climate. Get a whiff of the models that served our grandfathers well: They now combine the must of a midcentury hatbox with the musk of 21st-century body spray. Take a look at the grown-ups wearing wool caps decorated to the verge of doubling as stuffed animals. The impish self-consciousness of such nonsense shows that gussying up the head is, however awkward, serious business.

title: Classical Music This Week: Beethoven Reviewed and Birthdays
description: Happy Thanksgiving week, classical music lovers! There arent so many concerts this week (all the better to spend some time with recordings), but a few are choice.

title: Is It Still Possible to Be a Public Intellectual?
description: Each week in Bookends, two writers take on questions about the world of books. This week, Pankaj Mishra and Alice Gregory discuss the fate of the public intellectual in an age of specialization.

title: A Few Words About Grape Salad, Snapping and Badges
description: We all know that theres a lot of terrible news lately. The world seems even more immersed in frightening chaos than usual. And for journalists, its extremely dangerous out there. A Washington Post reporter, Jason Rezaian, has reportedly been sentenced to prison in Iran. Several journalists died in the Paris attacks, and journalists continue to be killed or imprisoned all over the world as they do their work. (The worthy Committee to Protect Journalists will do its best to continue fighting that, in part through its annual gathering in New York City this evening.)

title: Dance This Week: Sugarplums Everywhere, Two to Tango and Ballet for All
description: Balanchine Nutcrackers

title: When Spell-Check Cant Help
description: Heres another batch of sound-alike mix-ups, including a rarity  a homophone problem I cant recall seeing before. Put it on your list!

title: Volkswagen Is Subject of German Tax Inquiry
description: FRANKFURT  German prosecutors have opened another investigation into Volkswagen, this one focusing on whether the company broke local tax laws by making false claims about its vehicles carbon dioxide emissions.

title: High School Footballs Friday Night Bloat
description: High school football playoff season has begun across the country, and continues nearly till Christmas. The result will be not 50 titlists but at least 425 state high school football champions. In the N.F.L., every team save one is ground into dust. In high school football, its trophies galore!

title: Hollandes War on Liberties
description: PARIS  Horrific terrorist attacks, like those of Sept. 11, 2001, have a way of sweeping away careful political reflection in favor of emotion. Hand in hand with a propensity to respond overwhelmingly with armed force comes a temptation for governments to grab more powers and exempt themselves from longstanding rules in ways that undermine the foundations of democracy.

title: Telephone Time Warp
description: Dear Diary:

title: U.S. Economic Growth for 3rd Quarter Revised Up to 2.1%
description: The American economy turned in a better performance last quarter than first thought, expanding at a 2.1 percent rate, the government said on Tuesday.

title: Festive, Art Deco-Inspired Watches for Men
description: These rectangular timepieces convey elegance of a distinctly festive bent.

title: Party Face
description: These rectangular, Art Deco-inspired timepieces convey elegance of a distinctly festive bent.

title: Athens Blast Hurts None but Fuels Fears of Domestic Terrorism
description: ATHENS  A bomb went off outside the offices of a Greek business federation in the heart of Athens early on Tuesday, causing damage but no injuries, the police said. It was the first such attack under the countrys leftist-led government, fueling fears of a possible resurgence of domestic terrorism.

title: How to Talk to Your Relatives About Politics at Thanksgiving
description: Its time for that annual American holiday tradition: awkward political conversation at the Thanksgiving dinner table. With the 2016 presidential primary campaign in full swing and public interest on the rise, the odds are good that relatives will share their thoughts with you about why one candidate will win or how another is going to destroy America. I cant tell you how to keep your family away from sensitive topics, but here are brief answers to some frequently asked questions about current events and the 2016 race.

title: In Arguments Over Terrorism, Echoes of World War II
description: It gets your attention when a leader says we are at the beginning of a terrorist world war. It carries greater weight when that leader runs a major intelligence agency. And more weight still when that agency is German, its very name a product of the last world war and its lessons about fear and evil and the terrifying ease of losing ones soul: the Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution.

title: Brazilian Airline Azul Sells Stake to HNA Group of China
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  JetBlues founder, David G. Neeleman, has turned to China to raise funds for his Brazilian airline, Azul Linhas Areas Brasileiras.

title: Meeting With Franois Hollande, Obama Urges Europe to Escalate ISIS Fight
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama offered his visiting French counterpart emotional words of solidarity on Tuesday but made it clear that it was up to Europe to escalate its efforts to combat the terrorist group that killed 130 people in Paris this month.

title: Daily Report: Cool Drone. Is It Registered?
description: In recommendations released on Monday, a task force assigned by the Federal Aviation Administration said that nearly all recreational drones should be registered with the federal government. The goal, it seems, is to help keep drone pilots honest as they take to the skies.

title: 1940: A Mass for All War Victims
description: ROME  Fifty thousand persons packed St. Peters Church and Square this morning [Nov. 24] at a mass celebrated by Pope Pius XII for all the victims of the war and listened to an address by him before the altar in which he prayed to God to bring the peoples of the world to a peace based on justice and expressed his belief that the present hour was one of the gravest in human history. After rehearsing once more how, as head of the Church, he had worked long to re-establish peace among nations, Pope Pius said that although the noise of war seemed to drown his voice he turned to God for consolation.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 25, 1940

title: Jane the Virgin Season 2, Episode 7: New Pants Wednesday
description: Ah, its that familiar new-mother television plot: Jane has to find a babysitter. Not just any babysitter, but the perfect babysitter. Thats hard enough, but Jane has an additional, unconventional worry because she has no idea what Sin Rostro currently looks like and could, unknowingly, hire this evil woman to take care of her baby. Jane the Virgin is dramatic but, fortunately, not that dramatic. (At least not yet; who knows when and how Sin Rostro will pop back up in Janes life?)

title: Broadways Tony Awards Move From Radio City to Beacon Theater for 2016
description: The Tony Awards, unable to use Radio City Music Hall because of a scheduling conflict with the Rockettes, will be delayed by a week next year and then broadcast from the smaller Beacon Theater on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

title: Adam Skelos Talks of Missed Opportunity in Phone Call
description: A recorded call was played for the jury between Adam Skelos, the son of State Senator Dean G. Skelos, and Demetrios Raptis, the head of an association of Greek restaurant owners. In the call, Mr. Skelos suggested that Mr. Raptis missed an opportunity to take advantage of his fathers influence.

title: Why Pfizers Deal May Change the System ofTaxing Multinationals
description: Pfizers proposed merger with Allergan is a blockbuster deal in the pharmaceutical industry. History may remember the deal instead for finally killing off the United States outdated approach to taxing multinational corporations.

title: Fear and the High Cost of Terror
description: Times Editorial Page editor Andrew Rosenthal reflects on the familiar debate between national security and personal liberty in the new age of terror.

title: Microsemi Wins PMC-Sierra With a $2.5 Billion Bid
description: It took a sweetened $2.5 billion cash-and-stock bid, representing more than a 77 percent premium, for the chip maker Microsemi Corporation to finally convince PMC-Sierra to be acquired.

title: Patriots and Panthers Are 10-0, but Similarities End There
description: By holding off the Buffalo Bills on Monday night, the defending champion New England Patriots improved to 10-0. Despite the battle over Tom Bradys deflation suspension and injuries to Julian Edelman, Dion Lewis and now Danny Amendola, it cannot be too shocking that a team with New Englands pedigree is unbeaten.

title: Fear and the High Cost of Terror
description: Andrew Rosenthal, the editor of The Timess editorial page, reflects on the familiar debate over national security and personal liberty in the new age of terror.

title: Iranian Hackers Attack State Dept. via Social Media Accounts
description: WASHINGTON  Four months after a historic accord with Tehran to limit its atomic ambitions, American officials and private security groups say they see a surge in sophisticated computer espionage by Iran, culminating in a series of cyberattacks against State Department officials over the past month.

title: An (Evolving) Travel Guide to Cuba
description: Learn everything you need to know about how to plan a trip to Cuba with coverage from the New York Times Travel section.

title: The Gossamer Pleasures of Faerie Magazine
description: On the strange appeal of a lifestyle quarterly for those with a thing for supernatural sprites.

title: Travel Alert or No, Many in U.S. Are Determined to Go Places for Thanksgiving
description: CHICAGO  The State Department has issued a chilling worldwide travel alert, warning travelers that the threat of terrorism looms large. Cable news and Twitter carry round-the-clock breaking news of bombings and attacks around the world. Police officers patrol major airports with bomb-sniffing dogs and carry intimidating weapons like shotguns and AR-15s.

title: Your Guide to Thanksgiving Travel
description: Tips for the biggest travel day of the year, including readying your car for the trip, navigating the airport and where to celebrate if youre leaving the United States.

title: The Live Blog: A Fast Way to Report Breaking News
description: When news started streaming out of Paris on Nov. 13, the International desk at The New York Times scrambled to figure out what was happening and how we were going to cover it. One of the first questions we had was: Should we start a live blog?

title: 1965: Sheikh Abdullah of Kuwait Dies
description: KUWAIT  Sheikh Abdullah al-Sabah, 73, ruler of this major oil-producing nation and one of the worlds richest men, died today [Nov. 24] of heart failure. The crown prince, Sheikh Sabah al-Salem al-Sabah, was proclaimed the new ruler. Sheikh Abdullah had ruled Kuwait since its independence from Britain in 1961, and had been emir of the oil sheikhdom since 1950. Under his rule, the sandy little country on the east coast of Arabia acquired one of the most advanced social welfare systems in the world, and became a democracy with an elected parliament. He founded Kuwaits first parliament and cabinet and enrolled the sheikhdom in the United Nations. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 25, 1965

title: Chicago Protests Mostly Peaceful After Video of Police Shooting Is Released
description: CHICAGO  Demonstrators took to the streets of this citys downtown in tense but largely peaceful protests after the release of video on Tuesday showing the fatal shooting of a black teenager by a white Chicago police officer.

title: Rigatoni Sets You Up for Thanksgiving
description: Its easy to feed family and friends gathered at your house on the days after Thanksgiving. But what about the days before? Thats when my teenage son, just home from school and with friends in tow, is hungriest for home cooking.

title: Fewer Golfers, but Some Lush Courses Are Coming Back
description: BOCA RATON, Fla.  Weeds, crabgrass and fallen palm fronds cover the wildly overgrown greens of what was once the Mizner Trail Golf Club, its decrepit state emblematic of the fate of hundreds of golf courses around the country, many of them derisively known as rabbit patches or goat farms.

title: Impossible Wardrobes
description: A new book chronicles three performance-art projects by Tilda Swinton and Olivier Saillard.

title: A Car Dealers Wont Sell: Its Electric
description: More than seven years ago, President Obama called for one million electric cars to be on the road by this year, and the vehicles have gained a large fan club. Environmentalists promote them as a smart way to cut dangerous emissions. Owners love their pep and the gas money they save. Apple and Google have jumped into the race to build next-generation battery-powered cars.

title: Sorting Out What Russia and Turkey Say Happened in the Sky
description: Comparing the conflicting versions of the events.

title: Brief Candle in the Dark, by Richard Dawkins
description: Some lumbering robot, this Richard Dawkins. Lumbering robots was one of the ways in which this scarily brilliant evolutionary biologist described human beings vis--vis their genes in The Selfish Gene, his first and probably still his most influential book  more than a million copies sold. (His atheist manifesto, The God Delusion, has sold more than three million.) Were essentially a means of physical and, more important, temporal transportation for our genes, he explained. They can live on for eons after we take our own inherited genes and mate with those of that handsome boy behind us in the movie-ticket line who ended up sitting next to us or the ones belonging to that pretty girl whose change we picked up by mistake at the newsstand and with whom we then had an apologetic coffee. And so on down the line. Our lines. Dawkins has also called us throwaway survival machines for our genes. But only, I think, to make a biological point.

title: Tilda Swinton, Olivier Saillard and the Art of Dressing
description: Over the last few years, Tilda Swinton has collaborated with the fashion curator Olivier Saillard on three rather unusual live performances, now documented in a catalog called Impossible Wardrobes. In one piece, Saillard and Swinton made a dress to measure, with Swinton as a dress form. For another, the actress painstakingly carried historically significant items of clothing, like Napoleons coat, down a runway. In many ways, she explains, the clothes operated as a bridge to the person no longer inside them  almost as if the garment is a symptom or a leaf shed from a tree. In the final work, Swinton assumed the role of coat-check attendant, leaving bits of personal ephemera, like a drop of perfume or a lipstick-smeared tissue, in visitors pockets. I still prize the old shoes and tiny cardigans of my now sky-scraping children, Swinton says. They link to the past like portals.

title: In Renovation of Golf Club, Donald Trump Also Dressed Up History
description: STERLING, Va.  When Donald J. Trump bought a fixer-upper golf club on Lowes Island here for $13 million in 2009, he poured millions more into reconfiguring its two courses. He angered conservationists by chopping down more than 400 trees to open up views of the Potomac River. And he shocked no one by renaming the club after himself.

title: Human Error Cited in U.S. Strike onKunduz Hospital
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The American airstrike that destroyed a Doctors Without Borders hospital in Kunduz last month was the result of human errors, failures in procedure and technical malfunctions, according to military officials briefed on the internal investigation.

title: Cuomo Reaches Deal to Keep Open Alcoa Plant in Upstate New York
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said on Tuesday that the state had come to an agreement to keep open an Alcoa plant on the St. Lawrence River after promising the company nearly $70 million in state subsidies.

title: N.H.L. This Week: A Friday Afternoon National Broadcast
description: Every Tuesday, The New York Times will look at the week ahead in the N.H.L., highlighting hot  or not so hot  teams and players.

title: Abid Naseer Receives 40-Year Sentence for Bomb Plot
description: A member of Al Qaeda who plotted, but did not carry out, a car bombing of a shopping center in Manchester, England, was sentenced on Tuesday to 40 years in prison.

title: Pfizers Desire to Split Has Faded
description: Pfizers huge deal for Allergan will lower the drugmakers taxes, add solid assets such as Botox and reduce leverage. But it has also created a material adverse event. Pfizer is delaying a decision on whether to split the company by two years.

title: YouTube Kids App Faces New Complaints Over Ads for Junk Food
description: WASHINGTON  Visit YouTube Kids and typically it will not be long before promotions for junk food appear. The advertisements regularly show up in the form of funny contests and animated stories.

title: Review: Christopher Hitchens Expounds in And Yet ...
description: Christopher Hitchens died of complications from esophageal cancer in 2011. Were he living, hed turn 67 in the spring.

title: Paging Dr. Pigeon; Youre Needed in Radiology
description: Dogs that detect cancer? Check. Fruit flies can do it? Check.

title: What Does Marco Rubio Actually Think About Syrian Refugees? [Updated]
description: One way of running a presidential campaign is to treat it like a continuous game of magnetic poetry  throwing words together at random without regard for their meaning. And no, Im not talking about Donald Trump or Ben Carson.

title: Lukewarm Drinks, Enthusiastic Reaction
description: The temperature of a drink is not an issue typically up for discussion at the bar. Cocktails are cold, preferably very cold, except in those special time-honored instances (toddies, Irish coffee, Tom & Jerry) when theyre hot. Whatever the temperature of the room may be, the cocktails are not that.

title: Donald Trumps Affinity for Ted Cruz May Soon Be Changing
description: Donald J. Trump has been unyielding when it comes to trying to pinpoint the weaknesses of his top rivals for the Republican presidential nomination and exploiting them to no end. Except when it comes to Senator Ted Cruz.

title: Blue Origin Launches Bezoss Space Dreams and Lands a Rocket
description: This time, Jeffrey P. Bezos rocket went up  and it came down in one piece.

title: What Is Your Dream Sports Gift?
description: Send us your sports-related dream gift  the one thing in the sports world that would make you happier than anything else  and well compile the best ones. Then, this weekend, you can read what other New York Times readers wished for.

title: A Mixed Week for Plays at Broadway Box Office
description: Unhappy critics dont always hurt. Ecstatic ones dont always help. That was the lesson last week for two plays new to Broadway, according to figures released on Monday by the Broadway League.

title: Rare Video of Russian Amur Tiger and Cubs Hints at Progress in Poaching Fight
description: The Wildlife Conservation Society is working on many fronts to conserve wildlife and critical habitat. In recent weeks, developments have been grim, particularly the murder of two forest guardians working with the group in Cambodia. That gives extra value to small signs of success, including fresh camera trap video from Russias far east showing a female Amur tiger and three grown cubs exploring an overgrown logging road.

title: Identities of Jurors in Trial Over Freddie Grays Death Will Be Shielded
description: BALTIMORE  Citing intense media scrutiny around the coming trial of the first of six police officers charged in the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who sustained a spinal injury after being arrested in April, a judge ruled Tuesday that jurors in the case will remain anonymous.

title: Dark Matter and the Dinosaurs, by Lisa Randall
description: A good theory is an act of the informed imagination  it reaches toward the unknown while grounded in the firmest foundations of the known. In Dark Matter and the Dinosaurs, the Harvard cosmologist Lisa Randall proposes that a thin disk of dark matter in the plane of the Milky Way triggered a minor perturbation in deep space that caused the major earthly catastrophe that decimated the dinosaurs. Its an original theory that builds on a century of groundbreaking discoveries to tell the story of how the universe as we know it came to exist, how dark matter illuminates its beguiling unknowns and how the physics of elementary particles, the physics of space, and the biology of life intertwine in ways both bewildering and profound.

title: Ian Kershaws To Hell and Back: Europe, 1914-1949
description: Ian Kershaws chilling epic-size history produces aftershocks connected to our current news headlines. Polish soldiers close border. ... Rise of Austrian right. ... Grim jobs report. ... Shocking British vote. ... Germans want sanctions against Russia. ... Europe migrant crisis boils over. ... They are all so reminiscent of the drum rolls that preceded Europes descent into the pit of barbarism during a century of two world wars that almost destroyed its civilization, followed by 40 years of Cold War. Seventy years after the democracies, together with the Red Army, triumphed in World War II, and 25 years after the reunification of Germany, the new Europe has made what Kershaw deems an astonishing recovery.

title: Artists II by Jason Schmidt
description: The photographer discusses his images of James Turrell, David Byrne and more.

title: Inside the Artists Studios
description: Do you remember studying Joseph Campbells The Power of Myth? asks the photographer Jason Schmidt. Ive always been drawn to artists; maybe it sounds corny, but theyre the mythmakers of our time. But, he continues to think out loud, theyre also people who decode human experiences and what it means to be human.

title: Podcast: Fear and the High Cost of Terror
description: Terror attacks in Paris, Beirut, Mali and elsewhere around the globe reignited a familiar debate over balancing national security with personal liberty. How much of the latter are we willing to give up to protect our safety?

title: Harlems Beauty Boom
description: In the last year, choices for skin care, laser hair removal and other cosmetic services have increased dramatically.

title: Tunisia Declares State of Emergency After Explosion on Bus
description: TUNIS  An explosion tore through a bus carrying members of the presidents security guard through the heart of Tunisias capital on Tuesday evening, killing at least 12 people and prompting the president to declare a 30-day state of emergency.

title: $100 Million in Grants Announced for Indiana Culture
description: Indianas cultural institutions just got $100 million richer, thanks to a series of grants that were announced on Tuesday morning by the Lilly Endowment.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Squash, Eggplant and Tomato Tian
description: If youre looking for a colorful dish to brighten your holiday table, try this simple and elegant Vegetable Tian.

title: Vegetarian Thanksgiving: Stuffed Portobello Mushrooms
description: Portobello mushrooms are a great option for a vegan or vegetarian main course because they are large enough to fill a plate and can be stuffed with a variety of flavors.

title: Danish Composer Wins $100,000 Prize
description: Hans Abrahamsen, a Danish composer, has been awarded the 2016 Grawemeyer Award for Music Composition, a prestigious international prize that comes with a $100,000 award.

title: Light May Work on Nonseasonal Depression, Study Finds
description: Bright light therapy has been used effectively for seasonal affective disorder, the kind of depression that comes on at a specific time every year, often the dark days of late fall and winter, and then lifts. Now a new study has found that it may work to treat nonseasonal depression as well.

title: Travel Deals: Food Tours of Eastern Europe
description: Intrepid Travel is expanding its food tour offerings into Eastern Europe in 2016 with its Real Food Adventures, introducing travelers to home-cooked meals, street food and local food markets in four countries. The first trip,  to Slovenia and Croatia, leaves May 29 (from $2,119) and the second, to Montenegro and Macedonia, on June 9 (from $1,647), destinations where slow food is a way of life. Both 10-day tours include culinary and cultural highlights.

title: Review: In Creed, Rockys Back, as a Mentor, Not a Fighter
description: At a recent screening of Creed, as the familiar fanfare of Bill Contis beloved Rocky score signaled the start of the final round of the big fight, the audience burst into spontaneous applause. This was no sneak-preview crowd, primed with free admission and popcorn, but a room full of critics and journalists armored in professional skepticism. A cynic might say that the cheering was a Pavlovian reflex set off by a piece of commercial entertainment in the hands of a skilled, manipulative director. This cynic, however, was too busy choking up and clapping to form the thought.

title: Two Hours Into Deliberations, a Juror in the Sheldon Silver Trial Wants Out
description: Not long after jurors convened on Tuesday to decide whether Assemblyman Sheldon Silver, once one of the most powerful politicians in New York State, was guilty of fraud, there were already unmistakable signs that their deliberations had taken a contentious turn.

title: Into Africa: New West Africa Bureau Chief Makes Herself at Home
description: CONAKRY, Guinea  Dionne Searcey chronicles her adventures in Senegal, where she works as The Timess West Africa bureau chief.

title: Jonathan Mayer, Well-Known Online Security Expert, Joins F.C.C.
description: Among privacy groups in the United States, Jonathan Mayer is known as a vocal advocate who has defended the right of consumers to turn off online tracking of their browsing activities.

title: Jessica Jones Episode 5: Ive Seen Heroes
description: Like Netflixs Daredevil before it, Jessica Jones sets itself apart from other Marvel movies and TV shows by offering a view at a psychologically complex character. Jessica goes down various roads you probably would never expect a superhero  specifically one who may very well bump into Captain America or Iron Man at some point  to go down. And the show has, by and large, done a better job than Daredevil of laying out the tortured, masochistic logic that compels its characters to agonize over roads they didnt take and commitments they cant keep. The same is true of AKA The Sandwich Saved Me, the shows fifth episode, and the one that best explains why Jones is one of the most nuanced contemporary superheroes.

title: Prescience About Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Vatican Trial Begins Over Leaked Documents
description: VATICAN CITY  Five people, including two Italian journalists, went on trial in a Vatican courtroom on Tuesday on charges of illegally procuring and circulating confidential documents that were used to write two tell-all books detailing suspected mismanagement and corruption at the Vatican.

title: Chris Christies Low Profile in Courage
description: Heres a bumper sticker  Chris Christie: Because Youre Scared.

title: New York Police Officers Fill Courtroom as Man Is Charged in Their Colleagues Death
description: Scores of police officers packed a Manhattan courtroom on Tuesday to watch as a convicted drug dealer was formally charged with murder in the shooting of a plainclothes officer last month.

title: Its Sort of Good to Be the King
description: Like a more elliptical version of The Little Prince, this book (which was originally published in Germany) assembles a series of very short tales about a king who has much to learn, mostly about power and its limits. His expectations  that others will obey him automatically, that the universe itself will acquiesce to his wishes  are thwarted again and again. Yet with each snub or disappointment, this king actually appears to be learning and gaining perspective, giving the book an unusually thoughtful, philosophical backbone.

title: Le Garage Adds a French Touch to Bushwick, Brooklyn
description: Le Garage Catherine Allswang, a native of Normandy, has owned and cooked in restaurants in San Francisco and Paris. Her daughter, Rachel, an interior designer who grew up at her mothers side in the kitchen, has teamed up with her to open a place in New York. They have turned a former garage in Bushwick, Brooklyn, into an intimate restaurant, largely French, where the temptations on a concise menu include steamed mussels, foie gras with winter radishes and beets, potatoes stuffed with snails, pork shoulder braised in milk, and chicken for two. Creative cocktails are named for Frenchwomen like Simone de Beauvoir, who is represented by an alluring mix of Byrrh aperitif, Dolin dry vermouth, orange bitters and tonic water. The dcor, by Rachel Allswang, combines hard-edged industrial and sleek Art Deco: 159B Central Avenue (Suydam Street), Brooklyn, 347-295-1700, legaragebrooklyn.com.

title: Brad Pitt, Ryan Gosling and Other Stars at The Big Short Premiere
description: The star-studded cast attended the movies opening at the Ziegfeld Theater in Midtown Manhattan.

title: Rocky and Creed: a Critical Comparison
description: A look at what Times critics had to say about the original Rocky (1976), and the new Creed, the latest entry in the franchise.

title: After Attacks, the Soul of Paris Endures
description: Seven essays by Americans  expats, travelers and writers  trying to take the long view of Paris and pick up the pieces after the Nov. 13 attacks.

title: Margaret Keane of Synchrony Financial: When Hardship Informs Leadership
description: This interview with Margaret Keane, C.E.O. of Synchrony Financial, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: E.U. Proposes a Common Deposit Insurance Program for Eurozone
description: BRUSSELS  The European Union authorities on Tuesday proposed a system to share the cost of protecting savers during banking crises.

title: HBO Sets Its Sesame Street Debut
description: Sesame Street will make its debut on HBO on Saturday, Jan. 16 at 9 a.m., the premium cable network announced on Tuesday.

title: Mayor de Blasio Seeks to Reduce, Not Ban, Carriage Horses in Central Park
description: Mayor Bill de Blasio is pursuing a new twist on his longtime effort to end the Central Park horse carriage industry: reducing, not eliminating, its hoof print.

title: Brad Pitt, Ryan Gosling and Other Stars at The Big Short Premiere
description: Brad Pitt stood on a red carpet Monday night getting angry. He wasnt addressing the paparazzi, who have been known to stalk his wife and children. Theyre in Cambodia, he said, explaining why he arrived solo.

title: Vintage Art Jackets With Cult Appeal
description: Earlier this year, an employee of Londons Institute of Contemporary Arts (ICA) went into the institutions basement and found quite a treasure: piles of jackets designed by the Pop artist Peter Blake in 1978. The color-blocked jackets, which read The ICA Likes Art, had been in storage for almost four decades  but were surprisingly intact. So, beginning next week, the museum will sell 70 of the original jackets for 70 (roughly $105)  just in time for its 70th anniversary in 2016.

title: Thomas Libous, Ex-New York State Senator, Gets Probation and Home Confinement in Corruption Case
description: WHITE PLAINS  Calling his conduct disgraceful, a judge on Tuesday sentenced Thomas W. Libous, once the second-highest ranking Republican in the New York Senate, to two years of probation, six months of home confinement and a $50,000 fine for lying to federal agents during a corruption investigation.

title: Adele on 25: Song by Song
description: Adeles 25 is easily shaping up to be the best-selling album of 2015: Billboard reports that Adele Adkinss third album has broken the record for single-week sales set by  N Syncs No Strings Attached in March 2000. With at least 2,433,000 copies of the album sold in just over three days, 25 is also set to more than double the first-week sales of some of the biggest albums of the past 15 years, including Taylor Swifts 1989, the Beatles 1 and Eminems The Eminem Show.

title: The Art of the Thanksgiving Table
description: HARTSVILLE, S.C.  Of the many places to learn the nuances of traditional Thanksgiving etiquette, none are quite like Wardie Sanderss high school classroom.

title: Handed Lifes Twists, Notre Dame Quarterback Turns It Around
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  Notre Dame quarterback DeShone Kizer is stuck in a moment of self-reflection, having scrambled around the jarring juxtaposition that separates his present from his not-so-distant past.

title: Review: Juilliard String Quartet Shows Agility at Alice Tully Hall
description: Bittersweetness tinged the Juilliard String Quartets first Lincoln Center performance this season, an exhilarating, penetrating, often splendidly harrowing concert on Monday at Alice Tully Hall. Joel Krosnick, the quartets cellist since 1974 and its longest-serving member by far, announced in May that he would leave the group at the end of this season. With no musician remaining on the roster who played with any of the Juilliards founding artists, a new era for a hallowed institution awaits.

title: Striving to Make Travel Truly Pet-Friendly
description: Melissa Halliburtons inspiration for creating a global resource for travelers with pets in tow came from personal experience. After graduating from college, she settled on a petite Jack Russell-Chihuahua mix called Rocco. But taking him on the road proved to be a challenge in the Boston metropolitan area where she lived. I called several hotels and even though signs said pet friendly much of the information was incorrect, she lamented.

title: Rise in Early Cervical Cancer Detection Is Linked to Affordable Care Act
description: WASHINGTON  Cancer researchers say there has been a substantial increase in women under the age of 26 who have received a diagnosis of early-stage cervical cancer, a pattern that they say is most likely an effect of the Affordable Care Act.

title: Hotels Offer Variations on an Afternoon Tea Theme
description: Hotel afternoon teas have often tended to be pomp-and-circumstance affairs with traditional menus consisting of scones, dainty sandwiches and bite-size pastries. Some properties today, though, are doing away with the predictability by offering creative interpretations of the classic pastime.

title: Review: Ballet Hispanicos If Walls Could Speak Offers Vignettes of Urban Life
description: A man returns to his apartment after a hard day. He slumps into a chair by a table and turns on a hanging lamp. After a while, the light flickers and the man looks startled. Was that a ghost he just saw? Or was it merely his reflection in the mirrored wall behind him?

title: Bad Loans Weigh on European Banks, Regulator Reports
description: LONDON  Bad loans continue to weigh on the bottom lines of European banks despite efforts by the regions lenders to raise more capital and improve their risk profiles since the financial crisis, according to regulators.

title: Pop Facebook Quiz: Should You Take It?
description: More than 17 million people have taken a delightful little quiz on Facebook that displays their most-often used words in a sweet word cloud.

title: The Humans Sets Broadway Opening Date
description: For the family gathering for dinner in Stephen Karams play The Humans, Thanksgiving is fraught with secrets, sadness and tension. For the writer and creative team, however, the holiday brings good news: The drama, now playing Off Broadway in a Roundabout Theater Company production, will move to Broadway in January.

title: Ben Carsons Book Tour Draws Campaign Finance Complaint
description: On a 26-day book tour last month, Ben Carson held a news conference in a Books-a-Million store in Iowa, appeared often on TV to discuss his candidacy and sandwiched campaign rallies between book signings.

title: Afghan Soldiers and Foreigners Captured After Landing in Taliban-Held Area
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban captured at least 13 Afghan soldiers and two foreigners after their aircraft made an emergency landing in the northern Afghan province of Faryab on Tuesday, officials said.

title: The Artistry of Stephen Curry
description: Taras Domitro was not a basketball fan when he joined the San Francisco Ballet as a principal dancer in 2008.

title: Coverage of Paris Terror Attacks Lifts Network News Ratings
description: The three network evening newscasts had their biggest viewership in at least eight months with their coverage last week of the Paris terrorist attacks.

title: Chris Christie Defends Stance on Dangers of Accepting Refugees
description: Under fire for being heartless when it comes to refugees, Gov. Chris Christie on Tuesday defended his view that it was too dangerous to take in persecuted Syrians and warned that America could pay a deadly price for being politically correct about the matter.

title: Final Earnings at the Old Hewlett-Packard Fall Short of Wall St. Expectations
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Hewlett-Packard ended its life as one public company with a whimper.

title: Political Intelligence Firm to Pay S.E.C. Penalty
description: A firm that gathered intelligence inside the Washington Beltway for the benefit of its hedge fund customers agreed to pay a $375,000 penalty to the Securities and Exchange Commission over compliance failures.

title: Ways to Celebrate Thanksgiving, Old and New
description: Many families have their own traditions for Thanksgiving, whether it is an intergenerational breakfast, a game of flag football in the neighbors backyard, or something that takes people farther outside their homes, like a parade or a special volunteer activity. There are also a number of newer and nontraditional events in many American cities.

title: Kentucky Governor Restores Voting Rights to Thousands of Felons
description: Weeks before he leaves office, the governor of Kentucky on Tuesday issued an executive order that immediately granted the right to vote to about 140,000 nonviolent felons who have completed their sentences.

title: Anger at Turkeys Stab in the Back Fills Russian Social Networks and Airwaves
description: Within a few minutes after President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia called the Turkish downing of one of his nations warplanes on Tuesday a stab in the back, the phrase had been transformed into a hashtag on social networks by enraged Russian bloggers.

title: No Bail for Chicago Officer Jason Van Dyke
description: A court document describes the shooting of Laquan McDonald and recommends that Officer Van Dyke, charged in his death, is held without bail.

title: Review: Gabriel Miss and Guillermina Quiroga, Together for the First Time
description: Tango people keep late hours; Ive been at gatherings where the best dancers arrive at midnight. For this reason, my tango-watching is limited; I seldom have the stamina. On Saturday, however, I was ready at 11 p.m. at the Clemente Soto Vlez Cultural and Educational Center in SoHo to watch an event in tango history: Gabriel Miss performing with Guillermina Quiroga for the first time. Excitement among the audience in the packed ground-floor room was intense. The stars did not disappoint; people were calling for more.

title: Joe Biden Skips Thanksgiving in Nantucket; Meets With Martin OMalley
description: For the last four decades, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. has made a tradition of spending Thanksgiving with his family in Nantucket, Mass.

title: Review: Franco Zeffirelli's 'La Bohme' Revisits a Take on Love and Loss
description: The Metropolitan Opera revived Franco Zeffirellis 34-year-old production of La Bohme on Monday. Well, revived may be too strong a word. It implies a quality of animated freshness that didnt much characterize this tired performance.

title: Fantasy Sports Site Closes Digital Loophole Ahead of Hearing
description: One of the largest fantasy sports companies appears to have closed an easily accessible loophole that had been available for users to make bets from states where daily fantasy sports is illegal.

title: Advice to Retire By
description: I have been writing for a while about the mismatch between the unbiased investing advice that people need and the self-interested recommendations they often get from advisers, a.k.a. salespeople, at banks, brokerages and other financial firms.

title: Review: Rockettes in Radio City Christmas Spectacular
description: Legs. Stretched out bare on a beach, they unmistakably signal summer. But encased in velvet or sequins, prancing by the dozens across a celebrated New York stage and rising into the air like Roman candles, they can mean only one thing: Winter is almost here.

title: Thanksgiving TV Fare: Wild Animals, a Tame Train and a Tribute
description: One channel hopes your most fervent Thanksgiving wish is to be bored to death. Another is convinced theres nothing people want more than to rewatch movies theyve already seen a zillion times.

title: Pfizer and Allergan Deal Comes With an Extensive Prenup
description: Pfizer and Allergan thought up several situations where their blockbuster $152 billion merger agreement could meet resistance, including from shareholders, regulators and lawmakers, and even rival suitors.

title: Pictures of the Day: Macedonia and Elsewhere
description: Macedonia and More  Pictures of the Day

title: Nov. 24, 2015  Pictures of the Day
description: Photos from Macedonia, Israel, the West Bank and the United States.

title: Review: Victor Frankenstein Recasts a Tale That Keeps On Giving
description: You cannot keep a good monster down, especially when theres franchise money to be made. This doubtless explains Victor Frankenstein, a pop romp that exhumes Mary Shelleys famous monster-maker for a jaunty bromance with his bestie, Igor. Its a hyperventilated resurrection that owes less to Shelley (or most Frankenstein flicks) than to Guy Ritchies Sherlock Holmes diversions, which turned Holmes (Robert Downey Jr.) and Dr. Watson (Jude Law) into 19th-century action heroes complete with cheerfully deployed violence and self-regarding smiles.

title: Review: In The Good Dinosaur, a Reptile Tends to His Human Pet
description: Blink and you may miss the sly joke that sets The Good Dinosaur on its enchantingly eccentric way. It begins with a near apocalypse 65 million years ago and an asteroid racing toward Earth. And while thats around the time, more or less, that science hypothesizes the dinosaurs bit the dust, the wizards at Pixar have forged another creation story. Instead of crashing, the space rock zips past the big blue marble. Fast forward a few million years to what looks like the American Northwest, where two apatosaurs are farming the land, tilling the soil with honest sweat and giant noses.

title: The Video of Celebrations That Was Broadcast on 9/11
description: The exact origin of Donald J. Trumps insistence that he saw live television images on Sept. 11, 2001, of thousands and thousands of Arabs in New Jersey cheering as the World Trade Center came tumbling down remains a mystery.

title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing: Russia,Franois Hollande, Chicago
description: (Want to get this briefing by email? Heres the sign-up.)

title: A Definitive Debunking of Donald Trumps 9/11 Claims
description: How alarmed were New Jersey officials by reports of Muslims dancing in the streets of Jersey City and Paterson on Sept. 11, 2001, to celebrate the destruction of the World Trade Center?

title: Estate Sues Nahmad Gallery Network for Modigliani Portrait
description: In a fresh legal complaint filed on Tuesday, the estate of a Paris art dealer is seeking the return of a precious Modigliani portrait said to have been seized by the Nazis and now, the court papers contend, in the possession of the Nahmad family, a dynasty of art dealers that wields enormous power in the international art market.

title: Your Evening Briefing
description: Heres what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: White Student Union Groups Set Off Concerns at Campuses
description: The emergence of White Student Union Facebook groups claiming links to more than 30 universities has caused alarm among students and education officials, although the authenticity of many of the pages is being questioned.

title: A Toast to Back Then
description: A benefit for the Bowery Mission reunites clubgoers who remember when this TriBeCa nightspot was the gritty, downtown alternative to Studio 54.

title: Dream of New Kind of Credit Union Is Extinguished by Bureaucracy
description: Brewster Kahle didnt need to start a bank.

title: Healthy Newborn Found Abandoned in Nativity Scene at a Queens Church
description: For a few moments, the sight could have been confused for a miraculous arrival ahead of the Christmas season: A newborn baby, hours old and full term, appeared within a nativity scene at a Queens church on Monday.

description: Objects, artifacts and treasures worthy of becoming icons of 21st-century design.

description: Munem Wasifs deeply personal exhibit on Islam in Bangladesh took on added, urgent meaning a few days after it opened in Paris.

title: Two Paris Attackers Planned Another Assault, Prosecutor Says
description: PARIS  Two men who took part in the Paris terrorist attacks, and who died in a police raid days later, appear to have been planning a final assault, aimed at La Dfense, the business district west of Paris, the prosecutor investigating the attacks said on Tuesday.

description: Get recommendations from New York Times reporters and editors, highlighting great stories from around the web. What Were Reading emails are sent twice a week. Sign up

description: Exquisite, rare objects that honor the gift of giving.

title: Cokes Chief Scientist, Who Orchestrated Obesity Research, Is Leaving
description: Coca-Colas top scientist is stepping down after revelations that the beverage giant initiated a strategy of funding scientific research that played down the role of Coke products in the spread of obesity.

title: Ts 2015 Holiday Gift Guide
description: Luxurious, refined classics to be treasured forever (and yeah, some under $100).

title: Manhattan Dentists Lawyer Suggests Client Was High When He Spoke With Informer
description: The lawyer for Dr. John Wolf, the Manhattan  dentist who was accused last week of trading dental work for methamphetamines and possessing and distributing child pornography, provided a preliminary outline on Tuesday of his clients planned defense.

title: Alphabet Trying to Mix Heft With Start-Up Agility
description: The enduring struggle of life is figuring out how to maximize all the good parts and minimize all the bad. So it is with Alphabet, the technology giant formerly known as Google.

title: Peace Deal Comes With Hummus at Israeli Restaurant
description: KFAR VITKIN, Israel  The unassuming proprietor of an unassuming hummus place in this little village near the Mediterranean Sea has a dream: that one day, he will run a chain of restaurants across Israel where the sons of Isaac and the sons of Ishmael will be able to sit together at the table and share hummus. At a steep discount.

title: Douglass C. North, Maverick Economist and Nobel Laureate, Dies at 95
description: Douglass C. North, a Nobel laureate whose work in applying economic theory to history offered a new understanding of how societies coordinate peoples behavior, died on Monday at his home in Benzonia, Mich. He was 95.

title: A Conversation With Barry Rice
description: Mr. Rice, 60, is the founder of Barry Rice Architects, based in New York. Before starting the firm in 2000, Mr. Rice spent 13 years at Robert A.M. Stern Architects, and while there designed, among other things, the feature animation building for the Walt Disney Company in Burbank, Calif.

title: Rex Reason, Star of Sci-Fi Classic This Island Earth, Dies at 86
description: Rex Reason, a dashing movie star who played opposite Rita Hayworth and Clark Gable and starred in science fiction movies and two television series, died on Thursday at his home in Walnut, Calif., in Los Angeles County. He was 86.

title: Pfizer-Allergan Merger Is Latest Sign of Deal Makers Silly Pills
description: Even in these grim times, deal makers have descended into silliness.

title: Arctic Nations Seek to Prevent Exploitation of Fisheries in Opening Northern Waters
description: Ruth Teichroeb, the communications officer for Oceans North: Protecting Life in the Arctic, an initiative of the Pew Charitable Trusts, sent a note this evening about new steps related to an issue Ive covered here before  the rare and welcome proactive work by Arctic nations to ban fishing in the central Arctic Ocean ahead of the big melt as summer sea ice retreats more in summers in a human-heated climate.

title: Turing Refuses to Lower List Price of Toxoplasmosis Drug
description: Turing Pharmaceuticals, which sparked a fury two months ago by sharply increasing the price of a 62-year-old drug, said on Tuesday that it would not reduce the list price of that drug after all.

title: Calpers Paid $3.4 Billion to Private Equity Firms
description: For years, state pension funds have invested money earned by teachers, firefighters and other government employees with private equity firms without  having a full picture of how much they were earning and what they were paying in expenses.

title: Terrorism Response Puts Belgium in a Harsh Light
description: BRUSSELS  A month before the Paris terrorist attacks, Mayor Franoise Schepmans of Molenbeek, a Brussels district long notorious as a haven for jihadists, received a list with the names and addresses of more than 80 people suspected as Islamic militants living in her area.

title: Chicago Officials Response to Video
description: Officials in Chicago, addressing a dashboard camera video that shows the police shooting 17-year-old Laquan McDonald last year, called for calm and a peaceful public response. The officer was charged with murder Tuesday.

title: Medal of Freedom Awarded to a Class Act Group of 17
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama awarded the Presidential Medal of Freedom on Tuesday to an eclectic mix of Americans from the sciences, arts, sports, politics and human rights, some of them household names and others who he indicated should be.

title: Rare White House Accord With Koch Brothers on Sentencing Frays
description: WASHINGTON  For more than a year, a rare coalition of liberal groups and libertarian-minded conservatives has joined the Obama administration in pushing for the most significant liberalization of Americas criminal justice laws since the beginning of the drug war. That effort has had perhaps no ally more important than Koch Industries, the conglomerate owned by a pair of brothers who are well-known conservative billionaires.

title: U.A.W. Contracts Change Math for Detroit Automakers
description: DETROIT  When union contracts were finally ratified at Ford Motor and General Motors last week, a new era began in the American auto industry.

title: Office of Special Counsel Report to the President
description: The Office of Special Counsel released this report on its investigation into United States Commission for the Preservation of Americas Heritage Abroad and Jeffrey Farrow, a contract employee who had served as its executive director, while also working as a lobbyist.

title: U.S. Inquiry Finds Agency Chief Violated Rules
description: WASHINGTON  An obscure federal agency that employed a registered federal lobbyist as its executive director, and paid him a salary of more than $100,000 for his part-time work, violated federal contracting rules, according to a report sent to President Obama on Tuesday from the governments special ethics office.

title: Charles M. Cawley, Credit Card Pioneer, Dies at 75
description: Charles M. Cawley, who founded MBNA Corporation in a supermarket basement, transformed the company into the worlds largest independent credit card issuer, and sold it two decades later to Bank of America for nearly $35 billion, died on Nov. 18 at his home in Camden, Me. He was 75.

title: Frances Ambassador Knows How to Throw an Elbow
description: WASHINGTON  In the hours after the terrorist attacks in Paris left 130 dead, Grard Araud, the French ambassador to the United States, thanked all Americans for their solidarity except for one: Donald Trump, the Republican presidential candidate who pointedly said that the mass shootings had occurred in one of the toughest gun control countries in the world.

title: An Impasse Over Migration Strands Cubans in Costa Rica
description: MEXICO CITY  Cuban and Central American officials met in El Salvador on Tuesday but could not agree on how to resolve a standoff over migration policy that has marooned hundreds of Cuban migrants in Costa Rica and tested regional relations.

title: Montreals Message to an American Captain: Bienvenue
description: Montreals significant French influence spills over to its beloved Canadiens. Francophone coaches are considered essential, as the teams bench bosses give interviews in French and English before and after each game.

title: Jim Perry, 82, Bustling Host of a Range of Game Shows, Dies
description: Jim Perry, the genial host of the popular NBC game shows Card Sharks and $ale of the Century in the 1970s and 80s, died on Friday at his home in Ashland, Ore. He was 82.

title: A Single Mothers Busy School Days (and Nights)
description: The alarm on her phone goes off at 5:30 a.m. Natasha Jackson reaches for her glasses. It is Monday morning, and she will be racing the clock a dozen more times before the day is over.

title: West Virginia: Mistrial Request Refused in Mine Case
description: A federal judge on Tuesday refused to declare a mistrial in the case of Donald L. Blankenship, who was the chief executive of Massey Energy Company when 29 workers were killed in a company mine in 2010. Mr. Blankenships lawyer asked for the mistrial ruling after jurors finished their fifth full day of deliberations. But Judge Irene C. Berger of Federal District Court in Charleston said that she did not have any reason to believe that they are deadlocked and that extensive deliberations were not surprising after weeks of testimony. Mr. Blankenship is accused of securities fraud and of conspiring to violate mine safety regulations. Deliberations will resume on Monday.

title: Big Feller
description: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE  In most crossword puzzles, solvers are given a clue and are expected to open their minds to the possibility that there are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, than are dreamt of in your philosophy. Or at least to guess what kind of pun the constructor is making. Today, were doing the opposite.

title: Canada: Graft Pervaded Awarding of Contracts in Quebec, Panel Says
description: A culture of impunity surrounded the awarding of government contracts in Quebec, Justice France Charbonneau of the Quebec Superior Court said Tuesday in a statement before issuing a sweeping report on the ties among contractors, politicians, party fund-raisers, bureaucrats and members of organized crime. Testimony at public hearings held by a commission led by Justice Charbonneau captivated the province and led to several resignations, including that in 2012 of Grald Tremblay, a Montreal mayor who the commission found did not adequately fulfill his role of control and monitoring his administration. Justice Charbonneau said the commission confirmed there was a real problem in Quebec and that it was broader and more deeply rooted than we believed. Its report, which is about 1,700 pages long, makes 60 recommendations, including term limits for mayors and the adoption of anticorruption legislation based on an American law, the False Claims Act.

title: For Readers of The Times, a Preference for Keeping Liberties in Days of Terror
description: As France reacts to the recent terrorist attacks in Paris with a show of force  the police have been breaking down doors to raid homes, conducting searches without warrants and hauling suspects to police stations  the debate over how societies should balance civil liberties and national security takes on even greater relevance.

title: Who Are the Turkmens of Syria?
description: Turkmens or Turkomans are a Turkic people who live in significant numbers in many countries in Central Asia and the Middle East, including Afghanistan, Iran and Iraq, and are the dominant group in Turkmenistan. They have a culture and language related to Turkish; their name is said to derive from words meaning Turk-like.

title: Raise for Skeloss Son Was Tied to Contract, C.E.O. Says
description: When the email came from a top executive at Glenwood Management, the recipient, Glenn R. Rink, quickly distilled its significance.

title: Snapped Water Pipe in Hoboken Upsets Citys Daily Routine
description: One man tried to pedal his bicycle through a gushing flood of water in Hoboken, N.J., on Tuesday morning, only to fall into a sinkhole.

title: Scream Queens Season 1, Episode 10: Giving Thanks
description: It was a pretty tepid Scream Queens until the cover came off that turkey tray. Gigi, you dont look so good.

title: U.S. Military Deaths in Operations Against ISIS
description: The Department of Defense has identified 9 American service members who have died supporting the operation to eliminate the Islamic State militant group. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Canada: Syrians Arrival Is Delayed, and Officials Cite Need to Prepare
description: Canadas new Liberal government has delayed its plan to bring 25,000 Syrian refugees into the country by the end of the year. At a news conferenceon Tuesday, several cabinet ministers said that only 10,000 would arrive by the original deadline, with the balance coming by the end of February. We want to bring them in fast, but we also want to do it right, said John McCallum, the immigration minister. Mr. McCallum said the delay was not caused by security concerns after the recent attacks in Paris. Rather, he said, it related to preparing housing and services for the refugees, who will become permanent residents upon entry. Government officials said the selection process would favor families, women who are at risk and gay, lesbian bisexual and transgender people. Single men will be admitted only if they fall under the sexual orientation categories or if they travel with their parents. About 36 cities have agreed to accept Syrian refugees who are to be flown to Canada by the military, which will also provide temporary accommodations for about 6,000 people at some of its bases.

title: Freshman Standout Propels Marquette to a Title
description: In recent years, most of the nations top college basketball coaches traveled to tiny Rice Lake, Wis., trying to persuade Henry Ellenson to join their programs. Kentuckys John Calipari, Dukes Mike Krzyzewski, North Carolinas Roy Williams and Michigan States Tom Izzo were among those who showed up in the town of 8,000 to woo the 6-foot-10 Ellenson, a forward with guard skills.

title: The Case Against Woodrow Wilson at Princeton
description: Student protesters at Princeton performed a valuable public service last week when they demanded that the administration acknowledge the toxic legacy of Woodrow Wilson, who served as university president and New Jersey governor before being elected to the White House. He was an unapologetic racist whose administration rolled back the gains that African-Americans achieved just after the Civil War, purged black workers from influential jobs and transformed the government into an instrument of white supremacy.

title: Woodrow Wilson Cost My Grandfather Too
description: Gordon J. Daviss Nov. 24th Op-Ed, What Woodrow Wilson Cost My Grandfather, recounted the story of his grandfather, John Abraham Davis, an African-American man whose prestigious career in the Government Printing Office was destroyed after President Wilson segregated the government in 1913. In recent weeks, students at Princeton  where Woodrow Wilson also served as president  have demanded that his name be removed from university facilities. Below are some highlights from the hundreds of reader comments on the article.

title: Takata Said to Have Manipulated Testing Data for Troubled Airbag Inflaters
description: As early as 2000, the Japanese auto supplier Takata manipulated test results on airbag inflaters, according to a person with direct knowledge of internal company documents.

title: Q. and A.: Christina Lin on Chinas Antiterrorism Efforts
description: Chinese leaders have long been wary of joining global efforts against terrorism, worried about becoming entangled in foreign conflicts. But in recent days, after a series of terrorist attacks that killed several Chinese citizens, China has faced pressure to play a more active role.

title: Islam, Beyond the Stereotypes
description: When Munem Wasif was offered a gallery exhibit to coincide with Paris Photo earlier this month, he chose to show In God We Trust, his personal project on Islam in Bangladesh and his familys relationship to it. Although he was uncertain how people would respond to the exhibit, he felt that after the Charlie Hebdo attacks in January in Paris that it was important to encourage people to think about Muslims in ways that did not play into stereotypes.

title: The Struggle for Justice on Tribal Lands
description: THE Thanksgiving we now celebrate began in partnership. Long after Pilgrim and Wampanoag families first shared their respective harvests, Native American communities continue to work, formally and informally, with many of their neighbors.

title: Letter From Saudi Arabia
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Saudi Arabia is a country that is easier to write about from afar, where you can just tee off on the place as a source of the most austere, antipluralistic version of Islam  the most extreme versions of which have been embraced by the Islamic State, or ISIS. What messes me up is when I go there and meet people I really like and I see intriguing countertrends.
