description: A suspicious package found near the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan on Wednesday evening briefly disrupted travel ahead of Thanksgiving Day, according to the police.

title: Russia and Ukraine in a Standoff Over Crimea Power Outage
description: CHONGAR, Ukraine  Ground zero of the latest confrontation between Ukraine and Russia was a sea of mud and not much else on Wednesday.

title: Highly Unlikely
description: When something extraordinary happens, we often say its stranger than fiction. But reality routinely, every minute of every day, outdoes all realist fiction in its strangeness. Recently two women working on the same floor of a Florida hospital discovered they were sisters (they had been adopted by different families in the 1970s). We read this item in the newspaper and accept it as astonishing, but real. The same occurrence in a realist novel, though, would be called unlikely or unbelievable. Weve arrived at a point where not only is reality stranger than fiction, but we dont allow our fiction to be even close to how strange real life is every day.

title: Freeing Thanksgiving From My Family
description: IT was a few hours before dawn, and the cartoon characters were in sad shape. There they lay, half inflated in the streets encircling New York Citys Museum of Natural History: Snoopy and Hello Kitty and Kermit the Frog and Superman. They were tethered to the ground with giant nets, like something out of Gullivers Travels.

title: Pfizers Plan to Leave U.S. Unsettles Drug Lobbyists
description: WASHINGTON  Pharmaceutical giant Pfizer has long been the most politically active drug maker in Washington, and its representatives have tended to wrap themselves in the American flag while pressing their concerns with lawmakers and regulators.

title: Despite Global Events, U.S. Gasoline Prices Remain Low
description: HOUSTON  American travelers are being treated to bargains at the gasoline pump this Thanksgiving weekend. Prices are at their lowest level for the holiday since the financial crisis of 2008 despite heightened tensions in the Middle East and a spate of terrorist attacks that would normally lead to higher prices.

title: After Paris Attacks, Ties That Bind Patrons at a Cafe Also Burn
description: PARIS  La Belle quipe, where 19 people died during this months terrorist attacks, means the beautiful team, and those who frequented the corner bistro in the bourgeois bohemian 11th Arrondissement say the name is all too fitting.

title: Decorating Homes With Pilgrims and Turkeys Before Elves and Reindeer
description: I went to Long Island to get a turkey, Nunzio Gambino said. It was $40.

title: Pillow Fights at West Point Are Banned After Injuries
description: The superintendent of the United States Military Academy disclosed Wednesday that he would ban pillow fights like the one on Aug. 20 that left two dozen freshmen cadets with concussions and six with other injuries.

title: Paperback Row
description: PENELOPE FITZGERALD: A Life, by Hermione Lee. (Vintage, $17.95.) Elusive and eccentric, Fitzgerald (1916-2000) published her first book, a biography, when she was 58 and went on to win the Man Booker Prize with her third novel a few years later. Lee, a veteran biographer of literary figures (including Edith Wharton and Virginia Woolf), approaches her subject with surgical precision in this volume, one of the Book Reviews 10 Best of 2014.

title: F.S.U. Reported Few Rape Cases to the U.S.
description: In court papers that Florida State University fought to keep confidential, the former director of the schools Victim Advocate Office testified that in 2014, a total of 113 students reported being sexually battered, which is the same as rape in Florida. But the college reported only 14 cases to the federal government, records show.

title: Editors Choice
description: SPQR: A History of Ancient Rome, by Mary Beard. (Liveright, $35.) Like New Yorkers, Romans were aggressive and acquisitive and came from somewhere else; Beards wonderfully concise history unpacks the secrets of the citys success.

title: Treating Mental Illness in New York, From All Angles
description: As too many people know only too well, mental health is a world of unmet needs and untold suffering. Societys ability to identify and treat emotional ailments and addiction is painfully inadequate. Families, left to themselves, struggle and fail. They often lack the resources to confront problems or dont try: two things in plentiful supply are ignorance and denial.

title: Mother Who Left Baby at Queens Church Is Found; No Charges Will Be Filed
description: The mother of a baby who was left this week in an unadorned crche inside a Roman Catholic church in Queens was found and will not face criminal prosecution, the county district attorney said late Wednesday.

title: Black Leaders in Chicago Push for Investigation of Police Department
description: CHICAGO  A day after city officials released graphic video of a white police officer shooting a black teenager 16 times, some of the citys most prominent black leaders called on Wednesday for investigations into the Chicago Police Department and its handling of the shooting. They expressed anger and dismay toward the departments leadership, and some demanded the resignation of the police superintendent.

title: Verizon Commercial Suggests a Thanksgiving Without Phones
description: Imagine Thanksgiving without Instagram.

title: Mack McCormick, Student of Texas Blues, Dies at 85
description: Mack McCormick, a folklorist who spent a lifetime searching out forgotten or unrecorded blues singers all over Texas, helped revive the career of Lightning Hopkins and unearthed a trove of historical material on hundreds of blues singers, including Blind Lemon Jefferson and Lead Belly, died on Nov. 18 at his home in Houston. He was 85.

title: David Canary, Star of All My Children, Dies at 77
description: David Canary, who played the Chandler twins  evil Adam and guileless Stuart  on the soap opera All My Children for nearly 30 years, died on Nov. 16 in Wilton, Conn. He was 77.

title: Court in China Reduces Prison Sentence for Gao Yu, Prominent Journalist
description: BEIJING  A court in Beijing on Thursday reduced the prison sentence being served by a well-known journalist, Gao Yu, who had been convicted of leaking a Communist Party document that laid out plans for a campaign against Western liberal ideas, according to her lawyers.

title: Detective Shoots Unarmed Man During Raid in Brooklyn
description: A detective with an elite unit of the New York Police Department shot and wounded an unarmed 32-year-old man in his Brooklyn apartment on Wednesday as a team of officers tried to execute a search warrant for a gun, the police said.

title: N.C.A.A. Clears Players, Then Absolves Itself
description: So this is how the N.C.A.A. saves face.

title: Tall Lineup Frustrates Porzingis and Knicks
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Scott Skiles, the Magics coach, sought to improve his teams balance by shuffling his starting lineup for Wednesdays game against the Knicks. With the Magic coming off two straight losses, Skiles moved Victor Oladipo to the bench and replaced him with Channing Frye. It was not an easy decision for Skiles.

title: You Might Be Indignant
description: THURSDAY PUZZLE  Puzzle solvers are known for being especially fussy about things like spelling errors. Are you the type of person who notices a typo wherever they appear? Lets see how good you really are.

title: Charitys Onetime Leader Begins a Work-Release Program
description: A former Jewish community leader serving up to 10 years in prison for his role in stealing more than $9 million from the charity he ran has been moved to a work-release program in Manhattan less than two years into his sentence, New York State corrections officials said on Wednesday.

title: 4 Arrested in Shooting at Black Lives Matter Protest Are Identified
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The police on Wednesday released the names of four men arrested in connection with a shooting during a Black Lives Matter protest outside a police station that injured five protesters.

title: Muslim Refugee and His Family Find a Haven in Harlem
description: The second time men went to Drissa Cisses home to look for him, he knew it was time to run.

title: Rye Brownies
description: Melissa Clark makes rye brownies adapted from Claire Ptak's "The Violet Bakery Cookbook."

title: In Big Game, Rangers Slip on Home Ice
description: The highly anticipated battle between the top two teams in the Eastern Conference proved to be no battle at all Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: Another Loss Gives 76ers Share of a Dubious Mark
description: BOSTON  He is the most visible manifestation of the latest, and to date, most futile version of The Philadelphia Story. Coach Brett Brown, by virtue of his job description, is the frontman for the continuing disaster that is the Philadelphia 76ers.

title: Voices From the Chicago Protests
description: Demonstrators continue to take the streets of Chicago after dashboard-camera video of the shooting of the teenager Laquan McDonald was released.

title: What to Watch Thursday
description: Dont let the parade pass you by! Macys kicks off its 89th extravaganza. Also on your Thanksgiving platter: serenades by Billy Joel and Arlo Guthrie, a train ride to nowhere, and Stellan Skarsgard as a cop who sees dead people.

title: South Korea Fines Volkswagen and Orders Recall Over Emissions Scandal
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea on Thursday ordered Volkswagen to recall more than 125,000 cars here, saying a government investigation had found that the German carmaker had illegally manipulated an emissions device in cars with older diesel engines.

title: Corrections: November 26, 2015
description: FRONT PAGE

title: North and South Korea to Hold High-Level Talks Next Month
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North and South Korea have agreed to resume high-level talks next month to discuss easing tensions and improving relations on the divided Korean Peninsula, South Korean officials said Friday.

title: Happy Thanksgiving
description: Were taking a brief break for the holiday, but well return on Nov. 30 with our usual Monday offerings including Whats Going On in This Picture?, our daily Student Opinion question, News Qs and more.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: When I would tell people about the renovation, without exception, the first thing theyd say was, Please tell me youre keeping the wooden escalators.

title: Is a Tougher Medical Standard for Pilots Necessary?
description: To the Editor:

title: Marco Rubios Bankrollers
description: To the Editor:

title: Water Main Break in Hoboken, N.J.
description: To the Editor:

title: Be Thankful for Family  or Not
description: Highlights from the Opinion archives about bonding, squabbling, food and gratitude during the holidays.

title: Rejected Thanksgiving Balloons
description: Not every float can fly.

title: Sex After 50 at the Supreme Court
description: Fifty years after the Supreme Court, in Griswold v. Connecticut, granted married couples the constitutional right to use birth control, here we are back at the court, still wrestling with contraception. Am I the only one who finds this remarkable?

title: King Kevin Versus Queen Cersei
description: THE intense interest in the thrill-a-minute, through-the-looking-glass 2016 race, fueled by anger at maladjusted Washington and anxiety after the Paris attacks, has spawned predictions that Thanksgiving political debates will be noisier and nastier than ever. Plenty of turkeys with a bone to pick and plenty of dressing down to go with the dressing. The Democratic National Committee actually issued talking points for the lively conversations with Republican uncles, aunts and brothers. Clearly, the people at the D.N.C. dont have any Republican relatives. Its never a parley. Its a lecture. So I decided to let my Republican brother offer his red-state soliloquy now, hoping hed let me eat my white meat in peace. He-e-e-eres Kevin:

title: Altruism on the A Train
description: To the Editor:

title: Collaboration With ISIS, Then Escape
description: To the Editor:

title: Bernie Sanders Gets Immigration Policy Right
description: Senator Bernie Sanders released his immigration plan on Tuesday. To read it  and every citizen should  is to be yanked back in time, to an America that not so long ago was having a reasonable immigration discussion and a time when major reform had strong bipartisan support and a shot at becoming law.

title: What It Will Take to Fight the Next Epidemic
description: A new study of the Ebola epidemic that took more than 11,000 lives focuses much of its criticism on the World Health Organization for delays and mismanagement that compounded rather than curtailed the global threat.

title: Donald Trump, Meet a Syrian Refugee Named Heba
description: LESBOS, Greece  Ben Carson has compared Syrian refugees to rabid dogs. Donald Trump says that he would send them back.

title: From Indonesia, a Muslim Challenge to the Ideology of the Islamic State
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  The scene is horrifyingly familiar. Islamic State soldiers march a line of prisoners to a riverbank, shoot them one by one and dump their bodies over a blood-soaked dock into the water.

title: Climate Research at the End of the World
description: Scientists mine Greenlands icy environment for data to understand how climate change will alter the rest of the globe.

title: Venue for Conventions and Dog Shows Has a New Attraction: The Davis Cup
description: GHENT, Belgium  In many ways, the Flanders Expo exhibition center is a standard multipurpose building. Last week, a trade fair for food service outlets and institutional caterers filled its cavernous halls. In the past, big music acts occasionally came through.

title: An Infant, Breast-Feeding and a Wedding
description: My wife and I are invited to her cousins wedding six weeks after our baby is due. She plans to breast-feed at the festivities using a special dress and cape. (Neither breast nor baby shows.) But her mother and aunts are adamant that she use the bathroom. At 90 minutes a feeding, based on her experience, she would be there for hours. Same with pumping: She pumps for an hour every two hours. We will be flying cross-country with three small children for this wedding, and my wife doesnt want to spend the day alone. May she breast-feed discreetly in public?

title: When Cupid Is a Prying Journalist
description: My interview with Justin McLeod was winding down when I tossed out one last question: Have you ever been in love?

title: Paris Attacks Have Many in France Eager to Join the Fight
description: PARIS  The attacks by militants tied to the Islamic State less than two weeks ago in Paris have awakened a patriotic fervor in France not seen in decades.

title: FIFA, Recovering 48 Luxury Watches, Seeks to Cast Off Links to Giveaway
description: When they checked into their rooms at the Grand Hyatt in So Paulo, Brazil, just before last years World Cup, global soccer officials were greeted with leather gift bags from the countrys soccer federation. Each bag contained tourism books, a key ring, a Brazil jersey  and, in a small velvet pouch, a wristwatch worth $26,000.

title: A Doctor Revisits His Own Trauma
description: More than a year has passed since the beautiful summer day I rode my bicycle down a steep hill, crashed, and landed in the hospital, bruised and battered, and no longer an entirely intact human being. I wrote about the experience for Well.

title: Politics at Thanksgiving Table? Thats the Least of the Problem
description: Happy Thanksgiving? Wed like to wish our readers a joyous day of food and familial bonding. But we suspect some teeth will be used for gritting and not chewing, based on the responses to Brendan Nyhans article on how to discuss politics at the holiday dinner table.

title: Taking to the Streets of Chicago
description: A second night of protests saw thousands demonstrating over the shooting death of Laquan McDonald, who was killed by a police officer in 2014.

title: Worlds Biggest Animal Cloning Center Set for 16 in a Skeptical China
description: If all proceeds as planned, the worlds biggest animal cloning center will open next year in the northeastern Chinese port city of Tianjin, taking factory farming to a new level.

title: World War III
description: Mommy, please tell me again, how did World War I begin?

title: Pope Francis, in Kenya, Delivers Message of Humility
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Remember the poor. Respect the youth. Protect the unborn.

title: Britain and Germany Test Support for Stronger Steps Against ISIS
description: LONDON  The diplomatic push by President Franois Hollande of France to rally allies in the fight against the Islamic State since the Paris terror attacks has begun to stir European capitals, with leaders in both Britain and Germany taking tentative steps to test the level of support at home for a more robust military engagement in Iraq and Syria.

title: China Retools Its Military With a First Overseas Outpostin Djibouti
description: BEIJING  China announced on Thursday that it would establish its first overseas military outpost and unveiled a sweeping plan to reorganize its military into a more agile force capable of projecting power abroad.

title: Thanksgiving TV: Plan Your Other Binge
description: Thanksgiving is a time to be grateful for lifes blessings, which, for many of us, includes plenty of family and a long weekend.

title: In Miami, the Brainy Side of the Beach
description: On the kind of balmy February evening that draws snowbirds by the flocks to South Florida, I split from the flip-flop crowd clogging Lincoln Road Mall in Miami Beach and veered one block north to the New World Center. The Frank Gehry-designed glass and steel symphony hall opened in 2011, and at once established South Beach as a cultural destination. A cluster of patrons formed a white-haired clot in front of the box office where I learned that the evenings program, a recital by a third-year horn fellow with the centers New World Symphony, was sold out. True, it was a free event, but it required reservations and Dominic Rotella, the musician, was apparently the hottest ticket in town.

title: The Holiday Movie Season in Trailers
description: From Oscar hopefuls to blockbuster franchises, a look at select trailers from movies in theaters this season that may fit your holiday mood.

title: Xi Jinping Announces Overhaul of Chinas Military Forces
description: BEIJING  President Xi Jinping of China has announced a major reorganization of the nations military, state-backed news media reported on Thursday, laying out plans to create new command systems intended to integrate and rebalance land, air and sea forces into a more nimble Peoples Liberation Army.

title: China Says It Has Detained 2 Dissidents Sent Back by Thailand
description: BEIJING  The Chinese government confirmed that it had detained two dissidents who had been living in Thailand and had been given United Nations recognition as refugees, a state-run newspaper reported on Thursday.

title: China to Release Journalist Gao Yu From Prison Over Illness
description: BEIJING  Gao Yu, a well-known Chinese journalist serving a prison sentence on charges of leaking a Communist Party document, will be released because of serious illness, a court in Beijing announced on Thursday, after another court had earlier in the day cut the length of her sentence.

title: Theater Troupe Gives Those on the Margins a Front-Row Seat
description: MINNEAPOLIS  There are no stage lights. Sets and props are minimal. Unadorned costumes evoke character more than period. The audience sits on all sides in folding chairs that seldom extend more than three rows back. Casting ignores race, gender and age.

title: A 1950s-Era Timepiece, Reborn
description: From the time chronograph technology started to catch on in the late 1800s until the middle of the 20th century, the venerable Swiss brand Vacheron Constantin produced highly coveted timepieces. But in 1955, it stopped making the wristwatches, which had become too elaborately wonkish to suit changing tastes. Although the company began gingerly reintroducing chronographs in the late 1980s, the final 50s-era model, the Cornes de Vache, continued to obsess collectors. Only 36 were ever made: 26 in yellow gold, eight in rose gold and two in platinum. Now the company has reinterpreted the design. The Historiques Cornes de Vache 1955, available only in platinum, is, like the original, a sober classic distinguished by its cow-horn-shaped lugs. But a slightly wider face gives the watch a more modern, balanced look and feel. With its raised Roman numerals, midnight-blue alligator strap, sapphire-hued tachometric dial and clear crystal back, it makes keeping track of time an immeasurable pleasure.

title: 1940: Italy Breathes Easier After Pact
description: ROME  The diplomatic offensive launched by the Axis powers against Great Britain after the meeting between Benito Mussolini and Fuehrer Adolf Hitler at Brenner Pass is believed here tonight [Nov. 27] to have ended for the time being. Tension in Rome over a possible imminent spread of war in the Balkans also has passed suddenly. In the highest diplomatic circles, it was said today that no signing of any agreement by either of the Axis powers with Bulgaria was likely soon. Turkey, armed to the teeth under martial law and moving up fresh divisions toward the Bulgarian border, may also be expected to remain out of the war for some time.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 27, 1940

title: For Carly Fiorina, Peripatetic Childhood Helped Build Worldview
description: The 1969 Stanford Law School yearbook notified readers that Joseph Tyree Sneed III, a top professor with Harvard, Yale and Cornell on his rsum, would be taking leave from the California university to teach for a year in London and Ghana.

title: Pope Francis Celebrates Mass in Kenya
description: On his first official visit to Africa, the pontiff spoke to a large, rain-soaked crowd in Nairobi.

title: Migrants Arriving in Germany Face a Chaotic Reception in Berlin
description: BERLIN  On a stretch of sidewalk in Germanys capital, migrant families huddle under blankets, their eyes locked on a tall metal gate. Helpers in bright yellow vests hand out steaming cups of tea to guard against the cold.

title: Empire Season 2, Episode 9: On the Road
description: Cookie and Laz Delgados whirlwind romance reached its logical conclusion this week as a chance meeting with Lucious finally inspired someone to hit Google and figure out that hes aligned with his girlfriends enemies and coolly playing Big Heavys goons against Lyon Dynasty. Kicking him out may do more harm than good, though, as no one knows how hard Laz has advocated for the dynasty or how anxious the neighborhood guys are for a bigger bite of their profits. Without a sympathetic party talking the gang out of terser negotiations, business is bound to get prickly. With Cookies Cookout looming on the horizon, one wonders how long Lyon Dynasty really is for the earth. The independence from Lucious that Cookie and Hakeem have gone to desperate extremes to cultivate finally feels perfectly unsustainable.

title: Time Before Iraq Invasion Holds Lessons for Fight Against ISIS
description: LONDON  The adversary is different but, as war talk spills once more through the corridors of power  this time directed against the Islamic State  it is tempting to recall the fervor of earlier days, before the invasion of Iraq in 2003, as much for the lessons learned as for those that have been ignored.

title: 1965: French Launch First Satellite
description: PARIS  France today [Nov. 26] launched a 92.4-pound satellite into orbit, thereby becoming the worlds third full-fledged space power after the United States and the Soviet Union. The satellite, launched from the French Sahara base of Hammaguir, will orbit the earth for the next two weeks, sending back radio messages to tracking stations near Paris and around the world. President Charles de Gaulle hailed the launching as an important accomplishment. New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 27, 1965

title: Burkina Faso, a Year After Uprising,Will Head to Polls
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso  Voters in Burkina Faso will go to the polls on Sunday in the first national elections since a popular uprising last year forced out the countrys longtime president, Blaise Compaor, after he tried to extend his 27-year rule.

title: Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade
description: The annual parade in Manhattan went on with balloons, bands and visible security.

title: Movie Listings for Nov. 27-Dec. 3
description: Ratings and running times are in parentheses; foreign films have English subtitles. Full reviews of all current releases: nytimes.com/movies.

title: Thanksgiving Hotline Bling
description: Sam Sifton emails readers of Cooking five days a week to talk about food and suggest recipes. That email also appears here. To receive it in your inbox, register here.

title: A Very Trump Thanksgiving
description: Source.

title: Canadian Coach Gives Boost to Britains Davis Cup Chances
description: LONDON  In the 125-year history of the Davis Cup, the oldest and most prestigious team event in tennis, the closest a Canadian has come to getting his hands on the trophy was when the Montreal-born Greg Rusedski led Britain to junior Davis Cup glory as captain in 2011.

title: Pakistani Police Investigate Fire at Christian TV Station
description: KARACHI, Pakistan  Police officials said Thursday that they were investigating a fire this week that destroyed the office of a Christian cable television station in this southern port city.

title: Panthers-Cowboys Game Pits Tony Romos Streak Against Cam Newtons
description: On paper, a matchup between a 10-0 team and a 3-7 team might seem like a good reason to spend more time with your family. Think again. The 10-0 Carolina Panthers travel to Dallas to take on a 3-7 Cowboys team that is anything but typical.

title: College Football Games to Watch on Friday
description: Friday

title: Manchester International Festival Names New Executive Director
description: Englands Manchester International Festival on Thursday announced the appointment of a new executive director, Fiona Gasper, who for the last five years has been executive director of the Royal Exchange Theater in Manchester.

title: Belgium Lowers Terror Attack Alert Level for Brussels
description: BRUSSELS  Belgian officials on Thursday reduced their assessment of the threats facing Brussels, five days after saying that the risk of a Paris-style terrorist attack was serious and imminent, a warning that paralyzed the capital.

title: On High Alert Since Paris Attacks, French Gear Up for Climate Talks
description: PARIS  Just two weeks after the terrorist attacks in Paris, France is gearing up for an exceptional security challenge  the global mega-conference on climate change  that will test its ability to ensure the safety of nearly 50,000 visitors and 147 heads of state who will descend on the city beginning on Sunday.

title: New Curator for Frieze Projects in London
description: The Swiss curator Raphael Gygax will be the new curator of Frieze Projects, a program of commissioned art works that is featured every year at the Frieze London art fair.

title: Visiting Kunduz, a Taliban Target, Afghan Leader Urges Security Overhaul
description: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  President Ashraf Ghani on Thursday visited Kunduz, the first Afghan city in 14 years to fall, briefly, under Taliban control, and used his visit to call for major security changes in the city and surrounding province.

title: Kremlin Cutting Economic Links With the Turks
description: MOSCOW  The downing of a Russian warplane by Turkey threatened to lead to a wholesale breach in the countries relations on Thursday, with the Kremlin preparing to sever economic ties and Turkish officials saying they had no reason to apologize.

title: Trifonov Joins Philharmonic Board
description: The New York Philharmonic announced that the 24-year-old Russian pianist Daniil Trifonov is joining its board of directors. Mr. Trifonov, who is the current star soloist of the Philharmonics three-week Rachmaninoff festival, was elected to the board on Nov. 13.

title: New Yorks Week in Pictures: Nov. 26
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region include scenes from the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade and a church in Queens where a baby was abandoned.

title: Brazil Hedge Fund Star Looks Elsewhere for His Next Big Bet
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Luis Stuhlbergers Brazilian hedge fund has had an astonishing run  even in the face of his countrys sinking economy.

title: Anatomy of a Scene | The Danish Girl
description: Tom Hooper narrates a sequence from The Danish Girl featuring Eddie Redmayne and Alicia Vikander.

title: N.F.L. Week 12 Previews and Picks
description: 1. Steelers (6-4) at Seahawks (5-5)

title: Tom Hooper Narrates a Scene From The Danish Girl
description: The Danish Girl follows the lives of the artist couple Gerda Wegener (Alicia Vikander) and Lili Elbe (Eddie Redmayne), focusing on Lilis transition from a man (as Einar Wegener) to a woman. This scene shows Lili, living as Einar, at a pivotal moment leading up to that transition. In an interview, the director Tom Hooper discussed the scene and some of his ideas for the movie. Following are edited excerpts from that conversation.

title: With Luck on Their Side Thus Far, Rangers Look to Get Better
description: Yankees pitcher Lefty Gomez once said he would rather be lucky than good, but so far this season, the Rangers have been both.

title: West End Avenue, Two Days Before Thanksgiving
description: Dear Diary:

title: Review: In Submerged, a Limo Ride Hits Rough Waters
description: Theres claustrophobia to burn in Steven C. Millers Submerged, a modest thriller offering glints of talent amid predictable plot threads. Matt (Jonathan Bennett), a military reservist, struggles to raise his faltering younger brother, Dylan (Cody Christian), after the death of their parents. He also covets  and looks out for  Jessie, the daughter (Talulah Riley) of a wealthy businessman (Tim Daly) for whom he is a driver and surrogate son.

title: Review: A Whiff of Hidden Toxins in Stink!
description: When Jon Stewart signed off from The Daily Show with the instruction, If you smell something, say something, he wasnt speaking literally. Yet he would probably approve of Stink!, a heartfelt documentary about the chemical industrys aggressive efforts to conceal the thousands of potentially toxic ingredients contained in everyday products.

title: Portugals New Premier Takes Office, Facing Financial Balancing Act
description: MADRID  Antnio Costa, the Socialist leader, on Thursday took office as Portugals new prime minister, at the helm of a minority government that has pledged to comply with European fiscal commitments while also reversing some of the austerity measures that had turned Portugal into a model student for international creditors.

title: Review: In Killing Them Safely, a Debate on the Virtues of Tasers
description: The rise, use and abuse of the Taser form the discomfiting subject of Nick Berardinis Killing Them Safely, but an equally formidable weapon also goes on display: words. In the 1990s, the brothers Rick and Tom Smith amped up a decades-old invention to create their electricity-zapping home run product. Since then, their company, Taser International, has defended the Tasers virtues with on-message verbiage in the face of deaths associated with the weapon.

title: A Spieth Who Doesnt Live in His Brothers Shadow, at Least at Home
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.  Steven Spieth has five inches of height, and nearly that much hair, over his older brother, Jordan. But since the basketball season has started up again at Brown, fans at opposing arenas have zeroed in on what Jordan has that the 6-foot-6, mop-topped Steven will never possess.

title: Review: In Karski & the Lords of Humanity, a Holocaust Spy
description: One of the many interviewees in Shoah, Claude Lanzmanns definitive nine-and-a-half-hour 1985 documentary about the Holocaust, was Jan Karski, a Pole whose undercover missions in World War II gave early information to the Allies about the extermination of Polish Jews. Slawomir Grunbergs stately documentary Karski & the Lords of Humanity focuses exclusively on Karskis courageous adventures in intrigue and espionage.

title: Mama Says That Santa Claus Does Not Come to Poor People
description: New books reveal poignant, 19th-century pleas to Santa Claus as well as the bizarre fate of some heart-rending mail addressed to his workshop.

title: Review: In Tamasha, Finding a Path to Love, Show Business and Adulation
description: The clues come early in the Bollywood melodrama Tamasha, when a song mentions a love story within a larger story. The film (named after a kind of Marathi theater) begins with a boy, Ved, enraptured at the feet of a wizened storyteller in Shimla, India. Later, as an adult (Ranbir Kapoor), he meets Tara (Deepika Padukone) on vacation in Corsica. Their largely chaste relationship revolves around playacting, and they avoid exchanging real names. When Tara returns to India, they decide to never meet again, their idyll forever in amber.

title: Joseph Kosuth Show at Sean Kelly Gallery
description: The 1950s and 60s were peak years for the linguistic turn, a philosophical movement that looked to the analysis of language for solutions to traditional puzzles about consciousness and reality. Few artists were more profoundly affected by that trend than Joseph Kosuth, a pioneer of 60s-style Conceptualism. Agnosia, an Illuminated Ontology, a visually exciting and conceptually bookish installation designed by Mr. Kosuth, gathers together more than 40 works from 1965 to 2015 that feature electrically illuminated words, phrases and sentences. (Agnosia is an inability to make sense of sensory information, a condition usually caused by brain damage.)

title: Carl Andres Minimalism, Suitable for Walking On
Sheila Hicks, a Weaver Flirting With Installation Art
description: These two exhibitions confirm the ambition and physical command exuded by the work of Sheila Hicks, who started out in weaving and has spent her long career formulating different ratios of art, craft and design, with varying degrees of success.

title: Loie Hollowells Abstract Body Landscapes
Hollis Framptons Singular Sensibility
description: The filmmaker, photographer, essayist, poet, teacher, fabulist and proto-digital pioneer Hollis Frampton (1936-1984) eased off on producing photography after the 1960s but came back to it at the end of his too-short life. His final work in the medium, a portfolio of 14 pictures with the curious title ADSVMVS ABSVMVS, makes up this exhibition, which is also  but how can this be?  his New York gallery solo debut.

title: Review: In Janis: Little Girl Blue, Exploring Joplins Demons
description: In Amy Bergs documentary Janis: Little Girl Blue, the sound that erupts from Janis Joplin singing the 60s R&B classic Cry Baby comes as close as Ive heard to a grown-up singer capturing a babys primal squall. Heard today, this raw, insistent scream, from Joplins posthumously released 1971 album, Pearl, is as disturbing and powerful as ever.

title: Art Basel Miami Beach: A Focus on Female Artists
description: There may come a day when having a critical mass of women featured in an art fair is no longer noteworthy, but were not there yet. So its worth noting that Art Basel Miami Beach, which starts next week, has a significant number of female artists.

title: Review: Iraqi Odyssey Shows the Arc of a Family and a Country
description: Iraqi Odyssey, a two-and-a-half-hour personal history written and directed by the Swiss filmmaker Samir (full name, Samir Jamal Aldin), is the kind of documentary whose length and complexity make you approach it with some apprehension. Watching it is like slowly leafing through a giant scrapbook whose contents include the individual stories of a large extended family.

title: Storm King to Present Earthworks by Dennis Oppenheim
description: With 500 acres of verdant exhibition space, Storm King Art Center, in New Yorks Hudson Valley, is uncommonly positioned to execute large-scale earthworks conceived by Dennis Oppenheim but never fully realized in his lifetime.

title: China Bars Anastasia Lin, Miss World Canada (and Rights Advocate)
description: TORONTO  Clasping hands with youngsters in red Communist Youth League scarves, contestants from more than 110 nations descended on the southern Chinese island of Hainan this week for the 65th annual Miss World contest.

title: Review: The Danish Girl, About a Transgender Pioneer
description: The Danish Girl, Tom Hoopers new film, is a story of individual struggle that is also a portrait of a marriage. In this respect and others it resembles The Kings Speech, Mr. Hoopers earlier historical drama, a multiple Oscar winner a few years ago. In that case, the union of George VI and Elizabeth, the Queen Mother, was the foundation on which the tale of Georges elocutionary striving was built. Here, the marriage is bohemian rather than aristocratic, but the stakes, while personal, are every bit as profound and consequential as the matters of state that drove the monarch to the microphone.

title: Review: Lorca Madly in Love Portrays a Forbidden Romance Through Flamenco
description: After the great Spanish poet and playwright Federico Garca Lorca was assassinated during the Spanish Civil War, his homosexuality was concealed and suppressed for decades. In contemporary Spain, the truth is now widely acknowledged, but for an artist to treat the subject frankly, especially in the tradition-bound world of flamenco, as David Morales does in his show Lorca Madly in Love, still counts as taboo-breaking and bold.

title: 50 Years Ago, Unsafe at Any Speed Shook the Auto World
description: FEW DRIVERS could imagine owning a car these days that did not come with airbags, antilock brakes and seatbelts. But 50 years ago motorists went without such basic safety features.

title: Britain Adopts Black Friday With an All-American Frenzy
description: LONDON  The British dont celebrate Thanksgiving, of course, but they have enthusiastically embraced another great American holiday tradition: Black Friday. A little too enthusiastically, it seems. Now, some retailers are even trying to dial back some of the frenzy they unleashed just a few years after introducing the whole idea.

title: Making Merry With Music
description: Each holiday season brings an opportunity to tackle old standards or to add new hits to the canon. Here, the pop and jazz critics of The New York Times survey some of this years releases. (Prices may vary, depending on where purchases are made.)

title: Canadas New Leadership Reverses Course on Climate Change
description: OTTAWA  In less than a month, Canada has executed a complete about-face on global climate change.

title: Pop & Rock Listings for Nov. 27-Dec. 3
description: For full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. A searchable guide to these and other shows is at nytimes.com/events.

title: Parents Ready for Some Love From Silicon Valley Companies
description: Silicon Valley is beginning to admit it isnt just for young people anymore.

title: Hoping Not to Repeat the Past
description: Calls by governors to turn away new Syrian refugees are resurrecting memories of World War II internment camps for Japanese-Americans.

title: Resistance to Syrian Refugees Calls to Mind Painful Past for Japanese-Americans
description: Before the attack that changed the country, a group of girls would meet their 14-year-old friend, Yuka, at her house every morning. They would walk to school together and discuss their plans for the day.

title: Colleagues Ponder Sheldon Silvers Role in Albany if He Is Acquitted
description: ALBANY  Its a hypothetical that few lawmakers in Albany will openly entertain. But what happens if  just if  Assemblyman Sheldon Silver walks out of a Manhattan courtroom a free man?

title: Man Scales White House Fence as Obamas Celebrate Thanksgiving Inside
description: WASHINGTON  A man climbed over a fence in front of the White House on Thursday as President Obama and his family were inside celebrating Thanksgiving, the Secret Service said.

title: Crop Insurance Subsidies Prove Cutting Budget Is Easier Said Than Done
description: WASHINGTON  In April, Republicans newly in control of Congress celebrated their agreement on a plan to save $5 trillion  thats trillion, with a T  and balance the budget in a decade. We continue to get things done for the American people, boasted the House speaker at the time, John A. Boehner.

title: Macau Gambling Industry Faces Challenges on Multiple Fronts
description: MACAU  Macaus newest gambling palace has plenty to beckon deep-pocketed Chinese visitors looking for a good time.

title: Guy Lewis, Coach of Houstons Phi Slama Jama Teams, Dies at 93
description: Guy Lewis, a Hall of Fame basketball coach known for leading the University of Houstons Phi Slama Jama teams of the early 1980s, died on Thursday at a retirement home in Kyle, Tex. He was 93.

title: El Salvador: Priest Faces Abuse Inquiry
description: The archdiocese of San Salvador said Thursday that it had suspended a high-ranking priest while the church investigated allegations that he had sexually abused a girl over an eight-year period beginning when she was 9 years old. The accused priest, Msgr. Jess Delgado, 77, the archdioceses vicar general until his suspension, played a crucial role in the effort to canonize Archbishop scar Romero, who was assassinated in 1980. We ask for forgiveness from the victim and from society, said Msgr. Rafael Urrtia of the archdiocese.

title: Number of Migrants Illegally Crossing Rio Grande Rises Sharply
description: MISSION, Tex.  The numbers of migrants crossing the Rio Grande illegally have risen sharply in recent weeks, replaying scenes from the influx of Central American children and families in South Texas last year.

title: Cynthia Robinson, Sly and the Family Stone Trumpet Player, Dies at 71
description: Cynthia Robinson, a trumpet player and original member of the seminal psychedelic-funk-soul group Sly and the Family Stone, died on Monday in Carmichael, Calif. She was 71.

title: Black Friday Retail Workers Try to Make the Most of a Shopping Slump
description: On Black Friday, Jeffery Santos, 23, will rise at 4 a.m., grab a bagel and a strong espresso, jump on a train from the Bronx into Manhattan, and ready an American Apparel store on Broadway for its big 6 a.m. opening.

title: Open Season Is Seen in Gene Editing of Animals
description: SIOUX CENTER, Iowa  Other than the few small luxuries afforded them, like private access to a large patch of grass, there was nothing to mark the two hornless dairy calves born last spring at a breeding facility here as early specimens in a new era of humanitys dominion over nature.

title: Influx of West Africans in the Bronx Spurs Demand for Interpreters
description: Conversations were still bubbling when Afua Atta-Mensah took the microphone and welcomed everybody to the African Community Town Hall, held in the basement of the Bronx Museum of the Arts this month.

title: Safety Lapses and Deaths Amid a Building Boom in New York
description: Manuel Colorado, a 36-year-old construction worker, was installing decking last year at a new building in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, when he lost his balance and fell 19 feet to his death.

title: Turnaround Gives UConn Bowl Security Other Teams Envy
description: Needing to win one of its last two regular-season games to become bowl eligible in Bob Diacos second season as head coach, Connecticut got the job done on the first weekend, stunning Houston, previously unbeaten and nationally ranked, on Saturday in East Hartford, Conn.

title: Donald Trump Says His Mocking of New York Times Reporter Was Misread
description: Responding to criticism over remarks he made on Tuesday, Donald J. Trump, the Republican presidential candidate and real estate developer, denied on Thursday that he was mocking the appearance of a reporter for The New York Times with a physical disability.

title: The Mute Swan, a Surface Beauty in New York Parks
description: The approach of winter probably finds more New Yorkers anticipating the return of Tchaikovskys Swan Lake to the New York City Ballet than the return of the mute swans to Willow Lake, but there are at least a few hardy souls who visit the real thing within the wilds of city parks each year.

title: Coffee Table Books About New York
description: Looking for gift books? Need to cover an empty coffee table? Or to construct one? Here are some hefty holiday offerings, all about New York.

title: Cellphone Recording Leads to Arrest of Brazilian Senator on Obstruction Charges
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  The young actor aroused the suspicions of the senators chief of staff as they were about to meet in a hotel suite in Braslia this month.

title: Things to Do in the Hudson Valley, Nov. 27 to Dec. 6, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

title: Felled by Tumor, Model Finds Strength to Walk Again
description: It was a day in late September when Jinji Nicole stepped out her door, crossed Fifth Avenue and went for a walk around the Central Park reservoir.

title: Things to Do in Connecticut, Nov. 27 to Dec. 6, 2015
description: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

title: Mixing Whimsy and Prudence at the Macys Thanksgiving Day Parade
description: Minutes before the balloons began bobbing through the streets of Manhattan, crowds pushed up against the barricades that lined Avenue of the Americas and, just out of earshot, counterterrorism officials from the New York Police Department huddled on the sidewalk, the Radio City Music Hall sign looming overhead.

title: Restaurant Review: Deltas Serves No-Nonsense Soul Food
description: Deltas is the kind of place where your expectations are crucial to how much youll enjoy yourself. If youre looking for no-nonsense soul food like your mom made, in an upscale atmosphere  with prices to match  youre in luck. If youre expecting a modernized version of soul food, you might be disappointed.

title: Ben Carson to Visit Refugees in Jordan Amid Scrutiny of His Foreign Policy Credentials
description: Ben Carson, who is facing increasing scrutiny over his grasp of foreign policy, is traveling to Jordan on Friday to visit Syrian refugees, in order to gain an understanding of the pressing issue and to polish his candidacy.

title: Fall Out of Line
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  Fairly easy for a Friday, or at least mostly in my wheelhouse. Not only that, but this themeless by Peter Wentz was a fun solve, with some terrific 10-letter entries orbiting the grid.

title: Fatal Brooklyn Crash Renews Fears of Drag Racing
description: There are many questions about why James Miro, a young local barber, ended up dead in a Brooklyn creek this month, his car submerged for more than a day. Why was he driving there at 5 a.m., and why does surveillance video show him traveling at a high speed on Gerritsen Avenue, which he most likely knew was a dead end beyond which lay water?

title: Gunmen Strike Shiite Mosque in Bangladesh
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh  Unidentified gunmen opened fire on a Shiite mosque in northern Bangladesh on Thursday evening, killing one man and injuring three others during evening prayer, in an attack that echoes last months bombing of a Shiite procession.

title: Woman Is Fatally Struck in Brooklyn
description: A driver fatally struck a woman in Brooklyn on Thursday night, then injured about a dozen people  including himself  as he tried to flee, the police said.

title: What to Watch Friday
description: Suffering from a Thanksgiving hangover? Soothe your tummy and temper with songs from Bruce Springsteen and Andrea Bocelli, binge on a supernatural thriller series, or slip into your pjs with members of the Holderness family of North Carolina, known for their Christmas Jammies video.

title: Corrections: November 27, 2015
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Quotation of the Day
description: Im just an acting student and a beauty queen. What could they possibly be so afraid of?

title: Finding the Noir Without Looking
description: The pictures suggest a murder mystery, or at least a thickening plot. But the truth is far more innocent. These photographs were taken by Jason Langer, who lives in Portland, Ore., when he was visiting friends in New York City.

title: Donald Trumps Police State
description: In The Plot Against America, the novelist Philip Roth imagines an alternative history at the dawn of World War II. Charles A. Lindbergh, aviator hero and crypto-fascist, defeats Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1940. Rather than go to war against Nazi Germany, he foments an atmosphere of hatred directed at Jews in the United States.

title: Immigrant Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the Republicans Opposition Research Machine
description: The vast right-wing conspiracy Hillary Rodham Clinton once cited in 1998 works from cluttered offices on Capitol Hill, led by a man who was in high school when she first made the charge.

title: Europe the Unready
description: Thanksgiving as we know it dates not to colonial days but to the middle of the Civil War, when Abraham Lincoln made it a federal holiday. It is, in other words, a celebration of national unity. And our national unity is indeed something to be thankful for.

description: To the Editor:

title: How to Prosecute Abusive Prosecutors
description: WHEN it comes to poor people arrested for felonies in Scott County, Miss., Judge Marcus D. Gordon doesnt bother with the Constitution. He refuses to appoint counsel until arrestees have been formally charged by an indictment, which means they must languish in jail without legal representation for as long as a year.

title: The Made in Israel Label
description: To the Editor:

title: False Alarms About a National Crime Wave
description: The headlines are alarming: Murder is up around the country, caused by anything from more guns to a heroin epidemic to the so-called Ferguson Effect  the disputed idea that police officers have become less aggressive out of fear that their actions will be recorded by civilians and criticized after the fact.

title: Turn the Volume Down on Drug Ads
description: Watching television these days means sitting through ads for drugs to ease pain, induce sleep, overcome sexual dysfunction, alleviate depression, ease urinary tract symptoms and more. Some patients say the ads are helpful, but many doctors warn that they are often misleading.

title: Black Tape at Harvard Law
description: Cambridge, Mass.  IN a grand corridor of Harvard Law School, framed professors photographs hang on a wall. A week ago, someone put slivers of black tape over the faces of most of the African-American professors. I am one of those whose photograph was marked.

title: Communities of Character
description: We live in an individualistic age. As Marc J. Dunkelman documents in his book The Vanishing Neighbor, people tend to have their close group of inner-ring family and friends and then a vast online outer-ring network of contacts, but they are less likely to be involved in middle-ring community organizations.

title: Chinese Stocks Plunge 5.5%, Their Biggest Single-Day Drop in 3 Months
description: HONG KONG  Just when it looked as if a relative calm was returning to Chinese markets, stocks nose-dived again on Friday. The main Shanghai share index lost 5.5 percent.

title: Paris Slowly Coming to Terms With a New Vulnerability
description: PARIS  Two weeks after the Nov. 13 attacks here, many of the memorials around the monument in the Place de la Rpublique are bedraggled, the hand-drawn signs rain-soaked, the candles exhausted, the flowers dropping their petals.

title: Tighter Lid on Records Threatens to Weaken Government Watchdogs
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Department watchdogs ran into an unexpected roadblock last year when they began examining the role of federal drug agents in the fatal shootings of unarmed civilians during raids in Honduras.

title: Teammates for Life
description: Madelyn Walters and Jason Wheeler were brought together by baseball, and as he works to reach the major leagues, they are determined to support each others dreams.

title: Teammates and Cheerleaders for Life
description: There are no fancy hotels, first-class flights or rubbing elbows with celebrities in the anxious life of a minor-league baseball player as he dreams of making it to the major leagues. Most of those dreams take place on late-night bus rides along the lonely roads and dimly lit highways that run through the heart of baseballs minor league circuit.

title: Chinese Rights Advocate Known as Guo Feixiong Convicted of Unexpected New Charge
description: BEIJING  Yang Maodong, a hardened veteran of political protest in southern China, knew he had virtually no hope of winning his freedom on Friday when he was brought into a courtroom to face a judges verdict on charges that he had disturbed public order.

description: Heres what you need to know to start your day.

title: A Patek Watch and a Record Price
description: Watch industry buzz has been continuing all month about the $7.3 million price  a record high for a wristwatch  achieved by the Patek Philippe Reference 5016A-010 (left) at the Only Watch auction in Geneva. The amount was 10 times the low estimate of the sale price.

title: Statement by Chinese Rights Campaigner Sentenced to 6 Years in Prison
description: Yang Maodong, a Chinese human rights campaigner better known by his pen name, Guo Feixiong, was sentenced on Friday to six years in prison on charges of assembling a crowd to disrupt public order and picking quarrels and provoking trouble. Prosecutors had cited his role in organizing support for journalists protesting censorship at the Guangzhou newspaper Southern Weekend and for rallies calling for China to ratify the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

title: Six French Films That Speak to the Identity of the Nation
description: The shock of the Nov. 13 attacks in and around Paris refocused attention on debates that have convulsed French society for decades  about the marginalization of the Muslim population, about the tensions between Islam and French Republican ideology, about the identity of the nation itself.

title: Art for the Holidays: A New York Visitors Guide
description: So youre coming to New York City around the holidays, and youd like to see some art?

title: Online Polls Are Rising. So Are Concerns About Their Results.
description: Two of the most important trend lines in political campaign polling might be about to cross.

title: Q. and A.: Lu Yang on Art, Uterus Man and Living Life on the Web
description: While the new media artist Lu Yang was studying at the China Academy of Art in Hangzhou in the 2000s, she drew up a series of works dealing with mind control. Many were deemed too sensitive, even borderline unethical, and remain unrealized. But with the help of the Fukuoka Asian Art Museum in Japan, Ms. Lu was able to obtain dead frogs that had been used in a medical dissection to produce one of the works. The result is a six-minute video called Reanimation!  Underwater Zombie Frog Ballet (2011), in which frogs wired to electrodes dance in water to a funky electronic beat.

title: Turkey Seeks to Ease Tensions Over Shooting Down of Russian Jet
description: ISTANBUL  Turkey took steps on Friday to calm relations with Russia over the shooting down of a Russian warplane this week, calling for a presidential-level meeting, possibly at the climate talks in Paris next week.

title: 100 Notable Books of 2015
description: The years notable fiction, poetry and nonfiction, selected by the editors of The New York Times Book Review. This list represents books reviewed since Dec. 7, 2014, when we published our previous Notables list.

title: In Transparent, a Heroine Evolves Further Still
description: LOS ANGELES  On the set of Transparent, a handful of actors dressed for a flashback scene on a 1930s ocean liner  cloche hats, woolen jackets, long skirts  crowd together on benches in a large wooden container perched atop a gimbal, a device that can simulate the rolling of a ship. Sitting cross-legged on a long table a few yards away, the director Jill Soloway, who created this Amazon series, quietly throws out a few suggestions to the gently swaying actors.

title: 1957 | When Pfizer and The Times Worked Closely
description: Our editorial board wasted no words this week in describing the planned combination of the drug companies Pfizer and Allergan as a tax-dodging maneuver that enriches shareholders and executives while shortchanging the public and robbing the Treasury of money.

title: 1915: Goal of American Red Cross
description: One hundred million dollars is the financial goal of the American Red Cross Society, announced yesterday [Nov. 9] at a meeting held at the residence of Mrs. Whitelaw Reid, 451 Madison Avenue. A movement was also started to place all war relief societies organized here since the outbreak of the war under the direct control of the Red Cross. Miss Mabel Boardman, head of the Red Cross organization, said she hoped the money would be given as an endowment fund to place the society on the same basis as the Rockefeller and Carnegie funds. She urged every man, woman and child in this country to join the Red Cross and give $1.50 a year to help in this new movement for preparedness. Mr. Joseph H. Choate presided at the meeting. The New York Herald, European Edition, November 28, 1915

title: Student Debt in America: Lend With a Smile, Collect With a Fist
description: The American student loan crisis is often seen as a problem of profligacy and predation. Wasteful colleges raise tuition every year, we are told, even as middle-class wages stagnate and unscrupulous for-profit colleges bilk the unwary. The result is mounting unmanageable debt.

description: ISTANBUL  Thousands gathered across Istanbul on Friday to protest the arrest of two prominent journalists on charges of espionage over a report alleging that the countrys intelligence services had sent arms shipments to Islamist rebels in Syria.

title: Suspect Arrested in Chicago Shooting ofTyshawn Lee
description: The police in Chicago said Friday that they had made an arrest in the murder of a 9-year-old boy who was shot to death after being lured into an alley in one of the most notorious crimes in the citys recent history.

description: Information on events for possible inclusion in Spare Times should be sent to weekend@nytimes.com by Friday at 5 p.m. for publication that week. Longer versions of Around Town and For Children listings are in a searchable guide at nytimes.com/events.

title: Childrens Listings for Nov. 27-Dec. 3
description: Its like an alternate universe. The space is as crowded, noisy and bristling with energy as the New York we all know, but also softer, gentler and infinitely welcoming. Crime never threatens; traffic rarely collides; and all the taxis are tiny, round and cute. For that matter, so are the cabbies.

title: Financial Abuse of the Elderly: Sometimes Unnoticed, Always Predatory
description: It was only after Mariana Cooper, a widow in Seattle, found herself with strained finances that she confessed to her granddaughter that she was afraid she had been bilked out of much of her savings.

title: Finding a Path Back to Iraq, and Toward Securing Womens Freedom
description: UNITED NATIONS  YANAR MOHAMMED runs a secret network of safe houses in her native Iraq. The women who come through its doors are honor-killing runaways, rape survivors, war widows and assorted others who have been to the cliff edge of hell and back.

title: Financial Considerations for Collectors of Art, Antiques and the Esoteric
description: LOOKING back on some of the most popular antiques he has sold, Bill Rau, chief executive of M.S. Rau Antiques in New Orleans, said two truly stood out for both their value and scarcity.

title: 1940: Students Clash in Zagreb
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia  An incident that carries with it a heavy charge of political dynamite occurred in the Croatian university town of Zagreb today [Nov. 27] when extreme Croatian Nationalist students clashed with a group of moderate students supporting Dr. Vladko Matcheks policy of co-operation with the Serbs. The fight, in which a number of students were seriously wounded, occurred on the occasion of a meeting held within the university by the extremist group, which favors independence for Croatia. The university was closed and guarded by the police so as to avoid a possible disturbance, but the moderate students  those favoring Yugoslav national unity  forced their way in through the cellar and tried to break up the meeting. The clash which ensued ended only when the police quickly restored order and made a number of arrests. The incident assumed special importance in view of Yugoslavias uncertain diplomatic relations with a number of her neighbors. The position of this country, nearly surrounded by potential foes, resembles that of Czecho-Slovakia in 1939. In the internal situation, too, there is a parallel.New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, November 28, 1940

title: Inside the List
description: Killing Santa: Every year, around the time mall stores start playing Frosty the Snowman and Starbucks breaks out its red cups, the best-seller list hangs its stockings by the fire and waits for a visit from Richard Paul Evans. You know Evans: Hes the one whose self-published debut, The Christmas Box, sold something like eight million copies in the mid-1990s and landed him a fat contract with Simon & Schuster; since then, his cozy holiday-themed books have included Finding Noel, The Christmas List, A Winter Dream and The Mistletoe Promise, among others. Now hes back, right on cue, with The Mistletoe Inn, new on the hardcover fiction list at No.9. What draws Evans so repeatedly to Christmas? Readers prone to psychoanalyzing might find a clue on his website, where Evans describes the tsunami of misfortune that hit his family in 1970, the year he turned 8. My father lost his job and couldnt find work, and my mother began to exhibit the first signs of severe depression. My Tourettes syndrome manifested that year and I was ticking like crazy. In addition, I wet the bed every night, made worse since I shared the bed with my brother, he writes. During this dark time I had a soul-crushing fourth-grade teacher named Mrs. Covey. Ill never forget two weeks before Christmas when she ridiculed those of us who still believed in Santa with the words: Your parents lied to you. There is no Santa. Crushed, I went home and asked my mother if she had lied. My mother frowned. She said, Santa is the spirit of giving.

title: What Is Holding Back the Economy?
description: The Great Recession began in December 2007, and ended officially in June 2009. As of October 2015, the unemployment rates in half the states in the country had fallen to or below their pre-recession levels. In the other half, unemployment rates were still higher than before the recession.

title: France, 2 Weeks After Paris Attacks, Observes National Day of Mourning
description: LONDON  France, still reeling from deadly terrorist attacks two weeks ago, held a national day of mourning on Friday, centered on a memorial service in Paris that was tinged with patriotism, solemnity and no lack of defiance.
